column2: SHNEIDMAN--Dr. J. Lee. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our devoted, longtime member, Dr. J. Lee Shneidman, beloved husband of the late Dr. Conalee Shneidman and father of Philip and Jack. The Shneidmans were members of our synagogue for over forty years. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Roger Meltzer, President

FIRESTONE--Edwin. With deep sorrow the Officers, Directors, and Members of The National Antique & Art Dealers Association of America (NAADAA) mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Edwin Firestone. Edwin was a founding partner in 1946 of the Boston based firm of Firestone and Parson, noted dealers in antique silver and jewelry. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. James McConnaughy, President Arlie Sulka, Secretary

A giant inflatable rat, used by labor unions in protests against their employers or nonunion contractors, looms like a sci-fi monster over pedestrians at 55th Street and Broadway in Midtown Manhattan. Meanwhile, just a few blocks away,

DAVID--Edmonds Commander, USN, Ret., died at home at the age of 94. He graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy In 1939; served as Squadron Commander SE Anti-submarine Squadron; Flight Instructor at Pensacola Naval Air Station; Navigator on the U.S.S Philippine Sea (Admiral's flag during the Invasion of Inchon, Korea); B25 Squadron Commander European Theatre; Naval Liaison Officer at S.H.A.P.E; Second in Command U.S. Navy at N.A. A.F.I.; directed development and installation of the D.E.W. Line; closed the Brooklyn Navy Yard; Contract Administrator for the Navy Tomcat and the Lunar Excursion Module. Received commendations for his participation in the saving of the men on the Apollo 13. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Wilhelmina David, with whom he traveled the world and lived for many years In Tuxedo Park. He is survived by five children and four grandchildren. Services will be held at Arlington Cemetery on July 31st at 9:00am.

FISHER--Cary Fox on July 22, 2008. Wife of the late Peter R. Fisher. Survived by her children, Diane Fisher Johnson (Bruce), Julian Potter Fisher II (June), and Elizabeth Fisher Jalali (Conrad); grandchildren Julia and Elizabeth Fisher and Cary and Jane Jalali; sister Diane Fox Downs; brother Lawrence Webster Fox; and niece Ninna Fisher Denny. Memorial service to be held Friday, August 8, at 10am, St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

MacALLEN--James, passed away on July 28th at the Englewood Hospital. He leaves behind his partner of 43 years, sister Sue, and nieces. James worked for CBS as a Director, and he also produced and directed the TV show ''Camera Three''.
LOOMANITZ--Clara. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. David J. Nathan, Parnas;

The $25 and Under review last Wednesday, about vegetarian sandwich shops, referred incorrectly to the origin of a sandwich with hard-boiled egg and eggplant at Maoz Vegetarian (59 East Eighth Street, Greenwich Village, and 38 Union Square East, at 16th Street). It is a dish popular in Israel called a sabich. It is not European.
MAKOS--Jill Klepper. Love, James B. Makos.
YACHNES--Eleanor and Jessica. We pick wildflowers in your memory--goldenrod, thistle, and lots of phlox

RICHMOND--Julius B., M.D. It is with profound sadness that the members of the Board of Trustees of the Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute (FAMRI) note the passing of our beloved friend, mentor and educator --Julius B. Richmond, M.D. --formerly Surgeon General of the United States. Dr. Richmond over his long, diversified and splendid career did as much as anyone to protect and improve the health of his fellow citizens, and in particular children and adolescents. From 1953 to 1965 Dr. Richmond was chairman and professor of the Department of Pediatrics at the State University of New York, SUNY College of Medicine and became dean in 1965, serving in that capacity until 1970. In 1965 Dr. Richmond was appointed by President Johnson as the first national director of Project Head Start in the Office of Economic Opportunity. Head Start became a year-round program after the first summer; approximately 750,000 children are enrolled in Project Head Start each year in approximately 1,500 centers across the United States. Head Start is a comprehensive child development program. In 1971 Dr. Richmond was recruited by the Harvard Medical School where he became a professor of psychiatry and human development and chairman and professor of the Department of Social and Preventative Medicine. Simultaneously, he was appointed professor of public health in the School of Public Health at Harvard. While at Harvard, Dr. Richmond was honored to receive a presidential dual appointment as both Surgeon General and Assistant Secretary for Health. Both positions required senate confirmation. Dr. Richmond was the first individual ever selected to occupy both positions. He had the responsibility in the federal public health sector for some 50,000 employees. During his tenure as Surgeon General, Dr. Richmond focused on tobacco control efforts through the publication of the 1979 Surgeon Generals Report, presenting overwhelming scientific evidence of the multiple harms caused by smoking. Dr. Richmond has received a number of honorary degrees including ones from Yale and Harvard. He continued his professional activities as the John D. McCarthy Professor of Health Policy Emeritus, monitoring students and colleagues, right up until the last couple of months. He continued to teach and write, striving to shape health policies for health promotion and disease prevention, with a special emphasis on children and families as well as the low income population. Dr. Richmond was a brilliant, caring, hands-on pediatrician for nearly 70 years. In later years he took on the onerous task of continuing to educate the public by testifying in open court about the dangers of tobacco and how the industry had for decades manipulated scientific data. In doing so Dr. Richmond voluntarily subjected himself to many days of grueling cross-examination, and he did this while refusing to accept compensation as a skilled expert witness. As Chairman of FA MRI's Medical Advisory Board, Dr. Richmond was vital to the Board of Trustees in helping to direct over $200,000,000 in grants to some of the finest medical schools and research institutions in America and the world --including five Centers of Excellence. The scientific research is aimed at eradicating the diseases caused by exposure to second hand tobacco smoke, the money having resulted from a class action lawsuit filed on behalf of nonsmoking flight attendants against the tobacco industry. Dr. Richmond had one of the most extraordinary and productive careers in the history of American monitoring science and public education. His professional accomplishments were mirrored by his sterling character traits. His sense of humor was legendary as was his refusal to acknowledge his own importance. He was endlessly patient, civil, tolerant, incredibly well-informed and a true pleasure to be around. The members of the Board of Trustees of FA MRI are eternally grateful for the guidance of Dr. Richmond over the past decade as well as for the pure pleasure of his company and insights. Board of Trustees Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute Miami, Florida

WERTHEIM--Charles D . Born 1917 in the Bronx, departed the evening of July 24, 2008 to join his treasured wife of 64 years, Audrey. Charles will be remembered by his daughters Cheryl (Stephen) Gaudette and Lynn (Manny) DiMatteo. Charles was a proud WWII veteran and prominent business owner of Wertheim Typography Co. His sons-in-law strive to be as doting to their wives as Charles was to Audrey. Grandchildren Daniel (Colleen), Rebecca and Joshua Gaudette are committed to carrying on the fire with which Charles lived life. As Charles' lifelong friend Bob Smith gives life to his past, Charles' five great-grandchildren ensure his place in the future.

WALKER--June -Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc. expresses profound sadness at the passing of immediate past National President, June Walker. June was a remarkable woman with a fierce devotion to her family, determined to secure a rich Jewish life for her children and grandchildren. This was to be her most enduring legacy. Born into Zionism, she was a dedicated and tireless leader, demanding and passionate about Israel and the Jewish people. She came from a rich Hadassah tradition and credited her mother and aunt as her inspiration. For June, Hadassah had always been, and must always be, a proactive voice for American Jewish women, instilling a passion for participation among women to become engaged in both Hadassah and the global Jewish community. Involved in every aspect of Jewish communal life and with an unwavering allegiance to Jewish continuity, June proudly served as chairperson of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, coChair of the Confederation of United Zionists, as well as a member of both the World Zionist Organization Executive and the Jewish Agency Board of Governors. A bold thinker and a trusted friend to so many, she was described as a courageous dreamer of extraordinary dreams, committed to the well-being of others. Recognized for her extensive knowledge in the fields of education and healthcare, June worked for many years as a respiratory therapist at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, and ardently advocated for the betterment of the healthcare systems in America and in Israel. A lifetime of aspirations and achievements were proudly realized when June was recognized by Haifa University this past June with an honorary doctorate. June demonstrated unparalleled strength, commitment and humanity, even as she bravely battled the illness that finally took her life. She will continue to be respected and admired for her courage, her optimism and her sense of purpose. June will truly be missed by her Hadassah family and so many others whose lives she touched. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Barrett, her three children and six grandchildren, and may they find solace knowing she lived a full and meaningful life. May her memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Contributions may be made to Hadassah in June's memory for the June Walker Education Center. Nancy Falchuk National President Morlie Levin National Executive Director WALKER--June. Dear friend for 35 years. My inspiration. I will always miss you. Carol Fein WALKER--June. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of June Walker, Chair of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. June was an inspirational leader and a devoted advocate for Israel and the Jewish people. The impact of her tireless efforts will be felt for many years to come. We send our heartfelt condolences to her grieving family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard J. Sideman, Pres. David A. Harris, Exec. Dir. WALKER--June. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the loss if its remarkable, esteemed and beloved chairperson, June Walker. Her devotion to the well-being of others was the hallmark of her life. A gifted leader who enjoyed the respect, admiration and affection of all, June's love of Israel and its people and commitment to clal Yisrael was evident in everything she did. Leaders of the US and Israel held her high in regard and recognized her integrity, intelligence and sincerity of her advocacy. This was reflected in her unanimous election as Chairperson in 2007 and again in 2008. Similarly, she served with distinction as President of Hadassah. We pray that her entire family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The funeral will be on Thursday, July 31th at 11am at Congregation Beth Hatikvah, 36 Chatham Road, Summit, NJ. Malcolm Hoenlein Executive Vice Chairman WALKER--June. The Orthodox Union mourns the passing of Mrs. June Walker, Chair of the Conference of Presidents and past President of Hadassah. Her compassion, grace, wit and wisdom served her well as a true Jewish leader. She will be missed. Stephen Savitsky, President Rabbi Dr. Tzvi Hersh Weinreb, Executive VP
GERST-KATZ--Carole, artist passed away on Monday July 28, 2008. Her award-winning paintings are in homes throughout the states.

CULLEN--Thomas F., of Monroe Township, NJ, formerly of Kew Gardens, Queens on July 28, 2008. Husband of Elizabeth (Francy), father of Kathleen Stern, Patricia, Eileen and Maureen Cullen. Also two granddaughters. For information call M. David DeMarco Funeral Home, 732-521-0555.

HYATT--Stuart Q., of Middleburg, VA, passed away on July 19th, his 81st birthday, after a long illness. He is survived by his sister, Elva H. Clinard of Los Alamos, NM. His many friends in Middleburg contributed greatly to his happiness in his last years, as well as to his care during his illness. Cremation has taken place. His remains will be interred with those of his parents, Philip A. and Juanita H. Hyatt, and other members of his family in Hancock, NY.

BARBIERE--Giuseppa, on July 29th, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Francesco, loving mother of Charles and his wife Rosalie and Joseph and his wife Yvonne, cherished grandmother of Francis, Jo Marie, Frank, Louis, Eric and Ava. Reposing at the Torregrossa Funeral Home 1305 79th St., Brooklyn. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 25pm and 7-10pm. Funeral Mass Friday Our Lady of Guadalupe R.C. Church 9:30am. Entombment at St. John's Cemetery.
NATHAN--Lois. Great heart. Unforgettable friend. Sherry and Larry Cohen

An article on Monday about the outcome of the Tour de France misstated the given name of the Austrian rider who finished in third place and won the polka-dot jersey as the best mountain climber. He is Bernhard Kohl, not Bernard.

SIMON--Ellen. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to her husband, Peter, and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. Elliot J. Cosgrove, Senior Rabbi Steven M. Friedman, Chairman of the Board Brian G. Lustbader, President
CARUS--Alan. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member, Alan Carus. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Susan Zelman, President

Nathan Kensinger generally does not ask for permission when he photographs the decaying remnants of Brooklyn’s industrial waterfront. Since 2003, he has wandered into shuttered factories, padlocked basements and forbidding warehouses. He often goes along with other photographers who have an adventurous bent. He hasn’t been arrested, yet, but he doesn’t want to tempt fate, either.

City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., who is expected to run for mayor in 2009, has spent more on political consultants — about $600,000 since 2006 — than his presumed rivals have spent on their entire campaigns during that period. And he has racked up large bills for fund-raisers at expensive locations like the Bath Club in Miami and the Waldorf-Astoria hotel in Manhattan. Mr. Thompson, in fact, has spent campaign money at more than twice the rate of his likely competitors over the last two and a half years, according to the latest campaign finance filings.

The city could open as many as four vocational career schools by September 2009 to serve as models for an educational strategy promoted by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in his State of the City speech in January of this year.The mayor’s office made the announcement on Wednesday in conjunction with a report, Next-Generation Career and Technical Education in New York City [pdf], produced by the Mayoral Task Force on Career and Technical Education Innovation. The task force was headed by former Mayor David N. Dinkins and Sy Sternberg, the chairman of New York Life.

Updated, 2:48 p.m. | New York City Transit officials say a faulty encryption device was to blame for the widespread breakdowns in MetroCard vending machines on Monday and Tuesday. The problems left thousands of subway and bus riders unable to use credit and debit cards to purchase MetroCards during peak hours of the morning and evening rush on Monday, and again during the Tuesday morning rush.

The House of Representatives decided on Thursday afternoon to table, by a vote of 254 to 138, a Republican resolution to censure Representative Charles B. Rangel, the powerful New York Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. The resolution said Mr. Rangel “dishonored himself and brought discredit to the House,” citing a report in The New York Times on July 11 that Mr. Rangel occupied four rent-stabilized apartments in a Harlem building, including one that he used as a campaign office.

It came as no surprise, but the political career of Bernard Goetz, the so-called subway gunman of New York City renown, has been put on hold. Mr. Goetz was thrown off the ballot as a candidate for state committee member for the Independence Party in an Assembly district in Manhattan. He was challenging Fred Newman, a leading member of the party.

One of the trendy perks at progressive companies is unlimited vacation time. The pitch is that responsible adults are capable of managing their own time so why not allow them to decide which hours and days to work as long as as the work gets done. It's yet one more way that the employed are starting to resemble the self-employed. But as any entrepreneur knows, having the ability to take off as much time as you want doesn't necessarily mean that you'll use it. Often, the self-employed are so driven and consumed by work that vacations are all but squeezed out. I was about to write on this subject when I noticed that The Boston Globe Magazine had just written about the issue, touching on all the major points I would have made.

The freshmen entering Greene Central High School in Snow Hill, N.C., in 2005 thought they had something a little extra to look forward to, should they make it through the four years. That year, John Edwards began a program, College for Everyone, to pay a year's tuition for each graduate.

As more and more fans are mixing tourism with race attendance - check out my story on F1 tourism in this weekend's IHT F1 special report - the tradition of having drivers attend races in their own camper vans to avoid hotels and stay as close to the track as possible is continuing. While it was commonly done that way in the old days, it was Jacques Villeneuve who relaunched the trend amongst drivers. He encouraged his friend David Coulthard to do it, and the Scot continues to take his own bus/trailer/camper thingy around to the races and to camp out near the track.

Dozens of bombs blew up in Iraq every day, hundreds of sirens went off, tearing through the silence of the nights and the noise of the days, torn body parts and corpses overlying the streets and pavements, fresh blood stains the faces and the walls. But nothing made as much difference as that one bomb that went off in Samarra, shattering a holy shrine and planting the first seeds of sectarian violence in Iraq.

The idea of a high-end collection of exquisite perfumes is now thoroughly done. Hermès can make a plausible case for having started it with the Hermèssences, for which its perfumer Jean-Claude Ellena revolutionized minimalism and linearity into a new, purified luxury. Chanel's Exclusifs came along three years later and enriched the approach, as did Tom Ford's Private Blend three months after that. All are excellent.

The Star-Ledger of Newark and a smaller sister paper need to eliminate at least 20 percent of their staff and win concessions from trade unions to stay afloat, their management said on Thursday, or the company will sell the papers and possibly close the smaller one.

Defying gravity---and logic---prices for "super-prime" properties in central London continue to rise, according to the latest data from Knight Frank, the property firm. Although most of London recorded a slight drop, the value of houses priced above £10 million (about $20 million) is actually up 16.7 percent from a year ago, according to Knight Frank.

Carmelo Anthony will start at forward for Team USA at the Beijing Olympics. He completed his fifth year with the Denver Nuggets in the N.B.A. and led Syracuse University to the 2003 N.C.A.A. title. Anthony had 20 points in USA Basketball's blowout exhibition win over Canada, tying for the lead in scoring and minutes played. He has led Team USA in scoring in its last two international tournaments. He scored 17 points in the Americans' easy win over Turkey on Thursday and can be seen again when USA Basketball plays Lithuania on ESPN2 at 8 p.m. Eastern on Friday.

Bitten reader George Saddler sends a note (by USPS!) asking for a good oyster loaf recipe; the oyster loaf he's looking for is hollowed out French bread which is filled with a mixture of oysters, celery, onions, green peppers and seasoning, then baked. I've not only never made one -- I've never eaten one. Note that this is not a po-boy, and note that if you google "oyster loaf" you find a bunch of weird and not especially appealing recipes (I did not venture past page one of the search). Can the Bitten community help Mr. Saddler out?

For the past five years, the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service (take a breath) has been sponsoring "Key Ingredients: America by Food," a toothsome exhibition that is traveling across the country through February 2013. (Click here to see a schedule.) You can view the online companion anytime you want, however, to trace the 500-year history of our nation's eats or map the best roads for food-related traveling.

The new Harley-Davidson Museum opened on July 12 in Milwaukee. Like the great cathedrals of Europe, it is laid out on the cruciform plan.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- Quick now. Which Big East team won 10 games last season, finished the season ranked No. 17 and lost three games by a total of 16 points? That would be the Cincinnati Bearcats, who had a season that would appear to launch them into the national spotlight.Well, at least on paper. Certainly not in the eyes of the Big East media, which ranked the Bearcats No. 5 in the preseason poll.

By announcing today that military combat tours would be shortened from 15 to 12 months, President Bush was implementing a major recommendation that his Pentagon chief made months earlier.

Carl Icahn has been a busy blogger. The latest posts on his Icahn Report, which appeared Thursday morning, comprise of a critique of the financial press and an explanation of why he dropped his proxy fight with Yahoo. He also said that, after months of highly public feuding with Yahoo, he won't be making an appearance at its upcoming shareholder meeting.
Whenever I encounter badly designed software, I stand there, slack-jawed, mind boggling, and wonder what on earth the designers were thinking.

In remarks outside the Oval Office this morning, President Bush declared "a month of encouraging news from Iraq." But he did not mention a report on the front page of The Washington Post this morning that would constitute one of the most encouraging signs of Iraq success:"Al-Qaeda in Iraq Leader May Be in Afghanistan."
A British computer specialist lost the latest stage in his battle to avoid extradition to the United States on charges of hacking into 92 United States government computer networks.
The Blackhawks strike again. At 3 PM Eastern Time today, Scotty Bowman will be introduced as the new Senior Adviser, Hockey Operations, for the Chicago Blackhawks.
Pope Benedict XVI granted Paraguay’s president-elect, Fernando Lugo, an unusual waiver that will allow Mr. Lugo, a former bishop, to take office next month without violating church rules.

The United Nations World Food Program warned that successive poor harvests and flooding a year ago had resulted in millions of North Koreans facing hunger on a scale not seen in the North since a famine in the late 1990s.
The Reserve Bank said that Zimbabwe would drop 10 zeros from its hyper-inflated currency -- transforming 10 billion Zimbabwean dollars into 1 Zimbabwean dollar.

High-definition, Blu-ray discs offer consumers what is now the ultimate in picture quality: its programming is recorded in the 1080p format, delivering 1,080 lines of information, progressively scanned. If you own a large-enough 1080p flat panel TV, you'll be able to see the difference between its picture and that of a high-definition image transmitted by your local TV station, cable or satellite.

The best cuts of the best beef are so delicious that most attempts to improve them are pointless. But not all steaks are in that class, and to be honest, as great as a steak right off the grill can be, it is also somewhat predictable. The easiest way to reckon with boredom -- or the quality of the steak -- is to use a spice rub, one that adds flavor and crunch, and complements the flavor of the meat without overwhelming it.

Scientists in Bangladesh have been reappraising forecasts of eventual inundation of sprawling, crowded delta regions as seas rise in a warming world. According to several reports, a fresh satellite analysis shows that new lands formed by sediment carried from the crumbling Himalayas are adding to Bangladesh's land area -- at least for now.
Updated: Alan Schwartz, the former chief executive of Bear Stearns, has decided not to stay at JPMorgan Chase, which bought Bear in March in an emergency deal that stunned Wall Street.

[Update Thursday noon: Two middle-distance runners were dropped from the Romanian Olympic team Thursday after testing positive for EPO. "Elena Antoci and Cristina Vasiloiu were dropped from the Romanian Olympic delegation as both are under suspicion of doping," committee head Octavian Morariu told reporters. "Both stay at home."]
Many people consider Sydney's Games in 2000 the best run and most successful Olympics in history. Some of its best moments are preserved on YouTube.

Why didn't Hasbro buy Scrabulous instead of suing to shut down the popular online imitation of Scrabble on Facebook? "Once again, here is an embattled industry -- is this case board game manufacturers, getting walloped by a digital tidal wave," writes Blaise Zerega, the deputy editor of Portfolio magazine. "And the reaction? Lawsuits. Sounds a lot like Napster and Music." Zerega also writes:

Is this election becoming a battle of the "Celeb" versus "McNasty"?
Four private residences designed by John Lautner, the midcentury architect whose legacy may have been underestimated.

Bristol-Myers Squibb said on Thursday that it is offering $4.5 billion in cash for ImClone Systems, the drug maker that Carl Icahn, the activist investor, took control of two years ago after an intense proxy fight.
Mark Cuban may be the favored bidder, for now, in Tribune's auction of the Chicago Cubs, reportedly offering $1.3 billion for the storied sports team, according to The Deal.
CrowdFusion, a web publishing start-up founded by former Weblogs chief, Brian Alvey, has landed about $3 million in its first round of funding, according to Paid.Content.org.
Google, which in its time has ponied up cash for various start-ups, is considering making it official.

McCormick & Company, a leading seasonings retailer, has agreed to sell Season-All line as part of a deal to gain antitrust approval for its $605 million deal to buy Lawry's Seasoned Salt from Unilever.
Bill Miller, the Legg Mason stock picker, said on Wednesday financial stocks appear to have hit a "capitulation low" in mid-July, but held off endorsing them for investors.

Community Bank Investors of America, a private equity fund, has agreed to supply $5 million to invest in cash-strapped Freedom Bank. However, it said it will only buy the stake if Freedom raises an additional $15 million from other investors.

Clear Channel Communications, the nation's largest radio broadcaster, said that Bain Capital and THL Partners had officially completed their $17.9 billion buyout of the company, almost two years after Clear Channel first agreed to be purchased by the private-equity firms.

In one of the largest rounds of job cuts to hit the legal community since mortgage meltdown began, Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft announced that it is laying off 96 lawyers in the United States and Britain due to continued slowness in real estate finance and securitization, the firm's core practices.

The Financial Accounting Standards Board, under pressure from banks and auditors, voted unanimously on Wednesday to delay a new accounting rule that is aimed at forcing banks to put more assets on their balance sheets rather than hide them in so-called special-purpose entities.
A former Credit Suisse broker who is the of a fraud investigation into an auction rate securities scam may have fled to his native Bulgaria, The Wall Street Journal reported.
RAB Capital, the London-listed hedge fund, said assets under management fell by 12 percent to $5.9 billion in the first half, while first-half profit fell 44 percent.

Gas Natural, the Spanish utility, has agreed to buy a 45 percent stake in rival Union Fenosa from Spanish builder ACS, in a deal worth 7.6 billion euros ($11.8 billion), the companies said on Wednesday.

American lawyers seeking to bring a class-action lawsuit against the French bank Société Générale over its billions of euros in unexpected losses came to France on Wednesday looking for publicity, and plaintiffs.
The investment bank UBS has agreed to pay Massachusetts $1 million as part of an agreement to settle the state's investigation into the bank's sale of auction-rate securities to 17 cities and towns.

Sweden's Modern Times Group has acquired Bulgaria's-second largest TV channel, Nova Televisia, from Greece's Antenna Group for 620 million euros ($973 million) in cash, the company said in a statement Thursday.

Deutsche Bank chief Josef Ackermann, whose bank on Thursday announced a further $3.6 billion of write-downs for the second quarter, renewed calls for reforms in the financial sector in a piece appearing in The Financial Times.

Japan's TDK Corporation said it plans to buy Epcos, a German electronic parts manufacturer, for $1.9 billion in cash, in a move to expand sales of industrial-use parts and cope with fierce price competition, The Financial Times said.
Deutsche Bank made a further $3.6 billion of write-downs in the second quarter, taking its bill from the global financial crisis beyond $11 billion.

Despite a sharp rise in oil prices Wednesday, stocks rallied after the promise of more support from the Federal Reserve gave investors confidence that financial firms would work through their problems.

Morgan Stanley plans to use the $1 billion it saved by cutting 4,800 jobs this year to hire top-level executives in areas like derivatives, risk management and proprietary trading, The Financial Times reported.

Red Hat, the open source operating system and middleware vendor, has said it wants to hit $1 billion in revenue in three years. The 451 Group looks at how the company may need to use acquisitions to help reach that goal -- and whether it may become a takeover target itself.

Aozora Bank, the Japanese lender controlled by Cerberus Capital Management, posted a 75 percent decline in said first-quarter profit, on the back of a drop in fees declined and shrinking returns on hedge fund investments.

Pax World Management, the granddaddy of socially responsible mutual funds , agreed to pay $500,000 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it violated its own rules when two of its mutual funds invested in off-limits industries such as gambling and liquor, and oil and gas exploration.

Cities | Why are American cities experiencing "demographic inversion" -- with the poor and newly arrived living on the outskirts as the affluent take over the center? Among the reasons: "deindustrialization," lower crime rates, higher gas prices, and the young adopting different lifestyles than their parents. Chicago, for example, is "coming to resemble a traditional European city." [New Republic]
BP has apparently decided against an initial public offering for its renewables business.

The rock star life it wasn’t. From the moment I began working on this story, following 23-year-old Sean Carlson as he planned his first-ever tour from his home — actually, his father’s home — in L.A., it was clear that I would not be experiencing the perks that people usually imagine when they think of bands on the road. Instead of a plush custom-made “Pimp My Ride”-worthy vehicle, the F Yeah Tour would be criss-crossing the country on a vintage Blue Bird school bus, complete with narrow brown vinyl seats, pinchy windows and no air-conditioning. (The one concession to modernity: air cards, for Internet access.).

What is the maximum amount of money that can be charged upfront for a security deposit? We recently had to pay two months' rent as security, and I was under the impression that one month was the standard. If we do not plan on moving for at least two years, can a portion of this money ever be used as a rent payment?
... Well, I guess somebody has to do it.

At the Consumer Electronics Show last January, LG teased people with an announcement that it would introduce some sort of device that would play movies on Netflix's streaming, on-demand service. But it wouldn't say what device or how much it would cost.
Libya has released two Swiss citizens who had been held for 11 days after the arrest in Geneva of Hannibal Qaddafi, the youngest son of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
Andy Murray won his second-round match in a Cincinnati Masters tournament that has already lost three players to injury despite pain in his right knee.
Humorist Jack Handey explains his personal Olympic record. On the rings? He prefers French fries.

Mark Levine had read thousands of words about Michael Phelps and how his unusual proportions have helped make him this era’s dominant swimmer. That background didn’t matter much, because when Levine visited the U.S. training center in Colorado Springs and saw the elongated torso and short legs that compose Phelps’s 6-foot-4 frame, the sight still came as a slight shock.

For gold-medal hopefuls like gymnasts Nastia Liukin and Shawn Johnson, there’s just one big chance to make it as a marketing darling. Mimi Swartz, author of “Power Failure: The Inside Story of The Collapse of Enron,” and a regular contributor to PLAY, takes an amusing, up-close look at the scramble to hit Olympic paydirt.

When you’re the No.1 product of China’s sports-industrial complex and its first-ever track star, you’d better deliver. Jim Yardley, a correspondent in the Beijing bureau of The Times, takes a look at the Chinese machine that creates — and controls — champions like Liu Xiang, the country’s best hurdler and the undisputed centerpiece of China’s entire Olympic team, who has been forced to cope with the pressure and expectations to win for the glory of his country.
Think you know your Olympics trivia? Think again. John Tayman takes a look at the politicking, pandering and popularity contests of Games past.
The Florida Marlins knocked out Mike Pelfrey after he pitched four innings, and went on to win, ending the Mets’ weeklong stay atop the National League East.
The Boston Red Sox were talking to the Florida Marlins, a team with only a $22 million payroll, about their unhappy left fielder.
Chase Utley homered, providing the big blow in a five-run fifth inning, and the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Nationals, to move back atop the National League East.
A State Supreme Court justice placed a temporary restraining order on plans to start blasting rock at the Jerome Park Reservoir in the Bronx as part of the Croton Water Filtration Plant project.

Jimmie Johnson, coming off his victory in Sunday’s Allstate 400 at the Brickyard, has added a pair of races to his 2008 schedule. In addition to driving the No. 48 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet, Johnson, the two-time reigning Sprint Cup champion, will make his Truck Series debut in Bristol, Tenn., on Aug. 20 — driving the No. 81 Kobalt Tools Silverado for Randy Moss Motorsports. He will also drive the No. 48 Lowe’s Chevrolet fielded by Dale Earnhardt Jr.’s motorsports team in the Nationwide Series race at Watkins Glen on Aug. 9.

An article on July 23 about a retrospective of Dominique Delouche’s documentaries about great ballet dancers, at the Walter Reade Theater, misidentified a ballet by Michel Fokine that was the subject of an exchange between him and Alicia Markova that Markova recounts in the film “Markova, la Legende.” It is “Les Sylphides,” not “La Sylphide.”.

An article on Monday about Senator John McCain’s leadership of the International Republican Institute referred incorrectly to the significance of his role. Robert J. Lagomarsino headed the group from 1986 to 1992 while representing California in the House; Mr. McCain is not the only sitting member of Congress to have led the institute.

A listing of credits on Tuesday with a television review of “Lord’s Children,” an installment of the “Wide Angle” series on PBS, omitted a producer. Tamara Rosenberg is listed as the “reversioning producer” for “Wide Angle.”.

An article on Tuesday about the nature of glass described incorrectly the phase transition from water to ice. When water molecules are lined up into ice, energy (called latent heat) is released. The phase transition does not require energy to line up the molecules. (In the phase transition for glass, there is no latent heat.).

An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about a speech by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran to the Nonaligned Movement of nations meeting in Tehran misidentified the country that the United Nations has penalized for refusing to halt enrichment of uranium. It is Iran, not Iraq.

An article on July 16 about the history of corruption and lax oversight in the crane industry in New York City misstated the given name of a former official of the crane and heavy equipment operators’ union who testified in a federal union corruption case in 2006. He is Joseph Coriasco, not John.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about resistance to recycling in Houston misidentified, in some editions, the location of a recycling center used by T’afia, a restaurant that was shown. As the article noted, the recycling center is in West University Place, an autonomous city surrounded by Houston; it is not in Houston itself.

An article on Tuesday about the federal takeover of IndyMac Bank referred incorrectly to the maximum amount of insurance available from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for individual accounts. While the F.D.I.C. insures deposits in nonretirement accounts like checking and savings accounts to a maximum of $100,000, the maximum for retirement accounts is $250,000.

An article on Tuesday about the lack of a national database in the United States to track how people fare after receiving artificial joints misstated the financial history of one medical device manufacturer, Sulzer Orthopedics. While Sulzer, faced with lawsuits from patients implanted with one of its artificial hips, threatened to file for bankruptcy protection, it did not do so.

Chicago Cubs closer Kerry Wood had another setback Wednesday when the blister on his right index finger prevented him from throwing a simulated game.

The Coast Guard said the Mississippi River had been opened again after crews cleaned up about 2,500 gallons of oil that spilled Wednesday during removal of a barge that sank last week after a collision with a tanker.

President Bush signed into law a huge package of housing legislation that included broad authority for the Treasury Department to safeguard the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies and a plan to help hundreds of thousands of troubled borrowers avoid losing their homes.
Financial problems are causing America’s Black Holocaust Museum in Milwaukee, a museum started by a lynching survivor, to close its doors on Friday after 20 years.
Smoking appears to have started a fire that caused $70 million in damage to the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier George Washington, based in Norfolk, Va., naval officials said.
The head of the beleaguered Dallas Housing Authority has resigned after a federal audit revealed nearly $20 million in suspicious rental assistance payments, which included money for 45 dead clients.

The Columbus Blue Jackets re-signed the restricted free agent goalie Pascal Leclaire to a three-year contract through the 2010-11 season. Leclaire, 25, is coming off his best season, going 24-17-6 with a 2.25 goals-against average, .919 save percentage and nine shutouts in 54 games. He ranked second in the N.H.L. in shutouts, seventh in goals-against average and 11th in save percentage. Leclaire has the best record in franchise history, and his shutout total nearly doubled the previous club mark five set by Marc Denis in 2002-03.

Connecticut defensive tackle Jarrell Miller, one of the highest-rated recruits the Huskies have landed, has left the school, the university announced. UConn said Miller left the program for personal reasons.

The Indy Racing League’s IndyCar Series will race in Long Beach, Calif., and in Toronto for the first time next season. The Grand Prix of Long Beach will be run on April 19. It has hosted F1, CART and Champ Car races. Champ Car ran its final event there this season. The I.R.L. will then hold the Streets of Toronto race on July 12.

Lava Man, a 7-year-old gelding, was retired as thoroughbred racing’s richest claiming horse after X-rays revealed changes in the horse’s front ankles. Lava Man was claimed for $50,000 at Del Mar in 2004 and finished his career with 17 wins in 46 starts and earnings of $5,268,706. Doug O’Neill claimed the horse for the current owners, Steve Kenly and Jason Wood, and trained him the rest of his career.

Children are not at risk for lead exposure from synthetic athletic fields, according to a report released by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission. The commission evaluated synthetic athletic fields after lead was detected on some New Jersey fields, raising worry about exposure to children. But no tested field released amounts of lead that would be harmful, the commission said. While the evaluation found no harmful lead levels, the commission asked that voluntary standards be developed for synthetic turf to preclude the use of lead in the future.
In trials involving violent crime, prosecutors often fear that information could leak out in the process called discovery and be used to hurt people.

The Phoenix Country Club has expelled a member for speaking to The New York Times about the club’s policy of forbidding women in its men’s grillroom, a point of dispute among some members.
Seven years after the harsh lessons of the Sept. 11 attacks, New York City has improved the ability of its emergency agencies to operate together.
Iraq and the United States are close to a deal on a security agreement that Iraqi officials said satisfies the nation’s desire to be treated as sovereign and independent.

SHNEIDMAN--J. Lee, died on Tuesday morning, after a nine-month struggle with cancer, which he was diagnosed with only nine months after loosing his beloved wife Conalee. They were married for forty-five years. He recently celebrated his 79th birthday at home, after a lengthy hospital stay. Father of Philip and Jack, brother to Daniel and his Doris, uncle to Sam, Jonathan, Sarah and Aaron, and their respective families; he will greatly be missed. Professor of History at Adelphi University for forty years, Dr. Shneidman was a Medievalist. He was the author of several books: ''The Rise of the Aragonese-Catalan Empire: 1200-1350'' (2 volumes), which was translated into Catalan; ''Spain & Franco;'' and, co-author of the biography ''John F. Kennedy'' with his colleague and longtime friend Peter Schwab. Dr. Shneidman co-wrote psychohistory articles with his wife, Dr. Conalee Levine-Shneidman, on a diverse range of subjects: Aaron Burr, Catherine De Medici, Ivan the Terrible and many others. His articles also appeared in The Journal of Psychohistory, Hispania, and The American Historical Review. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, he attended New York University (Heights Campus), BA '51, New York University, MA '52; University of Wisconsin-Madison, Ph.D '57, and post-doctoral study in the ''Psychoanalytic Clinic for Training and Research'' at Columbia University. In 1957 and '58 he was professor abroad in Germany and Libya for the University of Maryland in Frankfurt A/M, which was the beginning of his world travels, most years accompanied by his wife. In more recent years he was the chair of the ''Seminar in the History of Legal and Political Thought and Institutions'' at Columbia University. A passionate stamp collector, he also wrote numerous articles for The Rossica Society Journal and The American Philatelist, among others. A life long Upper West Sider, ''Doc Shneidman'' was a dedicated patron of Barney Greengrass, the Sturgeon King. The funeral will be held at 11:45am on Friday, August 1 at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his name to Adelphi University, attn: Office of Advancement, 1 South Avenue, Garden City, NY 11530.

CAPORALE--Rocco. A professor and Italian American Scholar, died of complications of open-heart surgery June 30th. He received a Ph.D. from Columbia University and was Professor Emeritus in the Dept. of Anthropology and Sociology at St. John's University where he retired after 30 years. He established the Institute of Italian American Studies (INIAS), Pontes International, International Association for Magna Grecia, American-Italian Historical Association, etc. He published a ten-year sociological study on 42 villages ravaged by the earthquake in Southern Italy. He leaves his wife, Taina Elg, daughter Catherine Caporale, Ph.D., son-in-law, Jay Cordes, step-son Raoul Bjorkenheim and two grandchildren, Cosmo Bjorkenheim and Jacqueline Cordes, a sister Jolanda, and four nieces with families in Italy.

GERSON--Owen Simon, 8 years old, wonderful boy and perfect little brother, died Sunday July 27, 2008 on a rafting trip with his family on the Green River in Utah. Born on October 16, 1999 in Santa Fe, NM, he is survived by parents Alison and Stephane Gerson, brother Julian, and grandparents Gay Block and Malka Drucker, Gus and Dottie Block and Francine and Bernie Gerson. Owen, a smart, wise boy with amazing potential, attended the Little Red Schoolhouse. He loved swimming with his brother, playing anything with his dad, and making chocolate desserts with his mom. Among Owen's many passions were Playstation and Little League, the Yankees and the Cubs. He was a whiz at math and a voracious reader with an insatiable curiosity. He was just learning to play the guitar, loved travel and was fluent in French. His loving and mischievous personality made him a joy to be around. Owen will be dearly missed and will live on through all who knew and loved him. A service will be held at the Woodstock Jewish Congregation on Thursday, July 31 at 3pm. Donations can be made at www. JewishCommunalFund.org, and remembrances can be posted at http:// owengerson.blogspot.com.

At a time in the presidential campaign when there are accusations of going too negative, Ludacris, the rapper who once bragged in a song that he was ''from the school of hard knocks, sneak peeks and low blows,'' is drawing fire for doing just that. In a new ode to Senator Barack Obama, called ''Politics,'' Ludacris, right, calls Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ''irrelevant'' and also a nasty name common in hip-hop lyrics but not in the remarks of presidential candidates. Senator John McCain was the recipient of something that could be a schoolyard joke or an especially repulsive malediction, depending on the audience: ''McCain don't belong in any chair unless he's paralyzed.''

ArcelorMittal, the steel maker, said second-quarter profit more than doubled, exceeding analysts' estimates, on higher prices and deliveries. Income climbed to $5.84 billion, or $4.19 a share, from $2.72 billion, or $1.97 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 39 percent, to $37.8 billion. The company said profit will advance in the third quarter in Asia, Africa and the former Soviet Union. That will offset a decline in earnings in the European flat-steel business because of increased costs. The company, based in Luxembourg, said shipments in the quarter rose 2 percent, to 29.8 million metric tons.

8 P.M. (National Geographic) BEIJING OLYMPIC STADIUM They call it the Bird's Nest, a woven mass of 42,000 tons of steel and concrete that will seat some 91,000 spectators during the Olympics. This program looks at the design and construction of the stadium, above, which will play host to track and field competitions. At 9, ''Beijing's Olympic Pool'' explores the National Aquatics Center, an architectural feat of steel beams and pillows of high-tech plastic. 8 P.M. (13) GREAT OLD AMUSEMENT PARKS Long before Six Flags and Disney World, with their big-budget thrill rides, there were lower-key havens where the wooden roller-coaster ruled. This program visits Playland Park in Rye, N.Y.; Holiday World in Santa Claus, Ind.; and the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk in California, where riders on the merry-go-round can still try to grab the golden ring. Rick Sebak narrates.

PRICE--Marilyn Althea Matthews, 61, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend, passed away with her immediate family at her bedside in Orlando, Florida on July 22, 2008. Marilyn was a 31 year member of Soka Gakkai International, a Buddhist organization that promotes world peace, culture and education. Marilyn has been an educator in New York City, Houston, Texas and Kissimmee, Florida. She was a teacher at the Osceola High School of the Arts in Kissimmee at the time of her death. Her professional expertise was the English language and English literature. She has been a ''teacher who cares'' for almost 40 years. Marilyn Matthews-Price is survived by her devoted husband of 30 years, Keith I. Price; her only son, Matthew Sharuma Bowens of New York City; grandchildren-Millennium and Matias Bowens; her only sister Carol Mercedes Matthews of Houston, Texas and a host of relatives and friends. Services will be held on Saturday, August 16, 2008 at 11:00am, SGI-USA Orlando Community Center, 452 Semoran Blvd., Orlando, Florida 32807 (407) 482-3939. Repast to follow service: Crowne Plaza, Orlando Airport 5555 Hazeline National Drive Orlando, Florida 32812. In Houston Memorial service is forthcoming.

ZWANGER--Bernice Lomazov. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of Bernice Lomazov Zwanger, a distinguished member of the Class of 1949, generous benefactor, and beloved friend. Bernice was a steadfast supporter of the School and a succession of students have benefitted from her philanthropy and great spirit. Although her presence will be missed, her legacy will be long enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Jerome, their children, grandchildren, and the entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean ZWANGER--Bernice Lomazov. Bernice Zwanger, a retired lawyer and wife of Jerome Zwanger, M.D., a Long Island radiologist, died July 29, 2008, of complications from breast cancer. Mrs. Zwanger, born July 17, 1926 as Bernice Lomazov, was a graduate of Queens College and Brooklyn Law School, one of only three women law students in a class of 180. After practicing law for several years, she married Dr. Zwanger on May 22, 1955 and moved to Massapequa Park. Mrs. Zwanger is survived by her husband, Jerome, her daughters Susan Zwanger Mendelsohn, Melissa Zwanger, and Betsy Z. Budzinski, sons-in-law Steven Mendelsohn and Peter Budzinski, seven grandchildren, Eva Mendelsohn Stensvad, Alisa, David, Dan and Julia Mendelsohn, and Emily and Elliot Polur and one great-grandchild, Andrew Stensvad. Mrs. Zwanger was pre-deceased by her daughter, Roberta. Mrs. Zwanger was a patron of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a member of its Visiting Committee on Arms and Armor, chaired by Arthur Ochs Salzberger. She supported the University of Pennsylvania and the Brooklyn Law School, and recently endowed a reading room at the school in memory of her daughter Roberta. Mrs. Zwanger served on the Board of Directors of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing and Rehabilitation Center. In 2003, Mrs. Zwanger was admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the United States. Services will be held on Friday, August 1, 12pm, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury. Interment will follow at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale.

The Brazilian Voice newspaper in Newark first printed the gossip last Saturday that the winning ticket in the multistate Mega Millions lottery drawing of July 22 had been bought by a Brazilian immigrant at a supermarket in the city’s Ironbound neighborhood, which has large Brazilian and Portuguese populations. The source was hardly authoritative, but the rumors of the lottery prize in New Jersey got increasingly rich and more colorful.

Today is the start of World Breastfeeding Week, and partly to mark the occasion, about 30 women nursing infants rode the A train from NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia in Washington Heights to Nostrand Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Michels, a lawyer and politician from Washington Heights who served on the City Council from 1978 to 2001 and was active on environmental issues, particularly water quality, and tenants’ rights, died this morning. CBS won the network television ratings race on Thursday thanks to a rerun of "CSI" and "Big Brother." According to Nielsen's estimates, "Big Brother" led during the 8 p.m. hour, drawing 6.5 million viewers, which was slightly above average for the season. At 9 p.m., CBS's "CSI" earned 7.9 million, just trailing behind Fox's results episode of "So You Think You Can Dance" (8.5 million).

Technology bankers in Silicon Valley must be really bored these days. Not a single technology company went public in the second quarter of this year, according to the National Venture Capital Association. That is the first tech-free I.P.O. quarter since 1978.

As frightening as the anthrax attacks of 2001 may have been, they didn't lack for clarity. Letters arrived at well-known organizations with poison and statements like "Allah is great" and other suggestions that an Islamic-extremist enemy was striking again, just a few weeks after 9/11. Explanations, though, have seemed for years to be just out of reach of the public, which was greeted this morning with yet another strikingly ambiguous development.

Hello, Virginia Heffernan,

We have a rent-stabilized apartment in a Manhattan building that has been converted to a condominium in a noneviction plan. There have been electrical renovations in the building including provisions for submetering of our electricity use. Now the electricity usage appears as a separate charge on my rent bill each month.

Our rent-stabilized apartment will probably become destabilized in six to eight years as our rent and income rise. At that point, how large a rent increase can the landlord impose? Will the rent rise to market rates immediately, or is there some sort of percentage cap on any increase? Must the landlord perform improvements in order to increase the rent?

BEIJING - It's nearly 7 p.m. here Friday in Beijing - 7 a.m. Friday in New York - and I can hardly keep my eyes open. I've been in China for a little over 24 hours and the Olympic haze has already set in, in the form of major jet lag. I woke up at 2 a.m., and couldn't get back to sleep. But at least I had the chance to see the sun rise over the Olympic Green, and it was beautiful.

What else is there not to worry about? After I asked for additions to my list of 10 things I wouldn't worry about on vacation, more than 200 Lab readers responded. Most of them were far more interested in defending their right to worry, and I'll get to some of their concerns shortly. But first the limited supply of good news. Here are a couple of other potential nonworries:

Cornell's Jon Jaques gave Quad readers an inside look at the N.C.A.A. tournament in March. Now he's back to tell us how some Division I basketball players spend their summers. Jon is in his Southern California home this summer, where he is interning for Think Cure, the official charity of the Los Angeles Dodgers which benefits cancer research in local hospitals. He is also playing in Rico's Get Better League, which features college players from all levels. He'll be checking in with The Quad from time to time to let us know what he's up to. In this second installment he writes about the importance of summer leagues like Rico's and how they help players develop in the offseason. Be sure to check back for more from Jon in the next few weeks.

We are, no surprise, surrounded by books in our office. But in readying a review for publication, the one volume we still turn to more than any other is that old standby, Webster's New World College Dictionary. Over the years, flipping through its thin and scalloped pages to determine (for instance) whether there's a hyphen in "dog-eared" or whether "crapulence" will fly here, we have come to imagine a playful intelligence at work among the anonymous clerks and typesetters who tease each new edition of this thing into being, and who must do whatever they can to relieve their drudgery amid a treasure trove - the treasure trove - of words.

I've just emerged from my sustainability bunker long enough to enjoy Guy Trebay's look at the growing acceptance of shorts in offices. A report from The Los Angeles Times today about the death of Bruce E. Ivins, a government scientist, said that the Justice Department was preparing to charge him in connection with the 2001 anthrax attacks.

A quick news flash from my colleague Matt Wald describes two new advances in handling hydrogen as a means of storing energy -- a critical step if intermittent sources like the sun are ever going to become a big part of the grid. Matt, who has been writing about hydrogen as a fuel since the 1980s, cites two intriguing studies in the journal Science, including one that Daniel Nocera had excitedly mentioned to me not long ago. This professor of energy (not a common title) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, like many scientists pursuing an energy transformation, long ago concluded that the sun is the only energy source that can compete with coal. After all, coal is essentially fossilized sunlight, as Thom Hartmann noted back in 2000.

After stripping the kernels off a few ears of corn, you can use the cobs to make a quick, flavorful stock. All it needs are something like potatoes to add substance, seasonings and the corn. The entire process takes just about half an hour, and the result is a thick, satisfying vegetable stew.

At the new restaurant Alloro my friends and I ate fried spaghetti. On top of it was what the menu identified as a "light tomato and basil sauce," which wasn't conventionally saucy. It had chunks of tomato, many of which tumbled from, rather than joining forces with, the pasta. And it was disconcertingly sweet.

RICHMOND--Julius . The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of Julius Richmond, Honorary Fellow of the Academy and the 1999 recipient of the John Stearns Award for Lifetime Achievement in Medicine. We join many in remembering his outstanding national and international contributions to the fields of medicine and public health, and we are especially grateful for his support of the Academy. The Academy Board, Fellows and staff extend deepest condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D. President Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees RICHMOND--Julius B. The Board and staff of the Foundation for Child Development (FCD) celebrate the life of its longtime Board member and former Vice-Chair of the Board, Dr. Julius B. Richmond. Dr. Richmond brought his decades of experience in pediatric medicine, academia, and government to FCD's work. A tireless advocate for public health, Dr. Richmond's work on the cognitive development of poor children led to his appointment, in 1965 by President Johnson, as the first national director of Project Head Start, which has now served more than 20 million children. Dr. Richmond was a uniquely effective and compassionate champion in the fight to improve the physical and mental health of our nation's children, as well as their educational opportunities. He powerfully and consistently gave voice to the interrelationship between the health and education of children, demonstrating that both are critical to fostering child wellbeing. All Americans have benefited tremendously from his decades of leadership in advancing healthcare in our country. He was a friend, a mentor, and a sterling example of the true spirit of public service. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his entire family, and we are deeply grateful for all that he taught us and accomplished for America's children. P. Lindsay Chase-Lansdale, Chair Ruby Takanishi, President Foundation for Child Development

KJELDSEN--Anne Marie (Nana) of Bay Shore/Brightwaters, 86, died July 30 after a short illness. She is survived by four children: Mary Lou Cohalan of Bayport, Susan Roos of Brooklyn Heights, Robert and Barbara Kjeldsen of Babylon, and David and Deborah Kjeldsen of West Islip. A son, Peter, predeceased her, as did her husband of 62 years, Norman. She is also survived by 14 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren; her sister Dorothy Kelly of Douglaston; a brother Robert Noone of Queens; daughterin-law, Ingrid Kjeldsen of East Islip; and numerous nieces and nephews. Dedicated to community service, she served 45 years as a volunteer at Good Samaritan Hospital where she was a familiar figure at the main reception desk. She also supported the Hospitality Center at St. Patrick's R.C. Church in Bay Shore and numerous civic organizations in Islip and Babylon Town. Born in Chicago to Eunice and John B. Noone, she grew up in Douglaston, NY. A member of the Greatest Generation, she married Norman Kjeldsen, a naval officer, in 1941. The couple was stationed in Norfolk, VA, during World War II and remained there for 13 years to raise their five children. In 1958, when the Virginian governor closed public schools in defiance of a Supreme Court order to integrate them, she joined an ad hoc group that sued the State on behalf of displaced students. The suit, and the yearlong struggle to reopen schools, was the subject of a non-fiction book recounting the episode. An avid reader, she was interested in politics, current events and the world around her. She attended monthly lectures at the Foreign Policy Institute in Manhattan, studied French culture and language, which she spoke fluently, and took pride in having visited all the continents, included Antarctica. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway. (1/4 mile West of the Robert Moses Cswy.). Funeral Service to be held Saturday 11am at the Funeral Home. Interment to follow at Oakwood Cemetery, Bay Shore, LI. Visiting Friday 24:30 and 7-9:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Anne's name may be made to Good Samaritan Hospital, 1000 Montauk Highway, West Islip, NY 11795.
AROUND TOWN

'POETRY FROM THE ROOFTOPS' The spirits of place may, boldly or slyly, influence your reaction to art. The particular spirits of the Central Park Arsenal will be waiting on its terrace on Tuesday evening, along with three published poets. ''Poetry From the Rooftops,'' the second and last of the summer readings sponsored by the Academy of American Poets and the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, seems well matched with the arsenal's medieval turrets and the park's green backdrop.

NASH--Jack . The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Jack Nash, a dedicated member of the Boards of Trustees since 1990. Mr. Nash generously supported many trustee initiatives. Most recently his philanthropy has helped to establish Mount Sinai's new Brain Institute to research disorders of the brain and spinal cord. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Helen, children Joshua, also a Mount Sinai trustee, and Pamela, and the entire Nash family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center NASH--Jack. The Trustees and the staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the most esteemed members of the Library family, Jack Nash. A devoted Trustee for many years, a generous benefactor, and a great friend, Jack Nash and his beloved wife, Helen, have been great champions of the Library's Dorot Jewish Division in particular. Their generous support brought about a period of major growth for the Division, marked by the acquisition of a great many rare and antiquarian treasures, achievements ensuring the preservation of its worldclass holdings, and expanded access to its remarkable collections. We offer our heartfelt sympathies to Helen, to the Nashes' children--Pamela and Joshua--and to the entire Nash family. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President NASH--Jack. The Board of and Staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and of the Israel Museum mourn the death of our Founder, Board Co-Chair, and long time devoted supporter, Jack Nash. He and Helen have been invaluable to the growth of the Museum and its current Campus Renewal. Our heartfelt sympathy to Helen, Josh and Beth, Pam and George, and the entire family. Judy Steinhardt Co-Chair, AFIM Board James S. Snyder Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir. IM Monique Birenbaum Executive Director, AFIM NASH--Jack. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Jack Nash, a universally esteemed leader and cherished friend. As co-founder and general partner at Odyssey Partners, Jack was admired for his extraordinary accomplishments in the financial services industry. His exceptional success in business was matched only by his deep devotion to the Jewish community --a commitment he shared with his beloved wife, Helen; his son and daughterin-law, Joshua and Beth; and his daughter, Pamela Rohr, and her husband, George. For decades, Jack was one of America's great philanthropists, contributing his financial acumen and generosity to help millions of people in need and strengthen Israel and Jewish communities throughout the world. His abiding concerns live on in the continuing efforts of his family. Jack served on UJA-Federation's Board of Directors, as Joshua does today. Joshua also serves on our Investment Committee. In addition to their involvement in UJA-Federation, the Nash and Rohr families have been affiliated with several of our beneficiary agencies. We extend our deepest sympathies to Helen, Joshua, Beth, Pamela, George, Jack's grandchildren, and to all who loved Jack. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO NASH--Jack. The Trustees, Officers and staff of The Caroline and Joseph S. Gruss Life Monument Funds mourn the passing of our esteemed former Vice Chairman of the Board, Jack Nash, father-inlaw of our devoted trustee, George Rohr. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Martin D. Gruss, Chairman Jason G. Cury, President NASH--Jack. NATHAN--Lois (Lewis) , age 72 of Tiverton, RI formerly of Mamaroneck, died Tuesday, July 29, 2008 surrounded by her loving family. She was the beloved wife of Ives B. Nathan to whom she had been married for 53 years. Born in Bayonne, NJ she was the daughter of the late Harry and Ada (Bracker) Lewis. Mrs. Nathan received her BA from New York University and her MBA from Pace University. Prior to retirement she was a Marketing Executive with Lucent Technologies in Basking Ridge, NJ. Besides her husband, she leaves her three children, Scott J. Nathan and his wife Audrey of Franklin, MA, Bruce F. Nathan of Stuart, FL and Lisa Freedman and her husband Jeff of Framingham, MA; her sister, Phyllis Robin and her husband Murray of Babylon, NY; her brother, Robert Lewis and his wife Barbara of Washington, D.C.; as well as eight grandchildren: Samantha, Adam, Aaron, Jack, Samuel, Kirsten, Tess and Brock. She was preceded in death by her brother, the late Bernard Lewis. A Celebration of Life will take place Sunday, August 10, 2008 at 11:00am at the Villages at Mount Hope Bay at The Clubhouse, Tiverton, RI, www.mounthopebay.com/ location.html. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be directed to: Healing Co-Op, 272 Mitchell Lane, Middletown, RI 02842, www.thehealingcoop.org. The family was assisted by Sugarman - Sinai Memorial Chapel, Providence, RI.

PHILLIPS--Lois Farrell . Lois Phillips died July 30th after a battle with leukemia which she fought with good cheer and unflagging determination until her death. She was 68. Mrs. Phillips was a lawyer's lawyer, well known and much sought after for her knowledge of real estate law, and stood out among her peers because of her direct, no-nonsense approach to problems a trait she acquired in earlier years as an elementaryschool teacher at St. Mary's Elementary School in Manhasset. She began and spent much of her legal career at Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood and after a stint as a Assistant Bureau Chief in the Real Estate Finance Division of the Attorney General's office, joined Chehebar Deveney & Phillips as a partner. Mrs. Phillips was, as she proudly proclaimed, a Queens girl, and spent the last nine years living near Riverhead where she was active in local politics. She is survived by her husband, Robert, her two daughters, Alice and Regina, both lawyers, and her son, Robert, and by her grandchildren, Reid and Quinn, on whom she doted. Visiting hours will be on Sunday, August 3rd, at the AlexanderTuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Route 25A in Wading River, from 2 to 4pm and from 7 to 9pm. The funeral mass will be held at St. John the Baptist Church, 1488 North Country Road in Wading River, at 10am on Monday. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Down Syndrome Research and Treatment Foundation, www.dsrtf.org. Lois was a special, loving person and will be deeply missed.
WHAT Luxury hotel and residential development. WHERE Downtown St. Petersburg, Fla.

DeROSA--Thomas M. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Thomas M. DeRosa, a Life member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Brian M. Murphy, President Brian G. Andersson, Historian DeROSA--Thomas Michael. The family and innumerable friends mourn the death on July 30, 2008 of Thomas Michael DeRosa, 71, of Stuyvesant Town. Tom is survived by his children, Margaret and Tommy, his former wife, Joan, his grandchildren, Chelsea and Andrew, his brother, Francis, his sister-inlaw, Susan and other relatives in the US and Ireland. His second wife, Nancy, died in 2001. Tom was deeply committed to his work as an official with Local 1070 of DC 37, AFSCME, AFL-CIO. He was a devout Catholic who served as a Eucharistic Minister and as head usher at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Immaculate Conception and St. Andrew's. He was President of the Catholic Court Attaches Guild and a member of the Knights of Malta, the Knights of Columbus and the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. A community activist, he was affiliated with the Jefferson and McManus Democratic Clubs. There will be a wake on August 3, from 68pm at Mahar Funeral Home; 43 Main St.; Hoosick Falls, NY and the funeral mass at 9am on August 4 at Immaculate Conception Church in Hoosick Falls. A memorial service in Manhattan will be held at a later date. Donations may be made to Immaculate Conception (414 East 14th St., NYC 10009) or St. Andrew's (20 Cardinal Hayes Pl., NYC 10007).

10 P.M. (ABC) 20/20 Juju Chang hitches a ride on the tour bus of the Jonas Brothers -- Nick, 15; Joe, 18; and Kevin, 20 -- as they promote their latest album, ''A Little Bit Longer,'' and gets them to discuss their music, their love lives and the illness that nearly kept them off the road. Then Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, above left with Barbara Walters, talks with Ms. Walters about her whirlwind romance with, and marriage to, the president of France, Nicolas Sarkozy; how she juggles life as the first lady with a successful recording career; the provocative lyrics on her new album, ''Comme Si de Rien N'Était'' (''As if Nothing Happened''), which caused a minor diplomatic flurry when she sang of a love like Colombian cocaine; and her controversial past, including affairs with Mick Jagger and Eric Clapton. 6 A.M. (USA) MONK The network starts preparing for this obsessive-compulsive sleuth's 100th case, on Sept. 5, with a 12-hour marathon of the series's first 12 episodes. In a new episode at 9 p.m., Mr. Monk (Tony Shalhoub) finds himself suffering from lotto fever, but it turns out to be common jealousy when Natalie (Traylor Howard) becomes something of a celebrity when she steps in for a murdered lottery-show host.

LONEY--Fredrick Roosevelt, Jr. , 79, of Westerly, RI, died July 29, 2008 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. Mr. Loney is survived by his wife of 55 years, Nancy, and two children, Susan Allen Loney and Frederick Roosevelt Loney III, both of Providence, RI, and two grandchildren, Alice Loney Oestreich and Henry Oestreich. Mr. Loney retired from J.P. Morgan in 1997 after a career of 44 years. He was a past president of the Misquamicut Club in Watch Hill, RI, served on the vestry of St. James' Church in New York, and the Saint Anthony Educational Foundation. Memorial service will be held at the Watch Hill Chapel on Tuesday, August 5th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018 or Tabor Academy, 66 Spring Street, Marian, MA 02738. Services have been entrusted to the Buckler-Johnston Funeral Home, 121 Main Street, Westerly, RI.

A picture caption on July 10 with an article about a federal inquiry into allegations of voter fraud in three largely black counties in Alabama misstated the date that Albert Turner Jr., a Perry County commissioner who is the subject of an investigation, was shown in a polling place. It was in 2006, not during an election on June 3 of this year. (Because of an editing error, the incorrect date also appeared in the article.) The caption also misidentified the photographer who took the series of three pictures showing Mr. Turner at various stages of the voting process. They were by Carl Crocker -- not by John Allan Clark, the editor of The Perry County Herald who supplied the photographs to The Times.

In addition to two full and two half baths, it has a Florida room, a library, a recreation room, a den and a 15-by-20-foot living room with a fireplace. Additional acreage is available. Agent: Teresa Howell, Spotlight Properties, (931) 232-7222; www.spotlightproperties.com

SCHWARTZ--Bernard . Be loved and devoted husband of Florence for 62 years, died peacefully on July 30, 2008. Loving father of Edward, Susan and Steven and father-inlaw of Judy, Jonathan and Jil. Adoring and adored grandfather of Lisa, Samantha, Sarah and Benjamin. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 11:30am on August 1. Donations may be made to Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

'WALKING WITH DINOSAURS -- THE LIVE EXPERIENCE' Madison Square Garden is no stranger to roaring, rampaging beasts (and I don't mean overenthusiastic sports fans). The last time dinosaurs charged through its halls they were trying to devour Matthew Broderick and other innocent souls in the 1998 ''Godzilla'' remake. Now these reptiles are back and better behaved, at least toward people. But when it comes to the species' fellow creatures, the game is still eat or be eaten. That interplay is at the heart of ''Walking With Dinosaurs -- the Live Experience,'' which opened on Wednesday at the Garden. The touring show, which compresses some 200 million years of evolution into almost two hours (there's a long intermission), features 10 big (really big) stars like Brachiosauruses (above), Torosauruses and of course Tyrannosaurus rexes. Each life-size animatronic creation is controlled by a team using computers and hydraulics. ''It's like a giant remote-control car,'' said Scott Faris, the production's director. Five smaller species, including three Utahraptors, are wearable puppets, the ultimate Halloween costumes.

Nathan Kensinger generally does not ask for permission when he photographs the decaying remnants of Brooklyn's industrial waterfront. Since 2003, he has wandered into shuttered factories, padlocked basements and forbidding warehouses. He has not been arrested, yet, but he does not want to tempt fate, either. Mr. Kensinger's photographs are now on view in a small exhibition, ''Twilight on the Waterfront: Brooklyn's Vanishing Industrial Heritage,'' that opened on June 17 and runs through Aug. 30 at the central branch of the Brooklyn Public Library.

Instant I-was-there concerts in the big, empty pool basin by M.I.A., Blonde Redhead and TV on the Radio. Packed free shows on blazing Sunday afternoons. The thrift-store couture, the human mural of tattoos, piercings, sunburns and hair dye. Every other midriff drenched from a Pete Rose dive down the Slip 'N Slide.
