SLIDESHOW: In Color and In Black Photographs from two art shows: ''Kirchner and the Berlin Street'' at the Museum of Modern Art, and ''Imageless'' at the Guggenheim. The Kirchner show focuses on seven colorful paintings that depict stylishly dressed female streetwalkers, while the Guggenheim show dissects a work from Ad Reinhardt's ''Black Painting'' series, at left, to demonstrate the process of restoration.

They were hoping for a dream ticket, but now it appears they will have to settle for a speech. The leaders of an online campaign to pressure Senator Barack Obama into picking Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as his running mate have ended their bid, saying all signs indicate that Mrs. Clinton is not in serious contention for the vice-presidential slot.

Eileen G. Slocum, a doyenne of Newport, R.I., society who was a stalwart of the Republican Party both in Rhode Island and nationally and whose family history is dotted with connections to the most moneyed and powerful of the American aristocracy, died on Sunday in Newport. She was 92. Weakened after a stroke in the fall, she died after contracting pneumonia, said her daughter Margy Quinn.

FERRANTI--Redento D. , 85, an internationally recognized physician, passed away July 29, 2008, at St. Raphael Hospital in New Haven after a career during which he pioneered advances in pulmonary rehabilitation, promoted the importance of nutrition in patients with chronic respiratory insufficiency and spearheaded programs to study sleep disorders. Dr. Ferranti, a North Haven, CT, resident, is survived by his wife, Ida; six children: Marc, Peter, Paul, Thomas, Mary and John; and nine grandchildren. Friends may call at The Celentano Funeral Home, 424 Elm Street, New Haven, Friday from 4pm to 8pm, and are invited to attend a funeral mass at the Church of St. Mary, 5 Hillhouse Avenue, New Haven, Saturday at 10am.

An article on July 24 about the Franklin Avenue shuttle in Brooklyn, named the most punctual train in the subway system by New York City Transit, misstated its ridership. It averages 20,000 riders per day, not per week.

The late Tim Russert, moderator of ''Meet the Press'' and Washington bureau chief for NBC News, will maintain an imprint on the network for some time to come: His son, Luke, will serve as an NBC correspondent at large. The elder Mr. Russert, 58, died of a heart attack on June 13. He frequently mentioned Luke, his only child, in television appearances.

''There's no guarantee when it comes to technology,'' said John McAlary, the executive director of the New York State Board of Law Examiners, before the exams. ''There's always a risk that something can go wrong.''

The Books of The Times review last Friday, about ''This Land Is Their Land: Reports From a Divided Nation,'' by Barbara Ehrenreich, misidentified the charges on which Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, was arrested in June 2007 after he made what a law-enforcement officer said were sexual advances in an airport bathroom, an incident recounted in the book. He was charged with disorderly conduct (to which he pleaded guilty) and interference with privacy. (That charge was dropped.) He was not charged with soliciting sex. The review also misidentified the law enforcement agency that employed the officer. He was an airport police officer, not an F.B.I. agent.

FOR CHILDREN AMERICAN GIRL EVENT (Tuesday) Admirers of American Girl -- the book series, the dolls and the stores -- can take their enthusiasm to new heights at this program, a collaboration with the Top of the Rock Observation Deck at Rockefeller Center. Girls 8 and older are invited to have dinner at 5:30 p.m. at the cafe at American Girl Place, the Fifth Avenue store, and then have a private visit to the observation deck, from 6:30 to 9 p.m., for crafts, games and singing. At American Girl Place, 609 Fifth Avenue, at 49th Street; $75 (does not include cafe tip). Reservations required: (877) 247-5223.

A headline with an article in Business Day on Thursday about the House of Representatives' passing a bill that would empower the Food and Drug Administration to regulate tobacco referred incorrectly to the F.D.A.'s planned role. The agency would regulate tobacco through a new office created for that purpose; it would not regulate tobacco through the office that oversees drugs.

ON a hot, bright July afternoon I found myself standing at the tip of Croton Point Park, a peninsula in Westchester County that hooks far out into the Hudson River from its eastern shore near the town of Croton-on-Hudson. For me it was less than an hour's scenic ride on Metro-North from Grand Central Terminal. My guide for this excursion, Matthew Coolidge, had come in a small outboard powerboat. Mr. Coolidge is a soft-spoken student of geomorphology and the director of the Los Angeles-based Center for Land Use Interpretation, a nonprofit group founded in 1994 to document the myriad ways humans interact with the landscape. A few years ago the organization opened an office on the Hudson in Troy, N.Y. Mr. Coolidge began to fly over this landscape in helicopters and small planes, taking aerial photos for a book, ''Up River: Man-Made Sites of Interest on the Hudson From the Battery to Troy,'' published this summer (Blast Books), which graphically illustrates the impact of civilization on the river.

This house, on a quiet street close to the ocean and the Intracoastal Waterway, was built in 1925 but has been fully remodeled. Most of the Mediterranean architectural details are no longer visible. The two-story, 2,388-square-foot house has arched doorways that lead from a central living area with a plaster fireplace to a sitting room on one side and a dining room on the other. The kitchen was recently updated. It has terra-cotta tile floors, stainless-steel appliances and new cabinets. Upstairs, there are three bedrooms, including the master bedroom with its alcove seating area, walls of windows, and fireplace. There are hardwood floors throughout, and there are three and a half bathrooms. The master bathroom has a spa bathtub and a double vanity. Listing agents Shirley and Robert Wyner, Barclay International Realty Inc., (561) 835-4037; www.barclaysrealty.com.

Why should restaurants stop at Eat Local? Some environmental advocates believe they should Drink Local, too. On Tuesday, the Take Back the Tap campaign, spearheaded by Food and Water Watch, a consumer rights organization, and Riverkeeper, a water protection organization, called on New York City restaurants to stop selling bottled water and follow the lead of some city government institutions, like the City Council, which has banned bottled water from official events.

That old devil ''the media'' is back in the news, and it is still only summer. This particular villain is usually brought out in the fall, when one of the presidential candidates is feeling desperate and needs to blame someone else for what looks like a losing campaign.
Exit, Chased by Bear Alan D. Schwartz, the former chief executive of Bear Stearns, is leaving JPMorgan Chase, which bought Bear in March in a deal that shocked Wall Street.

The surges this year in oil and food prices could not have come at a worse moment for the typical American worker, who has not had a raise to speak of in this decade. Workers' leverage is gone. Companies are not creating jobs. Unions that negotiated big wage increases in the 1970s are shadows of their former selves. Cost-of-living adjustments, once commonplace, have disappeared. And the movement of jobs offshore, or the threat of it, has conditioned workers to not even ask for a raise, fearing they will join the millions already laid off.
When the history of the Great Market Crash of 2008 is written, perhaps the following will make for a fitting epigraph: ''Market is collapsing. No more $2k dinners at CRU!!''

BAGNALL--Roger S. The Trustees and Staff of the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, NYU, express their sympathies on the passing of Roger S. Bagnall, longtime educator and music lover, father of Roger Bagnall, Director of the Institute and his family.

J. Murdoch Ritchie, a biophysicist at Yale who used a potent neurotoxin derived from shellfish to help trace the way nerve cells conduct electrical impulses and famously asked the Central Intelligence Agency to share its supply of the poison with scientists, died on July 9 in Hamden, Conn. He was 83. Dr. Ritchie's death was confirmed by his family.

The freshmen entering Greene Central High School in Snow Hill, N.C., in 2005 thought they had something a little extra to look forward to, should they make it through the four years. That year, John Edwards began a program, College for Everyone, to pay a year's tuition for each graduate. But that apparently is not to be. The school's principal recently notified parents that the scholarship program ended with the class of 2008.

EDELSBOURGH--Marie M . Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. Elliot J. Cosgrove, Senior Rabbi Steven M. Friedman, Chairman of the Board Brian G. Lustbader, President

Built in 1921 and 1922, this oceanside residence reflects the romanticism of Palm Beach's Gilded Age. It was designed for one of the founders of the F. W. Woolworth Company by the architect Marion Sims Wyeth. The Old World-style, 10,500-square-foot house called Qui-Si-Sana (Italian for ''Here One Heals'') is surrounded by sculptured hedges. It has an open courtyard, a garden terrace and a formal pool terrace. The 54-foot-long oceanfront living room has floor-to-ceiling arched French doors that lead to terraces on two sides. There are open-air loggias with pebblewood cypress ceilings and lanterns. Oceanside lawns lead to the 175 feet of beachfront. Interior details include a grand stairway, barrel-vaulted foyer, four fireplaces and Cuban tile floors. The house has seven full and two half bathrooms. Listing agents: Cristina Condon and Martin Schaefer, Sotheby's International Realty-Palm Beach, (561) 659-3555; www.sothebyshomes.com/palmbeach.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about an address by Gov. David A. Paterson of New York in which he asked the Legislature to return for a special session in August to grapple with the state's fiscal crisis paraphrased incorrectly from one of his comments. He called on New York and other governments -- not ''citizens'' -- to ''cut up our credit cards.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about advances in light-emitting diodes paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Mark Rea, director of the lighting research center at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, on the future of L.E.D.'s. Mr. Rea said he expected L.E.D.'s to take a dominant position in downlighting, outdoor and track lighting, though not in general illumination. He did not say he expected ''limited success'' for L.E.D.'s.

NEWARK -- When they write the definitive history of the Great Brazilian Lottery Rumor, its authors may not be able to get much closer to its precise origins than the notebook of Leonardo Ferreira, a reporter for The Brazilian Voice newspaper, which is published here. It was Mr. Ferreira who, in the newspaper's July 26 issue, first printed the gossip that the winning ticket in New Jersey's Mega Millions lottery drawing of July 22 had been purchased by a Brazilian immigrant at a supermarket in the Ironbound neighborhood, which has large Brazilian and Portuguese populations. The jackpot was $126 million.

An article on July 17 about the release by Israel of five jailed Lebanese men in a prisoner swap with Hezbollah misstated the date of the assassination in Syria of Imad Mughniyeh, a senior Hezbollah official who the militant group said was killed by Israel. The assassination was in February, not June.

A music review on Thursday about the opening concert in the Mostly Mozart Festival, at Lincoln Center, referred incorrectly to a choreographed work to be performed this month that is a centerpiece of the festival. Although the work, ''Requiem,'' was inspired by Mozart's Requiem, the music of that Requiem is not heard in it.
China's New Era Deal makers in China are working overtime to be ready for the big event on Aug. 1. Not the Olympics -- those start on the lucky Chinese date of 8/8/08.

Missouri quarterback Chase Daniel led the Tigers to a 12-2 record and the upper levels of the national rankings last year. He finished fourth in the voting for the Heisman Trophy and passed for 4,306 yards and 33 touchdowns, both team records. He will contribute a diary to The New York Times during the college football season. In this entry, which was told to Thayer Evans, he talks about his summer classes, the preseason polls and e-mailing with Warren Buffett.
Although Texas Tech's No. 14 ranking in the USA Today Top 25 coaches' poll is its highest preseason spot in 31 years, Red Raiders Coach Mike Leach has tried to play down this season's expectations.

Just as I was starting to think about packing up and leaving the press box, the sky over Yankee Stadium told me I'd better hang around if I want to keep my socks dry. The heavens turned a nasty black and, pretty soon, opened up for about a 20-minute downpour. After holding off all afternoon, the rain came down in sheets on the empty Stadium with thunder and lightning crackling.

BEIJING -- For a stretch of Saturday evening, cars lined the sides of some of Beijing's highways, their drivers and passengers having climbed out and lined up along the guardrails. Overpasses and bridges were stuffed with people. They hung out on street corners and watched from hills and high-floor apartments.

In many ways it was a nice quiet and very hot day in the paddock today at the Hungaroring. But I had this strange experience of feeling that every time I turned around I was seeing Bernie Ecclestone, the sport's 77-year-old promoter, popping up all over the place and moving around at the fine, brisk, invigorated pace of a teenager onto something cool.

In Sunday's paper, I write about CriminalSearches.com, the first free, ad-supported database of criminal archives in all 50 states and 3,500 counties in the United States. The site presents the entertaining and somewhat guilt-inducing opportunity to dig for dirt on all your friends and colleagues.

Larry Rohter, who recently returned to the United States after many years covering Brazil, has a fascinating story in the Sunday paper examining how high oil prices may be blunting the globalization of manufacturing. Concerns over carbon dioxide emissions may be playing a role, as well. He starts out with an anecdote about Tesla Motors, which planned to build its batteries in Thailand, assemble most of the components of its electric sports cars in Britain, and then sell them in the United States.

Carmelo Anthony will start at forward for Team USA at the Beijing Olympics. He completed his fifth year with the Denver Nuggets in the N.B.A. after leading Syracuse University to the 2003 N.C.A.A. title. He'll be offering his insight on USA Basketball and the Olympic experience to beat writer Pete Thamel throughout the Olympic Games.

Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. women's water polo team, which is favored to win a gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. She'll be writing occasional posts for the Rings blog from the Olympics.

Taylor Spink Award at the Hall of Fame in 1989 and about his working for the commissioner's office as a historian after retiring from The Chicago Tribune.

One advantage Stephenie Meyer has over most best-selling writers is screaming teenage fans. Fans who scream even when tech guys cross the stage before she comes out. Then again, Meyer's sold-out appearance at the Nokia Theater in Times Square on Friday evening was sort of a rock concert. The cheerful and modest author, a Mormon and mother of three boys who lives in Phoenix, Ariz, was appearing with Justin Furstenfeld of the angsty band Blue October.
A rift between Egypt’s Christians and Muslims has widened due to increased sectarian violence.
Two people are dead and a fired worker is in custody after a shooting during a shift change outside a book warehouse in Bristol, a suburb of Philadelphia.
A federal judge called off a trial to hear lawsuits stemming from a 2006 plane crash that killed 49 people in Lexington after family members and Comair reached settlements in most of the cases.
A woman who helped a spy transmit military secrets to the Chinese government was sentenced to 18 months in prison.
A lawsuit claims that Florida’s proposal to acquire 300 square miles of Everglades land from United States Sugar was illegally brokered in closed-door meetings.
The judge overseeing the criminal cases for the five remaining defendants in the Jena Six case was removed against his will over his remarks about the teenagers.
After Pedro Martínez left the m0und on Friday, the Astros pinch-hitter Mark Loretta hit a grand slam against Mets reliever Aaron Heilman to break a 3-3 tie.
After an eight-inning deadlock, a single by Vladimir Guerrero and a base hit by Torii Hunter scored Reggie Willits for the only run of the game.
Manny Ramírez grounded into a double play in the ninth, but the Dodgers hope he will end their long-term star power drought.
More than three months after he suffered a rare foot ailment, Brian Bruney was activated from the 60-day disabled list Friday.
After suffering discomfort in his strained rotator cuff, John Maine will not pitch again until Friday night’s game against Florida.
The aid group Doctors Without Borders said Friday that it had been forced to pull staff members from two areas in the war-torn Darfur region because of attacks against them.
President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva signed a decree on Friday formally creating the Amazon Fund to fight deforestation of the world’s largest rain forest.
A London jury acquitted Barry George, 48, on Friday in his second trial for the 1996 killing of Jill Dando, one of Britain’s most popular television anchors.

After more than two weeks of deliberations, a jury was dismissed after failing to reach a verdict in a trial of three men accused of being accomplices in the 2005 bombings on the London transit system.
The International Atomic Energy Agency adopted a plan on Friday for inspecting India’s nuclear reactors, enabling India to finalize a pact with the United States for fuel and technology.
When Ken Griffey Jr. was traded to the Chicago White Sox on Thursday, few tears were shed in Cincinnati.
India’s central bank has released a report predicting an economic slowdown, rising inflation and dwindling corporate profit growth over the next nine months.
First Priority Bank of Bradenton, Fla., was closed by state regulators on Friday, the eighth bank to collapse this year as lenders grapple with failed loans stemming from a slump in home prices.

Minor league officials have fined and suspended 15 players and 2 managers for their roles in a bench-clearing brawl July 24 between the Class A Peoria Chiefs and the Dayton Dragons. The Midwest League did not identify the players suspended. Suspensions ranged from three games for most players to 60 days for one.

The Golden Gate Yacht Club has appealed a decision by the New York Supreme Court’s Appellate Division that stripped it of the role of challenger of record for the next America’s Cup. On Tuesday, the court ruled, 3-2, that Spain’s Club Náutico Español de Vela, not San Francisco’s Golden Gate club, should be the challenger of record, giving it the right to negotiate the terms of the next competition with the reigning America’s Cup champion, Alinghi of Switzerland. The decision reversed a lower-court ruling, which had given the right to the Golden Gate club.

Cablevision and NBC Universal have not come to an agreement for Cablevision to carry 2,200 hours of live online, broadband Summer Games coverage from Beijing that will be streamed to computers. The failure to make a deal also means that Cablevision subscribers will not receive NBC’s new Olympic basketball and soccer channels.

Trainers of horses that test positive for anabolic steroids at the Breeders’ Cup in October will face a one-year suspension from the event, and three-time violators will be banned for life, according to new rules announced Friday. The Breeders’ Cup will be at Santa Anita in California on Oct. 24-25. Beginning next year, the Breeders’ Cup said it would not fund stakes purses or award Breeders’ Cup Challenge events to racetracks in the United States or Canada unless they adopt model rules on anabolic steroids.

Jelena Jankovic was upset by Dominika Cibulkova, 7-5, 6-2, at the Rogers Cup in Montreal. Jankovic could have taken the No. 1 spot from Ana Ivanovic if she had reached the final. Instead, Cibulkova, 19, knocked out another seeded player, after defeating fifth-seeded Elena Dementieva and 12th-seeded Nadia Petrova. Jankovic has missed four chances to become No. 1.

The Clorox Company reported a fourth-quarter profit that fell less than analysts estimated as the maker of Glad trash bags and its namesake bleach increased prices and sold more of its products. Clorox's environmentally friendly cleaners and Burt's Bees products led sales growth in the quarter, suggesting the company would continue to expand amid record high prices for oil, corn and soybeans. Net income declined to $158 million, or $1.13 a share, for the quarter that ended June 30, from $164 million, or $1.07 a share, a year earlier. Excluding reorganization and other costs, Clorox earned $1.18 a share. The average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed was $1.10. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

PHILLIPS--Lois Farrell . Lois Phillips died July 30th after a battle with leukemia which she fought with good cheer and unflagging determination until her death. She was 68. Mrs. Phillips was a lawyer's lawyer, well known and much sought after for her knowledge of real estate law, and stood out among her peers because of her direct, no-nonsense approach to problems a trait she acquired in earlier years as an elementaryschool teacher at St. Mary's Elementary School in Manhasset. She began and spent much of her legal career at Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood and after a stint as a Assistant Bureau Chief in the Real Estate Finance Division of the Attorney General's office, joined Chehebar Deveney & Phillips as a partner. Mrs. Phillips was, as she proudly proclaimed, a Queens girl, and spent the last nine years living near Riverhead where she was active in local politics. She is survived by her husband, Robert, her two daughters, Alice and Regina, both lawyers, and her son, Robert, and by her grandchildren, Reid and Quinn, on whom she doted. Visiting hours will be on Sunday, August 3rd, at the AlexanderTuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Route 25A in Wading River, from 2 to 4pm and from 7 to 9pm. The funeral mass will be held at St. John the Baptist Church, 1488 North Country Road in Wading River, at 10am on Monday. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Down Syndrome Research and Treatment Foundation, www.dsrtf.org. Lois was a special, loving person and will be deeply missed.

OBER--Norman , author, 89, died of complications after heart surgery. He was the blessed and beloved husband of Benita Ober for 10 years and husband for 47 years of the late Anita Ober. Beloved father of Dody, Amy; fatherin-law to Les, Richard; loving stepfather to Wendi and Paul. Loving grandfather to Timothy and Michael. Greatgrandfather to Conner, Bailey and Kailyn. Norman's life and heart were rich in love for his family. No words can be said to capture this incredible human being. Those of us who were fortunate to have him touch our lives we will be forever grateful. May you be at peace my darling. Lovingly, Sweetie mouse. Services are, Sunday, August 3, 2008, 11:30am at Par-Troy Funeral Home, 95 Parsippany Road Parsippany, NJ 973-887-3235 a memorial Service in September, Date/Location TBD. Family Gathering Sunday to Wednesday at the Ober residence.

Kilo-what? Electricity is paid for by the kilowatt hour (kWh), a term invented 125 years ago. ''The Grid,'' a book by Phillip F. Schewe, says it takes about a pound of coal to produce one kilowatt hour, enough energy to run a large air-conditioner for an hour, wash 200 pounds of laundry or mill 300 pounds of grain (but probably not in a New York City apartment). Class Rate How much you pay depends on who you are. Nearly 85 percent of Con Ed customers pay the EL1 Residential or Religious rate, which worked out to about 30.1 cents per kWh in June. There are 11 other classifications, including EL7, customers who heat with electricity (and pay lower rates in winter); EL9, for large customers, some of whose rates differ by time of day; and EL11, for customers who generate their own power. EL is Con Edspeak for electric.

Two senators introduced a bill on Friday to compel the Food and Drug Administration to adopt comprehensive rules on sunscreen. Last summer, the food and drug agency proposed updated rules that would standardize the labeling on sunscreens, giving consumers more detailed information about their efficacy. But the agency has not yet made the regulations final.

9 P.M. (Starz) GONE BABY GONE (2007) In Ben Affleck's directorial debut two investigators (Casey Affleck, left, and Michelle Monaghan) search South Boston for a kidnapped girl whose mother (Amy Ryan, in her Oscar-nominated turn) may know more than she's telling. Morgan Freeman plays the chief of the police department's missing-children division. Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times that Ben Affleck ''has taken a satisfyingly tough look into conscience, to those dark places where some men also go astray.'' She added, ''I'm not sure exactly when Casey Affleck became such a good actor.'' 5:45 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: CHARLIE CHAPLIN''Charlie: The Life and Art of Charles Chaplin,'' Richard Schickel's 2003 documentary, is followed by five must-see films starring and directed by Chaplin: ''Modern Times'' (1936), above, in which the Little Tramp tries to build a home with a young slum girl (Paulette Goddard, who would become Chaplin's third wife that same year), at 8 p.m.; ''The Great Dictator'' (1940), the comic gem about a Jewish barber and Hitler look-alike, at 9:30; ''Monsieur Verdoux'' (1947), about a man who woos and kills rich widows, at 11:45; ''Limelight'' (1952), Chaplin's last American film, featuring his classic duo with Buster Keaton, at 2 a.m.; and ''A King in New York'' (1957), about a recently deposed European king who loses his money while stranded in New York and is accused of being a Communist, at 4:15. Robert Osborne and Rose McGowan are the evening's hosts.

Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda reshuffled his cabinet and his party's leadership on Friday to try to raise his low approval ratings. Mr. Fukuda kept Masahiko Komura as foreign minister and Nobutaka Machimura as chief cabinet secretary. He moved Bunmei Ibuki, the Liberal Democratic Party's secretary general, to the post of finance minister, and appointed Taro Aso, a former foreign minister, as the party's new secretary general. The party must dissolve Parliament's lower house and hold a general election by September 2009.

I wouldn't say Spanish cuisine is all over Hong Kong, but it has understandable appeal. There's paella (stuff on rice, a theme we know well) and tapas (dim-sum-like plates for sharing). By coincidence, I recently had two Spanish meals in two very different -- but equally recommended --neighborhoods. Both offer a good selection of mid-priced international cuisines and the chance to sit outside while eating, drinking and smoking (which is a plus or a minus depending on your habits).

The heavily favored Indian Blessing left five other 3-year-old fillies at the quarter pole and drew away for a seven-length victory in the $250,000 Test Stakes at Saratoga Race Course. The Test, the most prestigious race at Saratoga for 3-year-old female sprinters, was Indian Blessing’s seventh win of her nine-race career. She earned $150,000, pushing her career earnings past $2 million.

An article last Sunday about under-age immigrant workers who were detained in a raid in May at a kosher meatpacking plant in Postville, Iowa, misidentified the position that Representative Luis V. An article on July 20 about the economy’s effects on Americans’ vacations misattributed the saying that it is the journey, not the arrival, that matters. Although it has been attributed through the years to T. S. Eliot — as the article did — Leonard Woolf, the author and the husband of Virginia Woolf, in his autobiography, “Downhill All the Way,” cites Montaigne, the 16th-century essayist, as having written, “It is not the arrival, but the journey which matters.”.

An article last Sunday about the annual BlogHer conference, which helps female bloggers, misstated the number of women on a Forbes.com listing last year of the top 25 Web celebrities. There were four, not three. The article also misstated the type of work done by Lisa Stone, one of BlogHer’s founders, for HBO and E! television. She has produced interactive Web sites for them, not blog networks.

In 1971 and 1972 I produced a nationally distributed television documentary titled “Class . . . and the Classroom” that reported on conditions in Duluth, Minn., as the schools prepared to follow a class-desegregation mandate from the state. Duluth would have been the first school district in the nation to desegregate on class, rather than racial, lines (Emily Bazelon, July 20). The Duluth Board of Education eventually refused to comply with the state mandate, and chastened state-education officials backed down. A local TV station bought our program with the intention of keeping it off any channel in the community. Only a threat of a national exposé by Bill Greeley, who was then the radio-TV editor of the trade magazine Variety, forced the station to put it on air.

Daniel Kurtz-Phelan states in his article (July 13) that there “has been no significant decrease in drug flows out of Colombia or in the availability of cocaine or heroin in the United States.” Law-enforcement officials in 38 U.S. cities, however, have reported decreased availability of cocaine since January 2007. This coincides with a 30 percent jump in the price per gram of cocaine on American streets over the past year.

SEMELS--Clinton L., 77, of Key West, FL, passed away Saturday, July 19, 2008, at the Lower Keys Medical Center, Key West. He was born April 3, 1931, in New York, NY, to Harry and Blanche Marcus Semels. Dr. Semels graduated from the University of Iowa and New York University Dental College. He served in the U.S. Navy as a lieutenant. Dr. Semels operated a dental practice in Manhattan for many years before retiring to Key West 14 years ago. In the early days of the AIDS epidemic he was one of the few dentists who would treat those with the disease. He was a member of the Paradise Big Band and the Keys Chamber Orchestra. Surviving are his wife, Marlene A. Freeman of Key West; son, Jon Renfield of Los Angeles, CA; daughter, Dori Hartley of Fort Lauderdale, FL; and granddaughter, Alexandra Contreras of Fort Lauderdale. He was proceeded in death by his sister, Lou Levine. Memorial services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to the Paradise Big Band, 22931 Blackbeard Lane, Cudjoe Key, FL 33042. He was a good musician, a good man and a good friend. We will miss him.

WERTHEIM--Charles D. Born 1917 in the Bronx, departed the evening of July 24, 2008 to join his treasured wife of 64 years, Audrey. Charles will be remembered by his daughters Cheryl (Stephen) Gaudette and Lynn (Manny) DiMatteo. Charles was a proud WWII veteran and prominent business owner of Wertheim Typography Co. His sons-in-law strive to be as doting to their wives as Charles was to Audrey. Grandchildren Daniel (Colleen), Rebecca and Joshua Gaudette are committed to carrying on the fire with which Charles lived life. As Charles' lifelong friend Bob Smith gives life to his past, Charles' five great-grandchildren ensure his place in the future.

Address: 575 Park Avenue, at 63rd Street, #305 The Property: This one-bedroom one-bath co-op in the former Beekman Hotel is an ideal pied-à-terre. The monthly maintenance of $1,891 is probably too hefty for first-time home buyers, but it does include daily maid service and utilities. The kitchen is small and needs updating, and the rest of the apartment could use a paint job. But the bedroom is a nice size and has ample closet space, and the bathroom has been renovated with marble tile.

Aaron B. Charney, a former Sullivan & Cromwell associate who famously sued his employer in 2007, accusing it of discrimination, has landed at another large firm. In September, he will join the New York office of Clifford Chance as a fifth-year associate specializing in mergers and acquisitions. Mr. Charney's suit asserted that some Sullivan & Cromwell partners had discriminated against him because he is gay. The firm denied the charges at the time, fired Mr. Charney and filed a countersuit. The case was ultimately settled last October. Sullivan & Cromwell declined to comment last week.

FOGELSON--Gussie Lillian, (December 23rd 1912 to August 1st, 2008) died peacefully at home in her 96th year of natural causes. Beloved wife of the late Nathan B. Fogelson; adored mother of Robert M. Fogelson and Maria J. Fuente, David R. and Nancy Fogelson, and Jeffrey P. and Janet Fogelson; well-loved grandmother of Lisa Fogelson and Robert Ballard, Susie Fogelson and Gary Nelson, Michael Fogelson, Jennifer Fogelson Trzesniowski and Clint Trzesniowski, Maria Alvarez-Fuente and Joshua M. Fogelson; and great-grandmother of Camille Ballard, Isabel Nelson, Nathan Ballard, and Ingrid Lillian Nelson. She was a devoted sister to Miriam Schreck, Seymore and Roslyn Richman, and the late Grant and Penny Richman. She leaves behind a bereft family of nieces, nephews, cousins, and many friends. She brought her intelligence, strength, kindness, and love to her family and her community and will be remembered for her beauty, laughter, and wisdom. Services on Sunday, August 3rd at The Riverside Memorial Chapel (77th St. and Amsterdam Ave.) at 1:15pm. Shiva will be held at the home of Janet and Jeffrey Fogelson at 16 Oak Lane, Scarsdale, NY on Sunday and Monday evenings.

CAMMETT--John McKay, July 8th, 1927--July 30th, 2008. Husband, father, grandfather, teacher, respected scholar, activist against social and political injustice, died at home after numerous illnesses. Lover of all things Italian, he devoted his life to its history, culture, politics, beauties. US Navy 1945--46. Professor of History at Wayne University, Middlebury College, Hunter College, Rutgers University and John J. College-CUNY (1967--1991) where he served as Professor, Provost and Dean of Faculty (1969-1974) and helped build an institution to serve New Yorkers, to invent the emerging science of criminal justice and to integrate liberal education into the training of professionals. Author of Antonio Gramsci and the Origins of Italian Communism (1967) and editor, Bibliografia gramsciana (2007). Mourned by his wife, Sandi Cooper, daughters, Lisa, Ann (Marcia Gallo) and Melani (Angelo Manioudakis), grandchildren, Mena, Alex and Lena, brother, Stuart (Barbara), sister, Joanne Hansen (Robert), many relatives, countless friends and colleagues. Memorial to be announced. Contributions to appropriate social or political causes. CAMMETT--John. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Professor Emeritus of History John Cammett, an internationally renowned scholar of Italian revolutionary Antonio Gramsci, former Dean of Faculty, Provost, and Chair of the History Department at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, former Professor of History at the CUNY Graduate Center, and member of the Faculty Senate. His many years of exemplary service to CUNY will long be remembered. We offer deepest condolences to his wife, Sandi Cooper, Professor of History at the College of Staten Island and the CUNY Graduate Center, and to his entire family. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr. Chair Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein Chancellor CAMMETT--John. The members of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice Department of History mourn the loss of their revered colleague, Professor Emeritus John Cammett. As Chair of the department and later in retirement, he inspired us with his keen intellect, his scholarly achievements, and his warm friendship. We extend our condolences to his devoted wife Sandi, his children and grandchildren.

WILSON--Robert J.M., of Catonsville, MD, formerly of Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY, Gibson Island, MD, and Vero Beach, FL, died of pneumonia on July 16, 2008 at the age of 88. He was the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Albert J.M. Wilson of Greenwich, CT. He was the class of 1938 at the Choate School and graduated from Yale University 1942. In 1940 he joined a year long expedition to the South Seas on the Fahnestock Expedition on a three-masted, 137-foot schooner Director II. During a nine-month period, they traveled to American Samoa, Fiji, French Polynesia, New Caledonia, and Australia, recording music and collecting Pacific bird specimens for the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. The recordings brought back from the expedition were the first electronic recordings made in Oceania and are among the last field recordings made there before World War II changed the ancient cultures of the region forever. During the war, he served for four years in the South Pacific theatre attaining the rank of Captain in the Transportation Corps of the Army. He became President of the Adams Express and Petroleum and Resources Corporation, two closed-end investment management companies in 1975. He was instrumental in relocating them to Baltimore from New York in 1976. He served as President and a director from 1975 1986. He remained a director of both companies until 2006. He was a member of the Society of Security Analysts, a member and former Chairman of the Association of Publicly Traded Investment Companies, and he was a member of the Advisory Investment Committee for the Maryland State Retirement Systems. He was a former member of the New York Yacht Club, the Shelter Island Yacht Club, the Gibson Island Club and the Maryland Club. He is survived by his wife of 56 years Yvette Laneres Wilson, a daughter Mrs. Edward. H. Welbourn, III of Owings Mills, MD and two sons R.J. Montgomery Wilson, Jr. of Reading, MA and Geoffrey L. Wilson of Poughkeepsie, NY as well as six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: The Chesapeake Bay Foundation, 6 Herndon Ave., Annapolis, MD 21403.

MARSHALL--Peter Bennett, 75, Rutherford, NJ, July 29, 2008, of liver cancer. SHEINKER--Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Murry, loving mother of Ellen Abrams (Jordan), proud grandmother of Jill Alper (Todd) and Amy Miller (Jonathan), greatgrandmother of Matthew, Andrew and Jeffrey. May she rest in peace.

ROMNEY--Dr. Leonard S., died July 26 from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Survivors; beloved wife Eleanor, children Bennett and Dr. Carla Romney and brother Dr. Seymour Romney. Burial was on July 30, 2008 in Everett, MA. A graduate of Syracuse University, he received his doctorate from Yeshiva University in education.

BLOCH--Peter, 86, died July 31, 2008 in New York City. Beloved friend, noted journalist and historian and fluent in four languages. Born in Frankfort, Germany he left in 1939 as a teenager and joined the underground in Belgium. He later was interned in Switzerland. He came to the U.S. in 1949 and became a citizen in 1955. He was the founder and President of the Association of Puerto Rican-Hispanic Culture. He was the U.S. Representative of the French Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was appointed a Knight of the Order of Isabella Catolica in 1969 by the Head of the Spanish State.

OBER--Norman, author, 89, died of complications after heart surgery. He was the blessed and beloved husband of Benita Ober for 10 years and husband for 47 years of the late Anita Ober. Beloved father of Dody, Amy; fatherin-law to Les, Richard; loving stepfather to Wendi and Paul. Loving grandfather to Timothy and Michael. Greatgrandfather to Conner, Bailey and Kailyn. Norman's life and heart were rich in love for his family. No words can be said to capture this incredible human being. Those of us who were fortunate to have him touch our lives we will be forever grateful. May you be at peace my darling. Lovingly, Sweetie mouse. Services are, Sunday, August 3, 2008, 11:30am at Par-Troy Funeral Home, 95 Parsippany Road Parsippany, NJ 973-887-3235 a memorial Service in September, Date/Location TBD. Family Gathering Sunday to Wednesday at the Ober residence.

Phillip R. Bennett, the former chief executive of the failed commodities brokerage Refco, has agreed never to serve as an officer or director of a public company. The agreement, made with the Securities and Exchange Commission, comes after Mr. Bennett was sentenced to 16 years in prison in a criminal action related to Refco's downfall. The company went public in August 2005, but collapsed two months later after it disclosed that a $430 million debt had been concealed. Mr. Bennett later pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and fraud.

LETTERI--Joseph M., M.D. Established the care of patients with kidney disease on Long Island and helped create National and International guidelines and standards for dialysis. Joseph M. Letteri, born in Brooklyn 75 years ago, passed away suddenly on June 1, 2008 while visiting his ''old haunts'' in Tuscany with his beloved wife, Mary. His home was in Sands Point, NY, on Long Island. Dr. Letteri attended St. Peter's College in Jersey City and later, while attending Georgetown Medical School, was greatly influenced by Dr. George Schreiner, a pioneer in the study of kidney disease and dialysis. His further studies were at NYU and at Jefferson Medical College with Lawrence Wesson, M.D., and at Harvard with John Merrill, M.D., all of whom were early leaders in this new field of Nephrology. To fulfill the military obligation required of physicians at the time, he served in the United States Air Force at Wiesbaden Germany, as a specialist in kidney disease with the rank of Captain. Dr. Letteri became Chief of the Division of Nephrology at Nassau County Medical Center and moved to Long Island with his family in 1970. He established the teaching program in kidney disease that has produced many of the kidney specialists now caring for patients on Long Island. He was the first to bring sophisticated diagnostic and treatment methods for kidney disease to the people of Long Island and began dialysis for those whose kidneys had failed. When the State University of New York at Stony Brook began its medical school, Dr. Letteri was in the forefront in organizing the curriculum for instruction in kidney disease for medical students. His research studying the bone disease of renal failure patients at Brookhaven National Laboratories was also groundbreaking. Dr. Letteri rose to the rank of Professor of Medicine at Stony Brook. His activities included work with The National Kidney Foundation on the Medical Advisory Board for New York and later as the National Chairman of The Dialysis Committee that developed the guidelines for Dialysis. In 1987, The National Kidney Foundation presented him with the Lester Hoenig Award for outstanding contributions in Nephrology. His patients will attest to the fact that with all his accomplishments, above all he was a warm and caring doctor. Dr. Letteri was a sensitive parent and family man. He will be greatly missed by Mary, his wife of 48 years, his son Jeffrey Letteri and wife Mary Ann, and his daughter Marisa McCusker and her husband Jeffrey, and his grandchildren John, Austin and Meagan McCusker.

BRILL--Judith, most beloved wife of Joseph Artusa, devoted mother of Jason Zweibeck (Lauren), Benjamin and Laura Artusa. Cherished grandmother of Ethan. Loving sister of Michael (Patricia) Brill. You will always be in our thoughts and hearts forever. Services to be determined at a later date.

The wrapped-up look of winter is a new summer trend, although it may baffle some to see young women and men on Fifth Avenue in 90-degree weather with their necks swathed in gossamer wool, cotton and cashmere scarves. The reason is not rebellion; it's to combat air-conditioning. This style is downright functional, considering the white fox furs women were somehow persuaded to carry in the un-air-conditioned 1920s and 1930s.

THE FACTS Unlike individual gymnastic events, the team event is less about ego than national pride; think of it as one big Danskin-clad chest-bump. The strongest three women on each team go head to head on the vault, uneven bars, balance beam and floor; men follow the same format on the pommel horse, rings, vault, parallel bars and high bar. ''At the Olympic level, gymnastics becomes a lot more mental than physical,'' says Ron Galimore, a vice president of USA Gymnastics, the sport's governing body. ''With so much pressure, so many little things can go wrong.''

HEADING HOME No one would dare say it, but there is a clock ticking when you leave your team for the birth of your child. Sure, it isn't 24 hours, but it isn't a week, either. And once you cross that threshold of acceptable leave of absence, people start grumbling. I do miss baseball in some ways, but one thing I don't miss is the sacrifices you're expected to make in the face of life-changing events. There is a game pretty much every day, and to be absent from one is unheard of. You have to be dead, or someone else has to be dead, and after a day or two any excuse short of that is frowned upon.

TAKING A BREAK, MAY 23, 2008 Jose van Lieshout-van de Wiel, front left, 60, a psychologist from Tilburg, the Netherlands, stops with her hiking tour group for a picnic on the way from Assisi to Spello. ''I went with my husband and my sister -- there were 15 of us, 3 men and 12 women. My husband liked that. It was a walking trip, walking from one hotel to another for 11 days. We walked every day, from about 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., in the woods, on the hills, in the mud. Sometimes we passed a small village, and we drank a little local wine, which was very nice, but it was always raining, so we didn't see many people. It was silent in the woods and in the small villages; it was peaceful, but the rain was terrible. My husband sometimes travels to the Himalayas -- to Nepal and Tibet -- but I only travel to countries in Europe, and always with a group. I prefer to sleep in a hotel, not in tents any longer. For me, traveling is mostly about seeing local habits and local people and hearing the language and seeing the nature. And it's laughing -- traveling in a group, it's always nice to meet new people.'' As told to Austin Considine

Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, a law firm based in New York, jolted legal circles last week when it announced the layoff of 96 lawyers in its real estate finance and securitization areas. He asked very little of life, only to be with his adoring wife Eleanor, only to be with his loving children Caren Epstein, Sylvie Standley, and Jeffrey Katz, along with his revered grandchildren Brandon Epstein and Brett Standley. And he was with them all to the end, and always will be. Allen L. Katz suddenly and quietly passed away at his home in West Palm Beach. He was 76. He was past President of The Manhattan Beach Jewish Center, in Brooklyn, and while attending college joined his father Benne and brother Murray Katz in running the Williamsburg Steel Company. After the company was sold, he served as a consultant to the Acme Steel Company. His joy was giving, and all he gave to mourn his sudden passing. KATZ--Allen. How sad and how tragic. PHILLIPS--Lois Farrell. Lois Phillips died July 30th after a battle with leukemia which she fought with good cheer and unflagging determination until her death. She was 68. Mrs. Phillips was a lawyer's lawyer, well known and much sought after for her knowledge of real estate law, and stood out among her peers because of her direct, no-nonsense approach to problems a trait she acquired in earlier years as an elementaryschool teacher at St. Mary's Elementary School in Manhasset. She began and spent much of her legal career at Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood and after a stint as a Assistant Bureau Chief in the Real Estate Finance Division of the Attorney General's office, joined Chehebar Deveney & Phillips as a partner. Mrs. Phillips was, as she proudly proclaimed, a Queens girl, and spent the last nine years living near Riverhead where she was active in local politics. She is survived by her husband, Robert, her two daughters, Alice and Regina, both lawyers, and her son, Robert, and by her grandchildren, Reid and Quinn, on whom she doted. Visiting hours will be on Sunday, August 3rd, at the AlexanderTuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Route 25A in Wading River, from 2 to 4pm and from 7 to 9pm. The funeral mass will be held at St. John the Baptist Church, 1488 North Country Road in Wading River, at 10am on Monday. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Down Syndrome Research and Treatment Foundation, www.dsrtf.org. Lois was a special, loving person and will be deeply missed.

THE FACTS The longest of the sprints, the 400 meters -- one complete lap around the track -- calls for an uncommon mix of speed and endurance. While the 100-meter dash demands that runners explode off the blocks and proceed at full speed, the 400 is more of a gradual build. Some runners go out fast, while others hang back and try to control the second 200. Regardless, by the 300-meter mark, the pack has usually converged briefly before spreading out again during the final 100-meter homestretch, when the leaders make their surge. ''Anybody's capable of running a fast 300 meters,'' Harvey Glance says. ''It's the person who can control the last 100 meters who usually wins.''

MICHAEL SCHUMACHER, the seven-time Formula One champion, is having a tough time leaving his past career behind. Mr. Schumacher retired in 2006, but last December he took over the steering wheel of the taxi he was riding in and sped through traffic to make it to the airport on time.

THE FACTS Longer than a sprint, shorter than a distance race, the 1,500 is the middle child of competitive running, rebellious and unpredictable. It's the closest metric approximation to the mile, and winning requires equal parts speed, endurance and cunning. Jostling is a given, and as long as a runner doesn't impede the progress of a competitor, elbow jabs and shin kicks are fair game. The pack of runners moves like an organism, constantly changing shape, and all sorts of accidents can happen. Which, for the viewer at home, means three and a half minutes of fun and mayhem.

IN his July 29 Science Times article ''10 Things to Scratch From Your Worry List,'' John Tierney urged readers not to waste the summer consumed by guilt about their cars' supposed ''planet-destroying A/C,'' because an Edmunds.com report had concluded that ''the aerodynamic drag from opening the windows cancels out any fuel savings from turning off the air-conditioner.'' Mr. Tierney is on solid ground: Edmunds, a site that offers car-buying guidance, and Consumer Reports did not see much of a fuel-economy impact of either running the air or rolling down the windows in separate 2005 tests.

KORKIDIS--JoAnn, January 22, 1956, died, August 1, 2008. She was the beloved mother of John, Justin, and Jason. Services, 2-4pm, 7-9pm Sunday, R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Hampton Bays. Church service, 10:30am Monday, St. Rosalie's Parish Center. Burial, St. Michael's Cemetery, Astoria.

WERTHEIM--Charles D. Born 1917 in the Bronx, departed the evening of July 24, 2008 to join his treasured wife of 64 years, Audrey. Charles will be remembered by his daughters Cheryl (Stephen) Gaudette and Lynn (Manny) DiMatteo. Charles was a proud WWII veteran and prominent business owner of Wertheim Typography Co. His sons-in-law strive to be as doting to their wives as Charles was to Audrey. Grandchildren Daniel (Colleen), Rebecca and Joshua Gaudette are committed to carrying on the fire with which Charles lived life. As Charles' lifelong friend Bob Smith gives life to his past, Charles' five great-grandchildren ensure his place in the future.
FIFTIES STYLE $1,200,000

THE modern Olympic Games have become as much a global contest among designers and architects as among athletes. Each Olympics is expected to produce a logo, a signature building -- and a characteristic torch that symbolizes local tradition and national character. The Berlin Olympics of 1936 was the first to see a torch carried from Greece to the opening ceremonies. The Nazis knew torchlight parades -- from the great party conclaves in Nuremburg -- and Leni Riefenstahl made the similarities clear in her film ''Olympia.''

He helped strengthen all of our member agencies with technical support and funding, making all of us stronger collectively. We will miss his wisdom and his friendship. A pioneer in socially responsible investing has agreed to pay $500,000 to settle a claim by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company violated its own investment criteria. Two funds managed by the Pax World Management Corporation bought at least 10 securities between them that the funds' policies would have prohibited because the companies are involved in producing weapons, alcohol, tobacco or gambling products, the S.E.C. said in a statement last week.

With profound sorrow, the Aleph Society marks the passing of its Founding Chair Jack Nash and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Helen, his children Pamela and George, Josh and Beth, his grandchildren, and entire family. Jack was a giant among men and an admired communal leader. For Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz and us all, he was an inspiring figure and visionary philanthropist, whose penetrating insight enabled him to see what others could not. Under his leadership, the Aleph Society succeeded to publish the English translation of the Talmud, support Jewish education and to bring Jewish texts and learning to communities around the world, particularly Israel, the United States and the Former Soviet Union. We will miss him deeply and mourn the loss of a friend, a partner and mentor. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. FERRANTI--Redento D., 85, an internationally recognized physician, passed away July 29, 2008, at St. Raphael Hospital in New Haven after a career during which he pioneered advances in pulmonary rehabilitation, promoted the importance of nutrition in patients with chronic respiratory insufficiency and spearheaded programs to study sleep disorders. Dr. Ferranti, a North Haven, CT, resident, is survived by his wife, Ida; six children: Marc, Peter, Paul, Thomas, Mary and John; and nine grandchildren. Friends may call at The Celentano Funeral Home, 424 Elm Street, New Haven, Friday from 4pm to 8pm, and are invited to attend a funeral mass at the Church of St. Mary, 5 Hillhouse Avenue, New Haven, Saturday at 10am.

USAF (WWII). Entrepreneur, Builder, Civic Activist, Artist, USTA Senior Tennis Champion. Proud of his family and generous to all. A wonderful life.

THE FACTS At roughly 10 seconds in length, track and field's shortest Olympic race is also its most glamorous: the winner is anointed the fastest human alive. The American Carl Lewis gave the race its modern-day sizzle at the 1984 Olympics (it was one of four gold medals he won at those Games). Since then, the 100 has gained notoriety of a different sort, thanks to drug scandals beginning with that of Ben Johnson of Canada, who lost his 1988 gold medal after testing positive for steroids. Britain's Linford Christie, who won the gold medal in 1992, was banned from the sport for two years for alleged drug use; the American Tim Montgomery was stripped of his world record in 2005. And then there's Marion Jones, the former 2000 American gold medalist currently serving a six-month prison term for perjury involving her own steroid use.

MINTZER--Serena, 75, died after a hard-fought battle with lymphoma, in Southampton, NY, on July 31. Beloved grandmother of Zoe, Kira, and Jack, wife of Joseph, mother of Leslie and Laurence, sister of Fiora. An avid tennis player, swimmer, and beach lover, an independent thinker and free spirit, but above all a most loving grandmother to her cherished grandchildren. Always an unforgettable presence, she will be dearly missed. Services will be held at Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton, NY, on Monday, August 4, at 12:30pm. Donations may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation. A memorial service is being planned for early Fall.

AMBRON--Jacques Sr., a Jewish War Veteran and recipient of the Purple Heart was born Februray 2, 1925 in St. Cloud, France. He fled in 1939 with his family to come to America. He volunteered to join the army in WWII. He resided at the Veterans Home at Paramus, loved to do the New York Times crossword. Jacques Ambron (''Papu'') had a gentle and loving soul, who in his quiet unassuming way touched all those around him. He leaves behind Madeleine Ambron, three children, Nicole Idler, Jacques Ambron Jr., Nadia Kleinhendler, seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be deeply missed.

THE FACTS When Jim Thorpe won the first Olympic gold in the decathlon in 1912, King Gustav V of Sweden told him, ''Sir, you are the world's greatest athlete.'' Since then, the 10-event contest of speed, strength and agility has been the benchmark of track-and-field supremacy. Not only do champion decathletes run (nearly) as fast and jump (nearly) as far as many of the top athletes in individual events, they also do so over two grueling, 11-to-12-hour days. Day 1 consists of the 100-meter dash, the long jump, the shot-put, the high jump and the 400-meter dash. Then it all starts over again the next day with the 110-meter hurdles, the discus throw, the pole vault, the javelin and -- finally -- the 1,500-meter run, which may as well be a marathon after all that exertion. Women perform their own version of this multisport masochism in the seven-event heptathlon.

CAMMETT--John McKay, July 8th, 1927--July 30th, 2008. Husband, father, grandfather, teacher, respected scholar, activist against social and political injustice, died at home after numerous illnesses. Lover of all things Italian, he devoted his life to its history, culture, politics, beauties. US Navy 1945--46. Professor of History at Wayne University, Middlebury College, Hunter College, Rutgers University and John J. College-CUNY (1967--1991) where he served as Professor, Provost and Dean of Faculty (1969-1974) and helped build an institution to serve New Yorkers, to invent the emerging science of criminal justice and to integrate liberal education into the training of professionals. Author of Antonio Gramsci and the Origins of Italian Communism (1967) and editor, Bibliografia gramsciana (2007). Mourned by his wife, Sandi Cooper, daughters, Lisa, Ann (Marcia Gallo) and Melani (Angelo Manioudakis), grandchildren, Mena, Alex and Lena, brother, Stuart (Barbara), sister, Joanne Hansen (Robert), many relatives, countless friends and colleagues. Memorial to be announced. Contributions to appropriate social or political causes. CAMMETT--John. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Professor Emeritus of History John Cammett, an internationally renowned scholar of Italian revolutionary Antonio Gramsci, former Dean of Faculty, Provost, and Chair of the History Department at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, former Professor of History at the CUNY Graduate Center, and member of the Faculty Senate. His many years of exemplary service to CUNY will long be remembered. We offer deepest condolences to his wife, Sandi Cooper, Professor of History at the College of Staten Island and the CUNY Graduate Center, and to his entire family. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr. Chair Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein Chancellor CAMMETT--John. The members of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice Department of History mourn the loss of their revered colleague, Professor Emeritus John Cammett. As Chair of the department and later in retirement, he inspired us with his keen intellect, his scholarly achievements, and his warm friendship. We extend our condolences to his devoted wife Sandi, his children and grandchildren.

THE FACTS It's a mad sprint from one end of the pool to the other, over in fewer than 30 seconds. Swimmers are allowed to use any stroke, but the fastest by far is the crawl. (The term ''freestyle'' has become synonymous with the crawl as a result.) The brevity of the race allows for no error; one tiny mistake can mean a fraction of a second, which in this context is an eternity.

The five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for July 26 to Aug. 1. 1. A LAB IS SET TO TEST THE GENDER OF SOME FEMALE ATHLETES Organizers of the Beijing Olympics have set up a sex-determination laboratory to evaluate ''suspect'' female athletes. (Published July 30)

ALTMANN--Cecil Carl Maria, passed away in Geneva, Switzerland. He was born July 24th, 1934, in Vienna, Austria. Mr. Altmann was the son of cashmere manufacturer Bernhard Altmann and Wilhelmine Altmann and the beloved nephew of Maria Block Bauer Altmann. He leaves his beloved wife Sanda (m. 1970) and his loving daughter Ileana. From a first marriage, he leaves his devoted children Calixte and Bernhard-Olivier. He is also survived by two sisters, Ruth and Yvonne. He graduated from Harvard University in 1957 and moved to New York and Geneva, Switzerland. His brilliant mind and adventurous spirit pioneered new domains in mutual funds, finance and real estate. His generosity of spirit to family, friends, business associates and those who worked for him was all the more remarkable for the dignity and respect with which he treated all who were privileged to know him. A private service was held on August 2nd, in L' Eglise d'Archamps, Haute Savoie, France. His generous heart, seeking spirit and connected being will be missed by his family and friends.

CHEPLIN--Gregory M., of NYC and Fire Island, died at his home on Fire Island at age 80 of cancer on July 30, 2008. Ashes to be scattered at a private ceremony at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Heifer International, PO Box 8058, Little Rock, AR 72203.

FOGELSON--Gussie Lillian, (December 23rd 1912 to August 1st, 2008) died peacefully at home in her 96th year of natural causes. Beloved wife of the late Nathan B. Fogelson; adored mother of Robert M. Fogelson and Maria J. Fuente, David R. and Nancy Fogelson, and Jeffrey P. and Janet Fogelson; well-loved grandmother of Lisa Fogelson and Robert Ballard, Susie Fogelson and Gary Nelson, Michael Fogelson, Jennifer Fogelson Trzesniowski and Clint Trzesniowski, Maria Alvarez-Fuente and Joshua M. Fogelson; and great-grandmother of Camille Ballard, Isabel Nelson, Nathan Ballard, and Ingrid Lillian Nelson. She was a devoted sister to Miriam Schreck, Seymore and Roslyn Richman, and the late Grant and Penny Richman. She leaves behind a bereft family of nieces, nephews, cousins, and many friends. She brought her intelligence, strength, kindness, and love to her family and her community and will be remembered for her beauty, laughter, and wisdom. Services on Sunday, August 3rd at The Riverside Memorial Chapel (77th St. and Amsterdam Ave.) at 1:15pm. Shiva will be held at the home of Janet and Jeffrey Fogelson at 16 Oak Lane, Scarsdale, NY on Sunday and Monday evenings.

MARKARIAN--Shoghere. November 15, 2007, age 81, Manhattan. Protegee of Alan Hovhaness, Ms. Markarian majored in piano at Longy School of Music, attended Juilliard and Dalcroze, and accompanying classes with Martha Graham and Katherine Dunham. She premiered Khaldis, Hovhaness' Concerto for Piano, Four Trumpets & Percussion at Cherry Lane Theatre, performed in Shakespeare and the Armenian Theatre at Shakespeare Summerfest, and presented one-woman shows on the music of Hovhaness and letters of Arshile Gorky in New York and Boston. A faculty member of Diller-Quaile School of Music since 1982, Ms. Markarian previously taught piano at Bloomingdale School of Music, Cedarhurst School, and Womanschool. She is survived by her brother, Dr. Shant Markarian; nieces Kris and Johanna; nephews Shant, Jr. and Craig. The Diller-Quaile Piano Department held a remembrance in January. Interment and memorial service were held at Swan Point Cemetery, Providence.

SEMELS--Clinton L., 77, of Key West, FL, passed away Saturday, July 19, 2008, at the Lower Keys Medical Center, Key West. He was born April 3, 1931, in New York, NY, to Harry and Blanche Marcus Semels. Dr. Semels graduated from the University of Iowa and New York University Dental College. He served in the U.S. Navy as a lieutenant. Dr. Semels operated a dental practice in Manhattan for many years before retiring to Key West 14 years ago. In the early days of the AIDS epidemic he was one of the few dentists who would treat those with the disease. He was a member of the Paradise Big Band and the Keys Chamber Orchestra. Surviving are his wife, Marlene A. Freeman of Key West; son, Jon Renfield of Los Angeles, CA; daughter, Dori Hartley of Fort Lauderdale, FL; and granddaughter, Alexandra Contreras of Fort Lauderdale. He was proceeded in death by his sister, Lou Levine. Memorial services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to the Paradise Big Band, 22931 Blackbeard Lane, Cudjoe Key, FL 33042. He was a good musician, a good man and a good friend. We will miss him.

THE FACTS It used to be that to medal in this frenetic race -- two pool lengths each of butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke and freestyle -- you had to be strong in only three strokes. Now, thanks to the likes of Michael Phelps, swimmers can't afford a weakness. Though butterfly requires extra coordination, it delivers a jolt of speed. Backstroke may look awkward, but it allows easy breathing. ''Breaststroke's the toughest by far,'' says Eddie Reese, the head coach of the United States men's squad. The final and fastest lap is freestyle, which allows competitors to make up for lost time -- about three seconds, if they're flying. Since the I.M. is all about quick-change versatility, it offers some of the most frequent ''Holy cow!'' moments of the Games.

She began and spent much of her legal career at Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood and after a stint as a Assistant Bureau Chief in the Real Estate Finance Division of the Attorney General's office, joined Chehebar Deveney & Phillips as a partner. Mrs. Phillips was, as she proudly proclaimed, a Queens girl, and spent the last nine years living near Riverhead where she was active in local politics. She is survived by her husband, Robert, her two daughters, Alice and Regina, both lawyers, and her son, Robert, and by her grandchildren, Reid and Quinn, on whom she doted. The funeral mass will be held at St. John the Baptist Church, 1488 North Country Road in Wading River, at 10am on Monday. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Down Syndrome Research and Treatment Foundation, www.dsrtf.org. Lois was a special, loving person and will be deeply missed.

THE FACTS Olympic diving is like high-stakes aerial gymnastics: who can pack the most intricate and flawless combination of twists, flips and pikes into mere seconds of free fall? Whether divers are handstanding off the 10-meter platform or launching from the 3-meter springboard, success is in the splash -- the smaller, the better. ''As the last thing the judges see, it can put an exclamation mark on a great dive, and it can also earn a mediocre dive solid scores,'' says the University of Texas diving coach and former Olympian Matt Scoggin. Just as they hit the water, divers pull their hands apart, creating a hole in the surface of the water for their body to slide through; this is called ''ripping the entry.'' Unlike the flabby smack of a belly-flop, the sound of a body hitting the water perfectly at 35 miles per hour is akin to ''paper being torn apart,'' says the United States' Laura Wilkinson, who won gold in the platform at the 2000 Games. ''It's pretty breathtaking.''

LETTERI--Joseph M., M.D. Established the care of patients with kidney disease on Long Island and helped create National and International guidelines and standards for dialysis. Joseph M. Letteri, born in Brooklyn 75 years ago, passed away suddenly on June 1, 2008 while visiting his ''old haunts'' in Tuscany with his beloved wife, Mary. His home was in Sands Point, NY, on Long Island. Dr. Letteri attended St. Peter's College in Jersey City and later, while attending Georgetown Medical School, was greatly influenced by Dr. George Schreiner, a pioneer in the study of kidney disease and dialysis. His further studies were at NYU and at Jefferson Medical College with Lawrence Wesson, M.D., and at Harvard with John Merrill, M.D., all of whom were early leaders in this new field of Nephrology. To fulfill the military obligation required of physicians at the time, he served in the United States Air Force at Wiesbaden Germany, as a specialist in kidney disease with the rank of Captain. Dr. Letteri became Chief of the Division of Nephrology at Nassau County Medical Center and moved to Long Island with his family in 1970. He established the teaching program in kidney disease that has produced many of the kidney specialists now caring for patients on Long Island. He was the first to bring sophisticated diagnostic and treatment methods for kidney disease to the people of Long Island and began dialysis for those whose kidneys had failed. When the State University of New York at Stony Brook began its medical school, Dr. Letteri was in the forefront in organizing the curriculum for instruction in kidney disease for medical students. His research studying the bone disease of renal failure patients at Brookhaven National Laboratories was also groundbreaking. Dr. Letteri rose to the rank of Professor of Medicine at Stony Brook. His activities included work with The National Kidney Foundation on the Medical Advisory Board for New York and later as the National Chairman of The Dialysis Committee that developed the guidelines for Dialysis. In 1987, The National Kidney Foundation presented him with the Lester Hoenig Award for outstanding contributions in Nephrology. His patients will attest to the fact that with all his accomplishments, above all he was a warm and caring doctor. Dr. Letteri was a sensitive parent and family man. He will be greatly missed by Mary, his wife of 48 years, his son Jeffrey Letteri and wife Mary Ann, and his daughter Marisa McCusker and her husband Jeffrey, and his grandchildren John, Austin and Meagan McCusker.

MARKARIAN--Shoghere. November 15, 2007, age 81, Manhattan. Protegee of Alan Hovhaness, Ms. Markarian majored in piano at Longy School of Music, attended Juilliard and Dalcroze, and accompanying classes with Martha Graham and Katherine Dunham. She premiered Khaldis, Hovhaness' Concerto for Piano, Four Trumpets & Percussion at Cherry Lane Theatre, performed in Shakespeare and the Armenian Theatre at Shakespeare Summerfest, and presented one-woman shows on the music of Hovhaness and letters of Arshile Gorky in New York and Boston. ALTMANN--Cecil Carl Maria, passed away in Geneva, Switzerland. He was born July 24th, 1934, in Vienna, Austria. Mr. Altmann was the son of cashmere manufacturer Bernhard Altmann and Wilhelmine Altmann and the beloved nephew of Maria Block Bauer Altmann. He leaves his beloved wife Sanda (m. 1970) and his loving daughter Ileana. From a first marriage, he leaves his devoted children Calixte and Bernhard-Olivier. He is also survived by two sisters, Ruth and Yvonne. He graduated from Harvard University in 1957 and moved to New York and Geneva, Switzerland. His brilliant mind and adventurous spirit pioneered new domains in mutual funds, finance and real estate. His generosity of spirit to family, friends, business associates and those who worked for him was all the more remarkable for the dignity and respect with which he treated all who were privileged to know him. A private service was held on August 2nd, in L' Eglise d'Archamps, Haute Savoie, France. His generous heart, seeking spirit and connected being will be missed by his family and friends.

A menagerie of officials, baseball players, children and sea lions marked the 20th anniversary today of the reopening of the Central Park Zoo. After a five-year, $35 million renovation, the zoo reopened on Aug. 8, 1988, under new management. The Wildlife Conservation Society, which also runs the Bronx, Queens and Prospect Park Zoos and the New York Aquarium, took over the completely new 5.5-acre zoo, which had become known by the early 1980s as a decrepit and depressing habitat for animals.

Beijing is a good town for eating, with an estimated 70,000 restaurants. Because it's the nation's capital, nearly every Chinese regional and ethnic specialty is on offer. But after a few days, all that variety becomes dizzying, and the prospect of yet another unfamiliar dish in a typically raucous, over-lit Chinese restaurant grows less alluring. Sure, you can find passably decent Western food, but why come all the way to Beijing for that?

Carl Icahn has lost a lot of money in WCI Communities, the homebuilder based in Florida, but at least he can be grateful that the board said no to his offer to buy the whole company. It was just last year, in March 2007, when Mr. Icahn offered $22 a share for the company. The board found that offer inadequate, and Mr. Icahn started a proxy fight for board representation. He won, and became chairman, but never completed a takeover. Bloomberg reports his companies and funds paid $112.6 million, or $18.46 a share, for a 16 percent stake.

While many have been critical of the Chinese authorities for razing neighborhoods, displacing residents and cracking down on dissenters to prepare for the Beijing Games, it is useful to remember that similar measures have been taken in advance of previous Olympics as well. As the left sports commentator Dave Zirin has noted, in Los Angeles, Seoul, Atlanta and Athens, the years and months leading up to the Games were marked by the displacement of hundreds and even thousands of residents, as well as anti-crime roundups and the movement of "undesirables" from Olympic core areas.

This dish -created by my old friend Johnny Earles, a self-trained chef and owner of Criolla's in Grayton Beach, Fla. - is just a melange of quickly grilled fruit, brushed with a ginger sauce that itself takes about five minutes to put together. The sauce is a simple sugar syrup -- half sugar, half water, boiled together until the sugar melts -- and is infused with a lot of ginger. You could use other flavors instead (mint, lemon verbena, thyme, even chili), but ginger seems perfect to me.

In my rant last week about poor software design, I blasted certain New York taxis. I wrote that the credit-card payment screens come from two different manufacturers. One offers buttons that, when you pay with a credit card, let you add a tip of 15, 20 or 25 percent with a single finger-tap, which makes eminent sense. The other company created fixed-amount tip buttons - $2, $3 or $4 - which made no sense to me. Those amounts are almost never exactly what you want.

The McLaren driver Heikki Kovalainen won his first Formula One race Sunday after an engine problem forced Felipe Massa out of the Hungarian Grand Prix in Budapest with three laps to go. Massa overtook Kovalainen and the pole sitter Lewis Hamilton at the start and was heading for his fourth win of the season after Hamilton dropped out of contention with a tire puncture. But Massa’s Ferrari engine overheated toward the end, and Kovalainen took an 11-second victory over Timo Glock of Toyota.

Beijing WHILE eating dinner at a packed Spanish restaurant one recent evening, I found myself sitting next to two scorekeepers for the International Olympics Committee who had just arrived here. Apart from the crazy drivers, the city didn't seem that different from the ones in their countries, New Zealand and Canada.

ARANOW--Rita A., 91. Wife of the late Edward Ross Aranow died in peace surrounded by her family. She was the daughter of the late Anne and Louis Abrons. She is survived by her brother, Richard Abrons of Manhattan, her daughter and son-in-law, Vicki and Fred Feiner of Chappaqua, NY, her daughter, Judith Aranow, of Masonville, Colorado and son, Robert Aranow of Loveland, Colorado. In a quiet and unassumed way, she gave generously to those in need, asking for no public recognition in return. At her request, there will be no public funeral. Jade: The New Gold Here's a first: China will be presenting Olympic medals, left, that are made partly with the nonmetal material jade. Some may consider this merely a cosmetic adornment, but jade has significant meaning in Chinese culture. The use of jade flourishes in Chinese history for important artistic and ceremonial objects, and comparisons to jade abound in Chinese literature, as when Confucius likened human virtues to qualities of jade. FLORA ZHANG

Running Like the Wind When There Is None Tyson Gay ran 100 meters faster than anyone in recorded history on June 29, with a time of 9.68 seconds. But that did not count as a world record because Gay had a stiff tailwind of 4.1 meters per second. The maximum allowable tailwind for a world record is 2 meters per second.

The evidence amassed by F.B.I. investigators against Dr. Bruce E. Ivins, the Army scientist who killed himself last week after learning that he was likely to be charged in the anthrax letter attacks of 2001, was largely circumstantial, and a grand jury in Washington was planning to hear several more weeks of testimony before issuing an indictment, a person who has been briefed on the investigation said on Sunday. While genetic analysis had linked the anthrax letters to a supply of the deadly bacterium in Dr. Ivins's laboratory at Fort Detrick, Md., at least 10 people had access to the flask containing that anthrax, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the investigation publicly.
