WILSON--Robert J.M., of Catonsville, MD, formerly of Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY, Gibson Island, MD, and Vero Beach, FL, died of pneumonia on July 16, 2008 at the age of 88. He was the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Albert J.M. Wilson of Greenwich, CT. He was the class of 1938 at the Choate School and graduated from Yale University 1942. In 1940 he joined a year long expedition to the South Seas on the Fahnestock Expedition on a three-masted, 137-foot schooner Director II. During a nine-month period, they traveled to American Samoa, Fiji, French Polynesia, New Caledonia, and Australia, recording music and collecting Pacific bird specimens for the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. The recordings brought back from the expedition were the first electronic recordings made in Oceania and are among the last field recordings made there before World War II changed the ancient cultures of the region forever. During the war, he served for four years in the South Pacific theatre attaining the rank of Captain in the Transportation Corps of the Army. He became President of the Adams Express and Petroleum and Resources Corporation, two closed-end investment management companies in 1975. He was instrumental in relocating them to Baltimore from New York in 1976. He served as President and a director from 1975 1986. He remained a director of both companies until 2006. He was a member of the Society of Security Analysts, a member and former Chairman of the Association of Publicly Traded Investment Companies, and he was a member of the Advisory Investment Committee for the Maryland State Retirement Systems. He was a former member of the New York Yacht Club, the Shelter Island Yacht Club, the Gibson Island Club and the Maryland Club. He is survived by his wife of 56 years Yvette Laneres Wilson, a daughter Mrs. Edward. H. Welbourn, III of Owings Mills, MD and two sons R.J. Montgomery Wilson, Jr. of Reading, MA and Geoffrey L. Wilson of Poughkeepsie, NY as well as six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: The Chesapeake Bay Foundation, 6 Herndon Ave., Annapolis, MD 21403.

LUDACRIS AND DJ DRAMA ''The Preview'' (mixtape) Ludacris can't get no respect. Last year, on the remix to DJ Khaled's ''I'm So Hood,'' he issued a meta-protest: ''I'm so hood that Ludacris shoulda been on the original version.'' A clever line, sure, but also an honest gripe. One of the most nimble, stylistically versatile and creative rappers of the last decade, Ludacris remains conspicuously underappreciated. His propensities for comedy and vocal histrionics don't much help; he often appears to be trying too hard.

Under the Bush administration, the Department of Labor has shirked its responsibility to upgrade workplace safety. In seven years, it has issued but one major rule change protecting workers against a chemical toxin -- and that was forced on it by court order. Now, it's taken a giant step beyond benign neglect. Political appointees at the agency have been discovered in a rush to duck public disclosure and jimmy into place a pro-industry rule making it more difficult to limit workers' exposure to poisonous chemicals.

David H. Popper, a seasoned United States diplomat who, as ambassador to Chile in the tense early years of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's government, struggled to balance military and human rights concerns, died on July 24 in Washington. He was 95. His family announced the death.

Since the American invasion of Iraq in 2003, the oil-rich northern city of Kirkuk has been a political tinderbox-in-waiting that was largely ignored as war-fighting took precedence. Now that violence is way down, Iraqi leaders have no excuse not to peacefully decide the city's future. Their failure to do so has already raised tensions and could further shred Iraq's fragile social fabric -- and unleash more bloodshed. Kurds who run the semiautonomous region of Kurdistan should not be allowed to unilaterally annex Kirkuk, which they regard as their ancient capital but is also home to Turkmen and Arabs. They were promised a referendum in the Iraqi Constitution, but no durable solution can result without the participation of all groups. Overconfident Kurds and their American supporters have not been looking seriously for compromise.

RANDY NEWMAN ''Harps and Angels'' (Nonesuch) Randy Newman can do saccharine and he can do sour. At his best, though, his songs deliver complex flavors, with a pungent but searching ambivalence. ''Harps and Angels,'' his first album of new songs since ''Bad Love'' in 1999, presents a mess of conflicting feelings and motives. Intermittently brilliant, occasionally belligerent, it presents a vision of American identity as sprawling and ultimately as confused as the country itself.

ALYSSA GRAHAM ''Echo'' (Sunnyside) Alyssa Graham belongs to a species of contemporary jazz singer that harbors equal affection for songbook fare, adult-contemporary pop and the gentler strains of Brazilian music. She has the right voice for these inclinations, a sumptuous and flexible croon. She also has the right collaborators: ''Echo,'' her second album, was produced by the pianist and composer Jon Cowherd and features a cast of gifted and experienced players.

LLOYD ''Lessons in Love'' (The Inc./Universal Motown) Lloyd's second album, ''Street Love,'' from last year, was a small triumph of contemporary R&B. An almost impossibly delicate vocalist, Lloyd was backed by soul that was modern and feather light, taking cues from the early 1980s, but with tougher edges. The album's high point was ''You,'' which employed a Spandau Ballet sample almost as aching as Lloyd himself and did some of the early work toward softening the future heartthrob Lil Wayne, who delivered one of his most romantic verses to date.

New York City’s Health and Hospitals Corporation has signed a 10-year, $100 million contract with a profit-making medical school in the Caribbean to provide clinical training for hundreds of students at the city’s 11 public hospitals. The unusual deal, proposed by a member of the corporation’s board who has long worked for the Caribbean school, St. George’s University School of Medicine on the island of Grenada, has been met by an outcry from New York medical schools fearing that clerkship slots will grow more scarce and that they might have to increase tuitions to compete.

BEIJING -- I got a ride to the unusual Usain Bolt and Paolo Nutini news conference at the Puma store Tuesday, but was left to find my own way back to the Main Press Center, about a 35-minute drive away. I hailed a cab and showed the driver a card with the Main Press Center written in Chinese characters. He nodded, which I thought was a good sign, set the meter and started driving north, back toward the Olympic Green. But not long after merging onto the 3rd Ring Road (or was it the 4th?), where a string of red brake lights hindered our progress, he started speaking to me -- in Mandarin, of course -- and looking back at me every minute or so as we inched through the city's traffic.

I conceived the idea of walking from Flamborough Head to Spurn Head, along the Holderness coast of East Yorkshire; which lies to the north of the city of Hull, and to the east of York. It was about 60 miles and I could do it comfortably over three days. Why this walk along this coast? Well, the soil here - loess or clay - was deposited during the last ice age, and ever since then the long shore drift has been carrying it away to the south. The Holderness is, in point of fact, the fastest-eroding coast in Europe, with some six feet a year being lost to the North Sea.

Whenever I write about baby boomers reinventing themselves and forging encore careers, I am bombarded by e-mails from readers. They say that they, too, want to reinvent and would relish the chance to do work with social utility but are deterred or discouraged by the need to earn a living. That is why I continue to applaud the work of organizations like Civic Ventures and other resources (read through the comments to this post for many suggestions), which are helping people find ways to create these encore careers.
The sport adopted a new scoring system in 2006, retiring the “perfect 10” in exchange for scores that are better at differentiating difficult routines.

About two weeks ago, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice declared that "it's time for the Iranians to give a serious answer" to an offer to halt its nuclear program, which Iran claims is peaceful. Several days have passed since the informal deadline for a response. So when a letter from Tehran arrived at the office of European Union's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, it is safe to say that it was read with great interest.
Comcast is buying Daily Candy, the publisher of shopping and culture e-mail newsletters and Web sites, for about $125 million, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

Clotilde, whose CSA I wrote about when I visited Vermont last month, was away when I was there yesterday, but left me a small share of this week's goodies. If, in mid-winter, I remembered days like yesterday, I might become depressed: The cooking is so easy, the eating so delicious, the food so elemental - it is Eden.

[UPDATE, 11/13: A new United Nations report on the Asian "brown cloud" presses for a cleanup, even though such pollution might be blunting global warming.] The pall of pollution over Beijing and the Olympics reflects China's early stage of industrial development, and the sulfur content of its coal, of course. Pollution control has long taken a back seat to economic growth in the history of industrialization. In the United States and Europe, sulfur dioxide emissions have been substantially cut, but only in the last several decades and after the specter of acid rain gained front-page status. Chinese officials have sworn to clean up the air, but economic growth remains the country's top priority, and coal remains a critical underpinning of growth. [UPDATE 8/6: Several readers below note that democratic government matters, too.] Please explore The Times's prize-winning "Choking on Growth" series for more on China's pollution, and governance, challenge.
Humberto Leon and Carol Lim

I've always thought that the European hotels had a brilliant idea. When you enter the hotel room, you put your key in a slot by the door, and all the lights, electricity and air conditioning (if necessary) turn on. When you leave and grab your key, everything shuts off automatically, saving enormous amounts of energy and pollution.

Returning from vacation, I arrived home to find at my doorstop the latest issue of Portfolio, the not-quite-new Conde Nast business magazine, whose media critic is one Howell Raines, the former executive editor of The New York Times who left a couple of years before I got here. Anyway, I just read, somewhat dumbfounded, his latest column. It's about how all of us in business journalism are being sandbagged by those awful people running Exxon Mobil and the other major oil companies, who are busy gouging us while tossing the press their "malarkey" about supply and demand being behind the rise in oil prices. Raines, apparently, is among the legions who believe it's all a big plot by Big Oil, which could bring down the price with a snap of its powerful finger.
Carl C. Icahn took his first steps into the Internet earlier this year by beginning a blog. Now he's about to get some help.

After five seasons on the USA cable channel, NBC Universal moved the country music singing competition "Nashville Star" to its broadcast network this summer. Tuesday's season finale netted 6.3 million viewers, placing second for the hour behind CBS. So was NBC smart to move "Star" from cable to broadcast?

In a Gallup poll released today, Zimbabweans were more optimistic about their country's future than last year, perhaps reflecting some of the potential changes in leadership being discussed. On a scale of 1 to 10, those surveyed said a current 2.1 could turn into a 4.5 within 5 years.

Finales of "American Gladiators" and "Nashville Star" lifted NBC to second place in the ratings on Monday, trailing behind repeats on CBS, the consistent leader for the night this summer. According to Nielsen's estimates, both NBC shows matched their highest ratings of the season among adults 18 to 49. The two-hour "Gladiators" drew an average of 5.3 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., while "Nashville Star" attracted 6.3 million at 10 p.m.

What is vampire energy? No, it's not a new Indie band. It's the standby energy that some electronics use when they're not even turned on. This video is a nice explanation of what it is and how much different electronics syphon. The video was created by Nigel Holmes for Good Magazine.

Edouard made landfall as a 55kt tropical storm Tuesday morning around 7am CDT, between Sabine and High Island, Tx., right by the Louisiana border. Fortunately, this area is not very populated. Jefferson County, where landfall occurred, has about 240,000 residents, compared to about 4 million in the three neighboring counties to its west. However, in the same county, about 1 in 5 people live at or below poverty level, so even a weak storm can have a very negative effect. Incidentally, this is almost exactly where Rita made landfall 3 years ago, but as a Category 3 hurricane with 105kt winds.

Sue Makin , the newest contributor to this blog, is an American Presbyterian missionary doctor working at a 190-bed mission hospital in southern Malawi. She has been working in Africa for the past 18 years. According to a 2007 study of global maternal mortality rates, more than two-thirds of deaths among Malawian women of reproductive age are linked to pregnancy or childbirth - a larger proportion than in any of the 171 countries in the study.

Thanks to the Transportation Department, Americans now have a nice round number to accompany the endless stories of airport frustration. In 2008, more than one quarter of all U.S. flights were delayed, the agency said. At the bottom of airlines' worst performance in 14 years was New York's LaGuardia and Chicago's O'Hare.

Ma Jian is an acclaimed Chinese writer who lives in London with his partner and translator, Flora Drew. He is the author, most recently, of "Beijing Coma," a novel about the events surrounding the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. Born in Qingdao, he moved to Hong Kong in 1987 after some of his works were banned. Ten years later he left for England, but has returned to China continuously. Mr. Ma has previously contributed op-ed articles for The Times. In this interview he spoke from Beijing. (Interviewed previously in this series were Orville Schell and Ai Weiwei.)

Granitas are most similar to the shaved ice served on some New York street corners in the summer -- totally refreshing but hardly elegant. While shaved ice is just that, with overly sweet, artificially flavored syrup poured over it, a granita is a frozen flavored liquid. When you make it yourself, you control the quality of the ingredients, and, of course, the level of sweetness.

Men ages 75 and older should not be screened for prostate cancer. This is the important and definitive conclusion of the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, which for the first time has made a specific recommendation about the value of screening for prostate cancer.

Religion | Evolutionary biologists at the University of New Mexico hypothesize that religious separation is, in part, a response to the threat of disease. They found that more disease-ridden places (say, Ivory Coast) are more religiously diverse. So, they surmise, groups don't mix with one another to reduce the risk of catching something that can speed a trip to the Great Beyond. [Economist, Daily Telegraph]

The Englishman James Rossiter, a former test driver for the Super Aguri Formula One team, will drive for Andretti Green Racing in at least the next two races in the American Le Mans Series. Rossiter will team with A.G.R.’s Franck Montagny at the Road America track in Elkhart Lake, Wis., on Aug. 9, his first start in the United States, and at Mosport International Raceway in Bowmanville, Ontario, on Aug. 24. Robert Novak, the conservative columnist who learned recently that he has a brain tumor, says that his condition is ''dire'' and that he has retired, his home newspaper, The Chicago Sun-Times, reported on Monday. Mr. Novak, 77, announced July 28 that the tumor had been diagnosed the day before, and he released a statement saying he had suspended his writing and television appearances, but hoped to return to them.

Over the last 15 years Q. Sakamaki, a Japanese photographer living in New York, has forged a reputation as a documentarian of conflict and suffering. From the civil war in Liberia to the misery of sex workers in Bangladesh, he creates pictorial narratives of the devastation that unfolds when military or economic forces collide with ordinary human lives. But his new book, ''Tompkins Square Park'' (powerHouse Books), returns to his early days in New York, when he was still adjusting to a new home and a new avocation -- photography -- after giving up a job at an advertising agency in Osaka.

The Board of Trustees and staff of New York City Center express great sadness at the passing of Loretta Perlmuth, beloved wife of Bill Perlmuth, a devoted member of our Board for more than a decade. PERLMUTH--Loretta (nee Kaufman), passed away on August 2 at home with her family, after a two-year struggle with ovarian cancer. Loving wife of Bill Perlmuth for 57 years, teenage sweetheart and life companion; devoted mother of Lyn Perlmuth (Chris Larson) and Diane Gern (Walter); adoring grandmother of Emma and Harry Larson and David and Sophie Gern; loyal sister of Harvey Kaufman (Elaine) and Ruth and Mickey Perlmuth. Beloved by all of us. Beautiful, elegant, thoughtful, generous and affectionate, a lover of the arts and a true New Yorker for all seasons. She was particularly close to her immediate family, who will always remember the weekly dinners, many vacations, cultural, shopping and frozen yogurt expeditions and unfailing support. She had many friends with whom she shared dance and theater, exercise, travel, meals and conversation. A great lady who will be sorely missed by all who knew her. A service will be held today at 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell at 81st and Madison. The family will welcome family and friends at Loretta and Bill's home at 880 Fifth Avenue today from 3-9pm. No flowers please. Donations in Loretta's name to one of the organizations she and Bill were involved with would be appreciated. PERLMUTH--Loretta (Kaufman). The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center, as well as the Board, faculty, and staff of NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Loretta (Kaufman) Perlmuth, beloved wife of 57 years of William A. Perlmuth, Esq., our friend and colleague, fellow member of the Board, and former Chairman of The Board of NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases. To Bill and the entire Perlmuth family, and to the Kaufman family, our sincerest condolences. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman of the Board, NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean and CEO Robin L. Smith, M.D., M.B.A., Member, Board of Trustees Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Chairman Orthopaedic Surgery NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Steven B. Abramson, M.D., Director, Division of Rheumatology NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases David A. Dibner, Senior V.P. for Hospital Operations NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases PERLMUTH--Loretta. PERLMUTH--Loretta. It is with a heavy heart that we deeply mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend Loretta Perlmuth, the wife of our Foundation's President, Bill Perlmuth. To Bill, his daughters, sons - in - law, grandchildren and all other family members, we extend our sincerest condolences. Loretta was a truly wonderful and unique person and a lady in the truest sense of the word. We will sorely miss her graciousness and generosity of spirit. Loretta always put Bill and the family ahead of herself. May Bill and the family know of no more sorrow. The Harkness Foundation for Dance Etta Brandman Theodore S. Bartwink

A Hubble Point of View A selection of impressive images that the Hubble Space Telescope has sent back to Earth. In his book ''The Universe in Mirror: The Saga of the Hubble Space Telescope and the Visionaries Who Built It,'' Robert Zimmerman recounts how astronomers ''were terrified that somebody, some outsider, would take a ruler to one of those pictures and scoop them on some discovery -- something that had actually happened to one of the Voyager scientists,'' Dennis Overbye writes. nytimes.com/space

BOZINOVICI, Bosnia and Herzegovina -- Ratko Mladic, accused in Europe's worst massacre since World War II and now the most wanted fugitive for the atrocities in the Balkan wars, grew up in this poor, remote mountain village that is blanketed with crows. Here, as in many places where Serbs live, his military prowess, his undeniable suffering and the imponderable scale of the crimes he is accused of have made him as much a national myth as a man. He is a weathered survivor, his character forged by poverty, the slaying of his father and the suicide of his daughter -- with his own favorite pistol.

BEIJING -- Having inspired the international fashion world's name for bikini, the Marshall Islands will now join the international sporting world, competing for the first time in the Olympics. The Pacific nation's entire team of five athletes could fit around the dinner table, which seems somehow apropos, considering that its best athlete is a chef. Anju Jason, a tae kwon do athlete who has spent most of his life in Hawaii, cooks for Panda Express, one of the largest chains serving Chinese fast food in the United States. He finds some culinary feng shui in the alignment of his job and the Summer Games in Beijing.

PERLMUTH--Loretta (nee Kaufman), passed away on August 2 at home with her family, after a two-year struggle with ovarian cancer. Loving wife of Bill Perlmuth for 57 years, teenage sweetheart and life companion; devoted mother of Lyn Perlmuth (Chris Larson) and Diane Gern (Walter); adoring grandmother of Emma and Harry Larson and David and Sophie Gern; loyal sister of Harvey Kaufman (Elaine) and Ruth and Mickey Perlmuth. Beloved by all of us. Beautiful, elegant, thoughtful, generous and affectionate, a lover of the arts and a true New Yorker for all seasons. She was particularly close to her immediate family, who will always remember the weekly dinners, many vacations, cultural, shopping and frozen yogurt expeditions and unfailing support. She had many friends with whom she shared dance and theater, exercise, travel, meals and conversation. A great lady who will be sorely missed by all who knew her. A service will be held today at 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell at 81st and Madison. The family will welcome family and friends at Loretta and Bill's home at 880 Fifth Avenue today from 3-9pm. No flowers please. Donations in Loretta's name to one of the organizations she and Bill were involved with would be appreciated. PERLMUTH--Loretta (Kaufman). The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center, as well as the Board, faculty, and staff of NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Loretta (Kaufman) Perlmuth, beloved wife of 57 years of William A. Perlmuth, Esq., our friend and colleague, fellow member of the Board, and former Chairman of The Board of NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases. To Bill and the entire Perlmuth family, and to the Kaufman family, our sincerest condolences. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman of the Board, NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean and CEO Robin L. Smith, M.D., M.B.A., Member, Board of Trustees Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Chairman Orthopaedic Surgery NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Steven B. Abramson, M.D., Director, Division of Rheumatology NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases David A. Dibner, Senior V.P. for Hospital Operations NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases PERLMUTH--Loretta. The Trustees and staff of The Joyce Theater Foundation express their heartfelt sympathy to the family and friends of Loretta Perlmuth, a wonderful woman who will truly be missed by many. PERLMUTH--Loretta. It is with a heavy heart that we deeply mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend Loretta Perlmuth, the wife of our Foundation's President, Bill Perlmuth. To Bill, his daughters, sons - in - law, grandchildren and all other family members, we extend our sincerest condolences. Loretta was a truly wonderful and unique person and a lady in the truest sense of the word. We will sorely miss her graciousness and generosity of spirit. Loretta always put Bill and the family ahead of herself. May Bill and the family know of no more sorrow. The Harkness Foundation for Dance Etta Brandman Theodore S. Bartwink STRUHL--Joseph. An item on Monday in the ''Games at a Glance'' chart in the Olympics preview section about Natalie Du Toit, a long-distance swimmer from South Africa who has lost a leg, referred incorrectly to her place in the history of the games. HUTTNER--Richard David, passed away on August 3, 2008. He was a beloved husband of fifty years to Marsha, loving father to Lee and Kevin. He was a New York State Supreme Court Justice until his retirement. A previous Chairman of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, an Administrative Judge of the Family Court, and an adjunct professor at John Jay College. whom would you rather have a beer with? -- has been scorned by some as a superficial measure of whether a candidate would be a good president. Still, pollsters cannot help but ask it in one form or other, because voters say that likability matters as they consider whom they want on the television in their living rooms for the next four years. In a new variant, Lifetime Networks asked female voters whom they would rather carpool with and whom they would want to vacation with. In both cases, they chose Senator Barack Obama over Senator John McCain, according to Lifetime, which has been conducting a nonpartisan campaign since 1992 to engage women in the electoral process.

BEIJING -- Until recently, the sight of a Japanese warship steaming toward Chinese shores or of a Chinese aircraft swooping low over Taiwan would have provoked alarm across Asia. But when Japan's navy made its first Chinese port call since World War II and a Chinese charter plane ferried mainland tourists to neighboring Taiwan this summer, they were symbols not of China's dangerous rivalries, but of the diplomacy that President Hu Jintao has used to defuse them.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- The number of climbers thought to have died near the summit of K2 after a column of ice splintered and fell away on Friday, increased Monday to 11, the Pakistani military said. Two Dutch climbers were rescued and a third climber was known to have survived despite the astonishing cold near the top of K2, the world's second highest mountain.

In an era of spam, telemarketing, moving billboards and other forms of aggressive commercial solicitation, an old-fashioned form of advertising is surprisingly -- many say irritatingly -- resilient: fliers, restaurant menus and business cards slipped under the doors, wedged in door jambs or left on the stoops of houses and apartment buildings in New York City. Until now, homeowners have had no recourse to block the unwanted paper, often called ''lawn litter'' because in neighborhoods with yards much of the paper ends up on the lawn. But on Saturday, the city started enforcing a recent state law that prohibits the placement of ''unsolicited papers, fliers, pamphlets, handbills, circulars or other materials advertising a business or soliciting business'' at homes in New York City if the property owner has posted a sign saying such materials are not wanted. Advertisers who violate the law face fines from $250 for a first offense to $1,000 for repeat violations.

They’re not exactly singing “Kumbaya” with each other, but the owners of Johnny’s Pizza and Papa John’s Pizza in Sunset Park are coexisting. Considering how they felt a year ago, this could pass for brotherhood in Brooklyn. Last summer, John Miniaci Jr., a second generation pizzamaker, learned a Papa John’s franchise was opening — right next door to the restaurant his father started in 1968. The fans of the original Johnny — John Sr., who died shortly before the brand-name doppelgänger arrived — were aghast, circulating petitions and bemoaning the sad fate of mom-and-pop businesses in New York. The news even reached fans of Johnny’s serving in Iraq, after I wrote about it a year ago this Friday.

By a margin of almost 4 to 1 — and even a solid majority among registered Republicans — New York State voters support raising the state income tax on people who make more than $1 million a year, according to poll results released on Wednesday morning by Quinnipiac University. The results suggested that repeated warnings by Gov. David A. Paterson, who has said the state faces dire budget pressures, have been persuasive to New Yorkers, even though experts say the situation is not yet a crisis.

Soul food appears to be dying in Harlem and elsewhere in the city, Timothy Williams reports in a front-page article. Staples like butter beans, country fried steak, hog maws, oxtails, chicken livers, ham hocks, neck bones and chitterlings have become uncommon, and in some cases, unavailable, in this former soul food capital. The reasons can be chalked up to the vagaries of contemporary city life: changing tastes; health consciousness; the fast-food culture; and an influx of wealthier young adults — including African-Americans, long a customer base for soul food restaurants — who are more comfortable eating Indian or Thai dishes.

Overstock.com, as readers of this blog know, likes to sue people whom it deems responsible for the "naked short selling" that it blames for driving down its share price. It has sued more-or-less every big brokerage firm for facilitating such sales. It has also sued Gradient Analytics, a research firm that wrote negatively about Overstock, and Rocker Partners, a hedge fund that sold its stock short. (There is no claim that Rocker was a naked short seller, just an ordinary one that borrowed shares and sold them.)

Edouard's landfall Tuesday on a wildlife refuge on the north Texas coast suggests insured damages will be light if history is any guide. Edouard never achieved hurricane strength and Hurricane Humberto, which made a quick visit a bit further up the Texas coast in 2007, produced little damage. Neither storm was anywhere near the size and power Hurricane Rita in 2005. That storm caused about $6 billion in insured losses in current dollars, about half of those in Texas, and still ranks as the sixth most expensive hurricane in United States history. Rita produced an additional $3 billion in insured losses to offshore oil facilities as it approached the coast. There are no reports of significant damage or disruptions arising from Edouard.

Over the last few days, General Motors has made two related announcements. First, the company disclosed that it had lost a stunning $15.5 billion in the second quarter. And then, G.M. followed up that bad news by letting it be known that the company's board remained steadfast in its support for the chief executive Rick Wagoner. "Rick has the unified support of the entire board to a person," the company's lead outside director, George M.C. Fisher, told Bill Vlasic of The Times in an interview Wednesday morning. "We are absolutely convinced we have the right team under Rick Wagoner's leadership to get us through these difficult times and to a brighter future."

BEIJING -- Sanlitun, in eastern Beijing's Chaoyang neighborhood, is the city's oldest and most famous nightlife district. The bars are shoulder-to-shoulder for blocks. Some have neon lights and outdoor seating areas tended by menu-waving waiters trolling for tourists; others are just holes in the wall, foggy with cigarette smoke. Serious drinkers in China really like to smoke, and serious smokers really like to drink. Etiquette requires, moreover, that before lighting up yourself, you offer your companions a cigarette, so it's not impossible in such a bar to spot someone puffing away on two at once.

After the Mets had sweated out Aaron Heilman's blotchy ninth inning to edge the San Diego Padres, 6-5, on Tuesday night, Manager Jerry Manuel appeared in the interview room holding a bottle of water. The prop helped Manuel vividly explain how he felt about the Mets narrowly escaping with a crucial win. Given that Heilman's failure was almost as noteworthy as the Mets winning, Manuel was asked if he felt as if the team had actually won. Manuel held up the bottle, turned spiritual and said, "I feel like I need to be turning this water into wine." In the Gospel of John, Jesus turns water into wine at a wedding in Cana. It was the first miracle Jesus performed. By referencing water and wine, Manuel indicated that he was hoping for miracles in the ninth, too. With the erratic nature of the Mets' bullpen, Manuel might be hoping for miracles for a while.

FORTNER--Roberta Jean Olsen, wife of late Joseph G. Fortner, M.D., passed away on August 4, 2008. She was the beloved mother of Kathleen and Joseph Jr., mother-in-law of Holly Winger Fortner, and grandmother of Amanda and Margaret Fortner, and Christina and Genevieve Lewis. She is also survived by her sister, Kathleen Olsen March, of Cincinnati, Ohio. Born February 1, 1924 in Eureka, South Dakota, she was a graduate of the University of South Dakota, where she was a member of Kappa Alpha Theta. She completed her course work for her Masters in Social Work at Columbia University, and was a Docent at The Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was also a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She spent most of her life in Scarsdale, New York City, and Madison, Connecticut. She will be buried with her husband at a private service in Bedford, Indiana. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. She will be greatly missed by her grieving family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to St. Joseph's Indian School, Chamberlain, South Dakota 57326.

MATE--Esther ''Essie'' (nee Segal), 88, passed away on August 3, 2008 in Highland Beach, Florida. Our loving mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother and aunt, has been reunited with her bashert, our dearly missed Poppa Syd, in their everlasting Shangri-La. She is survived by her son Jon and wife Paula, her daughter Phyllis and husband Maurice, her beloved grandchildren Stuart, Jenna and Robyn, and great-grandchilren, Lily and Jack. Her warmth was the heart of our family. From her example, we learned what it meant to love someone for a lifetime. We remember her beautiful smile, her tenderness and playfulness, the sweet scent of her famous chocolate cake, and how lovingly she took care of all of us. Donations can be made to Palm Beach County Hospice (www.hpbc.com). Services on Thursday 11:30am at Gutterman and Musicant 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ.

SAMILSON--Jean, passed away on July 2, 2008, at 83, ater a brief illness. She is survived by her three children, eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was a long time resident of Tarrytown and New York City before moving to San Diego recently. In Tarrytown she was a volunteer at Phelps Memorial Hospital and for the Girl Scouts. In New York City, she volunteered at both the 92nd Street Y and the Amato Opera House. She was happiest when showing off the city to friends and family on her beloved walking tours. She visited many parts of the world and devoted much of her time to compiling albums about her cherished adventures. Friends and family were often the beneficiaries of her enthusiastic trip reviews. She will always be remembered for her zest for life. Contributions may be made to the Amato Opera House, www.amato.org

An article on June 25 about a positive drug test for Salute the Count, a horse trained by Rick Dutrow, the trainer of Big Brown, the Kentucky Derby winner, misstated the amount of clenbuterol in the horse's system. It was 41 picograms, not ''petragrams.'' A picogram is one-trillionth of a gram; there is no petragram. (The error was repeated in an article on June 28, and this correction was delayed for research.)

CAMMETT--John. The faculty, administration, staff, and alumni of John Jay College of Criminal Justice, CUNY, records with deep sorrow the death of our beloved colleague, Professor Emeritus, John M. Cammett. Dr. Cammett was an internationally renowned Gramsci scholar and a world renowned scholar of Italian Marxist History. He served as Dean of the Faculty and Provost when the college doubled and then tripled its size in the early 1970s, and oversaw the hiring of faculty that established John Jay as a true liberal arts college. He was a Chairman of the history department, and for many years served as a member of its faculty and on the faculty of the CUNY Graduate School and University Center. Dr. Cammett maintained close ties to the college after retirement. We express our condolences to his wife, Dr. Sandi Cooper, a member of the history faculty at the CUNY Graduate Center and the College of Staten Island, and to his children and his grandchildren. There will be a memorial service in September.

CESSNA--Bob, Actor/Play wright, 73, passed away on August 3 at New York Hospital after an intense and courageous battle with lung cancer. A drama major and graduate of Catholic University in DC, Mr. Cessna began his professional career as the understudy for the British cast of ''Beyond the Fringe'' that included Alan Bennett. He replaced Dudley Moore on Broadway and after a national tour in which he continued to play Dudley's material, he returned to New York and reopened at the Barrymore Theater. In the ''Mad Show'' at New York's New Theater, Mr. Cessna's performances are still remembered for their unparalleled versatility. His plays were produced offBroadway and in various workshops, and he was a playwright member of the 42nd Street Workshop and the Algonquin Theater Company. His ''First Week in Bogota'' was the first play to open Playwrights Horizons. Other plays that were produced include ''The Blue Moon,'' ''A Family Comedy,'' ''Trios,'' ''To Dress a Naked Window,'' ''Final Vows,'' and ''A Few of the Usual Nudes.'' His musical, ''Werewulff,'' written with William David Brohn, was produced at the Hartke Theater in DC to soldout audiences. He was also a scriptwriter for ''The Doctors'' and ''Another World'' and recently completed ''The Twinn Connexion,'' a screenplay based on the grammy nominated Hopkins twins, whom he also managed. He made Woodstock his home during the last few years of his life, where he continued to be active in the arts. ''Charlie's Birds'' will be given a full production this October, opening on the 11, at Maple Grove, an historic landmark in Poughkeepsie. Mr. Cessna is survived by his domestic partner and beloved companion of forty-four years, the Woodstock artist Gerald Hopkins. He is also survived by his sister Peggy and brothers Jack, Tom, Jim and numerous nieces and nephews. His enthusiasm for life and the arts, his keen intellect and his unbridled generosity will be deeply missed by all. Contributions in his memory should be directed to the Duchess County SPCA, 636 Violet Avenue, Hyde Park, NY 12538, 845 - 452 - 7722, www.dcspca.org/

The dog days of August? Not really, especially when it comes to political advertising during the Olympics. The Obama campaign plans to spend $5 million advertising on telecasts of the Games, and on Tuesday the McCain campaign moved to one-up it, releasing its own commercial as part of a $6 million Olympics advertising campaign. Senator John McCain's campaign declined to comment on the media purchase, which will include commercials on both NBC and the cable channels that are showcasing the Beijing Games this month. The purchase was first reported online by Advertising Age, and confirmed by an official close to the network.

In a first, the social networking firm MySpace has signed a deal to provide real-time video streaming of the three presidential debates and the debate between the vice-presidential nominees. As part of the agreement with the Commission on Presidential Debates, the nonprofit, nonpartisan organization that manages the debates, MySpace will offer a new site without advertisements, MyDebates.org. The site will have ways for viewers to watch live and recorded video of the events, to express their approval or disapproval of specific answers and to interact with each other around the issues.

An obituary on July 25 about Paul Bentley, the Dallas police detective who helped arrest Lee Harvey Oswald after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, included incorrectly, without qualifying its source, a remark Mr. Bentley remembered hearing after the arrest. Many years later, Mr. Bentley told oral history interviewers that on the road to police headquarters with Oswald, after hearing police dispatchers say the man in custody was a prime suspect in the assassination of Kennedy, he asked Oswald, ''Did you shoot President Kennedy?'' and that Oswald replied, ''You find out for yourself.'' Mr. Bentley's recollection is unsupported by other existing historical records. The obituary also described Mr. Bentley's role in the arrest imprecisely. Mr. Bentley adjusted the handcuffs after Oswald complained they were too tight; he did not snap the handcuffs on. (Another officer had placed his handcuffs on Oswald moments earlier.)

New York City is working to determine how extensively it needs to test the strength of concrete in buildings around the city after learning that prosecutors have found evidence that the area’s largest testing company often falsified results, William K. Rashbaum reports. The company, Testwell Laboratories, has been hired in recent years to analyze the strength of concrete on a raft of public projects, including work for the city, as well as legions of commercial and residential buildings that were constructed in the area. But investigators for the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, have discovered evidence indicating that for at least five years, the company has falsified some concrete test results.

We take electricity for granted until we don’t have it, like nearly five years ago, when the tens of millions of people lost power across eight states and parts of Canada on Aug. 14, 2003. Dozens of transmission lines and about 100 power plants shut down during the largest blackout in North American history, causing billions of dollars in damage.Despite the obvious hardships — the heat, the hikes down office tower steps — the blackout brought a lot people together. Andrew Keane from Highland Mills, N.Y. turned into an impromptu traffic cop. Apartment dwellers like Peter Chernin barbequed with his neighbors at West 47th and Eighth Avenue. Strangers huddled around Mark Barney’s battery-operated transistor radio in front of his 42nd Street apartment. Without refrigerators, Tom Downey, the manager at Muldoon’s Irish Pub on Third Avenue, served all his cold beer to parched patrons.

From 6 to 9 p.m. this evening, part of Brooklyn Borough Hall will be given over to an event recognizing 28 art works made by students in New York City high schools. Student art shows are common, but the theme of this one is not: preventing hate crimes.

A mural that is slowly going up on the industrial edge of Sunset Park is shaping up to be one huge Do Not Disturb sign directed at military recruiters. Its creators? A group of young women — barely out of high school — who are still smarting from what they saw as repeated and unwanted come-ons from recruiters who would stop them on the street, in school or call them at home. “If you go to some Manhattan schools or places where the families have a higher income, you don’t see the recruiters there,” said Ebony Thurman, 18, who was once approached by recruiters at the Atlantic Avenue subway station. “But if you’re in Brooklyn or in lower income neighborhoods, that’s where you really find them trying to recruit people. They tell you that you’ll get job skills or college money. And if you’re a girl they’ll flirt with you and say there a lot of cute guys you could meet if you enlist.”

BEIJING - At 7:20 p.m. Thursday night, I was watching the United States baseball team play China in a scrimmage that I should not even be watching. Were it not for the ingenuity and compassion of a volunteer who seemed genuinely distressed by the sight of two sweat-stained reporters, the esteemed Dave Sheinin of The Washington Post and I might still be outside and not inside trying to figure out such mysteries as why the teams were playing with two designated hitters (and thus a 10-man lineup), why the Chinese players did not have numbers on their backs, why the noise made when bat strikes ball sounds completely different at the Wukesong Baseball Field than it does in any other stadium, and why there were groundskeepers umpiring the game.

Q: With a bit of luck, my situation will soon change to include the possibility of outdoor grilling. I have been missing not only grilled meat, but also grilled vegetables - and grilled fruit sounds good too. And in general I like creating leftovers. Not that I am planning to eat these things every day, but I do wonder about the carcinogens said to come along with charring. Please comment! Thank you.
“Bernini and the Birth of Baroque Portrait Sculpture” at the J. Paul Getty Museum has to be one of the outstanding displays of 17th-century European sculpture in the United States in recent decades.

Beijing Fog/Smog- Juliet Macur has a report on our Rings blog noting how International Olympic Committee officials were bending over backward to avoid offending China despite the extraordinary soup of haze and pollution in Beijing on Thursday. Just have a look at this news conference statement by the committee president, Jacques Rogge: "The fog you see is based on the basis of humidity and heat. It does not mean to say that this fog is the same as pollution. It can be pollution, but the fog doesn't mean necessarily that it is pollution."Researchers Flee Stranded Bear- Scientists from the Wildlife Conservation Society had their field research on ecological impacts of eroding Arctic coasts near Prudhoe Bay interrupted by a polar bear that was stuck ashore because the sea ice in that part of Alaska was far offshore. Their bush pilot advised them to decamp, and they did. Polar bears in Alaska appear to be having a harder time than in some other parts of the Arctic, according to federal wildlife officials.Tropics: Heat = Deluge- Finally, I've written a story for Friday's paper on a study in Science Express clearly linking warmer stretches in the tropics to more frequent extreme downpours, the kind that can swamp a city with poor drainage, causing economic havoc and spreading waterborne illness. The study, by British and American scientists, found that the observed peaks in extreme rain events are about twice as high as what global climate simulations produce. This means that a) the models need work (a lot of scientists agree that they don't do well with precipitation, b) the satellite measurements are wrong (less likely), or c) some of both. Over all, the authors and other climatologists told me, the link strongly implies that a warming world will be a more downpour-prone world. That means trouble because of rising populations in vulnerable regions. Go to the international Flood Resilience Network and the Asia-Pacific Water Forum for what this means on the ground.

Q: Perhaps this is covered in your books, but I'm interested in brining. How long to brine different meat or fish? Is it possible to brine for too long? Is the ratio of salt to water critical, or does it just take longer with a weaker mixture? Why do some brine recipes add sugar? Can alternatives or additives to water be used (broth, juice, wine)? If you add seasonings or spices to the brine do they get absorbed by the meat or is the osmosis just a salt transfer process?

Eighteen places to play a simultaneous exhibition on the Internet against Magnus Carlsen of Norway, the 17-year-old prodigy who is No. 3 in the world based on up-to-date results, are being sold on eBay. The event is on Monday, Aug. 11, beginning at 2 P.M., East coast time. Two other opponents will be selected from two open tournaments on the Internet Chess Club, which is hosting the simul. Each of Carlsen's opponents will play black and will have 90 minutes on their clocks with five seconds added to their time after each move. Only players who are below the rank of master will be allowed to participate.

Ivory Tower | A physics professor says that in much of leafy academe, ignorance of math is almost a point of pride. "Because the people running the academy these days have no personal appreciation of math, and thus no qualms about coddling innumeracy." [Inside Higher Ed]

History | A critic has an idea to make Herodotus, the highly digressive "father of history," more accessible: an online edition with hypertext for all his tangents. He adds that Herodotus presaged the historical novel with "a grand vision of the way history works" in a not-quite-factual, yet plausible, "narrative of epic verve and sweep." The former New England Revolution forward Pat Noonan was traded to the Columbus Crew after re-signing with Major League Soccer. In exchange for trading Noonan’s rights, the Revolution received money for acquiring future players and the Crew’s first-round selection in the 2009 M.L.S. SuperDraft. Noonan, 28, had been playing for Aalesund in the Norwegian Premier League after a transfer from M.L.S. in January. He appeared in 119 games over five seasons for New England, scoring 37 goals with 29 assists.

Cristiano Ronaldo pledged to stay with Manchester United for at least the coming season but still wants to join Real Madrid, according to a Portuguese newspaper interview. Ronaldo told Publico he believed Real Madrid, the Spanish champion, submitted a “very high bid” after he expressed a desire to join them. But the Manchester United manager, Alex Ferguson, convinced him to stay next season when they met in Lisbon last month.

A former Toledo basketball player was charged with fixing games, a little over a year after a former Toledo football player was charged with point-shaving, according to a federal bill of information filed in the United States District Court in Detroit. Sammy Villegas, who played for four years at Toledo, is accused of shaving points in games during the 2004-5 and 2005-6 seasons. Villegas, a guard who finished his career in 2006, also paid money to another player who took part in the point-shaving scheme, prosecutors said. The other player was not charged or named in the bill. Villegas was charged with conspiracy to influence sports contests by bribery. Prosecutors said he received money and other gifts in exchange for fixing games.

The game between F.C. Barcelona of Spain and the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer at Giants Stadium was billed as an exhibition. It was more like a clinic as the Red Bulls were outclassed and outplayed. Barcelona, playing its second and last game on its United States tour, toyed with the Red Bulls, especially in the first half, when Samuel Eto’o and Xavi Hernández each scored two goals in a 6-2 victory. The Red Bulls’ goals were scored by Seth Stammler and Jorge Rojas. The attendance, 38,152, was far short of the 79,002 two years ago when the teams played. What was different this time? The Brazilian star Ronaldinho now calls A.C. Milan home and the Argentine striker Lionel Messi was in China for the Olympics.

Martin Truex Jr. agreed to a contract extension with Dale Earnhardt Inc. that will keep him in the No. 1 Chevrolet at least through 2009. The sides had a mutual option on the 2009 season, but Truex had been reluctant to commit. Now the sides are working on a longer deal.
Four members of the Bonanno crime family, including its acting boss, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to murder-conspiracy charges related to two separate mob murders dating back to 2001.

Versus will become the exclusive cable television home of the Indy Racing League next year with its agreement to a 10-year deal worth an estimated $60 million. Versus, which will take over from ESPN and ESPN2, will carry 13 races. ABC will continue to broadcast the Indianapolis 500 and four other I.R.L. events. The agreement also gives Versus the rights to carry all of the Indy 500 qualifying. Scott Guglielmino, a vice president for programming for ESPN, said shedding the 13 I.R.L. races was not connected to the network’s holding Nascar rights.
If you want to get your hands on Tom Golisano’s millions, you’ll have to wade through his 35-point candidate questionnaire.

Bill Self, the coach who guided the Kansas Jayhawks to their first N.C.A.A. championship in 20 years, signed a 10-year, $30 million contract. Self’s previous contract had three years left, but the new deal is retroactive to April 1.

Throughout the Olympics, Carmelo Anthony of the U.S.A. Basketball team will offer insights on The Rings blog about his experience in Beijing. Today, Anthony shares his thoughts about spending time with Michael Phelps, a fellow Baltimore native, and their talk about sports back home and about getting to each other’s events. “They can have our parade together in Baltimore” after they both win gold medals, Anthony says. “I’m amazed at what he can do in that water. He’s like a shark. I’ve never seen anyone swim like that before. Swimming never caught my eyes before I saw him.”.

It took only four minutes into their game against Norway for the U.S. women’s soccer team to fall behind, 2-0, and into a hole they couldn’t climb out of. As Harvey Araton writes, “Sluggish as the Americans were to start the game, they couldn’t blame their sudden predicament on weather, or pollution, just two deflating errors.”.

With the Summer Olympics starting tomorrow in Beijing, we thought we’d ask John Tayman — who produced a timeline of Olympic sports for the most recent issue of PLAY — to give us his short take on the long and often odd history of the Games’ events.

The American women’s basketball team displayed a physical style of play in today’s 71-67 victory over Australia in a pre-Olympic tournament game, George Vecsey writes. The Australian women, meanwhile, “suggested that the Yanks were indulging in a bit of head-hunting as intimidation, inasmuch as the two teams could meet in the finals of the Summer Games.” The first U.S. game in the Olympic tournament comes Saturday against the Czech Republic.

A brief report in the Currents column last Thursday about the Shibui Spa at the Greenwich Hotel, 377 Greenwich Street (Franklin Street) in TriBeCa, misstated the opening date. It opens Sept. 1, not in August.

Ecco, a division of HarperCollins, has acquired the rights to a memoir by Steven Tyler, below, the 60-year-old lead singer of Aerosmith. The book will go into Mr. Tyler’s childhood in the Bronx, his music career, his relationship with his four children “and all of the sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll imaginable,” the publisher said in a statement on Wednesday. Daniel Halperin, the publisher of Ecco, who has described himself as an avid fan of Aerosmith since the 1970s, will edit the book, which is to be published in 2009.
The top two acts on last week’s Billboard chart swapped places this week. Sugarland’s “Love on the Inside” (Mercury Nashville) rose one spot to No. 1.

ARANOW--Rita A. The Board of Directors, management and staff of White Plains Hospital Center mourn with extreme sorrow the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, Mrs. Rita Aranow. Rita's contributions to our Hospital have made possible our preeminent position as the leading health care provider in Westchester County. Her generosity to those less fortunate is unparalleled. We are truly greatful for her dedication to this hospital and our community. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Vicki and Fred Feiner, Robert Aranow, Judy Aranow and her entire family. Paul M. Weissman, Chairman, Board of Directors Jon B. Schandler, President and CEO

ARLINGTON, Tex. -- The way things are going, the Yankees may want to add a ticker to the bottom of the screen during telecasts, strictly for medical updates. The injury news comes with staggering frequency these days. An hour or so after announcing that Joba Chamberlain has rotator cuff tendinitis, the Yankees watched their new catcher take a crushing hit at the plate. Iván Rodríguez left after two innings of the Yankees' 5-3 victory over the Texas Rangers, though the other player in the collision seemed to suffer more.

BRAITERMAN--Meyer. Metro NY Health Care for All Campaign and PNHP NY Metro Chapter honor the life and work of our longtime board member, who directly helped so many as he fought tirelessly for universal coverage as a human right. His friendship and passion will be sorely missed.
Vendors waited Wednesday for customers at a market on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, where the economy has slowed after years of growth and citizens are coping with price increases.

TEN feet short of the finish line, Barbie Airplane was stranded. The cheerful contraption -- a Craftsman belt sander crowned with a powder-blue toy plane -- had been careening down the 75-foot racetrack moments earlier. Then the sander's rotating belt came undone, stopping it dead.

DAVIS--Ruth, on August 5th, 2008. Beloved wife of the late David, loving mother of Neil, Andrew and Philip. Adoring grandmother of Joshua, Ashley, Madeline and Jacqueline. Dear sister of Anne, Eleanor and Charles. Served the children of New York for 48 years as a teacher and administrator. Devoted herself to the continuing education of everyone, everywhere. Service Thursday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ELFMAN--Allan M., 66, of New York City and Philadelphia, PA, passed away on August 1, 2008. Brother of Harvey (Dina) Elfman, Partner of Jonathan Michals. Greatly missed by his beloved dog, Chance, and his many friends. Also survived by Nieces, Lauran and Louisa Elfman. Son of the late Louis and Hilda Elfman. Memorial Celebration of Life will be held on Friday, August 8, 2008 at 7:30pm at the Elfman and Michals Residence in New York City.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the arrest of John A. Gotti, once the acting boss of the Gambino crime family, on federal conspiracy charges linking him to the killings of three men in New York, misidentified the court in which Mr. Gotti appeared. It was the United States District Court in Manhattan, not the State Supreme Court.

Franklin Park Conservatory in Columbus, Ohio, tests a permanent light installation by the artist James Turrell in its Victorian glass Palm House in preparation for its unveiling on Friday night. The work is programmed to cycle through five color schemes.

DITSON--Kappy. A very special woman. Thank you for filling our lives with joy, laughter and love. You will be missed; however, we will smile when we think of you and tell Kappy stories. Love Lynda and Richard

GUDELL--Etta (nee Reiss), 91. Beloved wife of the late Siegbert. Adored mother of Loretta and Michael Soloway, Howard and Naomi Gudell. Cherished grandmother of Spencer, Seth and Melissa. Etta was the definition of a survivor up to her final days while battling lung disease. As a young girl, Etta escaped Europe just before the second World War, by miraculously making it to England via Poland, then to Palestine and finally to America, where her beloved husband Siegbert awaited her. You will forever be in our hearts. Service, Thursday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

The Frugal Traveler in Amsterdam After almost three months on the road, the Frugal Traveler, Matt Gross, craved a low-key weekend in Amsterdam, left, for week 12 of his European Grand Tour. ''Frugal relaxation in one of the most pleasant cities in the world -- that would be the ticket,'' he said.

SAMILSON--Jean, passed away on July 2, 2008, at 83, ater a brief illness. She is survived by her three children, eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was a long time resident of Tarrytown and New York City before moving to San Diego recently. In Tarrytown she was a volunteer at Phelps Memorial Hospital and for the Girl Scouts. In New York City, she volunteered at both the 92nd Street Y and the Amato Opera House. She was happiest when showing off the city to friends and family on her beloved walking tours. She visited many parts of the world and devoted much of her time to compiling albums about her cherished adventures. Friends and family were often the beneficiaries of her enthusiastic trip reviews. She will always be remembered for her zest for life. Contributions may be made to the Amato Opera House, www.amato.org

SPODAK--Joel. Born October 28th, 1924, Brooklyn, NY, passed away August 4th West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Manhasset, NY. Adoring husband of Norma, beloved father of Barbara and Lois, father-in-law of Alton and Dan, loving grandfather of Lou, Joseph, Jackson and Ben. He will be missed and loved forever. Memorial service on Friday August 8 at 11:45am at the President Club. To express condolences, donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

MARANS--Martin. He was 81. Son of Dave and Ray, husband of Rosalind, father of David and Carole, grand dad of Alex and Danny. With Mickey, Hannah, Herb and many others important in his life. While insurance was his career his life interest focused on music, movies, politics. Finding ''La Dolce Vita'' was his dream. Witty, charming and not bad looking either, we mourn his passing and celebrate his life. A September event is planned.

GERNER--Claire Kaplan, 92, died August 4, 2008 in Waterloo, Ontario, Canada. Born in Astoria, graduate of Hunter College, longtime resident of Chester, New York. Predeceased by husband Dr. Morris Gerner and brother Prof. Sidney Kaplan. Survived by her three children, four granddaughters, and six great-grandchildren. Gifts in remembrance may be made to the Kitchener-Waterloo Symphony, care of RatzBechtel Funeral Home, 621 King St. W., Kitchener, Ontario, Canada N2G 1C7

METCALF--Sheila Houghton, died July 25, of ovarian cancer, at the age of 55. Born in Providence, RI, she graduated from Miss Hall's School. After receiving her B.A. from the University of R.I., she obtained a B.S from the Columbia University School of Nursing. In addition, she graduated from City College with a degree in Landscape Architecture. She worked as a nurse in New York and then changed careers and joined the N.Y. Dept of City Planning in their Waterfront and Open Space Division. A project manager working to transform New York's Fresh Kills Land Fill into a park, she was at the Dept of Sanitation until her death. She was dedicated to the arts, to the expansion of open space in New York, and to the preservation of our neighborhoods. Ms. Metcalf is survived by her husband, George M. Cronin of New York. She is also survived by her mother, Mrs. H. P. Metcalf, Jr., her brother Stephen Metcalf, and her sister, Katherine Metcalf Sheldon, all of Providence; as well as ten nieces and nephews. Services are private. Donations can be made to Protect the Village Historic District. Checks should be payable to Open Space Institute/PVHD and mailed to Box 537, 511 Sixth Ave., New York, NY, 10011

HOUSING WOES Freddie Mac, the mortgage giant that has been hobbled by record foreclosures, cut its dividend by 80 percent after posting a quarterly loss of $821 million and predicted that home prices would fall further than projected. Bank United, Florida's biggest regional bank, symbolizes the excesses exhibited by banks as home prices soared -- and the pain afflicting them now that prices are falling. [C1.]

TAYLOR--Jud, film and television director, and past president of the Directors Guild of America, passed away on August 6, 2008, after a long illness. Taylor's many films included Foxfire, for which he won a Directors Guild Award for Outstanding Directorial Achievement, and Tailgunner Joe, which was nominated for an Emmy. He also directed episodes of many classic TV series running the gamut from original Star Trek episodes to, more recently, episodes of Law and Order: Special Victims Unit. In the 1960s, Taylor acted in films such as The Great Escape and played the recurring role of Dr. Gerson in the hit series Dr. Kildare. As actor or director, he worked with Steve McQueen, Denzel Washington, James Stewart, Charles Bronson, and Lee Strassberg. A warm and loving husband, brother, father and grandfather, and a creative, witty and talented man, Taylor is survived by his wife, casting director Lynn Kressel, his sister Diana Olken, two daughters from a prior marriage, Alexandra Taylor and Darian Taylor, and a granddaughter, Daisy Lee. Funeral services will be held at 3pm, Friday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that contributions be made in memory of Jud Taylor to the Directors Guild of America Foundation, 7920 Sunset Blvd., Suite 401, Los Angeles, CA 90046

FORTNER--Roberta Jean Olsen, wife of late Joseph G. Fortner, M.D., passed away on August 4, 2008. She was the beloved mother of Kathleen and Joseph Jr., mother-in-law of Holly Winger Fortner, and grandmother of Amanda and Margaret Fortner, and Christina and Genevieve Lewis. She is also survived by her sister, Kathleen Olsen March, of Cincinnati, Ohio. Born February 1, 1924 in Eureka, South Dakota, she was a graduate of the University of South Dakota, where she was a member of Kappa Alpha Theta. She completed her course work for her Masters in Social Work at Columbia University, and was a Docent at The Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was also a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She spent most of her life in Scarsdale, New York City, and Madison, Connecticut. She will be buried with her husband at a private service in Bedford, Indiana. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. She will be greatly missed by her grieving family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to St. Joseph's Indian School, Chamberlain, South Dakota 57326.

He is also survived by his devoted brother, Don and wife Sydelle, and their children and families.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about a drop in major and violent crimes at New York City schools misstated the name of a group that has questioned crime reporting in schools. It is the New York Civil Liberties Union, not the New York City Civil Liberties Union.

Most people tend to notice the pictures and ignore the frame. But a digital photo frame by the French interior designer Andrée Putman may upstage your vacation shots. She designed it for Parrot, a Paris-based company specializing in wireless and mobile-technology products. Ms. Putman's trademark minimalist style surrounds a 7-inch L.C.D. screen with a resolution of 720 pixels by 480 pixels. The frame has a Bluetooth chip to wirelessly copy photos from Bluetooth-enabled mobile phones and computers; it does not support Wi-Fi connections. There is a slot for camera memory cards and a mini-U.S.B. port for copying photos from computer to frame. The 10 megabytes of internal storage can hold up to 400 photos.

LOCHHEAD--Roger P., M.D., died on Saturday August 2, 2008 in Burlington, VT. Born on May 23, 1924 in New York, NY, he was the son of Archie and Suzanne (Aubry) Lochhead. He earned a B.A. from Dartmouth College in 1946, and his M.D. from Cornell University Medical College in 1951 and served in the US Navy during WWII as a Pharmacist Mate First Class aboard the U.S.S. Tortuga. Lochhead practiced internal medicine and cardiology in Montclair, NJ for more than 30 years. He is survived by his sons Cameron of Basking Ridge, NJ, and David of North Caldwell, NJ, his daughter Alison Sacknowitz of Westford, MA, his sister Suzanne Mink, and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to Vermont Children's Hospital, Fletcher Allen Health Care Development Office, 111 Colchester Ave., Burlington, VT 05401.

CAREY--Gary L. Teacher and Biographer, died August 5th in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his wife of 39 years Carol (Koshinskie) Carey who loved him truly, madly, deeply. Other survivors include his autistic son Sean and brother Paul J. Carey Jr. and wife Nancy. Another brother Edward Fawcett Carey predeceased him. Gary loved the theater, good books, movies and his cats. After 37 years of teaching at the School of Visual Arts, Gary retired May 5th 2008. Two days later he was hospitalized with complications from emphysema. He struggled valiantly for three months, supported by friends and family and the staff's at St. Vincent's and Methodist Hospitals. God bless them all. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday, August 9th at 10am at St. Augustine's Church. (Sterling Place and 6th Avenue, Brooklyn).

MARK MANNING looked up from his sketch pad, past the entrance of Sunny's Bar, and gazed at the pickup truck parked just beyond the porch. ''I feel like I'm home in Montana,'' said Mr. Manning, an artist (middle photo at left). ''The laid-backness of the people, the open spaces -- they are the closest thing I know to home.'' He was describing Red Hook in Brooklyn, the neighborhood of warehouses, funky bars and rundown roads that is a haven to would-be homesteaders fleeing Manhattan's hectic pace. Pioneers in spirit, they dress the part, strolling in prairie skirts and toting their infants in slings. Others tend bar at the local saloons wearing jeans and bright kerchiefs. A few, like Francis Kerrigan (above), an artist and the barkeep at Sunny's, trail beards worthy of the chuck wagon or crunch along graveled waterfront paths in battered hiking boots.

A rocket launching by a closely watched private company failed Saturday because its first stage was still thrusting slightly after the stages separated, the company's founder said. Elon Musk, the chief executive of the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation, said the first stage slammed into the second stage, leading to the loss of both. ''It's really just very sad,'' Mr. Musk said; if the separation had been delayed by a second or two, he said, ''this wouldn't have happened.'' The extra thrust was not obvious in ground tests of the engine, he said, because of the atmospheric pressure at sea level. The company, known as SpaceX, has lost all three of its first rockets, but has more launches in the works. ''We're never going to make that mistake again,'' he said. JOHN SCHWARTZ

Those of us who pay lip service to green living can now be more genuinely P.C. -- with the Dell Studio Hybrid PC, a fashionably curvy computer with special power-saving features. The PC, which starts at $500, weighs about four pounds and is about eight inches wide. Dell says it uses 70 percent less electricity than a standard PC, yet it is still powerful enough to run Windows Vista. Inside are a low-power Intel Pentium Dual Core processor, four gigabytes of memory and a 320-gigabyte hard drive.

Nikon's Coolpix P6000 point-and-shoot camera has a few odd tricks up its sleeve. Globetrotters will enjoy its built-in Global Positioning System sensor for geo-tagging -- or adding geographical information to photos -- and Luddites will love the camera's built-in Ethernet port. While most camera makers use Bluetooth or Wi-Fi for uploading images to Web sites, Nikon has added a full-size Ethernet port that lets you plug the camera into the Internet. The P6000 uploads images whenever it is connected, which could come in handy in cybercafes or hotels without Wi-Fi.

Selecting CDs for a car trip and juggling them in and out of a dashboard slot seems passé, now that you can carry hours of music on a digital music player, a U.S.B. thumb drive, a pocket-size hard drive or a memory card the size of a postage stamp. So Blaupunkt left the CD player out of its Brisbane SD48 car stereo, supplementing its radio tuner with inputs and card slots for all of those compact music carriers instead. The front panel has an analog auxiliary input, for connection to the headphone jack of a portable player or satellite-radio adapter, and an SD/MMC memory-card slot. A U.S.B. adapter cable plugs into the back.

Its owners are deploying its old-fashioned system — although new plans for computer-controlled light-emitting diodes are in the works — to illuminate the skyscraper, New York City’s tallest, at night to celebrate the Olympics. From Thursday night through Aug. 24, the building is illuminating its sides with the flag colors of 66 countries taking part in the Olympics.

The opening of the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing drew the world’s attention to China — and was also marked by protests against China throughout the world. In Chicago; London; Amsterdam; Lausanne, Switzerland; Warsaw; New Delhi; Ankara, Turkey, and countless other cities, protesters marched and chanted, criticizing China’s authoritarian regime, its record on human rights, its foreign policy and its treatment of Tibet. Many of the protesters focused on Chinese embassies and consulates. New York, of course, was no exception.In the morning, while a street entertainer played “America the Beautiful” on a steel drum, hundreds of people lined up in Battery Park waiting to board the ferry to the Statue of Liberty. At first, very few noticed a small airplane circling the statue, towing a banner that read, “Red Torch for Tibet.” The letters were difficult to read from the dock, and most of the people here were busy taking photos and keeping up with the line.

My column this Saturday tackles a hard-to-answer question: how much good can a company with a conscience really do? In the case at hand, the company is De Beers, which for nearly a century was an out-and-out monopolist that worked diligently (and successfully) to control the world's supply of diamonds -- and that, in the last decade, has had the kind of conversion experience you don't often see in large corporations. While still a big, dominant player (it sells 40 percent of the world's rough stones today), it competes quite happily in a market economy, where the goal is to expand the demand, not control supply. I did not know any of this until I started in on this column -- it was quite the revelation to realize that De Beers had become a more "normal" company.

One of the best parts of James Wood's stimulating little book "How Fiction Works" is its lucid explanation of one of the most powerful tools of novel-writing, the limber and elastic narrative technique known as "free indirect style." Wood suggests that this style - in which a third-person narrator and the characters he describes intertwine in magical ways - arises naturally from storytelling: "As soon as someone tells a story about a character," he writes, "narrative seems to want to bend itself around that character, wants to merge with that character, to take on his or her way of thinking and speaking."

While the candidates decide on running mates for the 2008 presidential election, most voters say that the choices will have little effect on their vote in November, according to the latest national CBS News poll. More than two-thirds of voters said their vote would be based mostly on the presidential candidates, and only 30 percent said the choice for vice president would have a great deal of influence on their vote.

DITSON--Kappy , of New York City, died August 5, 2008 at Roosevelt Hospital surrounded by her adoring family. Mrs. Ditson, nee Pearl Kaplan, was born December 6, 1917 in Livingston Manor, New York, the daughter of Louis and Ester Kaplan. After graduating from City College with a fine art degree, she began a career in the music business. Kappy broke new ground for women when she became the first female record promoter, representing Frank Sinatra, Patti Page, and other top names. She subsequently opened Pickwick Travel, where she handled the U.S. tours for performing artists including the Beatles, Rolling Stones and James Taylor. In her private life, Kappy was a great fan of jazz music. She was a voracious reader and lifelong seeker of philosophical truth. However, the thing she prized most in life was her vast circle of friends. She is survived by her beloved children, daughters Kim and Noele, son Harry; cherished grandchildren, Gigi, Ga brielle, Ariane, Nike, Samara, Lucy, Melissa, and Sam; and treasured great-grandchildren, Brittany, Jordan, and Jude. She was predeceased by her adored husband Lenny and her beloved daughter Leslie. A celebration of her extraordinary life will be held on Saturday at Tavern on the Green. She will be missed.
