SILBERKLEIT--Michael I. , the chairman of Archie Comic Publications, died August 5th in New York City at the age of 76, after a short battle with cancer. For much of the 60 years he worked at Archie Comics, Silberkleit shared the leadership of the company with Richard Goldwater, whose father, John Goldwater, and his partner, Louis Silberkleit, Michael's father, founded the company. The sons, who began working at the company as boys, later steered Archie Comics into the modern era of publishing as electronic production techniques and brand licensing became important. They encouraged the development of new characters, such as Sabrina, the Teenage Witch, and Josie and the Pussycats, and successfully licensed these and other characters through Archie Comics Entertainment. Silberkleit was also Executive consultant to the TV program, Sabrina, the Teenage Witch, a long running series starring Melissa Joan Hart. The company also published comic books as a licensee, including Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Sonic the Hedgehog. At various times Silberkleit was chairman of the Comics Association of America. The centerpiece identity of the company, which is based in Mamaroneck, New York, remains the brightly innocent presence of Archie and his girlfriends, Betty and Veronica, who made their comic debut in 1941. Over the decades Michael Silberkleit and Richard Goldwater steadfastly refused to introduce the worldlier and darker elements of teenage life, like sex and drugs and violence, into the Archie storylines. In doing so they preserved an image of adolescence for the target audience of 7-to-14 year olds. Silberkleit was determined to keep Archie an American institution, pure as childhood, yet up-to-date with the latest technology used by children today. For generations of readers, Archie and the Gang have represented the wonder and magic of childhood and Silberkleit fought successfully to keep this vision alive. Unlike some competitors who use longer formats, Archie Comics continues its tradition of telling accessible, short stories. In one of the many interviews Silberkleit gave, he said, ''The fact that our stories are funny, are non-violent, believable, clean and appropriate for youngsters makes us so appealing to the younger reader. This philosophy hasnt changed for more than 60 years. Many parents grew up reading Archie Comics and feel that our comics are appropriate for their kids.'' After an initial public offering in the early 1970s, when Silberkleit served as Treasurer, Archie Comics shares were traded publicly. But after ten years Silberkleit and his partner Goldwater bought the company back from shareholders and held it as a private, family-owned business thereafter. Currently, the company publishes over 10 million comics per year in a dozen languages worldwide. Born in New York City in 1932, Silberkleit attended the Fieldston School before going to Albright College as an undergraduate. He studied law after his graduation. Silberkleit was also active in the community, volunteering as an auxiliary policeman for the Scarsdale Police force. A resident of Rye and East Hampton, NY, Silberkleit indulged his mechanical aptitude with vintage sports cars, spending several years restoring a 1966 Austin Healey 3000 MKIII. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Lind Silberkleit, and their daughter, Alexandria, and by three adult children from a prior marriage to Karen Silberkleit: Susan Berkley, David Silberkleit and Amy Silberkleit, as well as grandchildren Isis and Elijah Shiffer. A private funeral and memorial service is planned for Sunday, August 10th. The family asks that, in lieu of flowers or other memorials, donations should be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Research

Yasmina left Lebanon to earn money and escape a domineering husband. Isaac fled Russia because of anti-Semitism. Irene traveled from Greece in hopes of attending medical school. Franca, from Italy, boarded a ship to rejoin her husband, who had been in America so long that their younger son didn't remember him. Real people? Yes and no. These are characters in ''With Nothing but a Dream,'' the latest Origins Project from City Lights Youth Theater. Each year the theater's members (some of whom are in character, above) work with a professional playwright to develop a script about New York history. This time they have not only based their characters on actual early-20th-century immigrants, but they are also presenting their play at a site that could not be more emblematic: Ellis Island.

FORTNER--Roberta Jean Olsen , wife of late Joseph G. Fortner, M.D., passed away on August 4, 2008. She was the beloved mother of Kathleen and Joseph Jr., mother-in-law of Holly Winger Fortner, and grandmother of Amanda and Margaret Fortner, and Christina and Genevieve Lewis. She is also survived by her sister, Kathleen Olsen March, of Cincinnati, Ohio. Born February 1, 1924 in Eureka, South Dakota, she was a graduate of the University of South Dakota, where she was a member of Kappa Alpha Theta. She completed her course work for her Masters in Social Work at Columbia University, and was a Docent at The Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was also a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She spent most of her life in Scarsdale, New York City, and Madison, Connecticut. She will be buried with her husband at a private service in Bedford, Indiana. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. She will be greatly missed by her grieving family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to St. Joseph's Indian School, Chamberlain, South Dakota 57326.
AROUND TOWN

Even in these dog days of summer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the city's health commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, traveled to a Brooklyn park on Monday to spread a piece of welcoming news among dog owners: They can now license their pets online. Dog licensing is a legal requirement, and violators can face fines of at least $200. But the mayor said that only 20 percent of the estimated 500,000 dogs that live in New York City are believed to be licensed, even though licenses are a requirement for dogs that frequent city parks. One of the goals of the new system, he explained, is to encourage more people to license their dogs.

FIEDLER--Caroline , born October 20, 1925, passed away August 6, 2008. A loving wife of the late Harold, mother of Adrienne, Claire and Jeffrey, and adoring grandmother to Jessica, Candra, Jamie, Kimberly and Ian. She gave of herself, with no pretense or expectations, to her family and friends and felt herself fortunate to have traveled extensively with Harold. She survived breast cancer in 1965 and became active in the American Cancer Society, counseling others and supporting them through their treatment. She was selfless, compassionate and always with a smile and a hug. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. Service to be held Friday, August 8, 2008 at Riverside Memorial Chapel located at 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY 10552 at 11am. Contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society. Shiva will be held at the home of Jeffrey and Joyce Fiedler, 36 Severn St., Scarsdale, NY 10583, Saturday night August 9th 7-I0pm, Sunday, August 10th 1-8pm, Monday, August 11th 1-9pm, Tuesday, August 12th 1-4pm.

7:30 P.M. (NBC) OLYMPIC SUMMER GAMES 2008 In the opening ceremony held at the Beijing National Stadium, competing teams will enter during the Parade of Nations according to the stroke count in the first character of the country's name in Chinese -- a traditional method of ordering names and objects -- placing Italy 191st and Australia 203rd, right before Zambia. The filmmaker Zhang Yimou (''Raise the Red Lantern,'' ''House of Flying Daggers'') is the chief director of the event, with 10,000 performers, including Celine Dion; Jay Chou and A-One, a Chinese pop act; more than 100 indigenous Taiwanese dancers; and a fireworks spectacular (which was tested in a dress rehearsal at the stadium, above) in which the Olympic Rings will be formed in the sky. 6 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY GAMES 2008 In this three-hour spinoff of the super-cute ''Puppy Bowl,'' more than 30 puppies representing countries from around the world (but retrieved mostly from Washington-area Petfinder shelters) will demonstrate strength, agility and charm in the Animal Planet Stadium as they compete for gold, silver and bronze medals in canine versions of Olympic events. The festivities begin with a Parade of Puppies, after which kittens will put on an artistic display. The athletes (including Vince, above, an Australian cattle dog mix) and their sports include Labs, spaniels and huskies in the dog paddle; retrievers, bulldogs and mastiffs in boxing; beagles, cattle dogs and Westies on the soccer field; and Shih Tzus, poodles and terriers in gymnastics. A pair of goldfish will judge.

In comedy circles, endurance usually comes up only in reference to boozing, writing sessions or retellings of ''The Aristocrats'' joke. But this weekend more than 300 comedians, stand-ups, improvisers and writers from around the country will participate in 54 continuous hours of funny. It's the 10th annual Del Close Marathon, named for and inspired by the Chicago improv guru who was a mentor to the likes of Tina Fey, John Belushi, Bill Murray, Mike Myers and Amy Poehler. The festival, founded after Mr. Close's death from emphysema in 1999, is run by the Upright Citizens Brigade theater in Chelsea; this year's event has expanded to four additional stages nearby. Starting on Friday at 6 p.m., comedy fans can see round-the-clock improv shows, with appearances by names-you-know-from-television, including Paul Scheer of MTV's ''Human Giant''; Jack McBrayer of ''30 Rock''; Nick Kroll of the late, unlamented ''Cavemen'' sitcom; and cast members and writers from ''The Daily Show,'' ''The Colbert Report,'' ''Late Night With Conan O'Brien'' and ''Saturday Night Live.'' Even at 3 a.m., there's a line out the door, said Anthony King, the artistic director of the Upright Citizens Brigade, though, ''around noon, you can get in pretty easily.'' (Above, from left, Matt Walsh, Ian Roberts, Ms. Poehler and Matt Besser of the Brigade.)With so many unscripted hours to fill, the organizers are pretty open when it comes to concepts.

EPSTEIN--Alice Kessler , a lifelong resident of Margate and Atlantic City, NJ, died August 6, 2008 in Littleton, MA at the age of 86. Born in Egg Harbor, NJ in 1922, she was the daughter of the late Celia Kessler and William B. Kessler and sister of the late Chester Kessler, founder and president respectively of William B. Kessler, Inc., makers of Hammonton Park Clothes. Alice was a past president and honorary board member of Jewish Family Services, where she was instrumental in expanding its mission. She was deeply involved in the founding and early growth of the William B. Kessler Memorial Hospital, in Hammonton, NJ, which was dedicated to the revered memory of her father. Alice was an honorary trustee of the Jewish Agency of Atlantic and Cape May Counties. She attended the University of Miami. Alice is survived by her two sons, Arnold Epstein of Concord, MA and Gary Epstein of Florham Park, NJ and three grandchildren, Andrew, Racheal, and Charlotte. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, August 13 at Congregation Beth Judah, Ventnor, NJ at 11 am. Memorial gifts can be made to Jewish Family Services, 607 N. Jerome Avenue, Margate, NJ.

We all know what it's like to sit around waiting for the cable guy. For the biggest shareholders of Cablevision Systems, the wait may be over. Rich Greenfield, an analyst at Pali Research, wrote on his blog Thursday that James L. Dolan, Cablevision's chief executive, will be paying a personal visit next week to the 20 largest shareholders of his company. The house calls come soon after Cablevision said it was considering a range of moves -- from buybacks to spinoffs -- to try to lift its stock.

On the shore of Lake Superior, this two-story, 649-square-foot condominium is in the Reiten Boatyard development, next to a swimming beach, indoor pool and boat landing. The unit has a wood-burning fireplace, spiral staircase to a sleeping loft (separate from the main bedroom), and an open living-dining area. There is a balcony overlooking the water, and there are several marinas nearby. Broker: Kathleen Russell, Apostle Islands Realty; (800) 514-6700; www.apostleislands.com.

Many people have been hurt by the subprime mortgage crisis, from homeowners to investment bankers. Yet some firms bet early against these risky home loans, reaping big profits in the process. Now one of these apparently prescient bears, the Blackstone Group, may be seeing light at the end of the tunnel. Not only has the alternative-asset giant been covering its bets against subprime, according to its president, Hamilton E. James, but it has been actively seeking to buy these assets.

This 2,540-square-foot unit is on the 36th floor in a building on Lake Shore Drive, with views north and east of Lake Michigan, as well as Navy Pier. It has an open kitchen with breakfast bar that has full water views, as do most rooms in the apartment, cherrywood floors and stainless-steel appliances. A balcony overlooks the lake, Ohio Street Beach and Olive Park. There are three and a half bathrooms. Agent: Naomi Wilkinson, Magellan Realty; (312) 622-1002; www.magellansells.com.
FOR CHILDREN

ROTHFELD--Samuel H. , died August 7, 2008, in New York City at age 94. Beloved husband of 66years of the former Betty Rabiner and father of Michael, Carolyn, and Robert. Grandfather of Adam and Michael Rothfeld, Benjamin and David Goldstein, and Ella and Augusta FoshayRothfeld. He was a urologist who invented an instrument that facilitated surgery on infants and babies, devised a surgical procedure that saved kidneys in infants and small children and published extensively on urological problems in children as well as urological conditions resulting from disease or damage to the nervous system. He established a urology program at the Alyn Hospital for children in Jerusalem, and the urology residency and research programs at Long Island Jewish Hospital where he was chief of that service. He helped to form the urology service at North Shore hospital where he was attending urologist and later in life served as chief of surgery at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, FL. He practiced diagnostic and non-surgical urology as chief of that service in a Veterans Administration Clinic until age 85. He served on the clinical faculties of Cornell Medical College and SUNY Downstate Medical Center. He was a surgeon during WWII in Burma, China and India. Service and interment will be private.
CODY--Elizabeth (Betty) , of Naples, FL died peacefully on July 30th in Burlington, VT. We will all miss her kindness, her laughter, her beauty and goodness. Cody and Riegelman Family

HOUSTON -- Treated like a rock star by her followers, Victoria Osteen, 47, is co-pastor of Lakewood Church, one of the nation's largest and fastest-growing megachurches. With a halo of perfectly coiffed blond hair, she preaches about love and acceptance alongside her husband, Joel, to more than 40,000 congregants every Sunday. But she was portrayed in court on Thursday as imperious, combative and possibly racist in a dispute with a Continental Airlines flight attendant, Sharon Brown.

Two dock spaces are available for an additional fee. Cedar Point amusement park is about four miles away. There is a heated pool. Broker: David Chervenic, Geneva Chervenic Realty; 330-686-1644; www.chervenicrealty.com.

Stung by the recent passage of legislation to expand government surveillance powers, two prominent liberal bloggers are teaming up with right-leaning Libertarians on a new political action committee to combat perceived threats to civil liberties. Trevor Lyman, who worked on behalf of the presidential campaign of Representative Ron Paul, spearheaded Mr. Paul's ''money bombs,'' in which thousands of supporters made nearly simultaneous online donations. Those efforts on behalf of Mr. Paul, Republican of Texas, resulted in record fund-raising drives, and Mr. Lyman is now offering his company's services to the coalition, called the Strangebedfellows, and their effort to raise money for the new AccountabilityNowPAC.

Reader comments on ''Can the Egg Cream Make a Comeback?'' -- about a Lower East Side candy store's efforts to revive the fizzy beverage, but in flavors like hazelnut, cappuccino and black and white: ''I grew up in the Bronx at Soundview Station on Morrison Avenue in the 1950s. I met my mom every night at 6:15 for our 'cocktail,' which was Shimmy's egg creams. I would boost myself up on the stool and watch as Shimmy put in the syrup, milk and seltzer in the glass and deftly swirled them around to create a beautiful foam. Then I would take two chocolate-covered raspberry treats for our appetizer. Ah, sweet memories!'' -- Barbara Indursky Nagpal

When a painting like "Landscape of a Thousand Miles" (千里江山图) from the Song Dynasty (960-1276) is showcased in the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics, it's hard not to feel a sense of national pride as a Chinese. Most people may respond with "Landscape of what thousand miles?" Most people -- Chinese or non-Chinese -- probably wouldn't respond strongly to a piece of ancient art. The spectacular fireworks, dazzling pyrotechnics and undulating waves of performers evoke far more wows and ahhs.

My Sunday column is about the need to rebalance American foreign policy, so that we're capable not just of blowing things up but also building things up. The military is indeed an important tool in foreign policy, but there are other essential tools: diplomacy, intelligence, foreign aid, trade and information. We've been developing our military muscles (80 percent budget increase since 9/11, including supplementals) but our other muscles have been sorely neglected. One indication of that is that we have more musicians in our military bands than we have diplomats.

States that fail to adopt a steroid ban in horse racing by the end of the year could lose their graded stakes status in 2009. The American Graded Stakes Committee of the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association passed a requirement this week that would penalize states if they do not adopt a proposed model rule steroid ban by Jan. 1. At least 10 states have approved the ban.

Because Manny Ramírez’s relationship with the Red Sox ended with some lingering questions about his behavior, Commissioner Bud Selig asked Rob Manfred, one of baseball’s executive vice presidents, to conduct interviews on the topic. Nascar denied that a former official, now suing for racial discrimination and sexual harassment, ever complained to her superiors about such problems. The employee often referred to herself with racial stereotypes and was repeatedly reprimanded for tardiness and other issues, Nascar said. Nascar said the firing of the employee, Mauricia Grant, last October was legitimate. Grant filed suit in June alleging 23 incidents of sexual harassment and 34 incidents of racial and gender discrimination over more than two years at Nascar.

Racing was canceled at Saratoga Race Course after torrential rain and hail washed out part of the stretch turn. The last program canceled at Saratoga was on Aug. 2, 2006, because of extreme heat. The New York Racing Association lost eight races to the deluge, the first storm-related loss of races at Saratoga in four years. Rain checks were issued, and the track stayed open for simulcasting.

The Buffalo Sabres re-signed defenseman Teppo Numminen after he missed all but one game last season after heart surgery. Sabres General Manager Darcy Regier said Numminen, 40, an unrestricted free agent, agreed to a one-year contract worth $1.1 million.

DORMAN--Michael L., of Bay Shore, NY on August 6, 2008. Inveterate reporter and writer, loving husband of Jeanne, devoted father of Pamela and Trish and fatherin-law of Stuart and Richard, delighted grandfather of Katie, Sammie, Nicholas and Sophia. Born in the Bronx, he was for many years a writer and editor at Newsday, a professor of journalism, and the author of more than a dozen books. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Summer Fellowship for Young Journalists, at The Poynter Institute, 801 Third Street South, St. Petersburg, FL 33701, or online at www.poynter.org, to The Fund for Investigative Journalism, www.fij.org, by check only to PO Box 60184, Washington, DC 20039-0184. A Funeral Service will be held Tuesday 10:00am at First Presbyterian Church of Babylon, Babylon, NY. Services entrusted to the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy., West Islip, NY 11795.

MOODY--Orville. Our friend Orville Moody died today in Dallas, Texas. If it is possible to be too kind and too generous, Orville was. He was a man without a devious or malicious bone in his body. History will report that he was a U.S. Open Champion, but he was a special man in many more important ways than golf. I talked to Orville every week for the past 45 years, and I will miss my friend. Edward Price
36 Hours in Denver

I went to a little park by the west moat of the Forbidden City as the time of the opening ceremony approached Friday. There was a man fishing there, by the moat. He was grumpy and chose not to tell me his name. He deflected most of my questions in a way that I found amusing and honest. ''No fish here,'' he said. ''Just here for fun.'' I asked him what he liked about the spot, which was beautiful. He said: ''It's cool here. There's wind. It's nothing special. Just good to have a breeze.''

SPIVAK--Irwin Howard , award-winning and internationally renowned photographer, jazz musician, and teacher, died peacefully on August 6, 2008. He was on his beloved Cape Cod and surrounded by family. He leaves behind his wife of 59 years, Janice; three daughters, Sarah Woolf, Jane Hughes, and Melissa Fox; three sons - in - law, Louis Woolf, Jerry Hughes, and Michael Fox; and eight grandchildren, Rebecca, Alex, Zack, Josh, Mollie, Caroline, Zoe and Jilly. Donations in his name may be made to the Jazz Arts Music Society of Palm Beach, JAMS, P.O. Box 3033, Palm Beach, Florida 33480.

ROTHFELD--Samuel H., *CORRECTION*, died August 7, 2008, in New York City at age 94. Beloved husband of 66 years of the former Betty Rabiner and father of Michael, Carolyn, and Robert. Grandfather of Adam and Michael Rothfeld, Benjamin and David Goldstein, and Ella and Augusta Foshay-Rothfeld. He was a urologist who invented an instrument that facilitated surgery on infants and babies, devised a surgical procedure that saved kidneys in infants and small children and published extensively on urological problems in children as well as urological conditions resulting from disease or damage to the nervous system. He established a urology program at the Alyn Hospital for children in Jerusalem, and the urology residency and research programs at Long Island Jewish Hospital where he was chief of that service. He helped to form the urology service at North Shore hospital where he was attending urologist and later in life served as chief of surgery at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, FL. He practiced diagnostic and non-surgical urology as chief of that service in a Veterans Administration Clinic until age 85. He served on the clinical faculties of Cornell Medical College and SUNY Downstate Medical Center. He was a surgeon during WWII in Burma, China and India. Service and interment will be private.

SURAK--Daniel J. , August 9th, 2007. Cherished friend, beloved Godfather and confidante. We mourn you, miss you, and love you still. Rest in peace Darling Dan, our thoughts and prayers will be with you always. Vito, Rosalyn & Juliet

SUGHRUE--Janet H., of New York City, after a six year struggle with cancer, she fought her battle with a strong faith and unwavering optimism supported by her family and many friends. Beloved wife of Peter M. Sughrue. Adored mother of Peter, Jr. and Justin, and loved by daughter-in-law Vanessa. Also survived by a sister, Mary McAloon of Parkland, FL., and predeceased by a brother, Benjamin. Janet graduated from Barat College of the Sacred Heart in Lake Forest, IL. She worked in the admissions office at Park Avenue Christian Day School, and later was CoDirector of Admissions at St. David's School. She will be waked at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Monday, August 11. Visiting hours will be from 2 to 5 and from 7 to 9 in the evening. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Jean Baptiste Church, 184 Lexington Avenue at 10am on Tuesday, August 12. Burial service will be private. In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions may be made to St. David's School 12 East 89 St., NYC, NY 10128 or to The American Cancer Society 132 West 32nd St., New York City, NY 10001.

ARANOW--Rita. New York University College of Dentistry records with sorrow the passing of Rita Aranow. Mrs. Aranow and the Louis and Anne Abrons Foundation generously supported numerous projects at NYU College of Dentistry, and stood firmly behind the mission and values of the College. The students, faculty, administration, and staff of NYU College of Dentistry extend sincere condolences to the Aranow family. Charles N. Bertolami, DDS, DMedSc Herman Robert Fox Dean NYU College of Dentistry ARANOW--Rita Abrons. Hadassah deeply mourns the passing of Rita Abrons Aranow, a truly compassionate and caring woman and one of our most generous benefactors. She embraced her family's tradition of philanthropy in order to repair the world. A Guardian of Zion, Rita was a passionate believer in education and generously supported Hadassah College Jerusalem and the Charlotte R. Bloomberg Mother and Child Center at the Hadassah Medical Center, Ein Kerem. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Richard Abrons, her brother, and Vicki and Fred Feiner, Robert Aranow, and Judy Aranow, her children, her five grandchildren, greatgrandchildren, and her entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Nancy Falchuk, National President, Hadassah

LYON--Frank Gilbert, died on August 5th at the age of 86 in Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his wife Mary Bacon Lyon, and children Wendy L. Richards, Charles W. Lyon II, Mark E. Lyon; grandchildren Christopher and Michael Fanjul, Frank and Lucy Lyon, Heather Lyon - Brunelliere; and one great-grandson, Leif Lyon Miller. He was born December 17, 1921 in Beverly Hills, CA to Nancy Player Janney and senator Charles W. Lyon, Speaker of the House, State of California. He attended U.C.L.A., University of Oregon, and finally, after World War II, U.S.C. A naval aviator, he served in the Pacific and was decorated three times with the Distinguished Flying Cross. He married Mary Estelle Bacon on January 24, 1948 in Pasadena, CA, and settled in La Jolla, CA. In 1958, he moved to Greenwich, CT, to join his brother, Charles W. Lyon Jr., as a partner in Roger L. Stevens Real Estate Investment Company. In addition, as a partner in Whitehead /Stevens he produced plays for Broadway. He was on the board of directors of First New Haven National Bank, Stevens New Haven Development Co., Beverly Wilshire Hotel, Cobra Petroleum, and Windermere Island Club. He was a trustee of Blair Academy in Blairstown, NJ, from 1969-2000 and established the ''Daddy Short Legs'' scholarship fund at Mercy College where he was named an honorary doctor of Letters in 2002. For the American Museum of Natural History he served as a trustee from 1981-1996, heading the Finance Committee for many years. In Greenwich, he was a trustee of the Bruce Museum. A passionate sportsman, he competed in swimming, water polo, tennis and golf, and he also enjoyed immensely skiing, surfing, and fly fishing. A fine yachtsman, he crewed with his brother in many Star boat championships internationally. He was a member of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Stanwich Club and the Brook. His other loves were traveling, wine, and cooking. He will be remembered for his generosity and lust for life which he shared with everyone around him. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Daddy Short Legs Fund at Mercy College, Dobbs Ferry, NY, attention Dr. Louise Feroe. A gathering in his honor will take place in the early fall. LYON--Frank G. The Trustees of the American Museum of Natural History and the entire Museum community are saddened by the death of Frank Lyon, Trustee of the Museum since 1981 and Honorary Trustee since 1996. He was a dedicated and steadfast champion of the Museum's mission to educate the public about natural science and world cultures. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife Mimi and the entire Lyon family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

Bernie Brillstein, a Hollywood manager and producer who helped mold the shape of television with his contributions to series like ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''The Muppet Show,'' died here on Thursday night. He was 77. The cause was chronic pulmonary disease, said Nicole Caruso, a publicist for Brillstein Entertainment Partners. In a 52-year show business career, Mr. Brillstein represented entertainers who ranged from the stand-up comedian Norm Crosby and the singer Frankie Laine to a later generation of comic rebels that included John Belushi, Dan Aykroyd, Gilda Radner, Lorne Michaels, Martin Short and others.

FRENKEL--Elisabeth Lily, on August 7, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Philipp. Loving mother of Irving (Barbara) and Steven (Nancy). Adoring grandmother of Paul, Allison, Johanna, Andrea, Evan and Clare. Great-grandmother of Mya and Brody. Service Sunday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

KEANE--Peter L., of Allendale, NJ died Thursday, August 7, 2008. Born in Manhattan, New York he lived in Flushing, Queens before moving to Allendale in 1960. Peter attended New York University and then Brooklyn Law School from 1938-1941. He began working at the Law Firm of Lord, Day & Lord in New York as an office boy while attending college and law school. In April 1942, he was admitted as an Attorney and Counselor at Law for the State of New York. He served his country from 1942-1945 in the U.S. Army Air Corp and discharged as a Master Sgt. Upon returning from service in 1945, he was assigned to the corporate department at Lord, Day & Lord Esqs. In 1971, he was elected managing partner and served until 1982. He remained of counsel until 2000. In July of 1971, he was elected President and Chief Executive Officer of American Export Industries. In October of 1994, he was appointed Senior Advisor to the Law Firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius in New York until 2000. Surviving is his beloved wife of almost 60 years, Susan (nee Hughes) of Allendale, NJ, devoted father of Susan Keane Vogel of Franklin Lakes, NJ and Peter Kevin Keane of Florida. Loving grandpa to Erin, Kevin and Devon Vogel and Michael and Nicole Keane. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave. Wyckoff, NJ. Funeral Mass Monday 10am at Church of the Guardian Angel, 320 Franklin Turnpike, Allendale, NJ. Interment Christ the King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Memorial Contributions may be made to Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club, 1930 Randall Ave., Bronx, NY 10473 in his memory. www.vpfh.com

With the mayor, comptroller, public advocate, four out of five borough presidents and two-thirds of the City Council all required to leave office in 2009 because of term limits, many are scrambling to extend their public careers by running for another job, in Albany, Washington or elsewhere in city government. A record 166 people have declared for city office so far, and while there will be some new faces on the Council, many of the old faces could also be around in different jobs.

BEIJING -- One of the United States' best hopes for a boxing medal will not compete in the Olympics after collapsing early Friday morning in a final effort to make weight. The coach of the United States' boxing team, Dan Campbell, said Gary Russell Jr., 20, a two-time national champion, was trying to shave a few extra pounds to get down to the required weight for a bantamweight, 119 pounds, when he fainted at the Olympic Village.

RICE--Eugene F., Jr., died in New York on August 4, a few weeks short of his 84th birthday. Professor of History at Cornell University (1954-1964) and at Columbia University (from 1964), he was an award-winning teacher and distinguished scholar. His books include the classic textbook The Foundations of Early Modern Europe, 1460-1559. He is survived by his sister Lucy Clarke; his children, Eugene, John, and Louise; his grandchildren, Daniel, Rebecca, and Lydia; and his companion Ron Caldwell. Gifts in memory of Professor Rice may be made to the New York City Ballet, 20 Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023.

Bankers working on a salvage plan for the Italian airline Alitalia are close to a package that would keep the carrier in Italian hands but flying a much-reduced network in partnership with a major European carrier. The plan, thrashed out by the Italian banking group Intesa Sanpaolo in the last two months, would merge the healthier parts of Alitalia with Air One, a much smaller, privately owned Italian airline, according to a person briefed on the proposals who was not authorized to speak publicly because the deal was not completed. The unprofitable parts of Alitalia and much of its debt would be placed into a separate entity that could sell some assets to reduce debt. The Italian government would most likely assume the rest of the debt.

Southbound traffic on the Bruckner Expressway was rerouted for about 10 hours on Friday after the rear of a dump truck, accidentally raised by the driver, hit a pedestrian bridge in the Pelham Bay section of the Bronx about 2 a.m. and caused a large part of it to collapse. There were no deaths, and the truck driver was the only person injured. He was listed in stable condition Friday evening at Jacobi Medical Center.

In a famous passage in the sixth book of "The Prelude" (1805, 1850), William Wordsworth recounts a walking journey in which he and a companion (Robert Jones) crossed the Alps without having been aware that they had done so. That is, they were already heading down when they believed they were still going up. The big moment they had looked forward to occurred without their noticing. What they had missed was the liminal experience of crossing a threshold, stepping across a line, passing from one state to another. One minute they're thinking about getting somewhere and the next minute they discover they're already there. They can hardly believe it and question the peasant who has informed them: "And all the answers which the man returned/ To our inquiries, in their sense and substance/ Translated by the feelings which we had,/Ended in this - that we had crossed the Alps."

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Sarah Hendee and Michael Hart misidentified the location of the ceremony. It was in St. John’s Church in Larchmont, N.Y. — not the Larchmont Yacht Club, the site of the reception.

An article on July 20 about the state of the Hudson River misstated the reasons that Roseland Properties decided to pull out of a development project on the site of a former General Motors plant in Sleepy Hollow. Roseland cited increasing costs associated with environmental restoration and a lack of agreement with the Village of Sleepy Hollow on a final plan; it did not cite the cost of environmental cleanup of the G.M. site itself. (General Motors has paid for that cleanup since the plant closed in 1996.).
An article on July 13 about the British composer Ralph Vaughan Williams misidentified an academic institution he attended. It is the Royal College of Music, not the Royal Academy of Music.
An article on July 27 about the country duo Sugarland misidentified the organization that gave it an award for the song “Stay.” It is the Academy of Country Music, not the Country Music Association.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the reunion of Return to Forever reversed the identities of two members of the group. Chick Corea was third from left, and Lenny White was fourth from left.
A collection of opinion pieces from Barbara Ehrenreich focuses on the casualties of our economy.

To the Editor: I very much enjoyed both reading and seeing the multimedia presentation of Frank Bruni’s article “A Taste of Scotland” (July 27). On his next visit to Scotland, I suggest that he travel to the Crinan Hotel (www.crinanhotel.com) in Argyll. On my last visit there, the prawns I ordered for a starter, on the menu, carried the note that they “... were landed at our dock at 17:30 this afternoon.” The venison that followed from Jura, which I could see across the sound from my table, was ambrosial. Two other places from our experience well worth the journey are Auchendean Lodge (www.auchendean.com) and Old Pines Hotel and Restaurant (www.oldpines.co.uk) . As a Scot long in exile, I well remember the bad old days of chips (French fries) with everything, but they are mercifully, if not long gone, long avoidable.

To the Editor: Brooklyn suffers in Seth Kugel’s piece on New York sake bars ("You Can Have Your Rice and Drink It, Too" (July 27). Zenkichi, on North Sixth Street in Williamsburg, is a quirky izakaya where the waiters seal your booth with a bamboo blind and you summon them by pressing a button. The passages are dark, mazelike and full of mirrors — it’s almost disorienting, but the sake selection is superb, and the hot little dishes are too.

Lill Saether and Maria Hjorth each shot a course-record 64 at the Scandinavian T.P.C. in Stockholm. Saether birdied six of her first seven holes and had a nine-under-par 135 total after two rounds. She led by one stroke over Hjorth and Lora Fairclough (66) and by two over Annika Sorenstam (71) and Johanna Head (70).

The Duke University star Amanda Blumenherst and the N.C.A.A. champion Azahara Munoz advanced to the United States Women’s Amateur final at Eugene Country Club in Oregon. Blumenherst, a three-time national college player of the year, beat 15-year-old Erynne Lee of Silverdale, Wash., 3 and 2. Munoz, an Arizona State star who is from Spain, defeated Belen Mozo of Spain, 4 and 3.

Scott Dixon passed Hélio Castroneves coming off the final turn on the one-and-a-half-mile oval at Kentucky Speedway to win the Meijer Indy 300 in Sparta, Ky. The victory was Dixon’s second in a row and sixth of the season. He is closing in on his second IndyCar Series championship.

Marcos Ambrose took advantage of a pit stop midway through the Nationwide Zippo 200 at Watkins Glen, N.Y., and easily beat Kyle Busch for his first career Nascar victory. Ambrose was in the pits on the 42nd lap when the fourth caution of the 82-lap race flew. He gained the lead on the 48th lap, then gave it up to pit for fuel. Ambrose worked his way to third place with 12 laps to go while Jeff Burton and Jimmie Johnson battled for the lead. But they ran out of fuel with three laps left. Matt Kenseth took third.

Top-seeded Andy Roddick advanced to the final of the Countrywide Classic in Los Angeles with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Denis Gremelmayr. He will face third-seeded Juan Martin del Potro, who defeated Mardy Fish, 6-2, 6-1.

A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about the purchase of a Manhattan apartment by the actress Linda Lavin misstated the location of another home she owns. It is Wilmington, N.C., not Wilmington, Del.

An article on June 29 about Hunter S. Thompson described incorrectly the context for a quotation by his widow, Anita Thompson, in which she said he was “surrounded by leeches and hanger-on-ers.” She was referring to the early ’70s, around the time that Mr. Thompson covered Muhammad Ali’s boxing match in Zaire; she did not mean at the time of Mr. Thompson’s death. And a correction in this space last Sunday misidentified Mr. Ali’s opponent in that match. He fought George Foreman, not Joe Frazier.
Entering Saturday’s game, Daniel Murphy was batting .500, at 9 for 18. And some of his best moments have come when he did not even swing the bat.
Persistent lightning and rain forced the suspension of third-round play of the 90th P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, forcing 48 of 73 players to complete the round on Sunday morning.

The “Checking In” article on the Square Feet page last Sunday about the reluctance of Americans to accept greener hotel rooms omitted a feature being adopted by the new Element hotel chain. Element does indeed have dual-flush toilets.
For the fans, who snapped up 20,000 of his new Jets jerseys in the first 48 hours since he joined the team, Brett Favre has already been a success.
The ages of the Chinese gymnasts have been a topic of conversation for months, but it has reached a fever pitch in Beijing.

The Scene Stealer column on July 27, about Hollywood’s financial relationship with Steven Spielberg, referred incorrectly to his directing credits. They include about 50 film and television projects, not more than 50 films.

An obituary last Sunday about the noted French bookseller Pierre Berès overstated what is known about an inscription on a first edition of Rimbaud’s “Season in Hell” that was sold by Mr. Berès. The inscription, “à P. Verlaine. A. Rimbaud,” may or may not have been written to Verlaine by Rimbaud; there is no consensus that it was. The obituary also misspelled the surname of a partner in Ursus Books and Prints in Manhattan who commented on Mr. Berès. He is William Wyer, not Wyler.

A guide to 10 Olympic events last Sunday erroneously included four athletes as medal contenders. None of these athletes qualified in their events: Veronica Campbell-Brown of Jamaica in the 100-meter dash; Daniel Kipchirchir Komen of Kenya in the 1500-meter run; Kaitlin Sandeno of the United States in the women’s 400-meter individual medley; and Cullen Jones in the men’s 50-meter freestyle event.

A picture caption in some editions last Sunday with an article about the Yankees’ 8-2 victory over the Angels carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of the Yankees’ Bobby Abreu hitting a home run was by Uli Seit for The New York Times, not by Ed Betz of The Associated Press.

An article last Sunday about the desire of Mark Cuban, the owner of the N.B.A.’s Dallas Mavericks, to also own the Chicago Cubs referred incorrectly to the baseball team’s championship history. The Cubs have indeed “won it all,” capturing World Series titles in 1907 and 1908.

Elizabeth Wentworth Peirce, the daughter of Anne Austin Griswold Peirce and Nathaniel Ward Peirce of Oyster Bay, N.Y., was married there on Saturday to James Edward Cochrane, a son of Susanne Cauthery Cochrane and Anthony George Cochrane of Douglas, on the Isle of Man. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Oyster Bay, with the Rev. Dr. Peter F. Casparian, the church’s rector, assisting.

Abbe Sandra Fischman, the daughter of Sherry G. Fischman and Dr. Alan S. Fischman of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Alexander Daniel Hocherman, a son of Beth S. Hocherman and Henry M. Hocherman of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Paul Golomb officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

Tasha Kelen Sakaguchi, the daughter of Lori Sakaguchi and Glenn Sakaguchi, who live in Honolulu, was married on Friday to Richard Avery Dickinson Jr., the son of Eileen Sullivan Dickinson and Dr. Dickinson of St. Albans, Vt. The Rev. Benjamin Thuan LeTran performed the ceremony at the Gate of Heaven Roman Catholic Church in Boston.
Diane Cleo Maranis and Christopher Scott Wade were married on Saturday evening in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Patricia A. Dabbah, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Woodway Country Club.

Jeninne Kamaria Lee-St. John and Keirn McHale O’Connor were married on Saturday in Williamstown, Mass. Justice Brian L. Burgess, an uncle of the bridegroom who serves on the Vermont Supreme Court, received permission from Massachusetts to officiate at Sheep Hill, a meadow on the property of a former sheep farm that is now operated by the Williamstown Rural Lands Foundation.

Dr. Andrea Sung Tieng, a daughter of Betty Tieng and Johnson Tieng of Flushing, Queens, is to be married on Sunday to Daniel Minoru Kanemoto, a son of Dr. Henry Kanemoto of Wausau, Wis., and the late Elizabeth Kanemoto. THE wonderful era of the ultra-cheap car could be over before it has begun. Introduced to great international fanfare in January at the New Delhi Auto Show, the Tata Nano was heralded as the great hope for the Indian middle class. A bare-bones sedan with a 623-cc engine, the Nano was promised to sell for only $2,500. It was going to get Indians off their scooters and into cars. But that was before prices for steel and other raw materials began to climb.

A huge market rally on Friday, driven by a drop in oil prices and a rise in the dollar, led the indexes to big gains. Oil futures fell nearly every day last week and ended at $115.20 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest level since early May. Quarterly losses at the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac still weighed on investors.

Is Afghanistan a Narco-State? Ambassador Thomas Schweich (July 27) just doesn't get it. Afghanistan profits from the opium trade because of prohibition, not in spite of it. Attempts to limit the supply of illegal drugs while demand remains constant increase the profitability of drug trafficking. For addictive drugs like heroin, a spike in street prices leads desperate addicts to increase criminal activity to feed desperate habits. The drug war doesn't fight crime; it fuels crime. Switzerland's heroin maintenance program has reduced disease, death and crime among chronic users. Heroin-maintenance pilot projects are under way in Canada, Germany, Spain and the Netherlands. Prescription heroin maintenance could deprive organized crime of a core client base, which might render illegal heroin trafficking unprofitable. It might also undermine Taliban funding in Afghanistan. Of course, admitting that drug prohibition is the problem rather than the solution is tantamount to admitting the emperor wears no clothes.

Lee Young, who emerged from a family with musical roots deep in New Orleans jazz, drummed for greats like Ellington and Basie, became a pioneering black man in music's executive suites -- and survived his musician brother, Lester, by a half century -- died on July 31 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 94. The death was confirmed by his grandson Wren Brown.

VIEWING ELEPHANTS FOR THE FIRST TIME, MAY 24, 2008 Michael Fredericks, 23, center, a master's student in divinity from Kingston, Nova Scotia, photographs a baby elephant at the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust elephant nursery, in Karen, just outside Nairobi. ''We spent a month in Kenya for my school, seeing what different missionary groups are doing, and learning about them. This was my first time leaving Canada, and it was an absolute eye-opener. I'd say most of my ideas of the world were completely changed -- partly by seeing the culture and the way that people live, and also by seeing the way the church is in Kenya. I think the church in North America has so much to learn from the church in Africa. The church in Kenya is so focused on doing good things for the community, doing the good works, whereas the church in North America is so focused on itself. When we had a few days of downtime, we did some tourist things. I'd only seen Canadian wildlife, and most of the zoos where I'm from are very small, so I'd never been exposed to giraffes or elephants or anything like that. So that was really something else.'' As told to Austin Considine

LIESEM--Gloria, died July 30, 2008 in Medina, Ohio at the age of 87. She previously lived in Rego Park, NY, where she served for many years as the secretary of Our Saviour Lutheran School, and in The Village of Rossmoor in Monroe Township, NJ. Gloria embraced the arts as a painter, a pianist and an opera fan until Alzheimer's dimmed her ability to relate to the world around her. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, Hermann Liesem, son and daughter-in-law, Paul and Linda Liesem, granddaughters Beth Harrington, Robin Byrne and Laura Liesem and two great-grandsons, Tyler and Jacob Harrington. A memorial service was held August 1. Donations in her name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, www.alz.org.

MERVIS--Jerry B., 77, died at his home in Stockbridge, Massachusetts, on August 7, 2008, after a courageous battle with ALS. He is survived by his devoted family, wife Arlene, children Michael and his wife Mindy, Faith Katz and her husband Alan, Matthew and his wife Jolyn Unruh, and his seven beloved grandchildren. May he be remembered with smiles by all those who shared his joyous life. Donations can be made to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 E. Flower Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014 (www.hov.org).

ROTHFELD--Samuel H., *CORRECTION*, died August 7, 2008, in New York City at age 94. Beloved husband of 66 years of the former Betty Rabiner and father of Michael, Carolyn, and Robert. Grandfather of Adam and Michael Rothfeld, Benjamin and David Goldstein, and Ella and Augusta Foshay-Rothfeld. He was a urologist who invented an instrument that facilitated surgery on infants and babies, devised a surgical procedure that saved kidneys in infants and small children and published extensively on urological problems in children as well as urological conditions resulting from disease or damage to the nervous system. He established a urology program at the Alyn Hospital for children in Jerusalem, and the urology residency and research programs at Long Island Jewish Hospital where he was chief of that service. He helped to form the urology service at North Shore hospital where he was attending urologist and later in life served as chief of surgery at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, FL. He practiced diagnostic and non-surgical urology as chief of that service in a Veterans Administration Clinic until age 85. He served on the clinical faculties of Cornell Medical College and SUNY Downstate Medical Center. He was a surgeon during WWII in Burma, China and India. Service and interment will be private.

Me and My Girls David Carr's brutally honest account of his chemical addiction (July 20) is testimony to the power of this disease and the promises of recovery. As a grateful recovering alcoholic of 27 years, I commend him for his courage and candor. Hopefully, this will help reduce the stigma of chemical addiction and even prod Congress to finally pass the Mental Health and Addiction Equity Act, which Representative Patrick Kennedy and I have sponsored in the U.S. House.
Chapter 7

MAROON--G., Skillman, NJ. G. Tyson Maroon died on August, 8th at Princeton Medical Center. He was 78. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he moved to Mendham, NJ in 1966 and lived there until 1990, then moved to Skillman, NJ. He received his BA from Fordham University and did graduate work at Columbia and New York University. After retiring from Schering Corporation, as product manager for Coricidin in 1976, he pursued his love for New York and began his real estate career at Kassis Associates Real Estate, followed by becoming SVP of Cushman and Wakefield Real Estate. He soon became one on the top brokers, representing many Fortune 500 firms. Known for his creative and innovative approach, he arranged the joint venture between Rockefeller Center Development Corporation and Lakeland Industrial Park which led to the 670 acre International Trade Center in Mt. Olive, NJ, one of the largest real estate projects in America. He was the founder of the New York Optimist Club and a dedicated New York Rotarian. His proudest achievement was serving as chairman of the ''Project New York'' committee in 1975 when New York was almost bankrupt, which eventually led to the highly successful ''I Love New York'' campaign. He was presented the key to New York City by Mayor Koch. He was a member of St. Charles Borromeo Church, the Old Guard of Princeton and Cherry Valley Country Club. He volunteered at Acorn Glen Nursing home and the Trenton Soup Kitchen. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Anita; daughters Donna Arsenault and Nina Lustik and grandchildren Zachary, Tyler, Connor Arsenault, Jenna and Jack Lustik. Memorial donations may be made in George's name to the National Stroke Association 9707 E. Easter Lane, Centennial, CO 80112.

No Free Bubble In his article on the bailout of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (July 27) Roger Lowenstein gets the small details exactly right -- recent events paint a worrisome picture of a movement toward government involvement in free markets, worrisome especially to those (like me, by the way) who believe free markets should largely be left to themselves to solve such problems. But Lowenstein seems to miss the big point: this is no typical crisis. Indeed, the fact that Paulson and Bernanke have taken such steps to avoid disaster speaks to its magnitude. Surely it is unconvincing to hear some investors expressing shock now that the implied government backing of these quasi-government ''agency'' bonds has become explicit. Maybe what they're really reacting to is not that the government should actually save these institutions, but rather that they just can't believe this day has actually come.

KIRSCHNER--Dr. Stephen A., died at age 87, on July 21, 2008. Born in Bronx, NY. A respected educator and administrator in the New York City School System for over 30 years, having retired in 1982 as Deputy Superintendent of District 22, Brooklyn. He received the Bronze Star for heroism during WWII in New Guinea. Dr. Kirschner attended NYU under the GI Bill, subsequently receiving his Masters Degree and Doctorate in Education from Columbia University, New York. Preceded in death by his beloved wife, Roselyn, and survived by his children, Mitchell B. Kirschner, Susan M. Shank, and Dr. Joan T. Kirschner, and six grandchildren. His legacy will be the generations of New York City children whose education was enhanced by his timeless efforts. Contributions can be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

THE NEWS Leaders of the two main parties in the fractious coalition government of Pakistan announced that they would begin impeachment proceedings against President Pervez Musharraf. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Musharraf ruled Pakistan for eight years after leading a military coup in 1999, and won a presidential election last year that was widely denounced. But his party was trounced in parliamentary voting in February. One of his two main rivals -- Nawaz Sharif, the prime minister he ousted in 1999 -- has been pushing for impeachment for months. The armed forces, which Mr. Musharraf, a retired general, once headed, are seen as unlikely to intervene to aid him now.

With a dramatic swiftness, many New Yorkers last week flung themselves into total black, an annual ritual that usually takes place later in the month. As one woman said: ''I'm tired of summer colors.'' So early one morning black came back in the form of a backless dress; an antique Asian robe; leggings and pants; a few street-sweeping hems; many more above-knee dresses. What seemed new were the colorful bags and shoes, never worn together. As if to telegraph a trend, blackish birds on a line appeared in Bergdorf Goodman's 58th Street windows, some with tiny red purses in their beaks.

NECESSARY STEPS In January of this year there was a photo in the Independent newspaper of a house about to topple over the cliffs at Skipsea Sands, a third of the way along the coast, and that decided me: I would do the walk. I thought it would be strange enough seeing all these homeowners of the abyss, but stranger still was the notion that if I traveled the whole way within 6 feet of the cliff -- or better still on the foreshore -- I would be taking a walk that no one would ever be able to reproduce, because the very land itself would've disappeared within months. I left the train at Bempton and set off for Flamborough Head along roads, because there were no direct paths marked on the map. As ever under these circumstances I feared for my life: in rural England the walker and the driver are pitted against one another, flesh versus steel; and while pedestrians may be a little self-righteous, it's nothing to compare with what I term ''The Divine Right of Cars.'' Still, the fields were full of ripening wheat, the hedgerows with brambles, there were larks in the sky and soon enough I reached the bird reserve at the end of the promontory, turning southwest past the white-painted lighthouse and along the grassy path beside chalk cliffs.

Rodrigo Corral's working relationship with Chuck Palahniuk began 10 years ago, when he designed Palahniuk's second book, ''Survivor.'' ''I knew 'Fight Club' well and was thrilled to be working on a project on the heels of such a successful book-to-movie,'' Corral said. ''Chuck's writing always has energy and movement, and often reads like a screenplay. It is so filled with dramatic visuals that to illustrate something literally from the stories would undermine the writing and its deeper meaning.'' Corral says he's never literal with his designs, ''because if I were, the covers would look like pulp horror novels.'' The image he devised for Palahniuk's latest novel, ''Snuff,'' covered two aspects of the book: sex and death. ''Real snuff films, as we know, are about death,'' Corral said, ''and there is an attempted-murder mystery in this story, so the girl hanging in the middle is a sign of what could come. (Swallowing a pill is also part of the plot.) As with all of Chuck's books, it's never about just one idea, so the story is not only about sex in the porn industry but about what its characters become. Women in porn become real-life blow-up dolls, and the mouth looks like it belongs to one of them.''

The Cardinals' season-long search for a dependable bullpen has had them chasing windmills with a major-league-high 27 blown saves. But their solution could be soon ready to return from the disabled list. Adam Wainwright began a rehab assignment on Friday, as he works his way back from a sprained middle finger. Wainwright, right, has been a starter for the last season and a half, but General Manager John Mozeliak said using him in relief was still a consideration. The Mariners lost patience with Wladimir Balentien when he was hitting under .200 in June with 35 strikeouts in 107 at-bats. But his raw power and a lower strikeout rate in the minors has him back in the mix.

GARY GRAHAM'S first boutique opens Monday in what was once a chandelier shop on the main floor of ABC Carpet & Home, and fans of his richly textured and romantically battered designs will find the location fitting. ''There's definitely a shared aesthetic,'' said Mr. Graham, who worked in product development at ABC before starting his clothing line in 2001. As the home-furnishing emporium's sole fashion boutique, there was still the matter of fitting in. To that end, Mr. Graham has forgone the trappings of an average clothing shop and constructed a circular space inspired by a Victorian lab, with mannequins that have ball-and-claw table legs and bear animal heads.

MONTGOMERY--Robert M. The Palm Beach Opera Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of Robert M. Montgomery, Jr., who, with his wife Mary, was a catalyst for the development of our company and a champion for the arts and arts education in our community. He was a current member of the Board and served as our Chairman for 25 years, during which time the company grew in to the outstanding artistic organization it is today. In 2005, the Board proclaimed him Chairman Emeritus and called him ''Palm Beach Opera's best friend and mentor.'' His remarkable dedication, generosity, and desire to see the arts accessible to all was instrumental in Palm Beach Opera's instituting programs designed to appeal to the entire family. A gracious host for numerous social events benefiting the opera, Mr. Montgomery made every guest feel at home with his genuine southern charm and kindness. We extend our deepest condolences to our dear friend Mary, to their daughter, Courtnay, and to all the friends and colleagues who share in this great loss. Marc S. Solomon, Chairman; Paul Kozloff, Vice Chairman; Mac Schwebel, President MONTGOMERY--Robert M. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Bob Montgomery, whose wisdom, guidance, and generosity helped build a rich cultural landscape for Palm Beach County. A gracious and hospitable gentleman with a remarkable commitment to excellence, he will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Mary and daughter, Courtnay. Cathy and Marc Solomon, and Family

An article on June 29 about Hunter S. Thompson described incorrectly the context for a quotation by his widow, Anita Thompson, in which she said he was ''surrounded by leeches and hanger-on-ers.'' She was referring to the early '70s, around the time that Mr. Thompson covered Muhammad Ali's boxing match in Zaire; she did not mean at the time of Mr. Thompson's death. And a correction in this space last Sunday misidentified Mr. Ali's opponent in that match. He fought George Foreman, not Joe Frazier.

EQUIPPED with a 16-millimeter camera, the fashion photographer Steven Sebring spent 11 years filming the punk rocker and poet Patti Smith. The result is not just an insightful and inspiring documentary, ''Patti Smith: Dream of Life.'' It is also 109 minutes of exquisite imagery. ''I approached the film the way I do my photography -- always looking for that one extraordinary moment,'' said Mr. Sebring, who, for his efforts, won the documentary cinematography award at this year's Sundance Film Festival.

WILLIAMS--Perry R. The Very Reverend Perry R. Williams died peacefully on Tuesday, July 22, 2008, at his home in Jamaica Plain, Massachusetts. Preceded in death by his wife of 55 years, Anne Ballentine Williams, Perry is survived by his son David B. Williams and daughter-in-law Robin Mahler of Bethesda, Maryland, formerly of Jamaica Plain; his daughter Sarah C. Williams Wilson and son-in-law Joseph D.C. Wilson III of Sewickley, Pennsylvania; his son Jeffrey P. Williams and daughter-in-law Zeva Ellman Williams of Oakland, California; his sister Gwendolyn Spencer and brother-in-law Richard Spencer of Bloomfield, Connecticut; his grandchildren Dylan and Graham Terhune, Emily and Jane Williams, and Stella and Molly Williams; a niece, nephews and numerous grandnieces. Born on June 13, 1924, in Rockville Centre, Long Island, New York, Perry was raised in Hempstead and Garden City, New York. He was a 1941 graduate of the St. Paul's School in Garden City; was a member of the Class of 1945 at Amherst College and earned a Bachelor's Degree in music and english in 1947, having taken two years off from his college education to serve in the Pacific during WWII as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy. Perry went on to earn a Master's in Music from Yale University in 1949 and Master's in Divinity from Virginia Theological Seminary in 1951. During his illuminating career as an Episcopal priest, Perry served as Rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Sharon, Pennsylvania, Associate Rector at Christ Church, Cranbrook in Bloomfiled Hills, Michigan and as Rector at Grace Episcopal Church, Orange, New Jersey. Highlights of his career include serving seven years as Rector of Emmanual Church in Geneva, Switzerland and twenty-one years as the Dean of Trinity Cathedral in Cleveland, Ohio. A memorial service will be held on Monday, August 11 at 11:30am, at St. John's Episcopal Church in Jamaica Plain and will be follow by a reception in the Church Hall. The service will be preceded by private interment at Forest Hills Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Perry's memory may be made to the Great Food Bank of Boston, P.O. Box 55860, Boston, MA 02205-5860; or to the Alzheimer's Associations, 311 Arsenal Street, Watertown, MA 02472.

John Gall, the art director of Vintage Books, began designing covers for Haruki Murakami's novels when Vintage published the paperback version of ''The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle.'' ''I was smitten with the design for the original hardcover'' -- by Chip Kidd, who usually does the author's American hardcover jackets -- ''and was hooked on Murakami,'' Gall said. ''There are recurring elements that appear in Murakami's books that I try to use semi-consistently on the covers,'' he added, ''like holes in the ground, running water, disappearing women, etc. I try to figure out new ways to use them each time. So there are lots of cropped women and circle motifs.'' Though Murakami's novels are set in the present, his characters ''can seem as if they're from another time -- hence the use of vintage Japanese art.'' Gall tries not to be too specific: ''The one for 'Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman' is based on Japanese chewing-gum packaging. No real literal context, except that there is a consistent food element to his books.'' Gall's cover for ''After Dark,'' one of whose characters spends the novel in a deep sleep, is a bit more literal.

Milton Glaser, best known for his ''I New York'' logo, was introduced to Philip Roth by the publisher Peter Mayer 35 years ago in Woodstock, where they all played softball. Roth admired a cover of The Atlantic that Glaser had designed -- an outline of the author's head with hand-drawn letters spelling ''Philip Roth'' in place of his facial features. ''One day he called and asked if I'd do a jacket for him,'' recalled Glaser, who has now designed 10 Roth novels, not counting various British editions. Which should not suggest that the process always goes smoothly. Roth is scrupulous about his covers, and there is always considerable back and forth. ''Much more,'' added Glaser, ''than with every author I've designed for except Nabokov, who sent me a detailed note about what 'Pnin' looked like; I did the cover exactly as he visualized it.'' Glaser rarely uses illustration for Roth's covers. ''The image that may be in someone's mind may exceed the intensity of my image,'' he said. ''Typography is a useful tool for not entering into this dilemma.'' For ''The Plot Against America,'' however, Roth had the notion of using a stamp canceled with a swastika. (''I was just following orders,'' Glaser said.) For ''Exit Ghost,'' Roth first wanted to use a moody photograph of George Plimpton (who figures in the novel) at Elaine's. When the photographer wanted $10,000 for the rights, Roth asked Glaser for a more economical treatment. Recently, Glaser completed yet another type-only jacket for Roth's forthcoming novel, ''Indignation.''

That is the affectionate nickname for the dozen or so older swimmers of Douglas Manor, an exclusive neighborhood in Douglaston, Queens, overlooking Little Neck Bay. As almost everyone knows by now, various major daily newspaper published, on July 10, a photograph of four Iranian missiles streaking heavenward; then Little Green Footballs (significantly, a blog and not a daily newspaper) provided evidence that the photograph had been faked. Later, many of those same papers published a Whitman's sampler of retractions and apologies. For me it raised a series of questions about images.[1] Do they provide illustration of a text or an idea of evidence of some underlying reality or both? And if they are evidence, don't we have to know that the evidence is reliable, that it can be trusted?

Going-privates are fraught with peril for shareholders. A going-private transaction is one in which management or a controlling shareholder takes the company private by squeezing out the minority shareholders. One risk is that management or the controlling shareholder will time the squeeze-out to take advantage of the minority shareholders when the stock is trading at a discounted price.

Last week I took part in a teleconference panel discussion about freelance journalism organized by the Society for American Business Editors and Writers. In the current economy, where increasing numbers of journalists are turning to freelancing both by choice and necessity, this panel was especially relevant. While graduate schools might be focusing on training the next generation of journalists for working in multiple platforms and in a digital environment, what was clear from our panel is that working freelancers also need to develop their entrepreneurial skills.

The Swiss banking giant UBS confirmed Friday that it had agreed to buy back nearly $20 billion in auction-rate securities from investors, a day after Citigroup reached a similar settlement with regulators for $7 billion as part of a wide-ranging investigation into the collapse of the market for the bond-like investments.

The Royal Bank of Scotland Group reported a half-year loss of 802 million pounds ($1.5 billion), its first loss in 40 years, because of 5.9 billion pounds (11.4 billion) in write-downs stemming from the American subprime credit crisis.

Reining in the runaway freight train otherwise known as the credit default swap market is a rising priority for regulators who oversee banks and insurers. It's a good thing, too, The New York Times' Gretchen Morgenson writes, given the secretive nature of the swaps, the losses they are generating at some companies and the size of the market: $62 trillion in default insurance is outstanding, with a fair value of $2 trillion at the end of 2007.
The Swiss firm Richemont, maker of Cartier watches and Piaget jewelry, said it would spin off its stake in British American Tobacco under a revamp prompted by tax changes.

REIT--Ann Kleinman, died in her Manhattan home on Thursday, August 7. Her parents, Celia Roth Kleinman and Clarence Kleinman, and her sister, Lorraine Kleinman Schulberg predeceased her. She is survived by nephew Peter Schulberg of Portland, OR and his son and daughter; niece Clare Schulberg of Los Angeles; cousins; and her many friends and colleagues. Her marriage to author Symour Reit ended in divorce. LORD--William G. II, August 27, 1923 -August 4, 2008. William Galey Lord II, 84, of Waquoit, MA, died at home August 4th. He passed away peacefully, surrounded by his family. Bill Lord was a D-Day paratrooper, an ocean-racing navigator, and a successful business leader, but most of all he was the ultimate family man and fun-loving friend to one and all in his large and extended community. Born in Philadelphia, PA on August 27th, 1923, William G. Lord II was the son of Edwin and Helene Schock Lord. He married the former Joan Malloch in 1947, and they raised their family in Irvington-on-Hudson, NY, retiring to their summer home on Cape Cod in 1996. Bill Lord spent his career in textiles, rising to the position of president of Galey & Lord, a division of Burlington Industries, and subsequently president of Crompton Co. Besides his wife of 61 years, William G. Lord II is survived by a son, Alexander Lord of Mt. Washington, MA, three daughters, Susan Lord of Alexandria, VA, Pamela Lord Camara of High Falls, NY, Meg Lord of Parsonsfield, ME and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Barnabas, Falmouth, MA at 2pm on Saturday, August 30th. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Cape Cod, 765 Attucks Lane, Hyannis, MA 02601.

10 P.M. (13, 49) MUHAMMAD ALI: MADE IN MIAMI In the fall of 1960 Cassius Clay, above, arrived in Miami after earning a gold medal in the Rome Olympics. He trained with Angelo Dundee at the Fifth Street Gym in Miami Beach and made his home in a series of hotels in the Overtown district of Miami, a bustling center of black entertainment and commerce known as Harlem South. During the next few years he adopted the black separatist teachings of the Nation of Islam while accumulating victories in the ring. In February 1964 his transformation was complete when he defeated the heavyweight champion Sonny Liston and two days later said he would be known as Muhammad Ali. This documentary about Ali and black Miami combines rarely seen film with interviews with Mr. Dundee; Ferdie Pacheco, a fight doctor; the Ali biographers Thomas Hauser and David Remnick; and the historian Manning Marable. 7 A.M. REBECCA MARTIN ''The Growing Season'' (Sunnyside) Rebecca Martin has a warm, unguarded voice, an instrument of modesty and forbearance. Her interior style can feel almost too spare for standards, though she has recorded good albums full of them, most recently with the jazz drummer Paul Motian. With her own songs, she manifests a deeper, more easeful authority. She can make the same phrase seem philosophical and conversational, and about as natural as sighing.

You're on the first tee of a member-guest tournament. You're the guest and your friend's buddies are standing around waiting as you warm up. Already, you feel like your golf swing is being silently analyzed for proper technique. You want to do well and the first tee is a symbolic moment. On the practice range a few minutes earlier, you felt smooth and confident, but now the first tee feels a world apart, full of tension and nerves. Worse, you just noticed that the windows of the pro shop and clubhouse dining room face the first tee box.

DAVID SANBORN ''Here and Gone'' (Decca) A few years ago Eric Clapton released ''Me and Mr. Johnson'' (Reprise), a high-gloss love letter to a formative influence, the bluesman Robert Johnson. ''Here and Gone,'' the 23rd solo album by David Sanborn, could have similarly been titled ''Me and Mr. Crawford,'' after the great alto saxophonist Hank Crawford. It's a tribute and a testament, brimming with conviction. It also happens to be a decent soul-jazz record.

An article on Friday about Victor Pinchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian who has become an international mover and shaker, referred incompletely to a lawsuit brought against him by a rival Ukrainian businessman. While the suit, which was settled in 2006, did indeed accuse Mr. Pinchuk of siphoning off $41 million in profits from an iron alloy producer he had purchased, it also included other allegations of wrongful diversion estimated at more than $500 million; the alleged diversions did not total only $41 million.

Welcome to real-time blogging of the women's gymnastics team final competition -- live from The New York Times headquarters in Midtown Manhattan.The United States is going for a gold medal behind the strength of Shawn Johnson, Nastia Liukin and Bridget Sloan. The Americans made the eight-team final with a second-place finish in qualifying. China, still seeking its first gold in this event, will be the Americans' toughest challenger. The Chinese had the top score in qualifying with 248.275 points, while the U.S. finished with 246.800 points.Romania, Australia, France, Brazil and Japan also qualified. Scores from qualifying do not carry over to the final.Joining us with analysis of the team finals, will be the head coach of the University of Georgia women's gymnastics team, Suzanne Yoculan.Yoculan, 2008 national coach of the year, has had a remarkable run of success in 25 years at the university. She has led her team to nine national titles, including the past four -- 2005 through 2008. Her teams have won 16 Southeastern Conference championships and have finished in the top three nationally in 19 of the past 21 seasons. Two members of her 2007-8 squad, Courtney Kupets and Courtney McCool, were United States Olympians in 2004. For more information about her program, visit this linkCheck back with us shortly after each rotation for analysis on what each did right, and what cost them on their scores.

So writes Jing Ulrich, who follows the Chinese equity market out of JP Morgan's Hong Kong office, in her latest note to clients. (For the record: A shares are stocks of Chinese companies listed on the Shanghai exchange; H shares are Chinese stocks traded on the Hong Kong exchange.) Since last year, Ms. Ulrich has been following the steep decline of the Shanghai A shares -- and the many steps the government has taken to stabilize the market. None have worked, and it is highly unlike that these two new proposals -- reforming the stamp duty and establishing a "stabilizing fund" to help prop up the market -- will work either.

Rundy Purdy, 26 and a budding novelist, is the second of 12 children, home-schooled on his family's 14-acre parcel "in the sticks,'' as he puts it, outside Binghamton in upstate New York. That's where Mr. Purdy lived, doing odd jobs to support his writing, until November 9, 2006.

The British man accused by an American prosecutor of "the biggest hack of military computers ever detected," who was covered on The Lede recently, will not be extradited to the United States just yet. The European Court of Human Rights has granted Gary McKinnon a two-week stay so that the full court can examine the case, his lawyers said today. [Guardian]
Wall Street is starting to worry about its golden child.
Before Russia's decision this morning to declare a halt to its military action in Georgia, residents of Tbilisi could be forgiven for thinking that their city was next in line for a ground assault.
YouTube has been . . . unusual to John Edwards.

Dwyane Wade scored 19 points, James dominated the game with his size and strength on both ends, and the U.S. Olympic team wrapped up the easy portion of its schedule with a 97-76 victory Tuesday night. (Aug. 12)
After a disappointing fifth finish at the 2004 Games, the Chinese team was not about to disappoint in 2008.
Last week, the Well blog featured "Six Rules Doctors Need to Know." So what about patients?
The war between two of the nation's most popular frozen yogurt chains is heating up -- on the financing front.

The 50 freestyle is perhaps the most misunderstood of Olympic swimming events.

New York Times: MTV Networks will host its first major awards ceremony dedicated to African musicians in Abuja, Nigeria, on Nov. 22, Variety reported. "The awards ceremony will be broadcast live as a two-hour show and feature performances by African and international stars."
