There's a certain gee-whiz aspect to research hinting that old elephant matriarchs, during severe drought, lead their kin to distant watering holes at locations that were evidently seared into memory from dry times in their youth decades earlier -- even as elephant groups led by younger females stay behind and suffer.

With speculation high that Senator Barack Obama may announce his choice of a running mate next week, possible candidates for the No. 2 slot on either the Republican or Democratic ticket are being eyed closely.

In an article on the Op-Ed page of the Times, Svante E. Cornell says that Russia is the aggressor in its war with Georgia. But in The Washington Post, Mikhail Gorbachev says it's all Georgia's fault. "The roots of this tragedy lie in the decision of Georgia's separatist leaders in 1991 to abolish South Ossetian autonomy," Gorbachev writes. "This turned out to be a time bomb for Georgia's territorial integrity." He later adds:
Shutterfly, one of the first photo sharing sites on the Internet, has survived the dot-com bust and competition from the likes of Kodak and Hewlett-Packard.
Former Olympic gold medalist Bart Conner gives his analysis on the U.S. men winning a surprise bronze medal. (Aug. 12)

Politics | The journalistic conceit behind a much-noted article on the demise of Hillary Clinton's campaign: the instant "campaign obit" is by its nature flawed, reflecting the views of those closest to the press. So, contemporaneous memos and e-mails can show better how things unraveled in real time. [Atlantic]
BEIJING - If Spain is supposed to be the United States men's basketball team's most formidable opposition in these Olympics, the competition isn't looking too imposing.

Ivory Tower | M&A? No, M.B.A.: Many are choosing to sit out the economic slowdown by polishing up their credentials at business school. But a new first-person account of the Harvard Business School experience may give them pause: it's $175,000 to attend a "factory for unhappy people." [Economist]

As Lehman Brothers seeks to raise more capital, the troubled investment bank could reap $7 billion by selling its Neuberger Berman asset-management unit, research analyst Brad Hintz wrote in a research note on Tuesday.

Not all was what it seemed during the spectacular opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics. Beijing organizers confirmed Tuesday that some of the fireworks display featured prerecorded footage. (Aug. 12)
Brian Hunter is back in the news. But this time, it's for the profits the commodity trader made for the hedge fund he advises.
The M&A credit market is still a wreck.

To read a description of the Olympic women's soccer match between the United States and New Zealand on Tuesday in Shenyang, written as it happened, read up from the foot of this post. It was the third and final group-phase game of the tournament for both sides.

BEIJING - When Nike spokespeople said they had invited "a few media" to an availability for the Jamaican sprinter Asafa Powell Tuesday, that idea was quickly dismissed by the wave of television cameras suddenly jockeying for position to hear him.

Apax Partners, the British buyout giant, is pursuing a sale of 10 percent of itself to Australian and Singaporean sovereign wealth funds and a Japanese investor, The Times of London reported citing unnamed sources.

BEIJING -- Not every athlete handles the agony of defeat with the same poise as he or she does the thrill of victory. And the pressure of the Olympic Games can cause even the strongest individuals to crumble.
Associated Press photo editor Jim Collins shares his favorite Olympic photos of the day. (Aug. 12)

Wall Street's losses are fast becoming India's gain. After outsourcing much of their back-office work to India, banks are now exporting data-intensive jobs from higher up the food chain to cities that cost less than New York, London and Hong Kong, either at their own offices or to third parties.

Despite a general slowdown in deal-making, many aerospace and defense bankers are still busy, Investment Dealers' Digest reports. Large companies in the industry, such as Lockheed Martin and Boeing, are helping to drive the activity as they acquire smaller competitors.

Moving boxes have become a common sight at Wall Street firms, where tens of thousands of bankers and traders have been laid off as the credit squeeze drags on. But a few of the people packing up and saying goodbye are holding passports rather than pink slips. And some are being told to move abroad - or else.

VendAsta Technologies, a software consulting and development company, has raised $3 million from from Victoria Park Capital to launch MyFrontSteps, a social software application focused on home improvement.

UBS will separate its business into three autonomous units after it identified weaknesses in its integrated one-bank strategy, the Swiss bank said Tuesday, after posting a worse-than-expected second quarter loss of around $330 million.

At a recent conference, Frank P. Quattrone opined that former New York attorney general Eliot Spitzer's landmark settlement in 2002, which forced the separation of investment banking from research, had been disastrous for the quality of research.

The Justice Department has challenged an agreement that Countrywide Financial reached in a bankruptcy court in Pittsburgh, saying it would make it harder to investigate and sue the mortgage lending giant.

Carl C. Icahn and other shareholders in Enzon Pharmaceuticals got their wish Monday, when the company said it would try to sell all or part of its commercial business, which includes four marketed drugs, royalties from third-party products and a manufacturing plant in Indiana.

Belgian-Dutch financial group Fortis said on Monday that together with Royal Bank of Scotland and Spain's Santander, it had sold a number of ABN Amro private equity assets to a consortium led by Goldman Sachs.
John C. Malone does seem to have a love of bartering.

With plans by UBS, Citigroup and Merrill Lynch to buy back nearly $40 billion in auction-rate securities, some closed-end fund firms that spent a pretty penny to reimburse their own investors may now be wishing they had waited a bit longer, The Wall Street Journal says.
Carl C. Icahn reported on Monday that he owns a 6.03 percent stake in the common stock of biotechnology company Biogen Idec, which the activist investor has been pressuring to put itself for up sale.
Another potential initial public offering in the technology sector withered Monday when chip maker Allegro Microsystems withdrew its planned I.P.O., citing "current market conditions."

Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Japan's largest bank, said it would bid $3 billion to buy the rest of UnionBanCal, a Californian bank it already owns two-thirds of, as it seeks growth beyond Japanese shores.

JPMorgan Chase incurred losses of about $1.5 billion for the quarter to date, as it continued to be hurt by wider credit spreads, lower levels of liquidity, as well as the disruption in the credit and mortgage markets, the bank said in a regulatory filing.

Wachovia increased its previously reported second-quarter loss to $9.11 billion to cover costs to settle a probe of auction-rate securities sales, and said it will cut more jobs as the housing market deteriorates.
Associated Press reporter Warren Levinson takes a tour of Beijing on his bike and learns that the city's traffic laws are a little flexible. (Aug. 12)
Hewlett-Packard said on Monday it plans to buy Colubris Networks, furthering the consolidation of wireless networking companies.
JDA Software Group on Monday agreed to buy i2 Technologies, a manufacturing supply-chain software maker, for $346 million.
The long-awaited authorized biography of billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, the first written with his cooperation, is scheduled for release on September 29, the publisher said on Monday.
InterWest Partners has raised $650 million 10th for its latest fund, the venture capital firm announced Monday.
Vietnam has reportedly tapped Credit Suisse to advise on the initial public offering of state-owned MobiFone, one of the country's top three largest mobile phone network providers.
Advanced Micro Devices is planning to release on Tuesday a high-speed computer graphics card that it says offers proof that its troubled merger with ATI Technologies is finally paying off.

Pilots at Delta Air Lines and the Northwest Airlines have approved a collective bargaining agreement. Ratification has been an element of Delta's efforts to achieve a smooth integration when it acquires Northwest later this year.

A "mysterious Russian billionaire" has paid a whopping €500 million (about $743 million) for an estate on the French Riviera, easily a record amount for a single residential property, the London Times reports.
Images of a three-bedroom chalet in the Chamonix Valley at the foot of Mont Blanc.

When William M.V. Kingsland, a threadbare eccentric and an amateur genealogist of the Upper East Side, died in 2006, officials found an apartment full of stolen artworks, including works by Picasso, Copley, Fairfield Porter and Odilon Redon. The F.B.I. continues to search for the owners.
BEIJING -- Back in 1992, Charles Barkley gave this bold and accurate summation of the Dream Team's first Olympic game."I don't know anything about Angola, but Angola's in trouble," he said.
The Odin, once a rusted hull docked in Berlin’s Tiergarten Park, has been transformed into a family home.

After a disappointing fifth finish at the 2004 Games, the Chinese team was not about to disappoint in 2008.

Few American Olympians are as big a character as the judoka Ronda Rousey. Her Olympic story is among the most compelling of the Games. The 21-year-old has overcome the suicide of her father, a two-year battle with bulimia and a severe speech impediment, and spent two years run away from home. A profile of her will run in Tuesday's editions of The Times.

This was the Yankees' lineup on opening day: Johnny Damon, Derek Jeter, Bobby Abreu, Alex Rodriguez, Jason Giambi, Robinson Cano, Jorge Posada, Hideki Matsui, Melky Cabrera. They never used that lineup again, largely because of injuries. There have been 92 versions since.
Mr. Solotaroff started The New American Review in 1967 as a highly unusual showcase for a rising generation of writers.

An article on Wednesday about the effect of high gasoline prices on charities and their volunteers misidentified the organization that runs Plainview-Old Bethpage Cares, a program on Long Island that assists the elderly. It is the Mid-Island Y Jewish Community Center, not the Jewish Association Services for the Aged.

An article on Sunday about the management style of Senator John McCain misstated the background of one of Mr. McCain’s senior advisers, Steve Schmidt, in some editions. Mr. Schmidt is not a former marine, and has never served in the military.

An article on Sunday about Senator John McCain’s campaign management style described his role as a Navy pilot in Vietnam incorrectly. He flew bombing missions as an attack aircraft pilot, but he was not a “fighter pilot.” (The error has appeared in numerous other Times articles the past dozen years, most recently on April 9 and on Dec. 15, 2007.).

An article on Monday about Congressional attention to privacy issues on the Internet misstated a word in a quotation from Andrea M. Matwyshyn, a Wharton School assistant professor who commented on the breadth of the problem. She said the legal questions were intertwined not only with privacy and contract law, but also with “computer-intrusion law,” not “consumer-intrusion law.”.

An article on Aug. 1 about a House vote to table a resolution to censure Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York Democrat, for bringing “discredit” to the House by occupying four rent-stabilized apartments in a Harlem building misidentified his alma mater. He is a graduate of New York University and of St. John’s University School of Law — not of the City College of New York, where questions have been raised about his support for a proposed academic center that will house his papers.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the initial public offering of Rackspace Hosting paraphrased incorrectly from remarks by Mark Heesen, president of the National Venture Capital Association, on the reasoning behind some technology companies’ decisions to register for public offerings. He said that many had registered to attract the attention of potential acquirers; he did not say that he was worried that many of those companies might not attract that attention.

An article on Friday about a delay in meeting Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s goal to reduce the number of homeless people in New York City by two-thirds over five years referred incorrectly to services that the state had provided $1.5 million for until this year. They are “after care” services, like employment assistance, job training and financial counseling — not “after school” programs.

An article on Friday about an agreement by Citigroup to buy back more than $7 billion in troubled securities and pay a $100 million fine to settle claims that it misled clients about the dangers of investments misstated the position of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which participated in the settlement talks, on penalizing the bank. The S.E.C. deferred a decision on any penalty; it did not elect not to exact one.

An article on Monday about China’s solid performance in the first qualifying session in women’s gymnastics at the Olympics described a patch on the team’s uniforms incorrectly. It is the emblem of China, not “the official Chinese Communist Party patch.”.
Mr. Furth was a playwright who collaborated on the Tony Award-winning musical “Company” and a character actor whose distinct profile enlivened dozens of popular television series.
An aide to an indicted state senator pleaded guilty and admitted that he conspired with the official to destroy e-mail messages and other evidence during an F.B.I. extortion probe.
The Mexican national team, under the new coach Sven-Goran Eriksson, will play Chile in a exhibition game on Sept. 24 at the Los Angeles Coliseum.
A judge upheld a gun ban at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, dealing a blow to gun rights groups.

U.C.L.A. quarterback Ben Olson will have surgery on his broken right foot, an injury that is expected to keep him out for at least two months. Kevin Craft, a transfer from Mount San Antonio College, and the redshirt freshman Chris Forcier are expected to compete for the Bruins’ starting job.
Natalie Coughlin and Aaron Peirsol successfully defended their titles by swimming the best times of their lives.

With the Los Angeles Galaxy in a seven-game winless streak, the team underwent a shakeup. Galaxy Coach Ruud Gullit resigned for personal reasons, and the team fired Alexi Lalas as the president and general manager, the club said on its Web site. The assistant Cobi Jones will take over as the interim coach.
A toddler whose remains were found inside a suitcase in Philadelphia this spring was starved to death by members of a religious cult, including his mother.

Three Syracuse men’s basketball players, who had been accused of sexually assaulting a female student, appeared before a university judicial hearing board on Monday that will rule on whether the players violated the university’s code of conduct. An Onondaga County grand jury decided two weeks ago not to criminally charge the players Jonny Flynn, Antonio Jardine and Rick Jackson. The Syracuse spokesman Kevin Morrow said university officials would announce their decision within five business days.
A suspect was shot to death and a sheriff’s deputy was injured after a standoff near an elementary school in Lula, the authorities said.
Denver police officers blocked off streets around a downtown hotel where they were investigating a possible cyanide death.

Unseeded Camille Pin of France upset seventh-seeded Ekaterina Makarova of Russia, 6-2, 6-0, in the first round of the Cincinnati Open. Pin, who is ranked 78th on the WTA Tour, said she focused on keeping the 57th-ranked Makarova off-balance by changing tempo. Fourth-seeded Katarina Srebotnik of Slovenia defeated Amanda Fink of the United States, 6-3, 6-3.
A Utah man accused of failing to report that his cousin produced and possessed the deadly poison ricin pleaded guilty to the felony charge.

A second defendant has pleaded guilty in the beating death of the former Villanova basketball star Howard Porter, the most valuable player of the 1971 N.C.A.A. tournament. Rashad Raleigh, 29, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in an agreement that called for him to be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. Another defendant, Tonya E. Johnson, earlier pleaded guilty to aiding and abetting aggravated robbery. A third, Fredquinzo King, also is charged with first-degree murder.
The Bush administration is proposing to let federal agencies decide for themselves whether construction projects might harm endangered animals and plants, according to a draft of rule changes.

A man charged with kidnapping his daughter in Boston is a German who lived in the guesthouse of a Los Angeles-area couple who disappeared in 1985.
At the Metropolitan Opera House, normally genteel opera lovers spent up to five hours in line sputtering over new policies on ticket exchanges.
The Yankees were humbled by the Minnesota Twins’ Glen Perkins and fell quietly, for their sixth loss in eight games on this trip.
A Bush administration plan to auction landing slots at New York airports has picked up a prominent supporter in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

A listing of credits on April 28, 1960, with a theater review of “West Side Story” on its return to the Winter Garden theater, misstated the surname of the actor who played Action. He is George Liker, not Johnson. (Mr. Liker, who hopes to audition for a role in a Broadway revival of the show planned for February, brought the error to The Times’s attention last month. ).
In the year since it opened, Dutchtown Ace Hardware has added a spark in Palatine Bridge, a farm and factory community in an all-too-quiet stretch of the Mohawk Valley.
Scrambling to contain fallout from a recall that threatens its reputation for quality, Whole Foods said it would tighten oversight of suppliers to keep unsafe products out of its stores.
A last-ditch campaign to save a tradition of school sports in Mount Vernon, N.Y., has raised $225,451, including $100,000 from the actor Denzel Washington, a former resident.
The contractor, whose provision of private security in Iraq has come under scrutiny, may have improperly obtained $100 million in contracts meant for small businesses.

Five years after the first Segways arrived in New York City, their use remains illegal.

Since 2002, when research was formally separated from investment banking, the quality of research on Wall Street has deteriorated, and many top analysts have left the business.
Mauritania’s prime minister, held since a military coup on Wednesday, was freed Monday and vowed that his countrymen would not accept the coup.
A second day of talks between President Robert Mugabe and the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai ended inconclusively.

As he prepares for his start at the against the Minnesota Twins on Tuesday, Mike Mussina is 15-7 with a 3.27 earned run average.
An Iranian vice president said in rare comments that Iran was a friend of Israeli people, newspapers reported on Monday.
A bail hearing for a Pakistani neuroscientist, Aafia Siddiqui, who is accused of trying to kill American soldiers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan, was postponed Monday.
Two Yemeni police officers were killed and several others were wounded Monday in a gun battle with suspected fighters from Al Qaeda.
The country’s chief prosecutor, known as a corruption fighter, was removed from office on Monday.
Michael Phelps dominated the 200-meter freestyle, grabbing his third gold medal and his third world record.
Three police officers were injured during rioting in Montreal that erupted late Sunday in response to the killing of an 18-year-old by the police the day before.

Gov. David A. Paterson presented a plan to cut New York’s spending on Medicaid assistance, higher education and pork-barrel projects.

Tight end A. J. Schable was back on the field after sustaining an injury when he and an offensive lineman slammed into each other on a kickoff return.

KLEIMAN--Michael Joel, a man of warmth, love and humor. He dedicated his life to children others institutionalized and animals others rejected. Playful and kind, compulsive collector and punster, demon scrabbler, he will be missed by colleagues, friends and family. Predeceased by his father Murray and sister Barbara, survived by mother Bella, brother Mark, sister-inlaw Isabel and niece Molly. Services Wednesday, August 13, 10am at Riverside Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon.

MANTELL--Pauline. Resident of Miami Beach, Florida since 1972, died at the age of 100. Prior to 1972, longtime resident of Brooklyn and Manhattan, New York where she was a social studies teacher in the NY Public School system at Tilden and Sarah Hale High Schools. She is survived by the family of her deceased sister, Rose Cohen, niece, Jo Ann White (Stephen), grandniece, Robyn Hickman (Sean), and great-grandnephew, Dylan Hickman. She was predeceased by husband, Herman Mantell, former President of the New York Jewish Teachers Association, Dean of Clinton High School, Jewish Civil Service, Deputy Controller to Abe Beame, former Mayor of New York City, Director of Excise Tax Board of New York. Also predeceased by her brothers, Nat Schwartz and Max Schwartz. Services will be held at the Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, New York, at 10:30am on Wednesday, August 13, 2008.

MORGAN--Edward Aikman, III, retired member of the New York Stock Exchange, age 77, of Port Washington, on August 8, 2008. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Edward IV and Katherine. Adored grandfather of Christine. Dear uncle of Bud and brother-in-law of Sally. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington, Wednesday 2-4 and 79pm. Religious service Thursday 10am at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

KLEMMER--Ray. The Board of Trustees and staff of Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City mourn the death of our past board president and longtime trustee. Ray's tireless work was responsible for greatly growing our mentoring services to the city's neediest youth. Our deepest sympathy to the Klemmer family. Katherine C. Linder, President Michael A. Corriero, Executive Director

MICALONE--Adeline (nee Costanzo) of Wilton, CT and West Chester, PA, on August 9, 2008 at the age of 97. She was the beloved and devoted wife of the late Dominic Micalone. She was an excellent cook in the Italian tradition and loved to take care of her family in all respects. She had a generous heart, loved everyone, and everyone loved her. She was always cheerful, joyful, wise, quick-witted, charming, intelligent, loyal, loving, religious, determined, and selfless to a fault. She loved current events, going to the opera, going to church, singing hymns, and reciting a daily Rosary. She was beautiful inside and out. A great light has truly been extinguished, and she will be missed more than words can express. She is survived by her loving daughter, Rosalie Turi, her beloved and devoted son-in-law, Joseph Turi, her adoring grandson, Joseph Turi, a baritone in The Metropolitan Opera Chorus, of whom she was most proud and who was the source of her greatest joy, and his lovely and loving wife, Ellen Turi, her sister, Marie Ritto, her faithful Yorkie, Marcello, and many nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her twin sons, Louis and Anthony, who died at birth, as well as her mother, Emilia, her father Pasquale Costanzo, five sisters, Margaret Costanzo, Emma Saracco, Elvira Crivelli, Edith Morelli, Margaret Narcisi, and three brothers, Peter Costanzo, Albert Costanzo, and Pasquale (Pat) Costanzo, Jr., and well as her niece, Marie Scogna and grandnephews, Joseph and Peter Scogna. Relatives and friends are invited to Funeral Saturday, August 16th at 9:30am at The Donohue Funeral Home, 1627 West Chester Pike, Westtown-West Chester 610-431-9000 donohuefuneralhome.com and to Funeral Mass at 11am Church of S.S. Peter & Paul, Boot Road, East Goshen, PA. Entombent S.S. Peter & Paul Garden Mausoleum, Springfield, PA. Friends may call Friday evening from 7-9pm at the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her name to: St. Jude Children's Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105.

KORFF--Marcella Heron Mittendorf, born in Pittsburgh, PA, November 18, 1920, passed away peacefully in New York City on August 9. Mother of four children: Mitten Wainwright, George Mittendorf, Anne Mittendorf Ely and Bill Mittendorf. She is also survived by seven grandchildren, five greatgrandchildren, a sister, Emily Bour and a brother, Dawson Heron. Funeral service on Wednesday, August 13 at 11am at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the ASPCA 424 East 92nd Street.

Matwyshyn, a Wharton School assistant professor who commented on the breadth of the problem. She said the legal questions were intertwined not only with privacy and contract law, but also with ''computer-intrusion law,'' not ''consumer-intrusion law.''

CLEMENTS--Carol Stride, of Hamburg Road, died Thursday, July 10, 2008 at her residence. Mrs. Clements was born in Jamestown, NY, the daughter of Carl Herrmann and Violet Barlow Stride. She graduated from Finch College and met her husband, Guy Morrison Clements while living at the Barbison Hotel in NYC. She was employed as a Fashion Coordinator with Saks 5th Avenue in New York City and was a partner in a NYC photographic studio. Gifts in lieu of flowers to Lyme Ambulance Assoc, Inc., 213 Hamburg Road, Lyme, CT 06371 or the New London Maritime Society, 150 Banks Street, New London, CT 06320. PARNES--Leon, died peacefully in his sleep at age 88 on August 10. Husband for 67 years to Susan, father of Robert (Gwenn), Marvin (Jane) and Joey (Ellen). An article on Monday about China's solid performance in the first qualifying session in women's gymnastics at the Olympics described a patch on the team's uniforms incorrectly. It is the emblem of China, not ''the official Chinese Communist Party patch.''

SANDS--Edith, 81 of Boca Raton FL, formerly of Bethpage NY passed away August 9, 2008. Predeceased by her beloved husband Dr. Arnold E. Sands. Loving mother of Dr. Deborah (Richard) Lubell, Dr. Steven (Lisa) Sands and Jonathan (Deborah Seife) Sands. Loving grandmother of Jennifer, Heather, Dana and Jordan. Services at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL. Donations may be made in her memory to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL, or the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.

As the Senate debate on the use of force against Iraq neared its climax in October 2002, Senator John McCain turned on the floor to Senator Evan Bayh to ask what had led him to take such ''a visible, as well as important'' role in seeking Congressional consent for military action. Mr. Bayh, a cautious Indiana Democrat, acknowledged it had not been an easy decision.

More than a dozen groups called for a boycott of the film ''Tropic Thunder,'' citing what they described as its disregard for people with intellectual disabilities. Paramount and its DreamWorks unit showed the film to advocates for people with disabilities, many of whom had expressed outrage at marketing materials showing Ben Stiller, its star and director, playing a weak-minded character named Simple Jack. DreamWorks executives and Mr. Stiller say the film, a movie-industry spoof, aimed its humor at actors who would do almost anything to get ahead. DreamWorks amended some materials but declined to change the film.

WHITMORE--Priscilla Norman ''Penny''. Penny Whitmore, 70, of Greenwich died Saturday, August 9th at her home in Greenwich surrounded by family after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by a daughter and two sons and their spouses: Elizabeth (Laurie) Whitmore Lippincott and Kevin F. of Dallas, TX, George Norman Whitmore and Erin C. of Hingham, MA, Stephen Bradford Whitmore and Sasha Loffredo of San Antonio, TX, a brother, Bradford Norman III of Bethesda, MD and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Friday at 11am at First Presbyterian Church, 1 West Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT.

An article on Friday about a delay in meeting Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's goal to reduce the number of homeless people in New York City by two-thirds over five years referred incorrectly to services that the state had provided $1.5 million for until this year. They are ''after care'' services, like employment assistance, job training and financial counseling -- not ''after school'' programs.

WEINER--Estelle. The secret dream of every parent and grandparent is to be as loved and respected as you were. Susan and Arnold and the Blair Family WEINER--Estelle Merians, of Rahway, NJ died peacefully in her home August 10, 2008. Predeceased by her husband, Dr. Morris Weiner, beloved mother of Jeffrey (Ivy) Weiner, Barbara (David) Stoller, and Jody (Marty) Schultz. Adored by eight grandchildren. Service today 11:30am in Menorah Chapels Union, NJ.

Led by a former Bush fund-raiser and a former senator who left the Republican Party, a group of current and former Republicans disenchanted with Senator John McCain are starting an effort called Republicans for Obama. Rita Hauser, a New York philanthropist who raised money for President Bush and his father, is helping to organize the push to draw Republicans away from Mr. McCain, the party's presumed nominee for president, and toward Senator Barack Obama, his Democratic rival. She will serve as a spokeswoman for the group, alongside former Senator Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, below, who was one of the most moderate Republicans in the Senate and became an independent after he lost his seat in 2006.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the initial public offering of Rackspace Hosting paraphrased incorrectly from remarks by Mark Heesen, president of the National Venture Capital Association, on the reasoning behind some technology companies' decisions to register for public offerings. He said that many had registered to attract the attention of potential acquirers; he did not say that he was worried that many of those companies might not attract that attention.

BARTELME--Elizabeth, a respected book editor, author and professor, died peacefully August 10, 2008 in Riverdale, NY. She was 87. Born in Minnesota, Betty was a graduate of the College of St. Catherine, St. Paul, MN, her trajectory in the publishing industry began at the Frick Museum followed by a career in the Catholic Books Departments of Pantheon, Macmillan and Doubleday. She was a professor at Hofstra University for many years and a contributor to Common Wealth Magazine. Her friends will remember her liturgical zeal and advocacy of Dorothy Day and The Catholic Worker. She was predeceased by her brother Joe and is survived by her brother Kenwood. She was a devoted friend of her sistersin-law Margaret and Emmarie and the beloved aunt of Tony, Peter, Nicole, Kevin, Scott and Jane. A memorial mass is being planned. Contributions can be made to the Bartelme Media Scholarship Fund at The College of St. Catherine, St. Paul, MN 55105.

When it comes to big-name entertainment and partying, it looks as though the Democratic National Convention in Denver later this month might have an edge over the Republican gathering in St. Paul in early September. Headlining the festivities during the Democratic convention will be the Black Eyed Peas (including the singer Fergie, left), Kanye West, Jennifer Lopez, Willie Nelson, Melissa Etheridge and Jerry Jeff Walker. A ''crib sheet'' showing a variety of events runs some 16 pages.

REIT--Ann Kleinman, died in her Manhattan home on Thursday, August 7. Her parents, Celia Roth Kleinman and Clarence Kleinman, and her sister, Lorraine Kleinman Schulberg predeceased her. She is survived by nephew Peter Schulberg of Portland, OR and his son and daughter; niece Clare Schulberg of Los Angeles; cousins; and her many friends and colleagues. Her marriage to author Symour Reit ended in divorce. Until her retirement several years ago, Ann was an executive editor and author at Scholastic and continued to work on projects with several of her long-time authors until her health failed earlier this year. Visiting Tuesday 5-9pm, service Wednesday 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Friends and colleagues are invited to join Ann's family from 5-9pm that evening at her home, 522 West End Avenue, to celebrate her life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to one of the NYC organizations providing food to the homeless.

An article on Wednesday about the effect of high gasoline prices on charities and their volunteers misidentified the organization that runs Plainview-Old Bethpage Cares, a program on Long Island that assists the elderly. It is the Mid-Island Y Jewish Community Center, not the Jewish Association Services for the Aged.

HOROWITZ--Louis, on August 9th, 2008. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude. Loving brother or Dr. William Horowitz and brother-in-law of Marylin. Dear uncle of Ruth Sternberg, Sandra Kramer and Susan HorowitzGersh. Also survived by four great-nieces and one greatnephew. WWII veteran. Services Thursday, 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

An article on Aug. 1 about a House vote to table a resolution to censure Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York Democrat, for bringing ''discredit'' to the House by occupying four rent-stabilized apartments in a Harlem building misidentified his alma mater. He is a graduate of New York University and of St. John's University School of Law -- not of the City College of New York, where questions have been raised about his support for a proposed academic center that will house his papers.

OLTROGGE--Margaret, on August 10, 2008. Loving mother of Caitlin and Sam. Cherished grandmother of Connor. Loved by her family, many friends and fellow actors for her energy, passion and lively spirit. Once met, never forgotten. Now gone, forever remembered. Services to be determined at a later date. Contributions in her name may be made to the American Heart Association.

An article on Sunday about the management style of Senator John McCain misstated the background of one of Mr. McCain's senior advisers, Steve Schmidt, in some editions. Mr. Schmidt is not a former marine, and has never served in the military.

An article on Sunday about Senator John McCain's campaign management style described his role as a Navy pilot in Vietnam incorrectly. He flew bombing missions as an attack aircraft pilot, but he was not a ''fighter pilot.'' (The error has appeared in numerous other Times articles the past dozen years, most recently on April 9 and on Dec. 15, 2007.)

A 32-year-old woman was killed in Queens on Monday night by the father of her two young children, the police said. They said that the children may have witnessed the killing. The police have arrested Pedro Ayala, 21, for killing Veronica Rivera, who was visiting Mr. Ayala at his home in Fresh Meadows with their 9-year-old daughter and 6-month-old son.

From watching polls in the presidential race this summer, it would appear that for all the campaign rallies, television advertisements and various attacks mounted by Senators John McCain and Barack Obama, not much has really changed. Mr. Obama continues to lead Mr. McCain by a few percentage points nationally, according to most recent polls. It appears that many Americans are not yet ready to make up their minds -- no surprise there -- or that after the extended primary seasons, they have taken a break and are not paying much attention to what the candidates are doing.

9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) CHINA PREP ''Wide Angle'' reports on the shaping of the next generation of Chinese leaders (above, a middle-school scene) as it follows four students through their final year at an elite high school where 1,800 teenagers compete for 59 spots in the country's top two universities. A year-end exam will determine their fate; those who score poorly will be forced to take low-paying jobs or go to trade schools. The students, who are busy with schoolwork from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., Monday through Saturday, are Mei Jiachin, a genius mathematician from a farming family; Zhang Lie, who wants to follow in his father's footsteps by studying law and joining the Communist Party; Chen Zhibo, a misfit science student who aspires to become the Bill Gates of China; and Gao Mengjia, a nerd -- his description -- with visions of becoming a hedge-fund manager. A rich one. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THE SECRET LIFE OF THE AMERICAN TEENAGER Amy (Shailene Woodley) tries to figure out where to live. Ricky (Daren Kagasoff) struggles to take responsibility for what he's done.
The funeral procession for Sgt. Ryan P. Baumann of the Army was Monday in Leonardtown, Md. Sergeant Baumann, 24, was killed in a bombing in Afghanistan.

FRENZEN--Irja Siltanen Karr, 77, died July 24th. She was born in New York City to Antti and Elsa Siltanen. Her father was killed in 1941 during the war between Finland and the USSR. She graduated from Hunter College High School in 1949; UCONN., BA, 1953; NYU MPA 1959. She proudly became an RN at age 60. She was a founding member of the Finlandia Foundation DC Chapter in 1959 and was president 1978-1981. In 1982, she was awarded Knight First Class of the Order of the Lion by the President of Finland. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Donald of Arlington, VA, her son Niels Frenzen of Los Angeles, her daughter Kirsti Noring of Arlington, VA and two grandchildren, Alex and Elina Noring. Memorial donations may be made to the Finlandia Foundation Scholarship Fund, payable to FFNCC Special Fund, c/o M. Makarainen 2500 Q Street NW, #

An article on Friday about an agreement by Citigroup to buy back more than $7 billion in troubled securities and pay a $100 million fine to settle claims that it misled clients about the dangers of investments misstated the position of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which participated in the settlement talks, on penalizing the bank. The S.E.C. deferred a decision on any penalty; it did not elect not to exact one.

My Thursday column calls on China to respond to the Dalai Lama's olive branch and push for negotiations to achieve a deal on Tibet's future. There is some hope, particularly given the interest on each side in a visit by the Dalai Lama to China to honor the victims of the Sichuan earthquake in May.

A few weeks ago Greg Roth, a colleague of mine at The Times, spoke of someone as having a "mirror career" to his. He and this other person had similar educational backgrounds, had worked for some of the same companies, and had even worked overseas in the same country. Though I'd never heard it before, I instantly knew what he meant and realized that I had been collecting a few "mirrors" in my own professional circle. I also started thinking about why it is smart to stay in touch with people whose careers mirror elements of yours.

I am wondering how the problems in the mortgage industry will impact the self-employed. I am self-employed and I was preapproved for a mortgage last year but decided to wait until I had 20 percent for the down payment. I would be getting a stated income mortgage. In other words, I would not have to provide proof of my income. I have a credit score of over 800, but I'm concerned that I may be denied a mortgage because of all the problems lenders are having.

I have read a lot about the advantage of making an extra payment to reduce the principal on a long-term mortgage. But when I make the extra payment, do I submit only the principal amount or do I submit an extra full monthly payment - that is, do I include the tax escrow payment as well?

Many readers commenting on this discussion have referred to Moscow's claims that Georgian troops were responsible for the deaths of some 2,000 people in separatist South Ossetia before Russian troops intervened. Human rights investigators have begun to look into these reports. Today, Anna Neistat of Human Rights Watch reported from South Ossetia that the team has found no evidence so far to substantiate the Kremlin's claims of widespread atrocities. The group has been able to confirm fewer than 100 deaths. Human Rights Watch did report that researchers witnessed "terrifying scenes of destruction" in four deserted ethnic Georgian villages, and said that the villages had been looted and burned by South Ossetian militias.

After President Bush said today that he would begin a humanitarian aid mission to Georgia and send Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to try to resolve the crisis in the Caucasus, Georgia's president, Mikheil Saakashvili quickly followed up by saying the U.S. was going to have a military presence at his country's ports. The Pentagon was equally quick to disavow that claim. Lincoln A. Mitchell, a professor at the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University and a specialist on Georgia, discusses the background of the strains and misunderstandings in the close U.S.-Georgia relationship. Professor Mitchell last visited the country in June and is the author of the forthcoming book, "Uncertain Democracy: U.S. Foreign Policy and Georgia's Rose Revolution."

The fascinating obituary of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn that ran in The Times last week describes a life of such extraordinary courage and commitment as to put the rest of us to shame. If anyone had earned the right to castigate Americans for decadence, it was surely Solzhenitsyn. Yet one comment in the obit seemed to me to strike a false, or at least a questionable, note. David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, is quoted as saying, "In terms of the effect he has had on history, Solzhenitsyn is the dominant writer of the 20th century. Who else compares? Orwell? Koestler?"

[UPDATE, 8/14: The Columbia Journalism Review has weighed in on the Rosenbaum critique of climate reporting (the Review was his main focus.] Boy, did Ron Rosenbaum ever do a selective reading of Dot Earth last week when he wrote a column for Slate on journalists' responsibility to cover dissent on global warming (and other issues). He lauded me for having some skeptical Web sites on the blogroll here, as evidence that at least one mainstream reporter paid attention to the full range of voices on the causes and consequences of climate change. But I was kind of dismayed that he didn't explore the posts, articles, and book chapters I've written on ways to keep climate and environmental coverage accurate and fair -- and also useful to society.

Two more Florida players will miss the season after tearing their anterior cruciate ligaments. Linebacker Brendan Beal, a freshman, was injured Monday; offensive lineman Jim Barrie, a sophomore, on Saturday. Tight end Cornelius Ingram, a senior, was injured last week. Dorian Munroe, a redshirt junior and a projected starter at safety, and John Curtis, a senior safety, were hurt in July.

Scott Gordon, who most recently was the coach of the Providence Bruins in the American Hockey League, was named Tuesday as the Islanders’ new head coach. Gordon, the A.H.L. coach of the year in 2008, agreed to a multiyear contract. Gordon, 45, was selected over two coaches who have previous N.H.L. experience, Bob Hartley and Paul Maurice. Gordon succeeds Ted Nolan, who was fired July 14 because of philosophical differences with Garth Snow, the general manager. Gordon led Providence to a 55-18-3 record last season, the best in the league. He was its head coach for five seasons. He played in 23 N.H.L. games as a goaltender for the Quebec Nordiques.

Joey Gilbert agreed to pay a $10,000 fine for a positive steroid test as part of a settlement with the Nevada Athletic Commission that will allow him to return to the ring as soon as Sept. 22. Gilbert agreed Tuesday to the fine and a one-year suspension retroactive to his last fight nearly a year ago. Gilbert (16-1), a middleweight, gained attention on the NBC reality series “The Contender” in 2005.

Tiger Woods said he had begun riding a stationary bike, could not move fast enough to catch his 13-month-old daughter and would not start swinging his golf clubs until next year. RESSLER--David Blair, passed away August 10 after a short illness. He was born November 28, 1918 in St. Louis, graduated Magna Cum Laude from both the Pingry School in Elizabeth, NJ and Yale University ('41), where he was also a member of Phi Beta Kappa and managed the Yale crew. He married Elizabeth Stockton Kirkby on September 12, 1941, followed by two years on the destroyer USS Buchanan in the Pacific. He was a civic leader in Quogue, NY for the past thirty years, serving in many government offices. He is survived by three sons: David Blair Jr., H. Kirkby and Stewart and by six grandchildren: Peter, Blake, Chelsea, Christopher, Hayden and Julia. He was predeceased by his wife and a fourth son Richard. A memorial service will be held at the Presbyterian Church in Quogue at 11:00am on August 15.

9 P.M. (Biography) ANIMAL HOUSE: THE INSIDE STORY Toga! Toga! Toga! In this celebration of the 30th anniversary of ''Animal House,'' Harold Ramis, John Landis, Peter Riegert, Karen Allen and Kevin Bacon reminisce about the movie, which celebrated youthful rebellion, fraternities run amok and food fights. (Above, a scene from the film with, from left, James Daughton, Mary Louise Weller, Tim Matheson and John Belushi.) This two-hour program also travels to Dartmouth College with Chris Miller, one of the screenwriters, to revisit the sites that inspired the story, and to the University of Oregon, the only campus where the film was allowed to shoot. 8 P.M. BARTELME--Elizabeth, a respected book editor, author and professor, died peacefully August 10, 2008 in Riverdale, NY. She was 87. Born in Wisconsin, Betty was a graduate of the College of St. Catherine, St. Paul, MN, her trajectory in the publishing industry began at the Frick Museum followed by a career in the Catholic Books Departments of Pantheon, Macmillan and Doubleday. She was a professor at Hofstra University for many years and a contributor to Commonweal Magazine. Her friends will remember her liturgical zeal and advocacy of Dorothy Day and The Catholic Worker. She was predeceased by her brother Joe and is survived by her brother Kenwood. She was a devoted friend of her sisters-inlaw Margaret and Emmarie and the beloved aunt of Tony, Peter, Nicole, Kevin, Scott and Jane. A memorial mass is being planned. Contributions can be made to the Bartelme Media Scholarship Fund at The College of St. Catherine, St. Paul, MN 55105.

LAWRENCE--Marjorie J., age 87, died in her sleep August 7th at her Manhattan home. Widow of film and TV producer Robert L. Lawrence, Marjorie was from 1971-2004 the owner and cofounder of the New Yorkbased The Pillowry, the first shop to sell handmade pillows fashioned from rare tapestries, antique Kilim, and pile rug fragments. Marjorie graduated from Birch Wathen School and Smith College with an art history BA, and then served in the O.S.S. during WWII. She married Bob, a U.S. Army captain, in 1946, and until she opened her shop was a homemaker in Manhattan, raising her sons Peter and Steven, and supporting Bob's career. An avid art and antique collector with a keen eye, she converted a growing interest in rugs and textiles into a thriving business that made use of her artistic talents. For many years she and Bob traveled North Africa and the Middle East, joyfully collecting textiles. Marjorie was renowned for her gourmet cooking, skill as a hostess, and gracious charm. She is survived by her sons, her sister Alice Low, and her grandchildren Vanessa and John Lawrence. A memorial service will be announced.

Adoring grandmother of Ted, Maddy, Benjamin, Kathryn, Will, Emily, Lilly, Jack, Charlie and Alexander. Funeral services to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 11:15 Thursday, August 14th. Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey on Tuesday rejected the idea of bringing criminal charges against former Justice Department employees who improperly used political litmus tests in hiring decisions, saying he had already taken strong internal steps in response to a ''painful'' episode. Two recent reports from the Justice Department inspector general and its internal ethics office found that seven department officials -- all but one now gone -- had systematically rejected candidates with perceived ''liberal'' backgrounds for what were supposed to be nonpolitical jobs and instead picked conservative lawyers.

Forty years after it first appeared on Broadway, ''Hair,'' the exuberant musical that is possibly the most enduring cultural artifact of hippiedom, was revived in Central Park in New York City on Thursday. The production has catalyzed considerable nostalgia for the late 1960s. What few recall, however, is that ''Hair'' had more than its share of misfortune; six members of the original company died prematurely, AIDS and drugs being the prime culprits. ''It's as though everything in 'Hair' turned into a nightmare,'' the executive producer of the original Broadway production, Bertrand Castelli, said in a recent documentary film about the show, ''Hair: Let the Sun Shine In.'' ''Everything that was joyful and harmless became dangerous and ugly.''

WILLIAMSON--Muriel, 94, died peacefully on August 11, 2008. The beloved wife of the late George S. Williamson, she worked for many years at Manhattan College in Riverdale, NY as secretary to the Dean of Students where she interacted with many students over the years. After retiring, she had a successful real estate career in Montauk, NY. She is survived by her son, George Stephen Williamson of Bedford Hills, NY and her devoted daughter Mary Elizabeth Payne of Southampton, NY and four grandchildren; Jeffrey Payne, Thomas Payne, Timothy Williamson and Brian Williamson. She will be sorely missed by her devoted sonin-law, Jeff Payne and daughter-in-law, Sally Williamson. Burial Service will be private.

CHEFETZ--Sheila Gloria Martha. We mourn the loss of our beloved Sheila, cherished wife of Myron Chefetz of Richmond, MA and mother of Jill, Laurence and Andia and stepmother to Alexander, Eugenie and Natasha. Devoted grandmother to 12 and a dear and loyal friend to so many. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Berkshire Museum are gratefully appreciated.

FREEDMAN--Howard, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center is saddened by the death of Dr. Howard Freedman. Dr. Freedman was a renowned neurosurgeon. He was the Chief of the division of Neurosurgery at Maimonides Medical Center for over three decades until his retirement in 1984. He was President of the medical staff from July 1974 through June 1975. He also served as Chairman of the Medical Ethics Committee. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his daughter and grandchildren. W. Wexelman, M.D. Pres. S. Farber, M.D. Pres. Elect H. Wasserman, M.D. Sec. E. Fitzpatrick, M.D. Treas.

SMITH--Rollins. It is with great sorrow we announce the death of Rollins Robinson Smith (Rib), on August 6, 2008. He was born in Douglaston, NY on October 8, 1927. He was the son of Roger and Barbara Robinson Smith. He died in Naples, FL, after a long, cruel siege of Parkinson's Disease. He graduated from the St. George's School in Middleton, RI and attended Trinity College in Hartford, CT. He leaves his widow, Joan B. Smith, sons Dale and Todd Smith and four grandchildren. He will be mourned by three stepdaughters and five step-grandchildren. He enjoyed a career in television commercial production, interrupted by service in the Korean War.

BEIJING -- The United States 4x200-meter freestyle relay team smashed the world record on Wednesday morning, helping Michael Phelps keep his gold-medal streak alive. The relay victory, in 6:58.56, helped Phelps earn his fifth medal of these Games, as he attempts to break Mark Spitz's record of seven gold medals in one event, which Spitz set in 1972. Earlier in the night, Phelps had earned his fourth gold medal with a world-record performance in the 200-meter butterfly. Phelps swam the opening leg, giving his teammates a substantial advantage. Ryan Lochte, Ricky Berens and Peter Vanderkaay continued to add to the lead, becoming the first relay team to break the 7-minute barrier, and beating the old record of 7:03.24.

One of the McCain campaign's new themes, that Senator John McCain has always put his country first, has been seen by some analysts as a subtle suggestion that his Democratic opponent, Senator Barack Obama, has not. But as he introduced Mr. McCain at a campaign event in York, Pa., on Tuesday, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman made the attack a lot more explicit, calling the election a choice ''between one candidate, John McCain, who has always put the country first, worked across party lines to get things done, and one candidate who has not.''

Homeowners lined up Tuesday for a foreclosure prevention workshop at Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Mass., billed as the largest such effort this year. Sponsors included the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, whose president, Eric S. Rosengren, said the number of foreclosures was still growing. The Federal Reserve said Tuesday that more banks tightened credit standards in July.

A year after financial tremors first shook Wall Street, a crucial artery of modern money management remains broken. And until that conduit is fixed or replaced, analysts say borrowers will see interest rates continue to rise even as availability worsens for home mortgages, student loans, auto loans and commercial mortgages. The conduit, the market for securitization, through which mortgages and other debts are packaged and sold as securities, has become sclerotic and almost totally dependent on government support. The problems, intensified by bond investors who have grown leery of these instruments, have been a drag on the economy and have persisted despite the exercise of extraordinary regulatory powers by policy makers.

The Croton Water Filtration Plant, which is being built deep below Van Cortlandt Park, in the northern Bronx, is not only one of the costliest projects in the city’s history, but one of the most troubled. Since the city agreed to the project in 1992, it has been plagued by delays, cost overruns, community opposition, accusations of bungled management and court decrees.

Supporters and foes of the Bloomberg administration’s plan to turn gritty Willets Point in Queens into a $3 billion development of stores, offices and apartments faced off in a confrontation that grew emotional and raucous at times. This much can be agreed on: An Orthodox congregation established by Eastern European Jews in 1888 occupies a lovely but crumbling neo-Classical building with a two-story Victorian Gothic interior at 415 East Sixth Street, between First Avenue and Avenue A, on the Lower East Side — a neighborhood where real estate prices have been soaring, placing pressure on owners of old buildings to sell their property to developers for retail and commercial uses.

Asking people where they were five years ago today during North America’s largest blackout does not have the significance of, say, the riots that erupted in the city after a major blackout in 1977. But the overnight power failure, which started at 4:11 p.m. on Aug. 14, 2003, was still cataclysmic in ways large and small.After the blackout, which left tens of millions of people in eight states and parts of Canada in the dark, the federal government beefed up rules governing utilities and has tried to make it easier for companies to build new transmission lines.

Donna de Varona is a two-time Olympic gold medalist in swimming, an Emmy award-winning broadcaster and a former board member of the U.S. Olympic Committee. She is currently co-chair of the Back Softball campaign to have the sport restored to the Olympic list in 2016.

The sixth night of the Beijing Summer Olympics on Tuesday generated an average of 27.7 million viewers, down from the 28.4 million in Athens in 2004, an evening that featured the scoring controversy over the men's all-around gymnastics final that ended with the American Paul Hamm winning the gold medal. It was the first time that viewership for NBC in Beijing has fallen against the comparable night in Athens.

Matthew Wald has just written a news article showing the power of a guaranteed market to bring about large-scale construction of energy technologies that currently cannot compete with the status quo. Manti Te'o is the top high school linebacker in the Class of 2009, according to Rivals.com. The Hawaii Gatorade player of year last season, the 6-foot-2, 220-pound Te'o had 90 tackles and 5 sacks for the prestigious Punahou School in Honolulu. The school's alumni include the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, Barack Obama; the L.P.G.A. golfer Michelle Wie and the AOL founder Steve Case. Te'o has yet to make a decision about where he will go to college, but he has decided to share some of his thoughts on his upcoming season and the recruiting process from time to time with The Quad. In this first installment, told to Thayer Evans, Te'o discusses what it's like to play in Hawaii, his Mormon faith and getting late-night phone calls from Charlie Weis.

BEIJING - Demetrius Andrade is reminded of his burden when he wakes up and when he goes to bed. The first and last face he sees every day is that of Rau'shee Warren, his roommate and the United States boxing team's other reigning world champion. Warren lost his opening bout Tuesday night, and Andrade, after blistering Andrey Balanov of Russia to advance to the welterweight quarterfinals Thursday, said he feels added pressure to win gold in his absence.

Amazingly, some editors who post here have deemed other editors' posts to be cranky. How could they think that? Perhaps so cutting a judgment is intended, um, ironically. The crowded banks of the sinuous Chao Phraya river were once considered the heart of Bangkok. But these days the river is largely peripheral for everyone but tourists -- the main business districts in the Thai capital are well inland from the big and muddy Chao Phraya. This is a shame because river life in Bangkok is still relatively vibrant, the temperature always seems to be a few degrees cooler and the well-lit monuments along the Chao Phraya are gorgeous to behold at night.

Climate scientists keep testing that turbulent world between data and society -- an arena far less safe than the laboratory or field camp, where a researcher becomes a potential target for both darts and laurels from those threatened or bolstered by his or her views. One new experiment is a nascent blog at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, with a fresh contribution by Josh Willis, whose work on ocean temperature trends has been discussed here. Dr. Willis says those who grasp at short-term wiggles in ocean or atmospheric conditions as evidence of global warming or cooling are like gamblers seduced by a hot streak into thinking they can beat the house.
UPDATE Comment from Google has been added.

It's hard to keep up with Paul A. Goble, the former State Department analyst on Soviet nationalities, as he follows the discussions in Russia about the Georgian standoff. We didn't even have time to post his piece on Tuesday on all the Russian Web sites that are providing detailed reporting on the Caucasus even as the mainstream press mostly follows the Kremlin's line. Among other tidbits, a Siberian source gave one possible explanation for why so many South Ossetians have Russian passports. South Ossetia is a haven for counterfeiting, not just of money, but also of passports. In his latest post, Mr. Goble spots some sharp criticism of Russian intelligence services, which failed to detect Georgia's plan to send forces into South Ossetia.

Lexicon | How did an ex-Soviet nation get the same name as a southern American state? The latter was named for the British king. Update: Andrew Cuomo said on Thursday that JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley have agreed to settle with regulators over auction-rate securities. Morgan Stanley will pay a $35 million penalty and JPMorgan a $25 million penalty. The penalties will be divvied up on a pro rata basis, which each state receiving money according to each's number of investors affected.

Redemption through victory is a bone-headed theme for the United States men’s Olympic basketball team. No country that has always been the best at something needs that kind of deliverance. Certainly, the American team has struggled in recent years: a collapse in the world championship in 2002; a worthless bronze in Athens in 2004 (so shameful that Dwyane Wade doesn’t even know where he put his medal); and a stunning loss to Greece in the 2006 world championship. But have they really morphed into a bunch of losers? Only in the way the Roman army did after its minor defeat at Gergovia -- which is to say hardly at all. If any team other than the "Redeem Team” tops the podium in Beijing, it’ll be a huge surprise, albeit not the apocalyptic sign it once was. The talent and skill gap between the American team and even its closest competitors -- Spain, Argentina and Greece -- remains considerable (although another spot-up shooter to bust zones would help). Unfortunately, that has not always mattered. The Americans now lug around a record of 95-7 since the pros started playing in 1992. Before you revoke your citizenship, though, consider that three of those losses came in Athens under Larry Brown, who browbeat an inexperienced, patchwork squad.

With stifling defense and above-the-rim play, the United States men’s basketball team dominated Greece on Thursday, 92-69, setting up a matchup against unbeaten Spain on Saturday. Kobe Bryant and Chris Bosh led the American team with 18 points each. “The performance rekindled memories of some of the dominant American Olympic teams of yesteryear,” Pete Thamel writes for The Times. “While the Greeks and other countries caught up to the United States in the past decade through better Olympic systems and more cohesive teams, this victory reminded the world that superior talent and athleticism can disrupt the best organizations.”.

The aura of supremacy long carried by Roger Federer may now be officially gone, as his sluggish play today led to a straight-sets loss against James Blake, a player Federer has beat handily in recent years. The loss by Federer, who will be losing his No. 1 world ranking to Rafael Nadal, means that he’ll go three straight Olympics without earning a medal.

“Sure, an Olympic cyclist can finish a 152-mile road race in less than seven hours,” Katie Thomas writes in The Times today, “but what would happen if you took away his finely tuned, aerodynamic, carbon-fiber racing bicycle and asked him to do battle on the streets of Beijing? Would it be like hiring Big Brown to be a carriage horse in Central Park? I was still finding my balance on my clunky, one-speed bicycle when Jason McCartney,” a member of the American cycling team, “answered the question and exposed it for all its armchair arrogance.”.

A FIRST-AID KIT and a packet of freeze-dried noodles might have been the camping essentials of old, but the new must-haves include portable showers, elegant lanterns and three-burner stoves. Best suited for car camping, such innovative items have given the weekend in the great outdoors a comfort upgrade. (Too cushy? There's always insect-repellant clothing spray, which the manufacturer says turns clothes into a shield against biting insects that lasts six weeks or six washings.) Thursday Styles looked at Gear Tests from the last two years and selected the testers' favorite tent, waterproof backpack, sleeping bag and outdoor shower. Then, we asked Mike and Terri Church, authors of the Rolling Homes Press series of RV and car-camping travel books, to test new lanterns, stoves, sleeping pads and bug-repellant clothing spray during a multistate camping trip and pick their favorites. Think of the resulting selection as first-class aid. SARAH TUFF

STEMWINDERS The speakers' schedule for the Democratic National Convention that begins on Aug. 25 is being made final, and on Wednesday the Obama campaign announced that former Gov. Mark Warner of Virginia will be the keynote speaker. The keynote is the featured role that Senator Barack Obama was given in 2004, and which propelled him to political stardom. Mr. Warner, who will speak on Aug. 26, is favored to win a Senate seat in Virginia in November. Democratic officials said Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania, an abortion opponent, would also address the convention on the same night. BAYH BACKLASH One person who is not yet scheduled to speak at the Denver convention is Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana, perhaps because he is considered a leading candidate to be Mr. Obama's running mate. But his presence on Mr. Obama's short list has also sparked a backlash because of his past support of military action in Iraq. On Wednesday, a Facebook.com group called ''100,000 Strong Against Evan Bayh for VP'' was set up. As of late Wednesday afternoon, the site was 99,000 short of its goal.

An article on Wednesday about a Government Accountability Office study reporting on the percentage of corporations that paid no federal income taxes from 1998 through 2005 gave an incorrect figure for the estimated tax liability of the 1.3 million companies covered by the study. It is not $875 billion. The correct amount cannot be calculated because it would be based on the companies' paying the standard rate of 35 percent on their net income, a figure that is not available. (The incorrect figure of $875 billion was based on the companies' paying the standard rate on their $2.5 trillion in gross sales.)

REICH--Eva, M.D . Died peacefully at home August 10 in Hancock, ME after a long illness. Born 1924 in Vienna to psychoanalysts Wilhelm and Annie Reich. Married William Moise; mother of Renata. Practiced as GP in rural Maine. Developed system of gentle child birth and care; taught worldwide. Donations to Downeast Health Services, 52 Christian Ridge Rd., Ellsworth, ME 04605.

GILLMAN--Hannie (Davidson) . Beloved wife of Stanley, miraculous mother of BJ and patron of the arts. Born in Holland, Hannie lived with passion and grace. Mrs. Gillman was a child prodigy of the dance and christened the Henry Hudson Hotel in NYC as a representative of her country. In her adult life, Mrs. Gillman was an ever-present force of inspiration for budding choreographers and noted dancers, working her magic behind the scenes at Dennis Wayne's Dancers, Lee Theodore's American Dance Machine, ABT, Mark Bogaerts and Jonathan Appel companies. Mrs. Gillman was instrumental in bringing the works of photographer Max Waldman to the public, sponsoring shows across America at universities and most recently in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda and Schomburg Library in NYC. Mrs. Gillman and her husband were active board members of the Bruno Walter Society, awarding annual scholarships to promising students of music. Mrs. Gillman was honored for her charitable works by the Dance Library of Israel, the Lincoln Center Library of the Performing Arts and received the Hannah J. Soloman Humanitarian Award. LAWRENCE--Marjorie J. , age 87, died in her sleep August 7th at her Manhattan home. Widow of film and TV producer Robert L. Lawrence, Marjorie was from 1971-2004 the owner and cofounder of the New Yorkbased The Pillowry, the first shop to sell handmade pillows fashioned from rare tapestries, antique Kilim, and pile rug fragments. Marjorie graduated from Birch Wathen School and Smith College with an art history BA, and then served in the O.S.S. during WWII. She married Bob, a U.S. Army captain, in 1946, and until she opened her shop was a homemaker in Manhattan, raising her sons Peter and Steven, and supporting Bob's career. An avid art and antique collector with a keen eye, she converted a growing interest in rugs and textiles into a thriving business that made use of her artistic talents. For many years she and Bob traveled North Africa and the Middle East, joyfully collecting textiles. Marjorie was renowned for her gourmet cooking, skill as a hostess, and gracious charm. She is survived by her sons, her sister Alice Low, and her grandchildren Vanessa and John Lawrence. A memorial service will be announced.

Our love, Thelly and Mel Turkel

It's not quite the same as having a receptionist take your calls, but the Supertooth 3 from Blue Ant Wireless does not need to take a lunch break, either. When properly configured, the Bluetooth-enabled speakerphone uploads a cellphone's address book and announces the name of the caller out loud. Calls can be answered without lifting a finger by verbally responding, ''O.K.'' During setup, users are guided through the pairing and uploading process. The device then uses text-to-speech technology to speak the name of the caller or the phone number of the incoming call. The speakerphone can be clipped to a car's sun visor to keep it within voice range of the driver.

WORK--John D. , 74, died August 9. Son of Howard C. Work and Nancy Keenan Work. Graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in 1951, Yale University in 1955 and the Harvard Business School in 1962. Most Global Positioning System devices are made to sit snugly in the confines of a car, where they rarely have to contend with dust, dirt or raging rapids. Garmin's new Nuvi 500, however, is intended to take more abuse than the average G.P.S. unit. The 7.6-ounce device is meant to work both in a car on the highway and in the hand on a mountain trail. The Nuvi comes with maps of the 48 contiguous states, Hawaii and Puerto Rico. It is resistant to water and dust and offers voice-based turn-by-turn directions while the user is on foot or in a vehicle (although it does not pronounce street names). An emergency locator feature indicates the exact longitude, latitude and elevation; it also includes directions to local hospitals and police stations.

The presidents of Georgia and Russia agreed early Wednesday morning on a framework that could end the war that flared up here five days ago, after Russia reasserted its traditional dominance of the region. Declaring that ''the aggressor has been punished,'' President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia announced early Tuesday that Russia would stop its campaign. Russian airstrikes continued during the day as mediators tried to broker an agreement and antagonisms seethed on both sides.

It is not every day that a prominent hip-hop producer and a speaker-wire company team up to make a pair of headphones. Beats by Dr. Dre, made by Monster Cable, are noise-reducing headphones specifically tuned to the demands of rock and hip-hop. Beats, like similar models from Bose and Sennheiser, reduce ambient noise and create a seal over the ears for better audio clarity. The red-and-black headphones can also be used as an iPhone headset -- with the included microphone attachment -- and fit almost any MP3 player or music-playing cellphone.

Cindy McCain, the wife of Senator John McCain, learned the meaning of ''grip and grin'' on Wednesday when enthusiastic supporters pulled her hands and she sustained a minor sprain in one of her wrists. She was shaking hands with supporters at a fund-raising luncheon with her husband in West Bloomfield, Mich., when one supporter gripped one hand tightly and another gripped her other hand, causing a wrench in one of her arms, campaign officials said.

SINCE opening in the late 1980s, the Knitting Factory in Lower Manhattan has served as a crucible for the cutting edge in the worlds of rock, jazz -- and style. Inside the club's Tap Bar, bands like Teenage Prayers, Tomahawk Chop and the Homecoming Queens play to crowds who improvise looks that are their own brands of performance art. On a recent evening, artists and fans accented their T-shirts with brash effects: loud graphics, suspenders and layers of gilt. Aviva Tilson of the band the Mighty Handful (bottom left) showed off a rainbow-tone zebra top. Briana Brink-Rivera (top left, center) made reference to the '80s, her off-the-shoulder tee a sexy homage to Jennifer Beals in ''Flashdance.'' Members of Radiates, another group, resurrected the fuchsia hair, drainpipes and black-on-black garb of early Kings Road, then tweaked the silhouette with striped hose and skinny suspenders -- an arch-streamlined update on punk.

Words cannot adequately express how much we will miss him but his legacy will carry on in all of our hearts forever. Survived by his loving wife Judy, devoted children Lloyd, Stephanie, Barbara, Sharon and his treasured grandchildren Andrew, Craig, Lauren, David, Michael, Emily, Allie, Josh, Jared, Jake and Kate. Services Sunday, August 17th, 11:30am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. SOLOMON--Herb. We thank you for touching our lives in the way you did. You will surely be missed. We love you. Scott and Rebecca SOLOMON--Herbert, Dear, dear friend. A very special person, kind, loving, giving, gentle man. Our hearts are broken. You will be sorely missed but never forgotten. Our love to Judy, Lloyd, Stephanie, Barbara, Sharon and all of the grandchildren. Joanne, Sid and Family Roz and Family

Last week, Canon added new models to its high-end camcorder line that will be available in September. The Vixia HF11, with an estimated price of $1,200, uses flash memory instead of the more common tape cassettes or revolving hard drives. Since flash memory dispenses with moving parts, battery life and shock resistance are better than in other camcorders. The Vixia comes with 32 gigabytes of onboard memory plus a slot for a memory card that can add as much as 32 gigabytes.

WHITTLE--Reed . We are saddened to report the death of Dr. Reed Whittle on August 12, 2008. Dr. Whittle died from complications of Sweet's syndrome at the age of 66. For more than 35 years, Dr. Whittle was an international management consultant to the leaders of Fortune 500 companies including Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Barclay's Bank, and several hospital chains and public utilities. His training as a psychotherapist as well as a management consultant gave him skills particularly useful to the field of human resources management. Dr. Whittle was born on January 25, 1942 in Jacksonville, Florida. He attended Culver Military Academy and Duke University. Active in the civil rights movement early in his life, he aspired to use the church as a vehicle for social justice and earned a doctorate from the University of Chicago Divinity School. For several years he served as a minister in the Boston area. Later he pursued post-doctoral work at the Sloan Business School at M.I.T. in organizational development and international management. Dr. Whittle was passionate about the outdoors. He was an avid fisherman, a scuba diving master, and a photographer. He traveled extensively, including Tibet, Papua New Guinea and the Amazon basin, where he spent several weeks living with a tribe. He is survived by his wife, Sassona Norton Whittle, two children, Scott Whittle and Dr. Amy Whittle, from his first marriage to Carolyn Lansden Whittle, his sister Sharon Utter-Whittle and brother Linford Whittle. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Immunology Institute, Mount Sinai Medical Center, 1425 Madison Avenue, Box 1089, NYC 10029. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Friday August 15, 10:30am, Madison and 81st Street, interment at Pleasant Hills Cemetery.

LEVY--Ethel C. , died peacefully at her home on August 7 at age 93. Born in Worcester, MA, she was a gifted student, the first female that her grandfather, Rebbe Handel, considered educable. Unable financially to accept admission to Radcliffe, she fulfilled her dreams by commuting daily to BU, graduating salutatorian, moved to New York, worked for Patrick Cardinal Hayes and married a young doctor, Sidney Levy, her constant companion until his death in 1983. We will always remember her unfailing optimism, abundant common sense, progressive social and political thinking undiminished by age or possessions, and, most importantly, her unfailing love for all of us. She is survived by brothers, Sam Chafetz (Lillian), Morris Chafetz, MD (Marion), sisterin-law, Judith Levy, children, Marilyn Miller and Harry Levy, MD, daughter-in-law, Leslie Carr, former daughter-inlaw, Carol Woodward, grandsons, Zachary, James and Sam Levy, granddaughter-inlaw, Nami Soejima. She was interred at Mt. Hebron in a simple ceremony she would have appreciated and, though her earthly hearing had long ago failed, she was hopefully able to listen to the words of gratitude spoken by her loved ones.

The turning point in Tim Kaine's campaign for Virginia governor in 2005 was an advertisement by his opponent featuring a father whose son had been murdered by a man Mr. Kaine represented on death row. ''Tim Kaine says that Adolf Hitler doesn't qualify for the death penalty,'' said the outraged father. ''The people of Virginia are entitled to know just what Tim Kaine is and what he stands for.''

The Tâke Personal Pocket Safe from Blackbox Innovations is like a safety deposit box to hold your critical digital information, including credit card and bank account numbers and all your passwords. The ''safe'' is a U.S.B. drive with a numeric keypad and encryption. After you enter your four-digit code, you have 30 seconds to insert the device into a computer before it locks. It also locks if it sits idle in the computer for more than three minutes.

9 P.M. (DIY) BLOG CABIN Maybe you're thinking Perez Hilton, Andrew Sullivan and Nick Denton in the mountains of Vermont with a wireless hookup? Dave Salmoni puts on a chain mail diving suit -- just the thing to tangle with the Humboldt squid -- and takes the plunge.

Updated, 6:05 p.m. | A severe thunderstorm passed over New Jersey, the Bronx and Westchester County, starting around 5:15 p.m. The National Weather Service issued and later canceled a tornado warning after Doppler radar indicated the fast-moving storm — estimated at 15 to 19 miles per hour — was capable of producing one. Hail the size of quarters and heavy winds were also predicted, as well as possible flash flooding in parts of the region. No actual tornadoes have been spotted.

Every day, the sick and the sad, the grateful and the good, make their way to a Bronx grotto, where a statue of the Virgin Mary peers down on them. They raise their hands in supplication, then lower them into a stream of water that splashes down the rocks and onto the floor. Today is the Feast of the Assumption, when Roman Catholics believe Mary, the mother of Jesus, entered heaven. This has special resonance in some parts of the city — apart from the suspension of alternate side parking — where new waves of immigrants have helped revive a tradition of Marian devotion that has waxed and waned over the generations.
