Bangkok is a city that promotes itself as a shopper's paradise. Over the last decade, many older buildings in the area between the Siam and Chidlom BTS stations in the heart of downtown have been completely renovated or else razed to make way for mega malls. Siam Paragon, the most ostentatious of the bunch, calls itself "The Pride of Bangkok." Many local residents call it noisy, architecturally uninteresting and overpriced. Nearby, the renovated and expanded Central World Plaza is a much hipper, better designed and somewhat quieter variation on the same theme.

A sponsor for whom I sell co-op apartments recently consulted me about a vacant unit. The apartment is in a line of two-bedroom units, but this unit is on the lobby level and is a small one-bedroom. Both the co-op offering plan and the building's original floor plan incorrectly classify the apartment as a two-bedroom. The number of shares and the maintenance are exactly the same for as the two-bedroom units above it. Can anything be done to reclassify this apartment as a one-bedroom and lower the maintenance charge?

LOS ANGELES -- When a sinkhole opened up in the Pasadena Freeway this summer, shutting down all northbound traffic, a lot of attention focused on the aging of what is California's first freeway and the first high-speed, limited-access road in the western United States. The Pasadena Freeway was once a model of modern freeway design, but people wondered anew how well the slow-speed curves and frightening on-ramps, with stop signs and no acceleration lanes, can continue to hold up to Los Angeles traffic. Unsurprisingly, this prompted a review of the freeway's distinctive features and design.

Are you better off than you were when Al Gore was vice president? If Barack Obama's campaign takes the advice of Robert Kuttner, the co-founder and co-editor of The American Prospect, it might start asking voters that question. "Most folks have assumed that Gore is off the VP list, but he hasn't been slotted as a convention speaker yet, which is curious since Gore is one of the party's superstars and its most effective spokesperson on energy and the environment," Kuttner writes at Tapped, his magazine's group blog. "Are they holding off because he's a finalist for Veep? And I have two pretty good sources who say Gore and Obama are actively exploring an administration slot for Al. What better post to be sustainability czar than vice president?"

Here are directions by public transportation to the beaches mentioned in the article. All are city beaches, except Fort Tilden and Jacob Riis Park, which are part of the Gateway National Recreation Area, operated by the National Park Service. Beaches are open for swimming from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day, when lifeguards are on duty, usually daily from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., in properly designated zones. Admission is free, but parking fees may apply at some locations. City beach information: nycgovparks.org. Gateway National Recreation Area: nps.gov/gate. Train and bus information: mta.info.

WIESENTHAL--Jerome. Always there with a screwdriver if we got locked in a bathroom. Always there with a vacuum at the ski house in Woodstock. Always there with a fashionably petite bathing suit. Always there with a joke to make us smile. Always there with wisdom and love. Miss you, Douglas and Stefanie Kahn WIESENTHAL--Jerome. Dearest brother, adored uncle and wisest friend. We love you so much. Happy Birthday -Kiss David. Joanie and Mike WIESENTHAL--Jerome M., born August 15, 1920, passed away August 12. He was born in Brooklyn to Herman and Evelyn Wiesenthal, and educated at Cornell University and Cornell Law School. He served in the US Navy during WWII as captain of LST 399 in the South Pacific. He was at the time the youngest LST ship's captain in that theater. He was a member of the bar and practicing attorney in New York for 67 years. He married the former Gladys Heilig on January 5, 1947. He is survived by his loving wife Gladys, his three children, Andrew, Douglas and Amy, and his daughter-in-law Billie Wiesenthal and son-in-law Michael Liss. He is also survived by three grandchildren: Benjamin, Daniel and John Liss. He was predeceased by his younger brothers Richard and Melvin. He was also loved by his brother-in-law Mike Kahn and his sister-inlaw Joan Kahn, along with his sisters-in-law Ellen Wiesenthal and Marion Heilig. He was also beloved by his nephews and nieces Douglas and Stephanie Kahn, David Kahn, Rob and Linnea Wiesenthal, Jay and Jane Cohen, and Gregory and Jeffrey Heilig, and their families. There will be a private service.

'THE PLANT THAT ATE DIRTY SOCKS' Children are famous for bringing home living things, from the potentially delightful (stray kittens) to the disquieting (the class's pet African millipede) to the disgusting (head lice). Some parents probably wish their kids would stick to something sane and sensible, like plants. But as fairy-tale readers know, a child who cultivates beans can get unexpected results.

GILLMAN--Hannie. The Trustees of the Bruno Walter Memorial Foundation mourn the death of our good friend and colleague, Trustee Emeritus Hannie Gillman. Her wise counsel, love of the arts, and warm, generous spirit will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her son BJ and his partner George, other members of Hannie's family and her many friends.

SOLOMON--Herb, of Jericho, NY. With profound sadness we announce the untimely passing of our beloved husband, father and grandfather on August 12, 2008. As the heart and soul of our family, he was our guiding light. His wisdom, integrity, compassion, grace, humor, humility and unassuming manner were only surpassed by his immeasurable love and devotion to each of us. He shared a lifetime with his true love which completed him in every way. His many significant professional accomplishments spanning more than half a century include senior leadership roles within the retailing and staffing industries. He was respected and admired for his professionalism, character and business acumen by all his colleagues and friends. Words cannot adequately express how much we will miss him but his legacy will carry on in all of our hearts forever. Survived by his loving wife Judy, devoted children Lloyd, Stephanie, Barbara, Sharon and his treasured grandchildren Andrew, Craig, Lauren, David, Michael, Emily, Allie, Josh, Jared, Jake and Kate. Services Sunday, August 17th, 11:30am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. SOLOMON--Herb. It is with profound sadness that Solomon Page Group, LLC shares the passing of Herb Solomon on August 12th. As a founder and ambassador for the SPG family over the last 18 years, Herb will be remembered for his grace, kindness and good will by everyone who knew him. As a professional, friend and perennial gentleman, he will be sincerely missed. SOLOMON--Herbert. The epitome of family and goodness. A genuinely great man who has blessed us and now, sadly, has left us. You touched our lives with your love, integrity and the selfless way you lived. You will remain forever in our hearts. With all our love, Scott, Steven and your loving grandchildren

When the Yankees drafted pitcher Gerrit Cole in the first round of the June draft, they believed he would sign with them and forego a college scholarship. It turns out that Cole has changed his mind and will go to U.C.L.A. According to a person involved in the negotiations, the Yankees have learned that Cole intends to go to college, no matter what they offer. The person was granted anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly before Friday's deadline for teams to sign drafted players.

8 P.M. (CMT) GONE COUNTRY 2 The seven performers competing in the second season of this reality talent contest are already established musicians. But can they sing country? In the premiere John Rich, above, of the country duo Big & Rich, tries to tickle the twang out of these R&B, pop and Broadway singers. The winner gets to go into the recording studio with Mr. Rich and cut a country single. Then, at 9 p.m., three city-slicker contestants from last season's ''Gone Country'' -- Maureen McCormick, Bobby Brown and Carnie Wilson -- star in a new reality series called ''Outsiders Inn,'' in which they become the proprietors of a country inn in Tennessee. 8 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: RITA HAYWORTH A full day of films dedicated to Rita Hayworth, beginning with ''The Loves of Carmen'' (1948), in which Hayworth plays a seductive Gypsy. Later in the day a string of four Hayworth musicals begins at 3:15 p.m. with ''Music in My Heart'' (1940), followed by ''Down to Earth'' (1947) at 4:30 p.m., ''Tonight and Every Night'' (1945) at 6:15 p.m. and ''You'll Never Get Rich'' (1941) at 8 p.m. The lineup also includes, at 2 a.m. on Saturday, a 2003 documentary about Hayworth titled ''Rita,'' narrated by Kim Basinger.

SUMMER ON THE HUDSON For those of us who've paid little attention to the redevelopment of the Far West Side, Riverside Park South, the well-tended space beneath the West Side Highway near 70th Street, is often overshadowed by its far more developed counterparts. Conceived as a peace offering of sorts by the real-estate titans who created the shimmering residential buildings overhead, it opened seven years ago but has had one unveiling or another ever since. To accompany its physical expansion -- the space is now 14 acres, two-thirds of its eventual size -- the Parks Department has put together an ever-expanding lineup of events.

ZACHARY--Cynthia Gerst, died unexpectedly at dawn, Tuesday, August 12. Wife of Henry, mother of Heather and Alex, sister of Adrienne Browning Laffey, mother-inlaw of Brett Rogoff. She also leaves bereft dozens of dear friends and family and hundreds of colleagues and clients in disbelief that the life-force that was Cynthia will no longer be there. Cynthia was Founder and President of Vantage Fundraising Counsel. Cynthia had three years of a very good life since a diagnosis of melanoma. Defying the possibility that there might be a difficult or tragic end, she lived her life as she always had. On August 1, she learned of multiple tumor sites. Still she was unbowed. Cynthia died as she had lived, defying the threat. In the process she gave herself years of a happy, active life, unburdening family, friends, employees, col leagues and clients from the fears surrounding the usual efforts to subdue cancer. No tests, no treatments, no surgeries, or agonizing fears would inhibit her mind or heart. Instead, she continued a life-long passion for collecting art, playing tennis, enthusiasm for travel and ardent love of family and friends. She lived her real life in real time. A memorial service will be held at 3pm Thursday August 21 at Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Cynthia Zachary Memorial Fund, NYU Langone Medical Center Development Office, 1 Park Ave 10th Floor, NY, NY 10016. ZACHARY--Cynthia Gerst. The Board of Directors, doctors and staff of the Children's Cancer & Blood Foundation mourn the loss of Cynthia Gerst Zachary, President of Vantage Consulting Group. She was a good friend to CCBF and to the children we treat. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family.

This 1,050-square-foot cabin, constructed in authentic chink-log style, is on 1.47 wooded acres. The cabin, built in 1994, has an open living and dining area with an eat-in kitchen and a central wood-burning stone fireplace. Multipane windows, wide-plank pine floors and log interior walls give the cabin a rustic appearance. The Toccoa River is less than a mile away, and this property includes deeded access so owners can put a boat in. The cabin has a screened porch and one bathroom. It's 15 minutes from the town of Blue Ridge. Taxes: $1,119. Agent: Tanya Bailey, North Georgia Cabins and Land, (706) 632-7111; www.cabinandlandsource.com.

FOR CHILDREN ACT YOUR AGE: PLAYS THAT GROW ON YOU (Friday through Sunday) Despite the title, the 9-to-18-year-old participants in this series of one-acts are having an experience extraordinary for people their age: they are starring in mini-musicals written expressly for them by adult theater professionals. The creative partnerships are a result of the One-on-One program, part of the 52nd Street Project, which provides theater opportunities for disadvantaged youth in the Clinton neighborhood. Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m.; Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, 52project.org. Free, but reservations required: (212) 642-5052.

This two-story, 4,500-square-foot house is on about one acre overlooking Lake Blue Ridge. The property has 235 feet of lake frontage that extends to the Toccoa River channel, which feeds the lake. The Forest Service owns the land on one side of the property as well as the land across the lake from the house. There is a deep-water dock with a 26-foot-wide boat slip. The house, which was built in 1998 and remodeled this year, has a loft in addition to its four bedrooms, an updated kitchen with granite counters, walls of windows, decks on several levels and an attached garage. There are two master suites. The great room has a stone fireplace and lake views. On the lower level, there is another reception room. There are four bathrooms. The house is being offered furnished, including dishes, bed linens, and other household goods. Taxes: $9,860. Broker: Shelley Draper, Draper Realty, (706) 455-2274; www.draperllc.com.

FISSELL--Frederica Kane, of Bedford, NY on August 9, 2008 at age 73. Rica was born in New York City to Frederick and Geraldine McGovern Kane, and was sister to Barbara Curran, Patricia FlachMittman, and Robert Kane. Rica was the loving wife of 48 years to William H. Fissell, Jr, dear sister-in-law to Elizabeth Griffin, devoted mother of Mary, Kate, Frederica, and William, and joyful grandmother to Rachel, Sam, and William. Rica graduated from the Convent of the Sacred Heart in 1952 and Manhattanville College in 1956; she was a dedicated volunteer for the Bedford Free Library from the 1970s until the time of her illness in 2008. Memorial service at Historical Hall in Bedford, NY, on Monday, August 18th, at 1pm. Friends may send memorial donations to the Bedford Free Library.

WHITTLE--Reed. Reed was a man for all our seasons: of celebrations and concerns, of intelligence and analyses, of new ideas and experiences -a fellow adventurer in life. We shared holidays together, dinners full of talk and laughter, the country and gardens, books, and more books, and, of course, fly fishing in the far corners of the world. Every man dies, but not every man lives. Reed lived with intensity, loyalty, and love. We miss him deeply. At this sad time, we reach out to his adored wife, Sassona, with enduring friendship. Torsos and heads from the South Bronx to South America hang on the walls of John Ahearn's studio. He glides along the tiles, which are covered by a silt layer of plaster dust from one of his sculptures in progress. He gently trims some stray plaster from a recent casting he did of a teenage boy. With a quick huff, he blows more plaster dust into the air, then steps back to get perspective.

Trades are never easy to evaluate because of the different needs of the teams involved. For every Doyle Alexander who goes 9-0 after being traded from the Braves to the Tigers in 1987, there is the potential for a John Smoltz to go 210-147 over the next 20 seasons for Atlanta. So when looking at the trades that happened this season, it is important to look at the entire context of the moves.

CROCKER--Jane, on August 12, 2008, at home, in Atherton, California. She is survived by her loving and devoted sons, Scott and Garrett Jacobs, and two grandsons, Jaxon and Justin Jacobs. A celebration of her life will be held at a date to be determined in September. May she rest in peace.

SOLOMON--Herb. Uncle Herbie, you were very special to each of us. We were truly blessed by your kindness, warmth, integrity, and love of family. Words can not express how much you will be missed. Cherished memories will live in our hearts forever. All our love, The Ramer, Fried, and Lacks families. SOLOMON--Herb, of Jericho, NY. With profound sadness we announce the untimely passing of our beloved husband, father and grandfather on August 12, 2008. As the heart and soul of our family, he was our guiding light. His wisdom, integrity, compassion, grace, humor, humility and unassuming manner were only surpassed by his immeasurable love and devotion to each of us. He shared a lifetime with his true love which completed him in every way. His many significant professional accomplishments spanning more than half a century include senior leadership roles within the retailing and staffing industries. He was respected and admired for his professionalism, character and business acumen by all his colleagues and friends. Words cannot adequately express how much we will miss him but his legacy will carry on in all of our hearts forever. Survived by his loving wife Judy, devoted children Lloyd, Stephanie, Barbara, Sharon and his treasured grandchildren Andrew, Craig, Lauren, David, Michael, Emily, Allie, Josh, Jared, Jake and Kate. Services Sunday, August 17th, 11:30am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. SOLOMONHERBERT ST#

More than seven hours after she won the silver medal in the women's gymnastics all-around, Shawn Johnson finally left the Olympic Green. She climbed onto the back of a golf cart and tucked her tiny body between her parents, Teri and Doug, exhausted after a battery of interviews. She leaned her head onto her mother's shoulder and sighed.

FISSELL--Frederica Kane, of Bedford, NY on August 9, 2008 at age 73. Rica was born in New York City to Frederick and Geraldine McGovern Kane, and was sister to Barbara Curran, Patricia FlachMittman, and Robert Kane. Rica was the loving wife of 48 years to William H. Fissell, Jr, dear sister-in-law to Elizabeth Griffin, devoted mother of Mary, Kate, Frederica, and William, and joyful grandmother to Rachel, Sam, and William. Rica graduated from the Convent of the Sacred Heart in 1952 and Manhattanville College in 1956; she was a dedicated volunteer for the Bedford Free Library from the 1970s until the time of her illness in 2008. Memorial service at Historical Hall in Bedford, NY, on Monday, August 18th, at 1pm. Friends may send memorial donations to the Bedford Free Library.

There was a time Friday night when Rafael Nadal was chasing shadows. As Novak Djokovic cruised through the second set, smashing winners, Nadal, the best defensive player in tennis, seemed flat-footed. Yet Nadal found an answer and a victory, 6-4, 1-6, 6-4.

The Chinese government's effort to improve Beijing's air quality appears to have worked to reduce carbon monoxide emissions, based on preliminary data collected by Columbia University's Spatial Information Design Lab. In a series of measurements taken along the Olympic marathon route, carbon monoxide levels dropped an average of 40 percent after the city put in alternate-day driving restrictions in which motorists could drive only on odd or even days. Unfortunately, other components of the city's air pollution, like particulate matter, are still at high levels, according to Sarah Williams, director of the lab. One of the main reasons for Beijing's high carbon monoxide levels is the large number of cars idling in traffic.

8 P.M. (Logo) ROXY: THE LAST DANCE It was a 1970s roller-skating disco that was retooled as a dance club in the 1980s. But it wasn't until 1990, when promoters started holding dance parties for gay men on Saturday nights, that the Roxy, above, a nightclub by the West Side Highway in Chelsea, found its groove. This documentary, part of Logo's ''Real Momentum'' series, mixes reminiscences with footage from the Roxy's raucous final night on March 10, 2007, which lasted until noon the next day. 9:30 A.M. PASAROW--Claire. Born August 26, 1918, New York City, New York. Died August 13, 2008, Beverly Hills, California. Claire was the matriarch of the Pasarow Family for the last generation. She reigned with an even and steady hand over a clan of four children, thirteen grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, Robert Jack Pasarow, and her son of 54 years, Jay David Pasarow. During the time she lived, the world as we know it changed dramatically. Throughout and during her life she became an accomplished artist, a successful businesswoman, and a philanthropist. She was indeed a true renaissance woman of the 20th and 21st centuries. Above all else, she loved her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren and will be very much missed by us all. She is gone from this earthly existence but will never be forgotten.

She may be well heeled, but Alice Dellal is more mosh pit than posh git. ''I love '90s grunge and punk,'' she says. Which only half explains the half-shaved mane, the nose ring, the well-worn brothel creepers and the ripped tights. For the London-based Dellal, a favorite of Vogue Paris and photographers like Nick Knight, rock and fashion are her patrimony: Uncle Mick (as in Jagger) and Uncle Mario (as in Testino) are her godfathers. ''My family influences me a lot,'' says the 21-year-old scenester. So what do her nearest and dearest think of her mowed tresses? ''Some people hate it,'' she admits, and ''some people love it. A Sports of The Times column in some editions on Saturday, about the performance by Michael Phelps in the 100-meter butterfly to win his seventh swimming gold medal at the Beijing Olympics, misstated the timing of the race. It was on Saturday morning in Beijing, not Friday morning.

An article by The Associated Press last Sunday about the collapse of the Wall Arch in Arches National Park, in southern Utah, misstated the condition of the nearby Landscape Arch. It is still standing; it did not collapse in 1991. (A portion of the Landscape Arch fell that year, making the arch thinner.).

An article last Sunday about the business strategy of Time Warner misstated the operating income of its film unit, which included Warner Brothers and New Line Cinema, for the 2007 fiscal year. It was $1.2 billion, not $1.2 million.

A capsule summary last Sunday about the legal problems of Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit misstated the circumstances in which Mr. Kilpatrick was accused of having assaulted a sheriff’s deputy. The deputy was trying to serve a subpoena on a friend of Mr. Kilpatrick, not on Mr. Kilpatrick himself.

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about Merrill Lynch’s agreement to unwind credit insurance it bought from a bond insurer, misidentified the name of that insurer at the time it was announced. It was XL Capital Assurance, not XL Capital. The column also misstated the relationship of XL Capital Assurance and a related entity, Security Capital Assurance. XL was a subsidiary of it, not its parent. (After the announcement, XL became Syncora Guarantee and Security Capital Assurance became Syncora Holdings.).

An article last Sunday about the online music ventures of Peter Gabriel misstated the year when he bought half of Solid State Logic, which makes high-end recording studio consoles. It was 2005, not 1995.

An article last Sunday about the conflict between bicyclists and motorists misstated the given name of the ride coordinator for the Morris Area Freewheelers, a New Jersey cycling club. He is Steve Diamond, not Scott.

A listing of excursions on Aug. 3 misstated the number of minor-league baseball teams in New Jersey. There are two minor-league teams affiliated with major-league organizations and six independent professional teams; there are not three minor-league teams.

A listing in “Residential Sales Around the Region” last Sunday, using information from the broker, gave outdated pricing and tax figures for the house at 45 Hunton Street in Dongan Hills, Staten Island, and failed to include information about subsequent construction at the address. To the Editor: Your “Readers’ Picks: Montreal” (Aug. 10) offered excellent suggestions, especially the walk from McGill College to the Old Port via Rue St.-Denis. But to refer to La Ronde’s “weekly fireworks” in your photo caption is like referring to the Pacific Ocean as “water.” La Ronde hosts the annual International Fireworks Competition on Wednesday and Saturday nights every summer. Two years ago, on a solo getaway to Montreal, I attended the Wednesday night entry from Portugal and the Saturday night performance by Canada. Both shows were staggering; each were 30 minutes long with over 5,000 components fired off, all tightly synchronized to custom music beds. This year, I brought my adult son and daughter along for the United States (Wednesday) and China (Saturday) entries; seven other countries competed this year.. Two minutes into the United Statesperformance, my son turned to me and said, “Dad, I’ve just seen more fireworks than I’ve ever seen in my entire life.” He’s 24. The United States ended up winning the gold, and the Chinese the bronze. The Web site for the International Fireworks Competition is www.internationaldesfeuxloto-quebec.com.

In her “On Language” column (Aug. 3), Caroline Winter imagines that our “individualistic, workaholic culture would be more rooted in community and quality and less focused on money and success” if we left the self-aggrandizing “I” in lowercase and started capitalizing the deferential “you” instead. An appealing fantasy, but our culture has, in fact, already tried that graphical gimmick. The result: the iPod and YouTube — hardly the end of consumerism and narcissism.

In her fine, whimsical investigation into the narcissism of traffic mergers (Aug. 3), Cynthia Gorney omitted a crucial aspect of the sidezoomer psychology: anonymity. Ask sidezoomers if they would crash a supermarket line of loaded carts or barge in front of 50 patrons waiting to buy tickets, and they vigorously deny ever contemplating such violations. Put them faceless and nameless inside an automobile, however. . . .

St. Gallen, Switzerland, is a quiet mountain town about an hour east of Zurich by car. Nestled between the Bodensee hills to the north and the Appenzells to the south, it boasts picture-postcard views, a handsome town center and one of the oldest and most important monastic libraries in the world. It’s also the destination for scores of fashion designers, who make pilgrimages in search of its famous lace.

We departed for China not, technically, from Kennedy airport but from the New York car service, a fact I mention for the smell. There is no experience more redolent and usually more odoriferous than a New York car service. Like celebrities with licensing contracts, each Lincoln has its own peculiar odor. I have shut the door and inhaled leather with notes of cigar plus window cleaner. I have smelled decaying flora, fake pine and armpits. When I left for J.F.K., the car smelled of kimchi and dry-cleaning.

Mention the cold war, and many of us recall in vivid detail its long, menacing reach into our otherwise innocent lives in midcentury American suburbia: the worry in our parents’ voices during the high-stakes poker game that was the Cuban missile crisis, the elementary-school air-raid drills and backyard fallout shelters, the specter of Soviet premier Nikita Khrushchev insinuating himself via television into our living rooms and threatening to bury us. But cold-war design — that’s another story, something that took place not where we lived but on the far side of the Iron Curtain, in a drab, poured-concrete landscape of bunkers, faceless prefab housing and monolithic government office buildings.

1. Tom Chapman and his wife, Ruth, opened the first Matches boutique in Wimbledon, England, 17 years ago. Since then, they’ve added seven more locations, developing a following among London’s fiercest fashionistas, Their latest effort, in Marylebone, reflects the area’s cosmopolitan feel. “It has a wonderful sense of individuality and charm,” Tom Chapman says, “which perfectly embodies the spirit of our customers: confident, free-thinking people who understand fashion but aren’t slaves to it” (87 Marylebone High Street; matchesfashion.com).

Bulgari | High Jewelry Necklace What makes this jewel worth $500,000? Partially, it’s the 49 emeralds, three tourmalines and 12 mandarin garnets, plus all the diamonds and 18-karat gold. It’s also the halo of a venerable Italian brand: 125 years old next year, known for instantly identifiable designs that mix precious and semiprecious stones in vibrant color combinations. But ultimately the price tag reflects time. Typically, it takes three to four months to source a grouping of stones. Drafting a design can be another three months, with as many as 60 revisions. Assembly — this piece has 160 different elements — adds at least a month and a half more. And finally there is extreme customer service: should a Tokyo client want to see a few gems while vacationing in Capri, Bulgari will fly some there, along with her usual salesperson from Japan. So factor that in, too. [?][?][?]NATHAN LUMP.

CRYSTAL CLEAR.

Samurai warriors epitomized physical prowess, valor and loyalty to their overlords. Samurai without masters were called ronin; they were wild things, a breed apart. The Samurai Shopper is obsessively ronin when it comes to hair products: I disrespect their authoritarian claims, their disappointing results. I pledge allegiance only to what works, and nothing works past midday, any day. I’ve tangled with every stud marketing suds: Ted Gibson, Frédéric Fekkai, Philip B, Peter Thomas.

Great style is eternal, which is why designers are re-editing their tried-and-true hits. Ann Demeulemeester’s new Collection Blanche cherry-picks key items from her 20-year career, including her 1998 asymmetrical “Holy” tank top (left), a deceivingly simple little black dress and a leather blazer that morphs into a three-quarter coat. At Balenciaga, Nicolas Ghesquière has been quietly reinterpreting classics from Cristóbal Balenciaga’s archives for the past couple of years; 15 originals are selected each season based on their craftsmanship and timeless appeal. Zero + Maria Cornejo is celebrating its 10th anniversary by making 10 of its greatest hits available once again; five screen prints by Cornejo’s husband, the photographer Mark Borthwick, have also been reissued for limited-edition T-shirts. And in what marks a new chapter in fashion re-editing, the designer Sophie Albou of Paris’s Paul & Joe has joined forces with Pierre Cardin. Albou bought a large stash of Cardin couture at auction and fell in love with the futuristic disco style of the clothes. She contacted the reclusive designer and struck a three-year deal to reproduce 10 of his styles per season under the Pierre Cardin for Paul & Joe label. The more fashion changes. ... [?][?][?]REBECCA VOIGHT.

Long before the Internet made cruising for sex just another perk of your BlackBerry, the quest for carnal knowledge was a more sophisticated act. Need proof? Check out “The Pretty Women of Paris” (Hanbury Press), a reprint of a long-lost directory to the who’s who of the Ashley Duprés of yore. Originally written in the 1880s as a catalog featuring filles de joie for visiting johns, the book features elegant pinup illustrations hidden between uncut pages and plenty of colorful, user-friendly descriptions. (One lady of the evening, Georgina Dupont, is described as possessing “a large pair of palpitating hemispheres that are always ready to burst out of her stays.”) Hand-bound in crimson French silk, the petite tome — not to be confused with the more lascivious “Guide des jolies femmes de Paris” recently written by a speechwriter in President Nicolas Sarkozy’s administration — is a love letter to all those forgotten members of the world’s oldest profession. [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.

Colette, the Parisian temple of all things conceptual and cool, practically invented the fashion-collaboration phenomenon, working with brands as diverse as Goyard and Kid Robot. Now it has teamed up with the Gap to bring its wares stateside for the first time. It’s opening a pop-up store in the Gap’s rotating concept space, adjacent to the flagship store on Fifth Avenue and 54th Street. Colette x Gap standouts include artist-created T-shirts, denim jackets customized by Olympia Le Tan and souvenirs by Kuntzel + Deygas, who are also responsible for the store’s video projections. Don’t dillydally: the hybrid shopping experience lasts only from Sept. 6 to Oct. 5. [?][?][?]LEE CARTER.

Take a good amount of Dada, whisk in one part Tim Burton, add a splash of the Flintstones and you have Maison Darré, Vincent Darré’s new design gallery in Paris’s First Arrondissement. A longtime fixture on the European fashion scene — he worked for Prada, Fendi, Chanel, Moschino and, most recently, Emanuel Ungaro — Darré jumped easily from dresses to décor. “I wanted to be free to design objects, wallpapers, rugs and furniture with the same freshness I brought to my early work in the fashion world, before it became so business-oriented,” he says. The intimate space, which he conceived of as “more a house than a gallery,” is punctuated by limited-edition pieces that often incorporate backbones, rib cages, femurs and other anatomical elements. “I like to think of it as a chaotic and surrealistic laboratory, close in spirit to the Wiener Werkstätte,” he says. “Every piece is numbered, and my artist friends will collaborate on special pieces for this metaphysical place.” (32, rue du Mont Thabor; 011-33-1-42-60-27-97) [?][?][?]SANDRA BALLENTINE.

Well before the plummeting value of the dollar was a hot topic, the movement to abolish the penny had been gaining currency. But where some see annoying spare change, others see beauty. Among the latter is Bing Bang’s Anna Sheffield, who was entrusted with creating a signature jewelry collection to celebrate Cole Haan’s 80th anniversary. Since Cole Haan was a pioneer of the all-American penny loafer, Sheffield had a ready-made inspiration for her multipendant necklaces and handbag charms, made of espresso gold vermeil and whiskey quartz. A key piece in the collection is the “keepsake coin,” meant to be worn in Cole Haan’s new moccasin-inspired handbags and high-heel patent leather loafers. Just a humble coin, you say? Look again. [?][?][?]ANGELA GAIMARI.

This fall, diamonds — as well as citrines, garnets, gold, heliotropes, zircons, opals, sapphires and common paste — are a girl’s best friend. Jewelry is back in a big way, and the coolest way to wear it is by mixing up the heirlooms and the costume. Can you tell which is which? [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER.

Life might feel more expensive than it did five years ago, but when it comes to the little necessities (therapy, Champagne, the perfect jeans), prices have barely budged compared to life’s real necessities (corn, oil, health insurance). Oh, lucky us. [?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

Louise Goldin’s obsessively precise knitwear is literally out of this world. This fall’s show, her second since graduating from Central Saint Martins, envisioned a chance meeting between an Inuit tribe and the crew of the starship Enterprise. Aside from the jagged motifs on short dresses, cat suits and hooded fur-trimmed tops, Goldin threw into the mix sporty drawstrings and soft harnesses; shoulders swollen with padding; fringe and pompoms that dangle from short hemlines; and, to flesh out her models’ hips, wads of cashmere. “It’s all an experiment,” says the 27-year-old London native. When her intersecting squares of ice blue, black and gray splinter and morph into Fair Isle-style patterns on tunic dresses, it’s as if a Cubist painting had been rendered in wool. “The artworks take on their own form, and I never know if they’re going to work — you have to live in the unknown.” Unlike many of her fashion contemporaries, Goldin isn’t the type to party with Hoxton hipsters on the weekend. Instead she shuttles between Gatwick and a factory in northern Italy, supervising every stitch and pushing her (entirely machine-made) knits to a finer, more vibrant complexity: “I want to create new techniques in knitwear so it can look modern.” And her dream clients? “Mary-Kate. Or Madonna,” she says, pointing to a carapace-like black dress with crystal-flecked shoulders. “She’d look fierce in that.” Available at Kirna Zabête in New York. [?][?][?]SUSIE RUSHTON.

Hats are the most consistent part of my wardrobe — they give me a sense of protection and a reason to get dressed up. This little blue Stephen Jones top hat is my favorite. I discovered Stephen when he graduated from Saint Martins in the late 1970s, and whenever I think, “Mamma mia! I have nothing to wear!” he sends me a sketch. Sometimes I make changes, but it’s usually something very minor, like “Keep in mind that I would like to have a rubber band to hold it on to my head.” What I like most about this hat is its symbolism. The shape represents formality and tradition, but there’s also a bit of irony. It has a veil, which I find flattering and practical, and the color references the blue wave I’ve had in my hair since 1989. I’m thinking of throwing it a 20th-birthday party next year. [?][?][?]ANNA PIAGGI, AS TOLD TO J. J. MARTIN.
Long live Queen: the band is back with its “Rock the Cosmos” tour — but, sadly, without its fabulous frontman, Freddie Mercury (R.I.P.).
The well-heeled Alice Dellal counts Mick Jagger and Mario Testino as godfathers, but she’s more mosh pit than posh git.
The impossibly chic L’Wren Scott is best known as Mick Jagger’s old lady. Which is the least of her talents.
If it's Tuesday, Rachel McAdams must be blond. So what if the Hollywood hottie has a few sociopathic tendencies?
A modern Medici worships at the altar of 21st-Century design. A visit to Hester Diamond's uptown palazzo.
SABLE BODIED.
AMAZING LACE.

PARURE / (pe roor&) / n. / A matching set of jewels or ornaments that has been démodé since Kenneth Jay Lane was the shiniest bangle in the box; a conspicuous display of wealth that could be making a comeback now that baubles are the new handbags, e.g., “I don’t know whether to wear my Paloma Picasso parure or mix and match my Marni choker and Verdura earrings with a Courtney Love Collection tiara.”.

For years I was a female King Lear in a Marni dress and Chanel ballet slippers, shouting “Reason not the need!” when the customs guy looked askance at the pile of bibelots I laid before him: hand-knits of spun gold from a darling little shop in Covent Garden, strangely wonderful garments sold exclusively at L’Eclaireur in the Marais, fuchsia gauntlet gloves uncovered on the Ponte Vecchio, clutches and satchels signed Fendi and Ferragamo.

Since 1913, when Duchamp modified a bicycle wheel and created the first “ready-made,” artists have incorporated manufactured goods into their work. On Sept. 27, the Museum of Art and Design reopens in its new home at Two Columbus Circle with a show called “Second Lives: Remixing the Ordinary.” It explores how 51 artists, artisans and designers transform mass-produced, often discarded objects into works of art. Much of the show focuses on clothing, like Susie MacMurray’s “Mixture of Frailties” (2004), a towering wedding dress made out of hundreds of rubber household gloves (above). The art often has a gentle political subtext: Terese Agnew’s “Portrait of a Textile Worker” (2005) is assembled from designer clothing labels. However different each piece is, in the end they all celebrate the beauty of everyday things. [?][?][?]CAROL KINO.

1. You’d never know Banana Republic slipped into its third decade this year, at least judging from the revamped classics in its 30th-anniversary collection. The label is also sponsoring a major Elizabeth Peyton show at Manhattan’s New Museum in October.

Judging from the fall collections, one could easily assume that Jean-Paul Goude’s 1981 book, “Jungle Fever,” which documents his work with Grace Jones in the late ’70s and early ’80s, had just been released. At Yves Saint Laurent, the models marched down the runway in baggy trousers, eye-obscuring wigs and the strong-shouldered jackets that were the hallmark of Jones’s 1982 “One Man Show” tour. For Louis Vuitton, Marc Jacobs went in for conical headgear, boxy sweaters and harem pants that billowed in the thigh and tapered toward a high ankle, while his signature line had nuns-on-vacation hoods like the ones Jones wore in “A View to a Kill.”.
THE MOURNING AFTER.
TRY ANGULAR GIAMBATTISTA VALLI COAT, $7,570. SPECIAL ORDER AT BERGDORF GOODMAN. JANIS BY JANIS SAVITT NECKLACE AND BRACELET. ALEXIS BITTAR RINGS. BALENCIAGA SHOES.

We all know about Vogue’s importance in fashion. But have you ever considered how the sensibilities of different editions influence what comes down the runway? Here, an international Vogue typology. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER.

With over two million citizens behind bars, the United States now needs color-coded handcuffs to sort them out. Unlike most things correctional, however, these restraints are festive-looking. You can get them in colors like Nexium purple and Barbie pink, and at a little over half a pound a pair, wearing them will help you tone your arms. Handcuff Warehouse sells Hiatt-Thompson’s professional-grade model 1010C ($26), made with “true swing technology” to make slapping them on a snap. Included are instructions and two keys, for quick escapes. Warning: Be prepared for bondage jokes. Also, Hiatt-Thompson’s “three-piece suit” (ankles, waist, wrists) was used by interrogators at Guantánamo Bay, even though Amnesty International deems it inhumane. Oh, and for evening, you’ll want a pair of 24-karat gold-plated ones ($90), in case you catch Lindsay Lohan boosting your heirloom fur. [?][?][?]LYNN PHILLIPS.

In 1926, Coco Chanel revolutionized fashion with the introduction of a little black dress in crepe de Chine, an idea that proved so culturally pervasive that today most women own at least one L.B.D. In recent years, the L.B.D.’s very ubiquity has seen it relegated to the high-fashion margins, dismissed as too safe, too boring — in short, too grown-up. However, whether due to the looming shadows of recession or a more random fashion meme, one thing is certain: the little black dress is back.

This season’s sickest pleasure is not Balenciaga’s crystal-embellished dress ($46,650, without tax) but the Australian comedy series “Summer Heights High.” The designer Kim Jones, Vogue’s Hamish Bowles, the photographer Alasdair McLellan and the accessories designer Katie Hillier are among the fashionable addicts of this eight-part mockumentary set at an underprivileged suburban high school in Melbourne. Chris Lilley, the criminally talented creator, also stars as the show’s three lead characters: Ja’mie King (left), a 16-year-old philanthropist/teen model on an exchange program from an exclusive girls’ school; Jonah Takalua, a break-dancing, graffiti-obsessed 13-year-old juvenile delinquent from Tonga; and Greg Gregson, better known to the students as “Mr. G,” the campier-than-Christmas “director of performing arts,” whose school productions include “Tsunamarama” (a musical about the 2004 tsunami set to the hits of Bananarama). The good news for “Heights”-challenged Americans, who up until now have had to get their fix on YouTube, is that HBO will start screening the show in November. As Ja’mie says as she stands up through the sunroof of her mom’s Volvo and waves goodbye to her erstwhile BFF’s, “Public schools rock!” [?][?][?]HORACIO SILVA.

The Spanish director Luis Buñuel joked in his autobiography that after his death he would like to rise from the grave and read what’s in the news. Were he to do so this fall, Buñuel, who died in 1983, would discover that he is suddenly everyone’s furry cup of tea.
Diane Paulus, the director of the Public Theater’s revival of “Hair,” takes over as the new artistic director for the American Repertory Theater starting this fall.

Thank you to Michael R. Gordon for the insightful and in-depth article about Iraq’s inner political struggles (Aug. 3). We often hear about the violence in Iraq; this piece is another reminder that power struggles are a driving force behind much of this news. We should all be paying more attention.jean esch.

KHATAMI--Marie Hoguet passed away on Wednesday, August 13, 2008 from a blood clot following cancer surgery in New York City. Her loving family will miss her profoundly. She was a brave and forward thinking 85-year-old who loved art and European and Asian cultures, a passion she shared with her husband of 57 years, Abul Khatami. We will remember so many things about her, but what stands out in our minds is her incredible spirit, fierce intelligence, and deep resounding laughter. She was as complete a human being as one could be. Marie Khatami was born in Millburn, New Jersey on February 3, 1923. She grew up in Manhattan with her five brothers and two sisters at 47 East 92nd Street. The girls attended Convent of the Sacred Heart; Marie's mother, Louise Hoguet, helped to found the St. David's School in 1951. Marie also attended Sacred Heart in Noroton, CT. and continued her studies in Paris and Siena until the imminent outbreak of World War II brought her home. She attended Barnard and completed her college education at Radcliffe in 1946, where she received a B.A. Her interests in Art History and Asian culture can be traced to the gift of a book from her father, Robert Louis Hoguet, when she was a girl, ''Folktales of Bengal'' by Lal Behari Day. Her parents had traveled to Asia and also traveled with their eight children throughout Europe when she was a child, instilling in her a lifelong love of European and Asian culture. That love compelled her to continue her studies in Chinese Art at the Asia Institute, where she obtained her Masters degree and where she met her husband, Sayyid Abulquasim Khatami, from Isfahan, Iran, who became an anthropologist at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. It was an art book lent by Marie to Abul that brought them together. They were married on January 9, 1951 and raised their four children in Manhattan. Marie is survived by her husband, Abul, who lives in Manhattan, Marie Norton of Manhattan, Jim Khatami of San Francisco, Renee Khatami of Manhattan, Jessie K. Wallen of Del Mar, California, and proud grandmother of Christopher Khatami, Patrick Norton, Sophie and Emme MacArthur, and Johnnie and Jimmy Wallen, and her sister Eleanor Hoguet de Give of Newburyport, Massa chusetts. A memorial service will be announced. She interred at Most Holy Trinity Church Cemetery in Easthampton, NY.
Film Dave Kehr

COPPI BARBIERI They have a singular name, but Fabrizio Coppi and Lucilla Barbieri, who make up the Italian photography duo Coppi Barbieri, share a multitude of artistic influences. ''Paintings, art, science, reading, movies and traveling are constant sources of inspiration,'' Barbieri says. In ''Dream States'' (Page 230), the couple paid homage to the dark Roman Polanski film ''Repulsion'' (far left). ''There was a lot of black makeup in this season's shows, and the animals also seem to capture the sinister feel of the movie,'' Coppi says. There's nothing dark, however, about the couple's personal life: they live in London with their 4-year-old son, Lorenzo (center), and find beauty in nature and everyday things. They have recently been photographing vintage dresses and broken household objects (above). They source the latter from their own home, and, perhaps in the interest of teamwork, they point to one culprit: ''Nothing is broken intentionally, but it happens that we have quite a few subjects -- especially having Lorenzo around!''

CROCKER--Jane, on August 12, 2008, at home, in Atherton, California. She is survived by her loving and devoted sons, Scott and Garrett Jacobs, and two grandsons, Jaxon and Justin Jacobs. A celebration of her life will be held at a date to be determined in September. May she rest in peace.

To the Editor: ''Simmering at the End of the Line'' (Dispatches, Aug. 10), about the oppressive heat in the Lower East Side-Second Avenue subway station, calls attention to a perennial problem ironically made much worse by the air-conditioning of subway trains. This overheating makes it dangerous or impossible for many senior or disabled people to use the subways in hot or even warm weather.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''As Records Fall, Technology Muddies the Water,'' Aug. 11: As a former collegiate sprinter, I know that there have always been arguments about fast and slow pools, the advantage of body shaving before a race and changes in swimsuit technology. These things provide a minor technical benefit, but a major benefit to the brain by providing sensations that make one feel slicker and faster in the water.

REZNIKOFF--Eleanore Auerbacher. Loving daughter, sister, and deeply caring friend. An enormously charismatic lady of great warmth, class, and stature. New Yorkbased theater producer who worked with Tony Awardwinning actress Colleen Dewhurst at the Long Wharf in New Haven on their stage production of ''Rainsnakes,'' which she co-produced with producing partner Marita Lindholm-Gochman. She produced stage plays and special events for Lincoln Center, the Yale Repertory Theater, and Circle in the Square before relocating to Los Angeles to work in motion picture publicity, marketing, and advertising on numerous feature films including, ''Truth Or Dare,'' ''Affliction,'' ''G.I. Jane,'' ''A Brief History of Time,'' and ''One Hour Photo.'' She subsequently worked as a communications officer for the UCLA School of Arts and Architecture, promoting exhibitions of faculty and student works, and the installment of a major work by preeminent minimalist sculptor Richard Serra at the school's Eli and Edythe Broad Art Center. She was a graduate of the United States International University School of Performing Arts, San Diego. Surrounded by her tireless caregiver and sister, Julia Bergstrom, and longtime friends James Teel, Diane Fineo, and Harrison Reiner at the time of her August 9 passing at Cedars--Sinai in Los Angeles. She was 57. A flag on UCLA's main campus was flown at half-staff in her memory. Also survived by bereaved mother Mary Jane Auerbacher, sister Alice, niece and nephew, Katrina and Lukas Bergstrom. Beloved by all who knew her. Taken from us too soon. Memorial donations can be made to the Lange Foundation, an animal shelter, at 2106 South Sepulveda Boulevard, Los Angeles, California, 90025.

BOUDREAUX--Jonathan Jude, died at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan on August 11, 2008, after a three-and-a-half year war with acute myelogenous leukemia. He was 36. Jonathan was born and raised in Thibodaux, Louisiana. He attended Nicholls State University in Thibodaux, and received a Master's degree in Theatre from Louisiana Tech University in Ruston, Louisiana. He moved to New York City in the autumn of 1996. He joined the Box Office staff at The New Victory Theater in the early days of the ''new'' 42nd Street when shuttered porn shops still lined the street. He then served a brief tenure at the William Morris Agency before becoming Executive Assistant to the President of The Rolfe Company, a Manhattan-based agency representing theatrical designers. A walking encyclopedia of American popular culture, Jonathan founded and served as Editor-in-Chief and Managing Director of www.tvdvdreviews.com, one of the first Web sites dedicated to reviewing television productions released on DVD. The site, which earned a loyal following for its pithy and timely reviews, regularly receives upwards of 3,000 visitors a day. From the time of his diagnosis in February 2005 until his death, Jonathan met his cancer with characteristically fierce stubbornness, irreverent humor, black sarcasm, and an even-keeled, clear head. His tenacity-combined with the unyielding support of friends and family--enabled him to survive countless rounds of chemotherapy, two bone marrow transplants, two brain tumors, and a cord blood transplant. He left his family and friends after affirming on multiple occasions that be couldn't have been happier and more, content with the life he led and the adventures he shared. Jonathan Boudreaux is survived by his longtime partner and companion, Christopher W. Czajka; his parents, Gail C. and Ronnie Boudreaux of Thibodaux; his sister Jenise and brother-inlaw Brian Jennings, also of Thibodaux; his grandparents, Orena and ''Red'' Adams; and countless aunts, uncles, cousins, neighbors, and family friends in Louisiana. He is also survived by scores of friends in New York City and across the country. Particularly steadfast in their support of Jonathan throughout his disease have been his boss and good friend Mickey Rolfe, Nicole Roberts, Kelly Demaret, Marsha Drummond, Kerri Chyka, and Sam Buffer, all of New York; Duane and Barb Czajka and Billie Lape of Rochester, NY; Kay and Eamon Daly and Katie Heilman of Chicago, IL; Allison Dillon of Nashville, TN; Caroline and Colette LaGarde of Raceland, LA; and the staff of the Education Department at Thirteen/WNET. Jonathan will also be remembered and celebrated by a new generation of relatives and friends, including his nephew Draven Michael Jennings and young Norah Elizabeth Czajka and Ian Stuart Lape. At Jonathan's request, no memorial service or funeral will be held. His most ardent wish was for his family and friends to briefly mourn his passing, and then live their lives to their happiest and fullest potential. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the National Marrow Donor Program (www.marrow.org), which provides patients around the world with life-saving bone marrow, cord blood, and stem cell transplants. He will be sorely missed. BOUDREAUX--Jonathan J. Our clients join me in grieving Jonathan's death and in sending our deep respect and condolences to his partner, Chris; his parents Gail and Ronnie; and his sister, Jenise. Jonathan's three-and-a-half year battle with leukemia was a lesson in grace, dignity, and the complete absence of selfpity --one we'd give anything not to have had to learn this way. We are profoundly indebted to him for his diligence and wisdom. We'll remember him for his gallantry, his unfailing sense of humor, that smile, and his sheer cussedness. So much more than a colleague for nine years, he was like the kid brother I never had. Mickey Rolfe The Rolfe Company, Inc.

Even if they belong to an opposing political persuasion, residents of Denver and the Twin Cities have reason to welcome the presidential conventions to their areas. The conventions (Democrats will gather in Denver from Aug. 25 to 28 and Republicans in Minneapolis-St. Paul from Sept. 1 to 4) will provide a big infusion of business as tens of thousands of delegates, alternate delegates, officials, news media representatives and others stream into the host cities. Already, businesses are hard at work creating memorabilia -- from belt buckles to buttons to bonbons and beyond -- aimed at persuading the party faithful to take out their wallets.

EICHENBERG SINCLAIR-Joan, 77, of Baltimore, retired analyst and Wall Street pioneer, died July 22, 2008. Born in East Orange, NJ to Eugene and Mary Klebold Eichenberg, she graduated from Chestnut Hill College in Philadelphia and received her MBA at NYU. A highly respected analyst and researcher, Joan worked at Merrill Lynch, Clark Dodge, First Harlem Securities, and Adams Express Co. Joan loved bridge, tennis, golf, and needlepointing. Memorial Mass, St. Joseph's Parish, August 27, 2008 11am. Donations to Animal Rescue Inc., PO Box 35, Maryland Line, MD 21105. She is survived by her husband Hugh, brother Gene, stepson, niece, nephews and two step-grandchildren.
SEYMOUR--Mary Anderson, 90, of Lenox, MA, on August 14, 2008. Wife of the late Dr. Thomas C. Seymour. Mother of Charles and Jeffrey. Bates & Anderson: 518-828-3371.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. ''It's not a romantic smoky eye,'' said Pat McGrath, the beauty creative design director for Procter & Gamble, of her Lanvin smolder. ''It's a bold, architectural one, accented with luxurious chrome touches.'' 1. Concealer did double duty at Lanvin. Laura Mercier Secret Camouflage was used on lips and skin -- along with foundation and a light dusting of face powder. For a less theatrical look, Pat McGrath suggests swapping cover-up for a nude lipstick.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''NBC Is Broadcasting Live, Except When It Isn't,'' Aug. 11: As a resident of the San Francisco Bay area, I am aghast at NBC's insensitivity for not showing the Olympics live, period. It is not a matter of disclaimer or having live telecasts to the Eastern or Central time zones; it's a matter of respect to those who don't live in the East or the Midwest.

To the Editor: Thank you for publishing Stephen A. Scheer's photographs of Manhattanville (''The Last Picture Show,'' The City Visible, Aug. 10). Although shot only six years ago, in light of Columbia University's plan to expand in the area, already the images appear elegiac. As a frequent shopper at Fairway, on Broadway and 132nd Street, I find all the locations familiar and comforting. Harlem Bait and Tackle and the West Market Diner will be particularly missed.

I am studying Egyptian Arabic and planning a trip to Cairo this fall. I have the opportunity to combine a week's visit to Syria with my trip. Are the safety concerns or anti-American feelings so strong that I should not go? I am traveling as a single woman, 60, but am former Peace Corps, have traveled in Egypt and Jordan several times, speak the language somewhat and have the resources to afford good, safe hotels and guides. -- P. Austin, Washington

For Jarrod Shoemaker, one of the Americans in the quest for a medal in triathlon, a half-mile-long hill at the beginning of the bike course may define the winner: ''That really long, steep hill is going to kill a lot of people's legs and is probably going to make the difference in the race.'' Below, Shoemaker shares how he will approach the competition. THE THREE-COURSE CONTEST Men and women's races, 55 athletes in each competition.

Don't toss away your straw hat and summer clothes just yet. It's true that Labor Day is only two weeks away and beachgoers, mindful of the shorter days, are starting to panic. Some women have begun combining black with white as a bridge into fall. But the idea that summer clothes should be mothballed the day after Labor Day is a relic from another time. Today people dress for the weather. And the kids wear straw fedoras year round.

TALK SHOW For a performer, the contrast between the moments with the audience in front of you and the moments alone back in your hotel room -- whether at the Waldorf or a roach motel outside Minden, Neb. -- is stark. For the extremely neurotic performer, that contrast between ''on'' and ''off'' gets worse with time. Judy Garland did my old ABC morning show shortly before she died. (That tape is gone. It was reused to tape ''Let's Make a Deal.'' Trust me.) I think it was her last television appearance -- 1968.

CERRUTI--Marcial, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Marcial Cerruti. Dr. Cerruti was a Thoracic Surgeon in the department of surgery at Maimonides Medical Center for over 40 years. He was a great surgeon, a gentle man, well respected by all who knew him. He was involved with the first open heart surgery at Maimonides. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues, friends and patients. Sincere condolences are extended to his wife and family. W. Wexelman, M.D., Pres. S. Farber, M.D., Pres. Elect H. Wasserman, M.D., Sec. E. Fitzpatrick, M.D., Treas. CERRUTI--Marcial, M.D. Dr. Joseph Cunningham and the Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, New York, mourn the passing of our respected and esteemed colleague and admired educator. Dr. Cerruti guided and taught generations of faculty, residents and students in the art and science of cardiothoracic surgery. His knowledge, compassion, and dedication to his patients, his fellow surgeons and his residents were legendary. Dr. Cerruti was an Attending Surgeon in the Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center and Clinical Associate Professor at SUNY Downstate Health Science Center at Brooklyn. We all will remember Dr. Cerruti's many contributions to the world of cardiothoracic surgery. He was a source of wisdom and inspiration.

KORN--Dolores ''Dee'', passed away on August 10, 2008 at age 74. Devoted wife, beloved mother, cherished mother-in-law, grandmother, sister and friend. Dee enjoyed a respected career at Kelner & Kelner a Manhattan law firm, where she spent much of her tenure as office manager during the 1950s and 1960s. She ultimately retired to begin and raise her family. She is survived by her husband Arthur, children Ronni and Mitchell, son and daughter-in-law David and Karen, and grandchildren Zachary, Emily and Elizabeth. She will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of receiving her love, loyalty, and friendship.

The last time Troy Percival made news as a closer was 2004, and the last time a Tampa Bay closer was relevant was, well, never. But with Percival out for two to four weeks because of a knee injury that could require surgery, Grant Balfour, right, and Dan Wheeler will be in line for saves. Balfour entered Saturday with a 1.21 earned run average. Wheeler filled the role for a while last season. Kosuke Fukudome might have gotten the message. A few days after Cubs Manager Lou Piniella said he was considering moving Fukudome out of the No. 2 spot in the batting order, Fukudome put together consecutive 2-for-5 games. He was still batting .167 for August, and his average has dropped every month since he hit .305 in April. If Fukudome's funk continues, though, expect Mike Fontenot and Mark DeRosa to pick up at-bats.

FISHMAN--Elizabeth, 98, of Sarasota, Florida and New York City died August 10, 2008. Born in Miskolc, Hungary, emigrated to New York. She worked closely with dress designers Claire McCardell, Donald Brooks, Ole Borden. She and her husband Sam were activists for human rights and civil liberties. They supported the Hungarian-American cultural community and the veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. Elizabeth loved to cook, bake and garden. Survived by her dear sister Margaret and many loving nieces and nephews.

HOCHROTH--Stanley, July 12, 1930-August 14, 2008. Attorney and beloved advisor to family and friends, Stanley Hochroth of Hillsboro Beach, Florida passed away on Thursday, August 14th following a heart attack. A graduate of DeWitt Clinton, NYU and NY Law School, he practiced law in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. He is survived by his devoted wife, Judith, his brother, Alan, his three children: Lisa, Martin and John; four adoring grandchildren, Margot, Max, Alex and Jaden, in whose memory he lives on. A service will be held on August 25, 2008 from 1pm-2pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (at W. 91st St).

CONSTANTINER--Teodoro. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Teodoro Constantiner. A longtime benefactor of Tel Aviv University and a devoted friend of Israel, his philanthropy was grounded in the Constantiner-Sourasky family's passionate legacy of support for Jewish identity and continuity. Together with his four brothers, Teddy's generosity nurtured the growth of important institutions throughout Latin America and Israel, including the Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center and the university's esteemed Jaime and Joan Constantiner School of Education. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved brothers Roberto, Arturo, Victor and Leon, and to the entire Constantiner-Sourasky family. William F. Cohen, Chairman Roni Krinsky, President

THE NEWS At a crucial moment during the opening ceremonies at the Olympic Games in Beijing, Yang Peiyi, a 7-year-old girl, is heard singing a stirring patriotic song -- but the audience is shown Lin Miaoke, 9, instead. BEHIND THE NEWS High-level Communist Party officials wanted perfection, but thought their best singer, Yang Peiyi, had overly prominent front teeth, so producers played a recording of her rendition while the model-pretty Lin Miaoke was on camera, singing away but not being heard. Officials acknowledged the legerdemain a few days later; they also acknowledged using digital effects to ''enhance'' fireworks displays seen on TV during the ceremonies.

Orans Elsen Lupert & Brown ELSEN--Gerri S. Gerri studied at Sarah Lawrence College and MIT, and was an architecture student, a designer, an artist, a musician and an athlete. In her early 20s, she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, but was able to live a long, happy and productive life. She was a wonderful and loving wife, mother and grandmother, and a devoted friend. We thank the outstanding doctors, nurses and staff there who took care of her. We loved her deeply, and she will always be a part of us. Her husband Sheldon Her daughter Susan and son Jonathan Her son-in-law Charlie and daughter-in-law Ellen Her grandchildren: Michael, Daniel, Maggie, Benjamin and Rebecca. ELSEN--Gerri. Our friend for over 35 years. Your love of family, music, art, architecture and film is memorableyour indomitable spirit throughout your life is inspirational. Our heartfelt condolences to Sheldon, Susan, Jonathan, and their families. Roberta and Les Lupert

KYDD--Andrea V., was a community activist and organizer who served as the Director of the Health Program at the Nathan Cummings Foundation from 1989 to 2004. Ms. Kydd was admired for her uncensored and candid commentary, her strategic organizing and planning skills, and her strong vision. She died on Monday, August 11, 2008 in New York City. She was 63 and lived in a home in Brooklyn that has been in her family for three generations. Ms. Kydd began her career of public service as an organizer for the Brooklyn Welfare Action Council in the late 1960s. She held leadership positions at the National Welfare Rights Organization, the Queens College University Year for Action, the Southside Community Center, the Food Stamp Project of the Childrens Foundation, and the Mid-Atlantic Region for ACTION, an umbrella federal agency for VISTA and the Peace Corps. Ms. Kydd also served as the Executive Director of the Youth Project, a national organization that provided resources for 14 to 15 year-olds. As the first Director of the Nathan Cummings Foundations Health Program, Ms. Kydd supported the work of nonprofits concerned with mind/body wellness, quality of life issues at the beginning and end of life and patient and family centered care, as well as racial, ethnic and gender disparities in access to health care. Ms. Kydd believed that wealth and income were the real determinants of the quality of health care in the United States. Ms. Kydd used all of the knowledge that she acquired while working on health issues at the Foundation so that she might die as she lived -in charge. She was well informed about her options for treatment, and gave definitive orders about the quality and type of care that she wished to receive until she died. Andrea Kydd is survived by a sister, Janice Kydd, and numerous aunts, uncles, cousins, colleagues and friends.

SOLOMON--Herb. We will miss you deeply since you touched all of our lives with your generosity, kindness and compassion. With all our love, Debbie, Craig, Michael and Joshua. SOLOMON--Herb, of Jericho, NY. With profound sadness we announce the untimely passing of our beloved husband, father and grandfather on August 12, 2008. As the heart and soul of our family, he was our guiding light. His wisdom, integrity, compassion, grace, humor, humility and unassuming manner were only surpassed by his immeasurable love and devotion to each of us. He shared a lifetime with his true love which completed him in every way. His many significant professional accomplishments spanning more than half a century include senior leadership roles within the retailing and staffing industries. He was respected and admired for his professionalism, character and business acumen by all his colleagues and friends. Words cannot adequately express how much we will miss him but his legacy will carry on in all of our hearts forever. Survived by his loving wife Judy, devoted children Lloyd, Stephanie, Barbara, Sharon and his treasured grandchildren Andrew, Craig, Lauren, David, Michael, Emily, Allie, Josh, Jared, Jake and Kate. Services Sunday, August 17th, 11:30am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. SOLOMON--Herb. It is with profound sadness that Solomon Page Group, LLC shares the passing of Herb Solomon on August 12th. As a founder and ambassador for the SPG family over the last 18 years, Herb will be remembered for his grace, kindness and good will by everyone who knew him. As a professional, friend and perennial gentleman, he will be sincerely missed. SOLOMON--Herbert. The epitome of family and goodness. A genuinely great man who has blessed us and now, sadly, has left us. You touched our lives with your love, integrity and the selfless way you lived. You will remain forever in our hearts. With all our love, Scott, Steven and your loving grandchildren

Nobody here has seen that picture as offensive, just a funny gesture to show we feel Chinese because of the Olympics in Beijing.

VISITING THE PLAIN OF JARS, XIENG KHOUANG PROVINCE, Feb. 4, 2008 Jeremy Baldock, 41, an engineering geologist from Shipton-under-Wychwood, near Oxford, England. ''There are in excess of 2,000 stone jars located around the Plain of Jars plateau and surrounding mountains -- some weighing many tons. My fieldwork involved visiting the sites and also some rock outcrops which were thought to be possible quarries for the ancient jars. This photograph is taken at only the second approximately 2,000-year-old quarry I had been to. I thought, how did people 2,000 years ago carve these jars and then transport them three kilometers to the site that we see them today, through this thick jungle? I also wondered if there were any unexploded bombs in the vegetation. One misplaced machete swipe could kill everyone in the party. About an hour after this picture was taken, an unexploded cluster bomb was found in the undergrowth 20 meters away. Another time while I was there, they cleared the land surrounding a jar site so that it could be opened to the public and found 2,000 unexploded bombs, many just below the surface. This was an area on which the children of the village played, and over which the villagers walk to fetch water from the stream numerous times a day.'' As told to to J. R. Romanko

ROSENBLATT--Minna, a leading figure among the first generation of antiques dealers responsible for the 1950s revival of Tiffany lamps and French, Austrian and American art glass from the Art Nouveau period died August 2nd at her country home in Walker Valley, New York. A resident of New York City, she was 94 and died of natural causes. A Brooklyn native, born on June 29, 1914, Minna Gootnick graduated from Richmond Hill High School. Lying about her age to secure a job, Miss Gootnick began her career at sixteen as an underage temporary employee of Macy's at Herald's Square during the 1930 Christmas season. She exhibited such an uncanny aptitude as a salesperson that the position quickly became a permanent one. While there Miss Gootnick spent all of her free time on the eighth floor in the Fine Glass and China department, enthralled by the objects on display. Seven years later she left Macy's to marry Saul Levy and raise a family. Mrs. Rosenblatt held a number of jobs during and after World War II to help support her then husband and two young sons. Mr. Levy died in 1947. Her love of antique glass resurfaced with her subsequent marriage one year later to Sidney Rosenblatt, a nationally renowned and award-winning journalist at Parade Magazine. With Sidney's encouragement, she began dealing antiques from the basement of their modest home on Stuart Street in Brooklyn. Most of these pieces were obtained for friends and neighbors and were purchased from local shops, flea markets, and even the Salvation Army. From those humble beginnings came her first storefront on Flatbush Avenue. As collectors recognized her discerning eye, extraordinary expertise, willingness to share her knowledge, and sound advice, the business grew and led to the establishment of a series of galleries on Madison Avenue. Mrs. Rosenblatt, together with Lillian Nassau, Maude Feld, Bea Weiss and Gladys Koch, are largely credited with restoring Louis Comfort Tiffany's artistic and commercial reputation. Arlie Sulka, current owner of Lillian Nassau LLC, recently said of Mrs. Rosenblatt, that she was ''one of the original 'Tiffany Girls' who helped create the market and the interest that exists today.'' Mrs. Rosenblatt's international clientele ran the gamut from leaders of industry to prominent figures in the fields of entertainment and politics, including the likes of Walter P. Chrysler, Jr., David Geffen, and Barbra Streisand. The near 50-year career of Mrs. Rosenblatt culminated in 2003, at which time Christie's auction house held a landmark sale of the remaining art objects from the gallery. A year or two earlier, Fordham University honored her and her husband's philanthropic and academic contributions by re-naming one of its institutions, generously supported by the couple, The Sidney and Minna Rosenblatt Holocaust Library. The facility is considered one of the top 25 libraries of its kind in the world. In addition to Mr. Levy, Minna Rosenblatt is predeceased by her second husband, Sidney Rosenblatt and by her son Joshua. Survivors include her sons George Rosenblatt of Walker Valley, New York and Daniel Rosenblatt of San Carlos, California, her sister Rose Levine of Brooklyn, New York, her brother Seymour Gootnick of Plainview Long Island, six grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

THE 1958 movie ''Thunder Road'' was on again the other night: Robert Mitchum running moonshine against some of the clumsiest rear-projection car chases ever. Mitchum drives a 1950 and a 1957 Ford in the film, recalling the starring role the Ford V-8 once played in American crime. The V-8 is cited in Bryan Burrough's 2005 book ''Public Enemies,'' which I picked up in paperback a few days after seeing ''Thunder Road'' again.

FLYNN--Arthur E., 73, died Thursday, August 14, in Bay Head, New Jersey. Flynn was born and raised in Boston, MA, and graduated from Boston College. Flynn attended US Naval OCS to become a lieutenant serving active duty for three years. Flynn moved to NYC to join prestigious firms on Wall Street, where he found great success as a private investor, before retiring in 2000. He was predeceased by his brother, Nicholas Flynn, earlier this spring. He is survived by his two daughters, Tracy Kennedy Flynn of San Francisco, CA, and Kerry Kennedy Flynn of Nantucket, MA, and he was ''Pops'' to Giang Flynn, and many beloved Flynns. Visitation will be from 4-8pm, Sunday at the Van Hise & Callagan Funeral Home, 812 Arnold Avenue, Point Pleasant Beach, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be offered at 10am, Monday at Sacred Heart Church, Bay Head, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the Fresh Air Fund, Freshair.org would be greatly appreciated.

Jack died peacefully at home in New York City on Friday, August 15, 2008. Beloved husband of Maureen Meehan O'Leary, he is survived by Tad Sennott, his wife Jennifer Kellogg and their twins, Ronan and Huxley. Son of Marie and Joseph O'Leary, Jack is survived by his sister Kathleen M. Kelly, brother Michael O'Leary and seventeen nieces and nephews. His brothers Joe, Bill and Walter predeceased him. A graduate of St. Joseph's Seminary Dunwoodie, he was ordained a priest in 1954 in the Archdiocese of New York and served at St. John the Baptist Parish in Yonkers, Bishop Dubois High School in Harlem and as a prison chaplain at the Manhattan Detention Complex (the Tombs). Later he was appointed Pastor of St. Joseph's Parish in Greenwich Village and then St. Monica's Parish in Yorkville. Since 1992 he has been Executive Director of the William and Miriam Meehan Charitable Foundation, and served on the board of East End Hospice. Jack loved their home in East Hampton. Friends may visit at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday, August 19th, 58pm. LAST Monday, hydrogen-powered vehicles from eight manufacturers drove off from Portland, Me., to start a 13-day cross-country tour that will end in Los Angeles on Aug. 23. The tour will make 31 stops in 18 states along the way, in an effort to convince Americans that hydrogen really is the fuel of the future (even if it really isn't a fuel, but an energy carrier). The 2008 Hydrogen Road Tour includes technologies like the Honda FCX Clarity fuel-cell sedan, which has a 280-mile range on four kilograms of hydrogen -- the energy equivalent of four gallons of gasoline -- and the BMW Hydrogen 7, a luxury sedan that stores its hydrogen as a super-cold liquid and burns it in a V-12 piston engine.

Q. Your desk is always a mess. How can this be, when you do most of your work on the computer? A. Some people need to hold information in their hands and write things down to think and work, said Julie Morgenstern, a productivity consultant based in New York. That's the way their brains work, she said. The computer hasn't changed that; in fact, it has brought more paper than ever to many offices by allowing people to make printouts.
