HELLER--Daniel Neal, 83, on August 3. Known for his quick wit, unfailing integrity and grit. ''Unstoppable'' in the courtroom. Nationally known as ''The Man Who Beat the IRS.'' Brooklyn born, attended Princeton and Cornell before graduating from NYU, then Harvard Law. Lauded as a ''winner'' by Time magazine. Defender of constitutional rights, won the first ''Government in the Sunshine'' case. Former GC to The Miami News, National Commander Jewish War Veterans, an observer at the Eichmann and Frankfurt war crimes trials, and White House invitee. Provided free legal aid to SCLC under Martin Luther King, Jr. Organized brotherhood rally to support Vietnam vets, which Francis Cardinal Spellman called ''his proudest moment.'' Guest of French Government at 20th anniversary of D-Day, obtained first public plea from Pope Paul VI to allow Russian Jews to emigrate. A 33 degree Mason; Vice Chair, Concert Assn of FL; Past President, FL Harvard Law School Assn; Founder, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Miami Beach. Married 55 years to love of his life, Diane, with whom supported Miami's Lowe Art Museum, Concert Assn of FL, FL Grand Opera, New World Symphony and many other arts and Jewish causes. Survived by Diane, children Lisa, Mona, Douglas, Brian and nine grandchildren.

STEP off the elevated subway at the center of Manhattanville and you may wonder if there's really a there there. The view from the station above 125th Street and Broadway can be disorienting: no little shops and bodegas to say, ''This is it.'' What you see instead are warehouses, bus depots and factories, as well as unmarked towers and a crosshatch of diagonal streets more reminiscent of the West Village. Yet there's something slightly magical about the way hills rise up around the area. A recent group exhibition of photographs dedicated to Manhattanville characterized its haunting mix of low-lying back streets, vaulted overpasses, vintage churches and riverfront as ''strange, unresolved or unsettling.'' No wonder few people agree on its future -- or even, for that matter, whether it exists in the first place. ''I've considered the whole area Harlem,'' said Sarah Martin, who has lived in the Grant Houses complex in Manhattanville since 1957, voicing the dismissive sentiment of some longtime residents.

WOOD--John Meyer, Jr. John Wood, a nationally recognized figure in investment-counseling, died of natural causes at Falmouth by the Sea in Falmouth, Maine. He was 83 years old. Born in New York City to Marion Peters Wood and John M. Wood Sr., he attended the Collegiate School and Harvard University. A member of the Porcelain Club, he enrolled in ROTC and joined the Navy where he served as an officer on the USS Sakatonchee (AOG-19, a Mettawee class gasoline tanker). Though the ship and crew were cited for three battle stars for service in the Pacific, John downplayed their role saying they were often overlooked as a target because the enemy ''didn't want to waste their ammunition.'' After the war, John attended Harvard Business School and graduated at the top of his class. He married Virginia (Chris) Cabot and joined the investment firm of Standish Ayer and McKay as a security analyst. He became a partner in 1952 and in 1965 became President of the firm, moving to Chairman of the board in 1978 wherein the firm's name was changed to Standish Ayer and Wood. He retired in 1989 shuttling between residences in Stowe, VT and Beaufort, SC. In addition to his duties at Standish, John served on numerous Boards including the New England Medical Center, Tufts University and as President of the Investment Council Association. He also participated in local town boards and politics, serving on the Medway Finance Committee and town Republican Party. John is fondly remembered as a strong leader and mentor to his colleagues. ''He always gave us enough rope to make our own mistakes, but never enough to hang ourselves,'' recalls Ted Ladd, current Chairman at Standish. John had a deep love of the sea, especially the Maine coast and Penobscot Bay in particular. As a boy, he summered in Islesboro where his father, ''the Captain'' allowed John and his brother Clayton (Archie) free rein to sail the Bay in a various assortment of boats of questionable seaworthiness. John was also an accomplished woodworker; several of his earlier boats were handcrafted in his barn in Medway, MA. He raced them with passion at the Sherborn, MA Yacht Club on Farm Pond, the location where the family lived for many years after Medway. John is survived by his wife Chris, sister Wendy living in Chaplin, CT, son John (Jay) M. in Falmouth, ME, and daughters, Susan C. of Marion, MA, Dr. Amy P. of Georgetown, ME, Virginia (Whistle) C. of Groton and five grandchildren, Meghan, Christopher, Tory, Courtney, and Max scattered around the globe. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his memory to the charity of your choice. Plans for a memorial service are forth coming.

Introduction: The wrinkle relaxer Botox, which contains the deadly neurotoxin botulinum toxin type A, is supposed to stay where you put it. But last April, Italian researchers reported in the Journal of Neuroscience that when they injected the toxin into rats' muzzles, it migrated to their brain stems; when injected directly into one hemisphere of the brain, signs of it manifested in the other as well. News outlets from perezhilton.com to Newsweek were quick to warn us against paralyzing our gray matter in pursuit of uncorrugated skin. But

WHAT will be the ripple effects of Russia's invasion of Georgia? For the former Soviet republics, Moscow has been the default power. Even among those that have tried to get nearer to the West -- like Georgia, Ukraine and the Baltic nations -- the Russian shadow is long. On its side is proximity, size, economic and political power, and links left over from many decades of living under a single national roof.

ROYSTER--Thomas Sampson, Jr., M.D. Beloved husband of Caroline (Linn) Henry Royster. Loving father of Thomas S. III, Elspeth R. Holch, John Snowden and Stephen Brooke. Also survived by sister, Helen R. Peck, five grandchildren and five great - grandchildren. Born December 22, 1918, St. Croix Virgin Islands. Died August 4, 2008, Duke University Hospital, Durham, NC. A graduate of the University of NC, University of PA Medical School. Received his surgical training at the Roosevelt Hospital, New York City. Captain U.S. Army Medical Corps. Practiced general surgery for 12 years in Henderson, NC. Held a fellowship with Dr. Michael DeBakey, Houston, TX and returned to Roosevelt where he spent the rest of his medical career. His happiest years in practice were at Roosevelt where later he was a Trustee and an Honorary Trustee of the St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Board. He was an accomplished, caring, surgeon and teacher. After retiring to Vero Beach, golf played a large part of his life. He was an excellent golfer. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. There will be a family graveside service at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to Roosevelt Hospital Development Dept., 555 W. 57th Street, New York, New York 10019.

PASAROW--Claire. Born August 26, 1918, New York City, New York. Died August 13, 2008, Beverly Hills, California. Claire was the matriarch of the Pasarow Family for the last generation. She reigned with an even and steady hand over a clan of four children, thirteen grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, Robert Jack Pasarow, and her son of 54 years, Jay David Pasarow. During the time she lived, the world as we know it changed dramatically. Throughout and during her life she became an accomplished artist, a successful businesswoman, and a philanthropist. She was indeed a true renaissance woman of the 20th and 21st centuries. Above all else, she loved her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren and will be very much missed by us all. She is gone from this earthly existence but will never be forgotten.

Tony Perrottet, the author of "The Naked Olympics: The True Story of the Ancient Greek Games," has a new book called "Napoleon's Privates: 2,500 Years of History Unzipped." It's devoted to "juicy" tales that somehow never made it into our history textbooks; the chapter titles include "Holding Your Own at Caligula's Orgies," "Who Didn't Have Syphilis in Belle Époque Paris?" and "Columbus Discovers the Clitoris." This particular Columbus (Renaldus) was a 16th-century Italian anatomist who, in fact, seems to have been beaten to the discovery of the clitoris by the ancient Greek physician Galen. None of which explains why, centuries later, men are still searching for it.

Southern California left guard Jeff Byers is an academic All-American candidate who is on the watch list for the Outland Trophy. He started 13 games last season and is in his second year in U.S.C.'s Marshall M.B.A. program. He talked with Thayer Evans recently about his enjoyment of bowling, the Trojans' quarterback situation and his recent run-in with Rocky Mountain spotted fever.

Teenagers have the highest car crash and fatality rates of any demographic group, partly because they woefully underestimate driving risks. Injury prevention programs can change their perspective, a new study shows -- at least for a while.

Only a few months ago, most Poles opposed the installation of an American missile defense in their country. Today, a majority supports the plan, which was given a go-ahead last week. John S. Micgiel, the director of the East Central European Center and executive director of the European Institute at Columbia University, explains why the shift in public opinion started before the Russians moved into Georgia.

One of the odd things about shooting Minis (as those of us who work on them usually call "The Minimalist" columns) for The Times web videos is that, for a host of very good reasons, we schedule a bunch in advance and do them all at once. That means that in mid-August, we were shooting what you might call November food. (Things are even stranger at magazines, where in mid-August they're working on Christmas or even mid-winter food.)

Bidding for Reed Elsevier's trade magazine unit is moving into the second round, with a slew of private equity firms keen on the asset, according to press reports. If we have learned anything from this unrelenting credit mess, The New York Times' Gretchen Morgenson writes in her weekly column, it is that greater disclosure is needed if investors are to regain their trust in the financial system. The news of Liu Xiang's sudden, stunning exit from the Olympics early Monday, before he had a chance to hurl himself across a single hurdle, certainly ranks among the biggest disappointments of the Beijing Games. Not only for Liu, who must certainly have felt the crushing expectations of the host nation as he limped toward the Games on a bad leg. And not only to his supporters in China, who almost certainly number in the hundreds of millions.

Jesús Sauceda of Matamoros, Mexico, pitched the fifth perfect game in Little League World Series history and the first since 1979 after he struck out all 12 batters in a 12-0 win over Emilia, Italy, in South Williamsport, Pa. The game went four innings instead of the usual six because of Little League’s 10-run mercy rule. Sauceda also starred at the plate, going 3 for 3 with six runs batted in, including a grand slam in the third.

The Philadelphia 76ers re-signed forward Andre Iguodala on Sunday to a six-year contract worth a reported $80 million. Iguodala, who was a restricted free agent, helped the 76ers reach the playoffs last season for the first time in three years. An official announcement is expected Monday.

One week, only one week left before the first European Grand Prix in Valencia, and Formula One personnel and media are still on the so-called summer break. I'll be in Valencia, and I'm looking forward to it. But for the moment, I've been taking advantage of the F1 summer break of 3 weeks between the races in order to do a whirlwind tour of family and friends in North America. So occupied have I been that I have not even thought about anything other than the highway and the friends and family. A dance column on Thursday about some works at the New York International Fringe Festival misstated the given name of the director of “The Third From the Left,” a play about the Martha Graham dance troupe. He is Jon Lawrence Rivera, not Joe.

A soccer report in the Sports Briefing column on Tuesday about the resignation of Coach Ruud Gullit of the struggling Los Angeles Galaxy gave an outdated record for the team and for the number of appearances by its biggest star, David Beckham. At the time of the report, the team had won 6 of its first 19 games — not 9 of its first 30, which was its total for 2007. And Beckham had played in 18 games — not “only five games because of injuries,” which was also a statistic from last year.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the possibility of changes to the Mets’ pitching staff misstated the statistics for Jon Niese, a minor league prospect in the organization. At the time of the report, he was 3-1 with a 3.12 earned run average at Class AAA New Orleans — not 6-7 with a 3.04 E.R.A., which were his earlier statistics at Class AA Binghamton.

An article on Wednesday about the rough debut for Charlie Zink, a rookie knuckleball pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, misspelled the surname of a knuckleballer from the 1930s and ’40s, when such pitchers were not as rare. He was Johnny Niggeling, not Niggling. (The error also appeared in an article in March 1984 about a catcher who played with Niggeling. That mistake was discovered during research for this correction.).

A Reporter’s Notebook article last Monday about Senator John McCain’s campaign misstated a distinction he will hold if he is elected president in November. Mr. McCain, who turns 72 on Aug. 29, would be the oldest person elected to a first term — not the oldest person ever elected to the presidency. (Ronald Reagan was 73 when he was elected to his second term as president, in November 1984.).

An article on Wednesday about a ruling by the Nevada Equal Rights Commission that a health club discriminated by charging men more for membership than women misstated the position that the American Civil Liberties Union of Nevada has taken on the issue. Although the group indeed agreed with one assessment that price differences based on sex were a lawful business strategy under current statute, the union does not believe that such practices should be legal, and has in fact sought to change the statute.

An article on Wednesday about Representative Charles B. Rangel’s announcement that he had helped preserve almost 400 federally subsidized apartments in Harlem misstated the given name of a state assemblyman who appeared with Mr. Rangel at a news conference. He is Keith L. T. Wright, not Kevin.

The Drilling Down column on Aug. 4, about the continuing popularity of Sunday newspaper coupons, referred incorrectly to the households that were part of a survey of how consumers use coupons. They were households that used grocery coupons at least weekly — not households that used any type of coupon at any given time.

An article in some editions last Monday about the ordeal of a Queens man, Yaghoub Khezri, 86, who spent four years in Iranian custody after returning to his native country to claim property, and was expected to return to New York soon, misstated the State Department’s role in the case. A documentary filmmaker helped Mr. Khezri secure passage to Switzerland, and the State Department is helping him return to the United States. The department did not help him leave Iran, however. (As of Sunday, he still had not arrived in the United States.).

HOCHROTH--Stanley, July 12, 1930-August 14, 2008. Attorney and beloved advisor to family and friends, Stanley Hochroth of Hillsboro Beach, Florida passed away on Thursday, August 14th following a heart attack. A graduate of DeWitt Clinton, NYU and NY Law School, he practiced law in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. He is survived by his devoted wife, Judith, his brother, Alan, his three children: Lisa, Martin and John; four adoring grandchildren, Margot, Max, Alex and Jaden, in whose memory he lives on. A service will be held on August 25, 2008 from 1pm-2pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (at W. 91st St).

FLYNN--Arthur E., 73, died Thursday, August 14, in Bay Head, New Jersey. Flynn was born and raised in Boston, MA, and graduated from Boston College. Flynn attended US Naval OCS to become a lieutenant serving active duty for three years. Flynn moved to NYC to join prestigious firms on Wall Street, where he found great success as a private investor, before retiring in 2000. He was predeceased by his brother, Nicholas Flynn, earlier this spring. He is survived by his two daughters, Tracy Kennedy Flynn of San Francisco, CA, and Kerry Kennedy Flynn of Nantucket, MA, and he was ''Pops'' to Giang Flynn, and many beloved Flynns. Visitation will be from 4-8pm, Sunday at the Van Hise & Callagan Funeral Home, 812 Arnold Avenue, Point Pleasant Beach, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be offered at 10am, Monday at Sacred Heart Church, Bay Head, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the Fresh Air Fund, Freshair.org would be greatly appreciated.

In the Robert Aldrich film ''Attack'' (1956) at 11 a.m., Mr. Palance, above, plays a lieutenant who must confront his cowardly captain in Belgium during World War II. ''Shane,'' for which Mr. Palance was nominated for an Oscar, is not in the day's lineup, but three other westerns with Mr. Palance are: ''Monte Walsh'' (1970) at 10 p.m., ''The Professionals'' (1966) at midnight and ''The Mercenary'' at 2 a.m. Tuesday.

ELSEN--Gerri S. Gerri studied at Sarah Lawrence College and MIT, and was an architecture student, a designer, an artist, a musician and an athlete. In her early 20s, she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, but was able to live a long, happy and productive life. She was a wonderful and loving wife, mother and grandmother, and a devoted friend. She was generous, kind, and great fun to be with. Over the 4th of July weekend, she had a bad fall on Martha's Vineyard, and was flown to Massachusetts General Hospital, were she died on Friday, August 15. We thank the outstanding doctors, nurses and staff there who took care of her. We loved her deeply, and she will always be a part of us. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 19 at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), New York, NY. Burial will follow at The Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY Shivah will be at 50 Fenimore Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can made to the Multiple Sclerosis Research Center of New York, 521 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10019. Her husband Sheldon Her daughter Susan and son Jonathan Her son-in-law Charlie and daughter-in-law Ellen Her grandchildren: Michael, Daniel, Maggie, Benjamin and Rebecca.

Even without its 2006 purchase of YouTube and its 2004 purchase of Picasa, Google has made substantial inroads into several online categories. Google Maps, above showing Miami Beach in satellite view, had a 31 percent share in July, compared with 46 percent for Mapquest, the maps category leader that preceded it online by nine years. (Google Earth, with a 1.8 percent share, is also in the maps category.) Blogger is second to MySpace Blog, which has a 22.4 percent share, but its share is double that of LiveJournal, No. 3 in the blogs/personal category, at 3.4 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

PASAROW--Claire. Born August 26, 1918, New York City, New York. Died August 13, 2008, Beverly Hills, California. Claire was the matriarch of the Pasarow Family for the last generation. She reigned with an even and steady hand over a clan of four children, thirteen grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. She survived her husband of 62 years, Robert Jack Pasarow, and her son of 54 years, Jay David Pasarow. During the time she lived, the world as we know it changed dramatically. Throughout and during her life she became an accomplished artist, a successful businesswoman, and a philanthropist. She was indeed a true renaissance woman of the 20th and 21st centuries. Above all else, she loved her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren and will be very much missed by us all. She is gone from this earthly existence but will never be forgotten.

Senator Barack Obama and the billionaire Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens met for a few minutes on Sunday in Reno, Nev., to talk about energy and the economy. Aides did not share the details of the meeting, but Mr. Obama, the presumptive Democratic nominee, took one question from a reporter, who wanted to know why he was meeting with the man who spent $3 million supporting the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth campaign against Senator John Kerry, the Democrats' nominee in 2004.

BOUDREAUX--Jonathan J. Our clients join me in grieving Jonathan's death and in sending our deep respect and condolences to his partner, Chris; his parents Gail and Ronnie; and his sister, Jenise. Jonathan's three-and-a-half year battle with leukemia was a lesson in grace, dignity, and the complete absence of selfpity --one we'd give anything not to have had to learn this way. We are profoundly indebted to him for his diligence and wisdom. We'll remember him for his gallantry, his unfailing sense of humor, that smile, and his sheer cussedness. So much more than a colleague for nine years, he was like the kid brother I never had. Mickey Rolfe The Rolfe Company, Inc.

After a five-decade history marked by more than its share of wars, coups, assassinations, terrorism and political, ethnic and sectarian strife, Pakistan would seem not to be a place where a departing president, especially one driven from office by threats of impeachment, could expect to glide placidly into a senior statesman's retirement at home. Generally under such circumstances, you'd expect the departing leader to be halfway to the airport before the ink on the resignation letter was dry, headed abroad for good with relatives and loyal retainers scurrying in tow.

Fay in Florida didn't quite make it to official hurricane status - which requires sustained wind speeds of at least 74 miles per hour- and that's just as well. Since 1900, Florida has been struck, on average, by a hurricane every two years. Category 3, 4 or 5 storms strike the state every four years, on average. The last big storm to come ashore was Hurricane Wilma in October 2005. Wilma, a Category 3 hurricane when it made landfall in Florida, produced more than $10 billion in insured losses from some one million claims.

There is a way to take the trepidation out of preparing ceviche, the Central and South American dish in which fish is ''cooked'' by marinating it in an acidic dressing: Cook the fish first. Calling this preparation ceviche is obviously akin to ''seared steak tartare,'' but so what? No one is likely to be able to tell that the fish was cooked with heat rather than acid.

An article on Saturday about a book of Hollywood photographs paired with prose poems by Bob Dylan misidentified the location of one of the photographs. A picture of a woman bending over handprints left in cement by Sophia Loren was taken in the courtyard of Grauman’s Chinese Theater, not along the Walk of Fame. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

An article last Tuesday about the ways in which Cubans view the American base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, misstated the background of the detainees who are held there. They were captured for their suspected roles in the war in Afghanistan or as part of what the United States calls its “war on terror”; they were not taken there from Iraq.

The Advertising column on Monday, about films and television series that drew on the advertising business, misspelled the given name of the actor who played Clark Gable’s boss in the 1947 film “The Hucksters.” He was Adolphe Menjou, not Adolph.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about NBC’s ratings during the Olympic Games referred incorrectly in two references to the organization that the network negotiated with for live prime-time broadcasts of some major events. It was the International Olympic Committee, not the Beijing organizing committee or the Chinese Olympic committee.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a controversial plan to play the “Pomp and Circumstance” March No. 1 without vibrato on the Last Night of the Proms music festival in Britain misidentified the conductor who led the festival’s final performance last year. He is Jiri Belohlavek — not Mark Elder, who conducted the Last Night of the Proms in 2006.
A capsule summary on Saturday for an article about the new horror film “Mirrors” misspelled the given name of one of the stars. He is Kiefer Sutherland, not Keifer.

An article on Saturday about new images of Enceladus, a moon of Saturn, misstated the speed at which the Cassini spacecraft flew by the moon. Cassini was traveling at about 40,000 miles an hour, not 64,000. (It was flying at 64,000 kilometers per hour.).

An article on Monday about Iran’s test of a new rocket capable of carrying a satellite into orbit misstated the name of the missile. It is known as the Ambassador of Hope, not the Ambassador of Peace.

An article on Friday about Japan’s import of Chinese laborers to do farmwork in the rural community of Kawakami because of a shortage of domestic help misidentified a resident who said, “I feel this is not Japan anymore.” He is Toshimitsu Yui, not Shimitsu Yuito.

STEINBERG--Solomon, 92, died on July 8, 2008 in Austin, Texas. Born in 1915 in New York, NY, he retired in 1980 after a 44-year career with the New York Times. He attended DeWitt Clinton High School, City College of New York, and New York University. Rather than pursue a career as a harmonica player on Vaudeville, he got a job at the Times, working his way up from switchboard operator and copy boy, to chemist and purchasing manager. In World War II, he was a sergeant in Company B in the 82nd Chemical Mortar Battalion. Following the war, he returned to the Times where he troubleshooted production problems and did research on ink and newsprint. In the early 1960s, he patented an invention that measured the amount of newsprint used on a press. In 1980, Sol retired to Austin with his wife, Elsie, and son, Richard. He was an active member of Austin's garden club community, member of the Lion's Club, an avid bridge player, a member for more than 50 years in the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry, member of the Congregation Beth Israel Brotherhood, and an accredited judge for the Men's Garden Clubs of America.

6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: BARBARA STANWYCKA daylong tribute to Stanwyck, beginning with ''Barbara Stanwyck: Fire and Desire,'' a 1991 documentary profile narrated by Sally Field. Stanwyck, who died in 1990, often played the seductress on screen. In ''Baby Face'' (1933), at 3:15 p.m., she stars as a conniving vixen who sleeps her way to the top of a banking empire. ''A Bride Walks Out,'' at 4:45 p.m., is the story of a model and a struggling engineer (Gene Raymond, with Stanwyck above) who marry and then struggle with domesticity. And in ''The File on Thelma Jordon'' (1950), at 9:30 p.m., she ensnares an assistant district attorney. 5 P.M. (History) HITLER'S FAMILY ''To put it colloquially,'' says the head of forensic medicine at the University of Munich after examining the medical records of Hitler's kin, ''the family had a screw loose.'' The researchers interviewed on the program say there was a history of mental illness in Hitler's family that the dictator tried to conceal. According to the researchers, Aloisia Veit, Hitler's second cousin, was murdered in the gas chamber of a Nazi mental hospital.

BERKOWITZ--Seymour Roy passed away on Friday, August 15, 2008. He was 82 years old. Raised in the Bronx, he attended James Monroe High School, before volunteering to serve in WWII as a pharmacist's mate attached to the 2nd Marine Division. He saw active duty in the Pacific and was part of the occupation forces in Nagasaki, Japan. Sy attended the Parsons School of Art & Design and graduated from NYU. He worked in the advertising business, and owned a studio called Donato & Berkley, Inc. Sy was one of the original ''Mad Men,'' (although he suffered none of Don Draper's angst). He was a member of the Art Directors Club and the Society of Illustrators. He traveled the world, was an avid photographer, gardener, loved music and dancing, and was an accomplished painter. Sy and his wife, Lorraine, were denizens of Manhattan culture. Sy was a loving husband, father, grandfather, friend and mentor to many in his field. He is survived by his children, Lynn and Brad Mintz, Ted and Heidi Berkowitz, Lisa and Lev Herrnson, and grandchildren, Sara, Sam, Greg, Alana and Jesse.

HYMAN--Michael A. The staff of Boulevard-Riverside Chapels and its affiliates extend our heartfelt sympathy to Arleen and the Hyman family on the loss of Michael. Michael was our longtime associate and dear friend for over 40 years. May they know of no more sorrow for many years to come. Stanley Misikoff, Martin Kasdan, Lewis Smith and David Alpert

MARMION--Dr. Harry A., 77, died August 14, 2008. Marmion attended LaSalle Academy in NYC and Fairfield University. He served in the Marine Corps as an infantry officer in Japan and in the Marine Corps Reserve for 26 years, retiring as a Colonel. Marmion was president of St. Xavier College in Chicago and Southampton College of Long Island University and vice president for academic affairs at Fairleigh Dickinson University. Marmion was president of the Eastern Tennis Association and was named the United States Tennis Association's 43rd president and chairman of the board. He authored two books, ''The Case Against a Volunteer Army'' and ''Selective Service: Conflict and Compromise''. He leaves his wife of 54 years, Patricia; three daughters and sons-inlaw; Elizabeth and Tierney Carlos, Sarah and Bruce Zabriski, and Sheila and Don Breakell; and nine grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to the Harry A. Marmion Scholarship Fund at LaSalle Academy by visiting www.Lasalleacademy.org or LaSalle Academy, 44 East 2nd Street, NY, NY 10003. To express condolences, friends are encouraged to visit www.nelsenfh.com. Following a funeral mass at St. Bede's Catholic Church in Williamsburg, VA, a memorial service is planned for the fall in Southampton, NY.

JEWETT--Thomas Hardin. August 14, 2008. A devoted husband and son, a patient, generous father who never failed the people he loved, Tom was a true Southern gentleman. Born in Wilmington, North Carolina, July 4, 1922, he grew up in Winston Salem. After two years in the infantry during WWII, he returned to graduate from the University of North Carolina in 1947. He joined the newly formed Coca Cola Export Corporation in July 1947, retiring as Assistant Treasurer of the Coca Cola Corporation and Senior Vice President and Treasurer of the Coca Cola Finance Corporation in 1984. During his years at Coke, Tom worked in Hawaii, Manila, Japan, New York, Nassau, Buenos Aires and Atlanta. After retirement, he taught at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Virginia. At the time of his death he lived at Fearrington Village in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. He will be missed and remembered by Jean Curtin Jewett, his wife of 61 years; his six children: Kelleher, Curt (Maria), Robert (Amy), Susan (Marsha), Leslie (Patrick) and David (Paula); and nine grandchildren (Valerie Jewett, Beth Toriello, Tom and Joe Jewett, Patty, Danny, Andrew, Sarah, and Emma Paddon). ''Love has no ending.'' A service will be held at 11:00 on August 30 in the Chapel of the Cross on the campus of the University of North Carolina. Friends and family are invited to the service and to join the family at home afterwards.

MINKIN--Vera, passed away on August 7th, 2008 at the age of 93. She was an independent woman ahead of the times. Formerly the registrar at Newark State College (Keane University). Dean of students at Bronx Community College. Her humor, intelligence and love will be missed by her extended family and many friends.

SEIFE--Irwin, M.D., 80, of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Binghamton, NY and Denver, CO, passed away on August 13, 2008. Beloved husband of Rae Seife. Loving father of Deborah Seife (Jonathan Sands) and Jeffrey (Alane) Seife. Loving grandfather of Jacob and Isabel. A gifted radiologist devoted to his patients and community for 45 years. He served as chief radiologist at Binghamton General Hospital and Rose Medical Center (Denver, CO). He also served as the head of CedarSinai Medical Center's women's imaging center (Los Angeles, CA) and was responsible for Blake Hospital's (Bradenton, FL) outpatient radiology unit for several years.

SAVIDGE--Patricia of Brooklyn and Shelter Island, died Sunday August 17, 2008. Born Patricia Gauvin Anderson, November 1st, 1916. Father Dr. Robert Burns Anderson, Mother Dorothy Gauvin Anderson. Beloved wife of the late Richard E. Savidge. Attend Packer Collegiate Institute, Dana Hall, Smith College and the Sorbonne. As a young woman, she performed with the Schubert production of The Student Prince and the Papermill Playhouse. She also played the Queen of Sheba with Ringling Brothers Circus. She later pursued a long career as a real estate broker in Brooklyn Heights, subsequently she retired to Shelter Island Heights. Loving mother to John and Clinton. She left five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Donations in her memory may be made to The American Heart Association, The National Alzheimer's Foundation and NYU Hospital. Services St. Mary's Church, Shelter Island at 1pm Wednesday.

HOROWITZ--Stanley B. United Jewish Communities (UJC), its Board of Trustees and staff mourn the passing of Stanley B. Horowitz, a dear friend to the federation system, Israel and the global Jewish community. Stanley served as president and CEO of the United Jewish Appeal (UJC's predecessor organization) for 12 years, from 1983 to 1991. Prior to his work at UJA, Stanley served in various capacities at the Jewish Community Federation of Cleveland for 18 years, acting as executive director for eight of those years. Stanley was dedicated to helping those in need on a local, national and international level. May the Horowitz family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and may his memory be for a blessing.

KHATAMI--Marie Hoguet Passed away on Wednesday, August 13, 2008 from a blood clot following cancer surgery in New York City. Her loving family will miss her profoundly. She was a brave and forward thinking 85-year-old who loved art and European and Asian cultures, a passion she shared with her husband of 57 years, Abul Khatami. We will remember so many things about her, but what stands out in our minds is her incredible spirit, fierce intelligence, and deep resounding laughter. She was as complete a human being as one could be. Marie Khatami was born in Millburn, New Jersey on February 3, 1923. She grew up in Manhattan with her five brothers and two sisters at 47 East 92nd Street. The girls attended Convent of the Sacred Heart; Marie's mother, Louise Hoguet, helped to found the St. David's School in 1951. Marie also attended Sacred Heart in Noroton, CT. and continued her studies in Paris and Siena until the imminent outbreak of World War II brought her home. She attended Barnard and completed her college education at Radcliffe in 1946, where she received a B.A. Her interests in Art History and Asian culture can be traced to the gift of a book from her father, Robert Louis Hoguet, when she was a girl, ''Folktales of Bengal'' by Lal Behari Day. Her parents had traveled to Asia and also traveled with their eight children throughout Europe when she was a child, instilling in her a lifelong love of European and Asian culture. That love compelled her to continue her studies in Chinese Art at the Asia Institute, where she obtained her Masters degree and where she met her husband, Sayyid Abulquasim Khatami, from Isfahan, Iran, who became an anthropologist at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. It was an art book lent by Marie to Abul that brought them together. They were married on January 9, 1951 and raised their four children in Manhattan. Marie is survived by her husband, Abul, who lives in Manhattan, Marie Norton of Manhattan, Jim Khatami of San Francisco, Renee Khatami of Manhattan, Jessie K. Wallen of Del Mar, California, and proud grandmother of Christopher Khatami, Patrick Norton, Sophie and Emme MacArthur, and Johnnie and Jimmy Wallen, and her sister Eleanor Hoguet de Give of Newburyport, Massa chusetts. A memorial service will be announced. She will be interred at Most Holy Trinity Church Cemetery in Easthampton, NY. Contributions may be made in her memory to the charity of your choice.

ELSEN--Gerri S. Gerri studied at Sarah Lawrence College and MIT, and was an architecture student, a designer, an artist, a musician and an athlete. In her early 20s, she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, but was able to live a long, happy and productive life. She was a wonderful and loving wife, mother and grandmother, and a devoted friend. She was generous, kind, and great fun to be with. Over the 4th of July weekend, she had a bad fall on Martha's Vineyard, and was flown to Massachusetts General Hospital, were she died on Friday, August 15. We thank the outstanding doctors, nurses and staff there who took care of her. We loved her deeply, and she will always be a part of us. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 19 at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), New York, NY. Burial will follow at The Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY Shivah will be at 50 Fenimore Road, Scarsdale, NY. Ralph Reed, the former director of the Christian Coalition and an associate of the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff, was a no-show at a fund-raiser for Senator John McCain in Atlanta on Monday night, even though Mr. Reed had sent out e-mail messages asking people to attend. Mr. Reed's absence quickly threw Senator Barack Obama's campaign, which had seized on Mr. Reed's ties to Mr. McCain, into I-told-you-so jubilation. ''Faced with the embarrassing prospect of holding a fund-raiser with one of Jack Abramoff's closest associates, the McCain campaign scrambled today to scratch Ralph Reed from tonight's program,'' Tommy Vietor, an Obama spokesman, said in a statement. He added that ''the real question isn't why Reed isn't showing up, but why a so-called reformer would invite him at all.''

Funeral service Wednesday, August 20, 10:30am, St. John The Evangelist RC Church, 348 East 55th St. Interment Washington Memorial Park. Visitation 9:30am to 10:15am at the church.

An article on Saturday about new images of Enceladus, a moon of Saturn, misstated the speed at which the Cassini spacecraft flew by the moon. Cassini was traveling at about 40,000 miles an hour, not 64,000. (It was flying at 64,000 kilometers per hour.)

ELIAS--Beatrice Klein of Monroe Twp., NJ on August 17, 2008. Beloved daughter of the late Morris and Rose Goldstein. Wife of the late Irving Elias and the late Irving Klein. Mother of Elliot Klein and Gary Klein; stepmother of Arthur Elias, Gerald Elias and Estelle White. Also survived by four grandchildren and 10 step-grandchildren. Graveside service 12:45pm on Wednesday at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, under direction of Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ.

WEIN--Dr. Arthur B. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Dr. Arthur B. Wein of Bethesda, MD. A devoted ATS supporter for more than 25 years, Dr. Wein was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment to the ATS and the Technion. The Arthur B. Wein M.D. and Mary Lou Barker M.D. Dormitory and the Samuel and Miriam Wein Academic Lectureship in Medicine, named for Dr. Wein's parents, were among the crucial projects he and Mary Lou supported. Dr. Wein was honored with a Technion Honorary Fellowship in 1998 and was a member of both the Technion International Board of Governors as well as the regional Board of Directors. A leading orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Wein participated in the first total hip replacement in the Washington, D.C. area, and served as an Army physician during World War II. To Mary Lou, children Daryl Wein and Cynthia Lett, and the entire family, we express our heartfelt condolences. Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Paul Shatz, Washington, D.C. Region President Irv Elenberg Washington, D.C. Region Director

ROBSON--Thomas W., age 74 of Bridgewater, NJ died Friday, August 15, 2008 at his home. Born in Mount Vernon, NY, he was the son of the late Thomas and Anna Robson. Tom had lived in Flushing, NY before moving to Bridgewater 40 years ago. Tom served in the Army Quartermaster Corps during the Korean War and was a part of the Military Honors Detail. He was a plant supervisor for the New York Times in Edison, NJ for 14 years, before retiring in 2001. In his retirement years, Tom loved to garden and was an avid bird watcher. He loved nature and all of God's creatures. Tom is survived by many special people; his wife, Marie Robson, Florence Leta and her family, his sister - in - law, Jeanne Giordano, his niece, Julie Memoli, his three nephews, Joseph, Steven and Matthew Giordano and 13 grandnieces and nephews. A funeral mass will be held on Wednesday, August 20, 2008 at 10am at the Church of the Little Flower, 310 Plainfield Ave., Berkeley Heights, NJ. Friends may visit with the family on Tuesday, from 4:00 to 7:00pm at the Kearns Funeral Home, 103 Old Highway 28, Whitehouse. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested memorial donations to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105 (www.stjude.org/tribute). For more information or to send condolences please visit www.kearnsfuneralhome .com

If there is an Olympic sport that receives little respect from the average American fan, it is synchronized swimming. Bring up synchro, and the first thing many people mention is the spoof done by Harry Shearer and Martin Short on ''Saturday Night Live'' in the 1980s. But when the duet and team competitions in the sport that could be described as a combination of swimming, gymnastics and figure skating are televised this week, some women from a certain generation who grew up in certain parts of the country will be watching and remembering what for them was one of the few competitive sports for girls when they were in high school.

MARTIN--Jacqueline. By the grace of Jesus Christ, Jacqueline Almond Martin entered into heaven on August 16, 2008. She was 94. Mrs. Martin was born on December 1, 1913, in Albemarle, NC, and lived in NYC all of her married life. She maintained a house in Greenwood, VA, and also a residence in Key Biscayne, FL. Mrs. Martin spent the summers in Quogue, NY with her daughter and son-inlaw, with whom she lived with for the past several years. Throughout her life she loved her family immensely, sharing her joy for gardening, cooking and teaching us about life in accordance to her faith that Jesus Christ is the son of the living God. Her family is assured by this same faith. Her many loved ones, both young and old, often sought her wise advice. She was predeceased by her husband, H. Bradley Martin and her stepdaughter Ann Martin Johnston. She is survived by her daughter Alice Martin Takach, her son H. Bradley Martin, her stepdaughter Helen Martin Bryan, 18 grandchildren and 28 great-grandchildren. She will be loved and remembered forever. Mrs. Martin will be laid to rest next to her husband H. Bradley Martin in Friends Cemetery, Westbury, NY.

URROWS--Grace, on August 16th, 2008 at Danbury Hospital, Connecticut after a short illness. Born in New York City; of Sherman, CT and Indian Harbour Beach, FL. Survived by her loving husband Arthur; sons David of Hong Kong and Chris Lund (Diane Wallace) of Ontario, Canada, and grandchildren Sam, Hannah, Ethan and Helen. Grace worked for many years in healthcare administration, most notably at Montefiore Hospital. Memorial services to be announced.

A week ago, Chris Russo was Mike Francesa’s partner on WFAN, and they were a month short of celebrating their 19th anniversary as sports-talk radio’s most powerful team. On Tuesday, Russo became the star, director and executive producer of Mad Dog Radio, a 24-hour sports-talk channel on Sirius XM, the recently merged subscription satellite radio service with 18.5 million subscribers and Howard Stern as its king. Starting Sept. 15, Russo will return to afternoon drive time, from 2 to 7 p.m., putting him in competition with Francesa. Perhaps more important, as Sirius XM tries to build Russo into a star, he will be the boss of a crew of hosts on his channel, which will get under way in October.

KNOWLTON--Gen william A. Knowlton, on August 10th, 2008 at Virginia Hospital Center, Arlington, Virginia. A January 1943 graduate of West Point and a career Army officer, General Knowlton served in the 7th Armored Division in WWII and the Ninth Infantry Division in Vietnam, earning three Silver Star Medals. He was the Superintendent of West Point from 1970 to 1974 and completed in 1980 but continued to serve the military in various capacities. He was also a Director of the Chubb Corporation for nine years and a trustee for Davis and Elkins college. General Knowlton is survived by his wife, Marjorie D. (Peggy) Knowlton, of Alexandria, Virginia; three sons, William A. Knowlton, Jr., Lieutenant Colonel, US Army, Retired, of Burke, Virginia; Davis D. Knowlton of Manila, Philippines; Timothy R. Knowlton of Mill Valley, California; a daughter, Hollister K. Petraeus of Fort Myer, Virginia; seven grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery (Memorial Chapel) on November 21, 2008 at 1:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be to the West Point Fund or Army Emergency Relief.

MORSE--Margaret 95 years old, passed away on Saturday morning, August 16th. She was born on March 3rd, 1913, and was predeceased by her husband Bernard Morse. Margaret was a pioneer in promoting tourism to the State of Israel through her company, Margaret Morse Tours. Over her career she raised millions of dollars for Jewish Charities and Organizations, brought thousands of Jewish visitors to Israel, and gave unselfishly of her time. She was the recipient of countless awards presented by the State of Israel. Margaret leaves her daughter Wendy, her two grandchildren Robyn and Michael, and five great-grandchildren; Morgan, Danielle, Sam, William, and Zachary. Additionally, she leaves two sisters; Florence and husband Mike Benay and Eleanor Halpern, and nephews Jeffrey and Elliott. Donations may be made to American Friends of Magen David Adom 2100 E. Hallandale Beach, Hallandale, FL 33009.

The Chinese government's effort to improve Beijing's air quality appears to have worked to reduce carbon monoxide emissions, based on preliminary data collected by Columbia University's Spatial Information Design Lab. In a series of measurements taken along the Olympic marathon route, carbon monoxide levels dropped an average of 40 percent after the city put in alternate-day driving restrictions in which motorists could drive only on odd or even days. Unfortunately, other components of the city's air pollution, like particulate matter, are still at high levels, according to Sarah Williams, director of the lab. One of the main reasons for Beijing's high carbon monoxide levels is the large number of cars idling in traffic.

BUTT--Hugh R . The Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (LICR) wishes to express its profound debt of gratitude to Dr. Hugh Butt. Dr. Butt was personally selected by Daniel K. Ludwig to guide the scientific establishment, staffing and programs of the Institute. As Chairman of the Scientific Committee from the Institute's inception in 1971 to 1987, Dr. Butt defined the character and set the course of the global activities of what is now the largest international cancer research institute. His uncompromising commitment to excellence, his inherent dissatisfaction with the status quo, and his insistence on a closer integration between laboratory and clinical research, gave rise to principles that still guide the Institute today. Hugh Butt's critical role in launching LICR stands as his enduring legacy to mankind's battle against this disease. Lloyd J. Old, M.D., Chairman, LICR Board of Directors Edward A. McDermott, Jr., President Andrew J.G. Simpson, Ph.D., Scientific Director

EICHENBERG SINCLAIR-Joan , 77, of Baltimore, retired analyst and Wall Street pioneer, died July 22, 2008. Born in East Orange, NJ to Eugene and Mary Klebold Eichenberg, she graduated from Chestnut Hill College in Philadelphia and received her MBA at NYU. A highly respected analyst and researcher, Joan worked at Merrill Lynch, Clark Dodge, First Harlem Securities, and Adams Express Co. Joan loved bridge, tennis, golf, and needlepointing. Memorial Mass, St. Joseph's Parish, August 27, 2008 11am. Donations to Animal Rescue Inc., PO Box 35, Maryland Line, MD 21105. She is survived by her husband Hugh, brother Gene, stepson, niece, nephews and two step-grandchildren.

Both loved their family, their friends and their community very much. EDLIN--Paul , passed away August 16th. He had been battling cancer for 10 years and died at home from an apparent heart attack. He was 77. Paul was a truly gifted artist and, though recognized late in life, achieved acclaim for his unique talent for making collages from tiny fragments of postage stamps. Over the last ten years his art was the subject of many solo exhibitions at galleries and museums including The American Visionary Art Museum (Baltimore), Collection de l'Art Brut (Lausanne) and more recently a 2007 solo show at Colgate University's Longyear Museum. His work is in many prominent private and public collections. Paul is survived by his brother Charles, nephews Jay and Andrew, Claudia Montes, Lillian Bernstein, five grandnieces and nephews, Maxine Ferguson, and many fellow artists and admirers. The family extends its gratitude to Dr. Carol Portlock and Stacy Corcoran of Memorial SloanKettering for there wonderful care and attention. Private services were held Tuesday.

The local newspapers all weighed in today on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to place wind turbines atop the city’s skyscrapers and bridges, as well as off the coastline of Queens and Brooklyn. The New York Times’s assessment is that it would be complicated and expensive and barely begin to meet the growth in demand for electricity that is expected in the coming years,in part because skyscrapers would have to be designed or retrofitted at great cost to accommodate the extra weight of the turbines and insurers would have to be persuaded to cover them. And New York is not a particularly windy city, so a few buildings facing New York Harbor might be the only sites that make sense.

If searching for a running mate were as simple as posting an ad and asking for resumes, here are a few qualifications that Senator Barack Obama might be looking for: Someone who is "not about ego, self-aggrandizement, getting their names in the press, but our focus on what's best for the American people. I think people will see that I'm not afraid to have folks around me who complement my strengths and who are independent."

"The University of Illinois has refused to release records related to Sen. Barack Obama's service for a nonprofit educational project that put him in contact with activist William Ayers, a 1960s-era radical and now education professor," reports Mark Silva at The Chicago Tribune's Swamp blog.
Environmental Operating Solutions, a water purification company based in Massachusetts, has closed a $5 million round of financing by closing a second $2.5 million tranche, according to VentureBeat.

Temasek, the investment fund run by the Singapore government, is nursing a big loss so far on its investment in Merrill Lynch. But the fund, already Merrill's largest shareholder, might consider buying even more, Temasek's chairman said Thursday.

Turn Inc. has closed a $15 funding round led by Focus Ventures, making it the latest in a string of online advertising networks to score venture-capital financing. AdWeek points out that Lotame, Media6 Degrees and ContextWeb have also gotten venture capitalists to open their wallets in recent months.

Lehman Brothers came close to a deal to sell 50 percent of its shares to Korea Development Bank earlier this month before the talks fell through, The Financial Times reported, citing unnamed sources. The report follows an article in The New York Post that said Lehman held talks with South Korean investors about a possible capital infusion.

Music | An N.Y.U. doctoral student sees the Beatles as conservative icons, not just because of ''Taxman" and "Revolution," but "Let It Be" (laissez faire), "Happiness Is a Warm Gun" (pro-gun rights) and "Lady Madonna" (anti-welfare). But the Republican concedes the Beatles invite many interpretations. Unlike the Constitution, he insists. [USA Today]

Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp is completing its split into five publicly traded companies Thursday -- a move intended to give each business more focus and value than the previously cluttered whole.
Babcock & Brown said Thursday that its chief executive, Phil Green, and its chairman and founder, James Babcock, would resign, MarketWatch said.

"If the new man looking for love on ABC's 'The Bachelor' looks familiar, that's because he was rejected last season on 'The Bachelorette,'" the Associated Press reports.

Although still struggling, emerging-market strategies gained some momentum during the quarter ended June 30, according to Hedge Fund Research.

NBC Universal said on Wednesday that it had signed an agreement to acquire Carnival Film and Television, an independent production agency in Britain, giving it a base of operations for international expansion.

A series of financial scandals at major Dubai companies threatens to derail the Gulf Arab emirate's ambitions to become an international business hub unless the government tackles corruption head on, analysts say.

Update: Ms. Monahan dropped her sexual-harassment lawsuit against Mr. Iseman, saying she brought the lawsuit to "deflect attention from my own misdeeds with allegations that I now retract and that should never have been made."A former assistant who sued the founder of private-equity firm Caxton-Iseman Capital for harassment has pleaded guilty to stealing more than $45,000 from him, Bloomberg News reported.

The long-gestating initial public offering of Poland's flagship airline PLL LOT will take place in late 2009 at the earliest as the carrier restructures to return to profitability, its chief executive said on Wednesday.
SailPoint Technologies, a maker of identity management software, has raised $6.5 million in a third round of funding. All of the company's existing investors participated in the round.

Earlier today we tracked the events in the gold medal softball game as it was being played. To read an account of the action, written as it happened, scroll down the page and read the inning-by-inning narrative written by our expert commentator perched inches from her television screen here in New York.

The message below, from Diana H., a blog reader in South Dakota, tells a sadly typical story of how the elderly can be conned, cheated and harassed, in this case by a stranger but more commonly by family members or caretakers. Is this elder abuse? You bet it is, both financial and psychological, and more common, if less dramatic, than instances in which the elderly are beaten, starved or otherwise physically abused.

This year more than most, I sense a number of intriguing story lines entering the season-ending Slam. If it hadn't already, the Nadal-Federer rivalry has now joined the ranks of Sampras-Agassi, McEnroe-Borg-Connors, Evert-Navratilova and Seles-Graf. Despite Roger Federer's embarrassing loss to Rafael Nadal at the French Open and the heartbreaker at Wimbledon (where both displayed the mental fortitude of champions, Federer in coming back from what looked to be lights out in the fourth set tiebreaker, and Nadal in sticking to his guns and pulling out a 9-7 fifth set), and even his early exits in Toronto and the Olympics (singles), I have a feeling Federer will keep his end of the bargain for a while longer. He's been shaky of late, but it was encouraging to see how excited he was winning gold in the doubles finals at the Olympics. Perhaps that will translate into the confidence he needs going into the Open. Throw in a young, hungry and still-improving Novak Djokovic, and the plot thickens.

[Chronicle Review]

Turns out tycoon Mikhail Prokhorov may not be the "mysterious Russian oligarch" who paid somewhere around €500 million for a French estate after all. A spokesman for Prokhorov's company, the Onexim Group, told the Moscow Times that the outgoing billionaire is not the buyer of Villa Leopolda, the seaside estate built near Villefranche by Belgian King Leopold II in 1902.

The United States opened play in the semifinal round of regional qualifying for the 2010 World Cup at Estadio Nacional Mateo Flores in Guatemala City Wednesday night. In the other game in Group 3, Keon Daniel scored two goals as Trinidad and Tobago defeated Cuba, 3-1, in Havana.
Photosynth, a sophisticated technology from Microsoft, turns a bunch of overlapping photos into a 3-D panorama.

The United States team, on the back of Carli Lloyd’s goal in overtime, defeated a strong Brazil team today to win a gold medal in women’s soccer. Brazil dominated much of the game, but they couldn’t get the ball in the goal, while the United States team, beat so resoundingly in their opening game, defended the gold medal they won in Athens.

Like most sports radio fans, I have spent the last few days reeling over the breakup of “Mike and the Mad Dog,” Mike Francesa and Chris Russo, WFAN’s longtime drive-time duo. I grew up on the show in New York, but after leaving the city years ago I could catch up with it only when I returned. But then the YES Network began simulcasting the show to fill its afternoons, and the three of us were reunited.

It’s been quite an Olympics for the hamstrings. They’ve determined the outcome of more events than Michael Phelps’s freakishly long arms. Sanya Richards blamed a “grabbing” hamstring for her loss in the 400 meters; sprinter Tyson Gay’s hamstring pull at the U.S. Olympic Trials reduced him to a non-factor in Beijing; and Chinese hurdler Liu Xiang’s heartbreaking exit from the Games, while directly caused by a sore Achilles tendon, “almost certainly was related” to a severe hamstring injury he suffered a few months back, says Dr. Bryan Heiderscheit, an assistant professor of physical therapy at the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and an expert on hamstring injuries. Injured hamstrings, Heiderscheit says, are especially common in sports that involve fast, hard spurts of running, such as the track and field sprints, but also football and soccer. “The million dollar question is why,” he says. Despite reams of research, there’s no answer. What is known, though, is that a hamstring injury is self-perpetuating. An athlete who’s suffered one is at an enormously increased risk of another. Again, researchers don’t know why that is, although a new study by Heiderscheit and his colleagues is suggestive. In the work, 11 athletes hobbled by hamstrings underwent a M.R.I. examination. In all but two of them, the hamstrings showed “substantial changes in the tissue,” even a year and a half after the injury, Heiderscheit says. Some sections of tissue were enlarged and scarred; others atrophied. The whole was, in effect, remodeled. How that metamorphosis contributes to later injury and, more important, how to use the M.R.I. findings to avoid re-injury “will require a lot more study,” Heiderscheit says.

In a stunning end to American dominance in softball, Japan today upset the undefeated United States team, 3-1, to claim the gold medal. “The United States, which had beaten Japan twice earlier in the tournament, was left with the silver medal, and the nagging sense that they have sustained a loss they may never avenge,” John Branch writes for The Times. “Softball has been removed from the Olympic program in 2012, and maybe beyond, meaning that many, if not all, of the United States’ well-known players have ended their Olympic careers on a sour and lasting note.”.
August is supposed to be the time for breezy beach reads. But a crop of books released this month suggests otherwise.
Jonathan Mahler chronicles Salim Hamdan’s journey from street urchin to jihadist, as well as the lives of the lawyers who transformed him into an international symbol in the war on terror.

The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about cosmetic surgeons who want patients to stop smoking, misstated part of the name of a medical association. It is the American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery, not the American Association of Cosmetic Surgery.

Nascar suspended indefinitely seven crew members for Joe Gibbs Racing for attempting to manipulate a horsepower test after a Nationwide Series race last weekend. While Nascar decided against barring the cars from future races, the penalties were among the harshest it had levied. The crew chiefs Jason Ratcliff and Dave Rogers were suspended and fined $50,000 each. The drivers Tony Stewart and Joey Logano were each docked 150 driver points. Gibbs Racing was stripped of 150 owner points for each car and placed on probation for the rest of the season.

The N.C.A.A. banned the horse-collar tackle. It will assess a penalty this season when a runner is yanked to the ground from the inside collar of his shoulder pads or jersey. Other changes included a clarification of rules on chop blocks and implementation of a 40-second play clock that will start as soon as the ball is ruled dead.

St. Louis Rams running back Steven Jackson ended his holdout as his agent continued negotiations for a new contract. Jackson, the centerpiece of the team’s offense, is entering the final year of a deal he signed as a first-round pick in 2004. The Rams cut off negotiations in late July on the first day of training camp and said there would be no further talks until Jackson reported.

Michael Iavarone, who heads the syndicate that owns the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner Big Brown, said Philadelphia Park and Monmouth Park were in the running for Big Brown’s final prep race before the Breeders’ Cup. No matter where he races, Big Brown will race on grass next. With an offer to increase the total purse of the Sept. 13 President’s Cup to $1 million should Big Brown compete, Philadelphia Park may be the leading contender. The race is currently worth $250,000.

The giant gates of Temple of Heaven Park swung open at 6 a.m., magnets pulling people into a new day. People quietly poured out of apartment buildings and low-slung hutong neighborhoods and drained through the gates of Beijing's favorite morning gathering place. Slowly the corners of the park filled, even the shady spots deep among the tight rows of cypress trees that date back 800 years. Over there, a man performed the slow-motion dance of tai chi. Over here, a woman scratched her back against a tree. Everywhere, people gave themselves pat-downs to loosen their muscles.

Senator John McCain was dogged by questions Wednesday about whether he would select a running mate who favors abortion rights, but he refused to show even a little dark-suited leg on the issue. In response to Laura Ingraham, the conservative radio talk show host, and two participants at a town-hall-style meeting at New Mexico State University, Mr. McCain said that his administration would have ''pro-life policies'' and that his running mate would share ''my principles, my values and my priorities.''

President Bush addressed the national convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars on Wednesday in Orlando, Fla. Afterward, Mr. Bush, lower center, was almost mobbed by conventioneers. From Orlando, he flew to New Orleans for another speech.

Here's something to remember while you watch the presidential conventions. The lush weeklong extravaganzas -- staged in the name of ordinary Americans -- will be largely paid for by private, unlimited donations from corporations, deep-pocketed donors and (a few) unions that shop 24/7 for privileged government access. How much cash are we talking about? More than $112 million is expected from private donors -- by far the lion's share of the cost of the two conventions.

Two vaccines against cervical cancer are being widely used without sufficient evidence about whether they are worth their high cost or even whether they will effectively stop women from getting the disease, two articles in this week's New England Journal of Medicine conclude. Both vaccines take aim at the human papillomavirus, or HPV, a common sexually transmitted virus that usually causes no symptoms and is cleared by the immune system, but which can in rare cases become chronic and cause cervical cancer.
Now it's Senator John McCain's turn. After his town-hall-style meeting on Wednesday in Las Cruces, N.M., Mr. McCain headed to his home near Sedona, Ariz., for three days off the campaign trail.

FORD--Quintin U., a Darien resident of fifty-five years, died peacefully in his sleep at his home on August 9th. His wife Barbara B. Ford; his daughter Hilarie F. Arguimbau and husband Vincent of Darien; his son Todd W. Ford and wife Patricia of Charlotte, VT; and stepson Niles W. Wheeler and wife Kim of Millbrook, NY, survive him. He is also survived by four grandchildren: Alexandra Arguimbau, Quintin Arguimbau, Samantha Ford, Marcia Ford and two step-grandchildren, Alexander Wheeler and Margaret Door. Mr. Ford was born in New York City on March 4, 1918 the son of Ellsworth and Consuelo Ford and grew up in Rye, NY and Greenwich, CT. He graduated from Choate School in Wallingford, CT and attended the University of Pennsylvania until he enlisted in the Army during World War II. Serving in the Army Counter Intelligence Corps (CIC), he saw action in North Africa, Sicily, Italy (where he was wounded in Anzio) and finally Germany. After the war he joined Bankers Trust Company in New York City and retired in 1978 as Executive Vice President. He was also a member of Wee Burn Country Club and Potatuck Club in Sandy Hook, CT. At his request, no service is planned. Those who wish to remember him may send donations to Post 53, P.O. Box 2066, Darien, CT 06820 or to the Potatuck Club, P.O. Box 704, Sandy Hook, CT 06482.

TWO New York City Masters coaches, each with a different approach, explain their dolphin kick technique. Streamlined arms are essential, said Patrick Cantrell, a coach at Asphalt Green. Enter the water with arms straight out in front of your head, pinching your ears back, with one hand over the other. Many people fail to hold their arms tightly enough against the head, a position requiring shoulder strength and rotator-cuff flexibility. ''Don't be like Superman,'' who keeps his arms loose so he can look around while flying, Mr. Cantrell said. ''Be like Aquaman.''

JANOWITZ--Henry. The Department of Medicine of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the passing of Henry Janowitz, M.D. An internationally renowned leader in gastroenterology, Dr. Janowitz served as Chief of Gastroenterology at Mount Sinai from 1958-1983. His many achievements included novel discoveries related to peptic ulcer disease and elucidation of the natural history and treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family and friends. Paul Klotman, M.D. Chair of Medicine JANOWITZ--Henry. The Dr. Henry D. Janowitz Division of Gastroenterology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourns the loss and celebrates the life of the brilliant physician who founded our clinical and academic unit 50 years ago, led it for 25 years, and gave it his name. Generations of students and specialists established their knowledge base and polished their skills under the tutelage of this extraordinary clinician, consultant, researcher, writer, lecturer, and teacher. His wisdom, his inspiration, and his example will live forever in our hearts and in our profession. Lloyd Mayer, M.D., Director Steven Itzkowitz, M.D., Associate Director David B. Sachar, M.D., Director Emeritus JANOWITZ--Dr. Henry D. Distinguished physician at Mt. Sinai Hospital and Medical Schools. Son of Rose and Sam Janowitz, beloved husband of Adeline R. Tintner, beloved father of Anne and Mary Janowitz, and grandfather of Kita Rose and Andrew Grinberg. Riverside Memorial Chapel, Thursday August 28, 11:45am. Donations may be sent to Visiting Doctors Program, Mt. Sinai Hospital.

LAMOTTE--W. Mitchell (Mitch), of Winnetka, IL and Jupiter, FL, died suddenly August 6, 2008. He was 69 years old. He passed away peacefully, while vacationing with his family in Jamestown, RI. Mitch was a lifelong sailor, ardent sportsman,and a successful business leader, but most importantly, he was a committed father and husband. Mitch was born in Philadelphia, PA September 3, 1938 and he grew up in Wilmington, DE and Louisville, KY. He graduated from Tower Hill School and Princeton University, where he was a member of The Tiger Inn Club. After college, Mitch married his wife of nearly 47 years, Elizabeth Ewing (Betsy) of Louisville, KY. Mitch enjoyed a long and distinguished career in the insurance industry beginning with Chubb and ending with Johnson & Higgins. He spent 30 years at J&H, the last fifteen of which he ran the Chicago office and served on its Board of Directors. Mitch believed in leaving this world a better place for future generations and consequently volu nteered at the following organizations over the years: The Boys and Girls Clubs of America, The Lincoln Park Zoo, Hadley School for the Blind and Resources for the Future. In addition to his wife, Betsy, Mitch is survived by a son, Bolt (Kirsten); two daughters, Anne (Patrick) Kiggins and Nicole; four grandchildren; and one brother, Nicholas H. LaMotte (Susan). Memorial contributions may be made to the Boys and Girls Clubs of Chicago, c/o Janelle St. John, 550 W. Van Buren, Suite 350, Chicago, IL 60607. A memorial service will be held on September 12th at 4:00pm at Indian Hill Club, Winnetka, IL.

Moving swiftly to capitalize on the success of Chinese athletes at the Olympics, government officials in Beijing will send most of China's gold medalists to Hong Kong next week, ahead of legislative elections there on Sept. 7. The athletes' visit, announced Wednesday by the Hong Kong government, comes as democracy advocates here are struggling to hold on to their 26 seats in the 60-member Legislature. A resurgent Chinese national pride has helped pro-Beijing candidates this summer. If pro-democracy politicians fall below 21 seats, the Chinese government's allies would be in position to reshape election laws and other legislation in ways that would further cement Beijing's control. Yeung Sum, a longtime critic of Beijing who is seeking re-election, said he worried that gold medalists might campaign with pro-Beijing candidates. Thomas Chow, the director of the Hong Kong Leisure and Cultural Services Department, said the city's decision to invite the athletes had nothing to do with the elections. KEITH BRADSHER

Giuliani, whose presidential campaign sputtered to an end this year after the Florida primary, will return to the spotlight during the Republican National Convention, where he will be the keynote speaker. The news that Mr. Giuliani will speak on the second night of the convention comes as Senator John McCain is facing concern from social conservatives that he might choose a running mate who supports abortion rights. Mr. Giuliani struggled during his own bid for the Republican nomination to play down his stances on some social issues, including abortion.

ISRAEL--Larry J. The Board of Tulane University and the entire Tulane community deeply mourn the death of Larry J. Israel. Larry was a true civic leader in his native New Orleans and a great friend to Tulane. He was a shining example of the difference a loyal, dedicated individual can make in the world. Through a life well lived, Larry upheld his family's generations-long tradition of service and philanthropy. He gave of himself to numerous organizations, including the New Orleans Tourist and Convention Commission, Audubon Park Commission and the Port of New Orleans. In April of this year, Larry received the prestigious Judah Touro Society Award in recognition of 18 years of guidance as a member and past chair of the board of Touro Infirmary. Larry's devotion to his alma mater was as strong as his unstoppable enthusiasm for its student-athletes. As a member of the Tulane board, he was instrumental in restructuring the Tulane athletics program at a crucial point in the late nineties, and his support later helped to carry the Green Wave through the difficult post-Katrina period. He gave his time freely, serving most recently as chair of the Board's Endowment Management Committee, where his expertise and financial acumen were invaluable to the academic and financial growth of the university. We will dearly miss Larry and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Ann, and their three children. Philip Greer, Chair of the Board, Tulane University Scott S. Cowen, President, Tulane University

Iran has executed a 20-year-old man, Reza Hejazi, who was sentenced to death for a murder he committed when he was 15, according to the daily newspaper Etemad. The killing revived an international debate over Iran's punishment of those who were minors when they broke the law. Meanwhile, the judiciary summoned two prominent actors, Parviz Parastui and Ezzatolah Entezami, and a movie director, Kiumars Poorahmad, for trying to collect money to help save the life of Behnood Shojaee, who is on death row for a murder he committed when he was 17. The three said the victim's family had agreed to allow him to be spared in return for a generous amount of money, called blood money under Iran's law. But a judiciary official told the news agency ISNA that relatives of the victim filed a complaint, denying that they had agreed to forgive the murder. NAZILA FATHI

EDLIN--Paul, passed away August 16th. He had been battling cancer for 10 years and died at home from an apparent heart attack. He was 77. Paul was a truly gifted artist and, though recognized late in life, achieved acclaim for his unique talent for making collages from tiny fragments of postage stamps. Over the last ten years his art was the subject of many solo exhibitions at galleries and museums including The American Visionary Art Museum (Baltimore), Collection de l'Art Brut (Lausanne) and more recently a 2007 solo show at Colgate University's Longyear Museum. His work is in many prominent private and public collections. Paul is survived by his brother Charles, nephews Jay and Andrew, Claudia Montes, Lillian Bernstein, five grandnieces and nephews, Maxine Ferguson, and many fellow artists and admirers. The family extends its gratitude to Dr. Carol Portlock and Stacy Corcoran of Memorial SloanKettering for there wonderful care and attention. Private services were held Tuesday.

Reports of feral cats being beaten, burned and mutilated are surfacing in the Woodlawn area of the Bronx. The first report surfaced late last month when a resident was walking and noticed she noticed a gray cat skulking which large gash across its back and seemed a bit haggard, she said. A couple days later, Animal Nation, a nonprofit rescue group, reported receiving a frantic call from a teenage girl who found a tabby that had been badly beaten and its tail was burned to the bone. A veterinarian later said that most of the cat’s teeth had been broken or knocked out, that it had suffered major head trauma and burns to its gums, likely sustained when it tried to bite out the flames on its tail. The young tabby was euthanized.

A number of Bronx elected officials gathered on the steps of the Borough Hall this morning to endorse Elizabeth A. Taylor, a candidate for a boroughwide contest for Civil Court judge. A press conference for a judicial candidate is rarely much of a political development. But as is often the case in New York City politics, endorsements can reveal larger messages about political relationships.

There will be a show of Democratic unity this afternoon in an effort to topple a longtime Republican state senator from Queens. One of the Democratic candidates, Albert J. Baldeo, will be withdrawing from the race and endorsing City Councilman Joseph P. Addabbo Jr.

Gov. David A. Paterson on Friday said he supports Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s efforts to explore ways to run for a third term, calling the possibility of four more years of a Bloomberg administration “a great idea.”

My column this Saturday is a mini-history of the sins of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two entities that are supposed to help the country in times of financial duress, not add to its problems, as they have done. What got me going was an article I saw in The Boston Globe (which is owned by The New York Times Company), in which Freddie Mac's chief executive, Richard Syron, made the absurd claim that the company's troubles stemmed from his insistence that it reorient itself towards its mission of making affordable housing available to Americans. This -- to put it nicely -- is a crock, as I try to point out in the column.

It's funny to mention (thanks, Houken) the future of Chanel after Karl Lagerfeld, as Lagerfeld's birthday approaches in early September. Part of the appeal of the Wertheimer brothers is that they're so private. I see Alain Wertheimer from time to time up at Chanel-usually after most of the editors have cleared out of Karl's studio-and you can ask him almost anything, except about Chanel. Horses, no problem. But he doesn't discuss Chanel and of course he doesn't discuss Lagerfeld. I'm glad I've had a window into this rare owner/designer relationship, and I really prefer not to think of the fashion world without Lagerfeld. It won't be the same when he decides to call it a day-not as fun, not as intelligent, not as historic-minded. In an era of multibrands and luxury conglomerates, just think what this one family has done to preserve not merely a business but also a way of working. Chanel is a unique culture, and I suspect it's helped the perspective of the Wertheimers that their reference/compass points are France, England and New York, where they mainly live.
