Eugene Upshaw, the 63-year-old head of the National Football League Players Association, died on Thursday morning of pancreatic cancer, and the football establishment spent the rest of the day singing his praises. "Gene Upshaw did everything with grace and dignity," the NFL commissioner Roger Goodel said. Mr. Goodell's predecessor, Paul Tagliabue, pointed to Mr. Upshaw's "positive impact on the structure and competitiveness of the entire league." Adam Schefter, an analyst with the NFL Network, called him "one of the most influential figures that has ever been involved in the sport of football." Newsday's football writer Bob Glauber: "There's no question in my mind that his legacy will, in hindsight, be perceived as not good, but great." And on, and on.

The Los Angeles Galaxy signed midfielder Eddie Lewis on Thursday, a day after Lewis played for the United States national team in a 1-0 victory at Guatemala in a World Cup qualifier. To make room for Lewis, 34, the Galaxy traded forward Carlos Ruiz to Toronto FC for first- and second-round selections in next year’s M.L.S. supplemental draft and salary budget considerations. The Galaxy held the top spot in the M.L.S. allocation table, and used that position to acquire Lewis. Lewis joins the Galaxy following a one-year stay with Derby County of the English Premier League. Ruiz, who captained the Guatemalan national team, appeared in 10 games for the Galaxy this season with one goal.

New filings with the Federal Election Commission on Wednesday showed that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, had been able to cut into her mountain of debt to vendors. Mrs. Clinton finished July with $10.8 million in unpaid bills, compared with the $12 million she had the month before. She has also lent her campaign more than $13 million.

Tropical Storm Fay came ashore on the Florida coast for the third time in less than a week on Thursday, bringing more torrential rain to the already waterlogged state. The storm, which came ashore near Flagler Beach with top winds of 60 miles per hour, was moving west at 5 m.p.h. Flooding was widespread, and National Guard troops patrolled streets in Melbourne.

10 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) THE THIRD MAN (1949) Carol Reed's classic post-World War II thriller starred Joseph Cotten and Orson Welles, above. But equally important to the film's success was Trevor Howard's turn as a crusty British military officer, a role he specialized in during the 1950s and '60s. Turner Classics dedicates a full day, beginning at 6 a.m., to Mr. Howard's work as part of its ''Summer Under the Stars'' series. Other highlights include ''Operation Crossbow'' (1965), at 12:15 p.m., in which he plays a military adviser who is skeptical about reports that the Nazis are building long-range missiles, and another film directed by Reed, the Joseph Conrad adaptation ''Outcast of the Islands'' (1951), at 8 p.m. 7 A.M. Admirals' Row, a collection of historic buildings at the southwestern edge of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, housed high-ranking officers from the 1840s until the early 1970s. The city wants the Army National Guard, which owns the property, to transfer the land so that the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation can demolish the houses and replace them with a supermarket and a large industrial building. Residents of nearby public housing projects would be given preference in hiring.

How much more do New Yorkers earn than people with similar jobs elsewhere in America? About 30 percent, according to a report released on Tuesday by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The average hourly wage of people employed in the metropolitan region last year was $25.38, nearly $6 an hour more than the national average of $19.56, according to the report. New Yorkers' wages were significantly higher than the national averages in every category, but the premium paid in New York was significantly bigger for some jobs than for others.

ISRAEL--Larry J. The Board of Tulane University and the entire Tulane community deeply mourn the death of Larry J. Israel. Larry was a true civic leader in his native New Orleans and a great friend to Tulane. He was a shining example of the difference a loyal, dedicated individual can make in the world. Through a life well lived, Larry upheld his family's generations-long tradition of service and philanthropy. He gave of himself to numerous organizations, including the New Orleans Tourist and Convention Commission, Audubon Park Commission and the Port of New Orleans. In April of this year, Larry received the prestigious Judah Touro Society Award in recognition of 18 years of guidance as a member and past chair of the board of Touro Infirmary. Larry's devotion to his alma mater was as strong as his unstoppable enthusiasm for its student-athletes. As a member of the Tulane board, he was instrumental in restructuring the Tulane athletics program at a crucial point in the late nineties, and his support later helped to carry the Green Wave through the difficult post-Katrina period. He gave his time freely, serving most recently as chair of the Board's Endowment Management Committee, where his expertise and financial acumen were invaluable to the academic and financial growth of the university. We will dearly miss Larry and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Ann, and their three children. Philip Greer, Chair of the Board, Tulane University Scott S. Cowen, President, Tulane University

SHATTUCK--Julie Follansbee-Pratt . Our Mother, grandmother, aunt and dear friend, Julie Follansbee Pratt Shattuck, who found pure joy in nature, food, language, art, and friendship died August 16th at the age of 88. An actress, she was the youngest of five children, certainly the most Bohemian, and always championed the underdog, in her heart and in her life, perhaps because she felt she was one. Although Julie was a master gardener, an accomplished French cook-worshipped all things French--who served food as if it were love itself, a world traveler, a Thespian from Brecht and ''The Gin Game'' to ''Regarding Henry'' and ''Law and Order,'' was adored by two husbands, the photographer, Charles Pratt and International Attorney, Francis Shattuck, she never quite fathomed how powerfully she affected those around her. Julie read everything from Marcel Proust to Bill Maxwell, who was her dear friend and on whose birthday she died, ever loyal. She was as disarmingly hilarious as she was generous to her friends and family. We will miss her passion for peonies and her apple tree, for smelly cheese, for a rare bottle of wine, for the Democrats, for the pitch perfect dramatic moment. She is survived by her only child, Mike Pratt, her ''one miracle,'' and his wife, Carol, her grandchildren, Julian and Sam Pratt, stepchildren, John Shattuck and Tina Stenhaus and the many devoted friends and family who will hold her enchanting, irreverent presence close to them, always.

For New Yorkers who might want a break from pork buns for breakfast while at the Olympics, there are bagels to be had, even in Beijing. The best known place in Beijing for New York-style bagels -- translated as ''beigu,'' or ''precious wheat'' -- is Mrs. Shanen's Bagels. The bagels, slightly smaller than the average version found in New York, with a crisp crust and soft insides, are the product of a Brooklyn-bred Chinese-American entrepreneur, Lejen Chen, who wanted a taste of home when she moved to China.

With the Democratic National Convention rolling into town this weekend, Denver residents are taking up a long-established New York tradition: subletting. And the profit potential is as high as the Mile High City itself. Convention organizers are expecting 50,000 credentialed attendees, said Chris Lopez, spokesman for the Denver Host Committee, but the city could swell by more than twice that figure by some estimates, with the array of protesters, grass-roots supporters and others trying to attend Senator Barack Obama's acceptance speech or just to be near the big show.

JANOWITZ--Dr. Henry D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of Dr. Henry Janowitz, our beloved mentor and internationally recognized giant in his field. Founder and former Chief of the Division of Gastroenterology, his exceptional knowledge, both in and out of Medicine, was profound and encyclopedic. His legendary erudition lives on in generations of gastroenterologists privileged to be his apprentices, to whom he imparted both the science and art of his specialty. He emphasized meticulous historytaking and involvement of the patient and family in the pursuit of diagnosis and cure. He received the Jacobi Medallion in 1974, an award honoring physicians for distinguished achievement in Medicine. He will always be remembered as a gentleman and scholar. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. James Capozzi, MD, President Steven Weinfeld, MD, Vice President Peter Rubin, MD, Officer Amy Weinstein, Administrator

DANZIG--Leonard S., M.D. , 82, of Little Silver, NJ, died on August 20, 2008 after a long illness. He was born in Newark, NJ and grew up in Hillside and Asbury Park. Dr. Danzig graduated from Columbia College and the University of Buffalo School of Medicine. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army in Europe. He practiced medicine for many years in Red Bank, NJ. Dr. Danzig had a passionate interest in classical music, opera, and the visual arts, and he traveled widely. He was predeceased by his parents Samuel and Mae Danzig and sister Helen Scorben. He is survived by his wife Elaine; his sons Allen, Andrew, and Robert; daughter Anne Schneider; grandchildren Lauren, Mariel, Jonathan, Emily, Sophia, and Theodore; and sister Charlotte Brauer. We will dearly miss him.

So much for decoupling. I do, however, have a small gripe with this NYT article. It suggests that the linkages of international markets via exports and imports make a synchronized world business cycle inevitable. Actually, there's a problem with that. You can do international linkages quite easily in a simple Keynesian model, and economists have been doing that since 1952. But when you try to run the numbers, they're never big enough to explain the actual degree of synchronization. (A bit on that here.)

Science | The bigger the brain, the smarter, an article says. At least when it comes to certain areas of the brain, like Einstein's, which was "salvaged, sliced into 240 pieces and stored in jars for safekeeping." And smart brains are like fluorescent bulbs: they use less energy. [Scientific American]

Lexicon | "Pwn" is a Web slang term derived from "own" (and rhyming with it) meaning dominate or humiliate. It gained currency in gaming culture -- "You just got pwned!" -- and may have come from typo of "own," since "p" and "o" are next to each other on the keyboard. [Wikipedia, Urban Dictionary]

To follow the Olympic gold medal match between Germany and Spain, click on "read more" and read down. The Spanish were seeking their first-ever Olympic gold in the sport, the Germans their third. And it means a lot in both countries, where field hockey is a very popular sport -- and probably got even more popular after this memorable final.

Music | To find out "what makes music sound good," a study uses the notes on a piano to turn "music into math." It finds "that superficially different styles-Renaissance music, classical and Romantic music, jazz, rock, and other popular forms-all make remarkably similar use of the geometry of chord space." So Pythagoras was right all those centuries ago. Got it? [Seed]

Steve & Barry's, the bankrupt retailer, won court approval to sell its assets for $163 million after the company agreed to drop a condition of the deal that would have protected its founders from lawsuits. Steve & Barry's co-founders, Steve Shore and Barry Prevor, are investors in the new company. KATZ--Terry G. , passed away at home surrounded by her loving family. Devoted wife of Jack, loving mother of heart to Andrea and son-inlaw Jim, cherished grandmother to Danielle. Juan Carlos Ramírez-Abadía, a Colombian accused of smuggling billions of dollars worth of cocaine into the United States, was extradited on Friday to face federal charges of homicide, drug trafficking and money laundering in the United States, Brazil's justice minister said. Mr. Ramírez-Abadía, 45, is reputedly a leader of a notorious drug cartel, Norte del Valle, in Colombia. The United States State Department, which posted a reward of up to $5 million for his capture, has said he commanded a drug and money-laundering operation reaching from Colombia into the United States and Europe.

Getting Ink at the Games In Beijing, athletes, Olympics support staff and tourists are packing into local tattoo parlors to have a permanent commemoration of their time in China inked onto their bodies.

Both stages have now been revealed for the conventions. When the Democrats gather Monday night, they will face a multilevel platform at the Pepsi Center in Denver with runways. One week later, on Sept. 1, the Republicans at the Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul will face a clean and simple stage.

The Creative Coalition will once again be adding considerable star power to both the Democratic and Republican conventions. The coalition, a nonprofit organization that advocates for the arts, will be sending a delegation of celebrities including Spike Lee, left, Quentin Tarantino, Annette Bening, Anne Hathaway, bottom left, and Neil Patrick Harris to both conventions. It will also be hosting two major concerts, the Black Eyed Peas in Denver and the Charlie Daniels Band in Minneapolis-St. Paul. But the coalition is also taking a page from the books of political fund-raisers and using the convention setting to raise a little cash. The group will be selling sponsorship packages to convention events, much the same way that the host committees for the two cities sold corporate sponsorships to pay for the conventions.

Before his United States team played Japan on Saturday morning for the bronze medal, Manager Davey Johnson planned to make a quick speech. Just to remind his players that a consolation prize in what might be the final Olympic baseball competition was better than no prize at all. ''It's a pretty good group,'' Johnson said after the United States lost, 10-2, to Cuba on Friday night. ''They're not a group I need to motivate a whole lot.''
NEWMAN--Jeannette . You will remain in our hearts forever, Mother. Jeff & Charles and their families

Muslims shouted slogans about freedom from India as hundreds of thousands of people protested Friday in Srinagar, in Indian-controlled Kashmir. Tensions have been high since May, when a dispute over a parcel of land in the Himalayas near Amarnath, a Hindu shrine, reignited long-simmering hostilities in the region.

LEON--Joseph L. , 79. Died August 21. Publisher, inventor, scientist. Loving husband of Masha. Extraordinary father of Laura, Karen, Nina (Michael). Adored grandfather of Michelle, Susan, Steven Cohen, Rachel and Alexandra Olney. Services Sunday August 24, 9:30am Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapels, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, www.myeloma.org.

9 P.M. (Hallmark) DEAR PRUDENCE Jessica Fletcher meets Martha Stewart in this new comic mystery, in which Jane Seymour, above, plays Prudence, a prim domestic diva who escapes to a small Wyoming town to take a break from her TV series. There she transforms into an amateur detective who calls on her on-air sidekick, Nigel (Ryan Cartwright), to help look into a fishy suicide that just might be murder. 6 A.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: LAUREL AND HARDY Despite their ''essential'' position in America cinema, are you ready for a straight shot of 33 films with Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy? The daylong celebration of this slapstick comedy duo commences with 11 short films in a row (typically about 20 minutes each), beginning with ''Night Owls'' (1930), in which Laurel and Hardy play two vagrants who try to help a police officer keep his good name. ''Way Out West'' (1937), at 9:45 p.m., is regarded as one of the pair's finest films and was nominated for an Oscar for its score. In it, Stan and Ollie encounter an endless array of hiccups on the road to delivering the deed for a valuable gold mine to its rightful owner.

The Senate Republican campaign organization is cutting back on television advertising in close races, and Senator John Ensign of Nevada, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, is faulting his apparently stingy colleagues. In an unusual public rebuke, Mr. Ensign said on Friday that his fellow Republican senators had not stepped up to his July challenge to contribute enough money so Republicans could match well-heeled Democrats dollar-for-dollar in crucial states. Democrats have a budget of about $45 million at this point.

FLOWERS--Esther F . On Thursday, August 21, 2008 at her home in Rye, New York, at 91. Beloved wife of Roy, who predeceased her in 1993, loving mother of William, Kenneth, and Richard, all of New York City, Carolyn Wilson, of Salt Lake City, and Donald of Larchmont, New York, dear older sister of Lois Fischle of Upland, California, and nurturing grandmother to nine grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday morning, September 13, 2008, at 11am at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church. FLOWERS--Esther F. The Clark & Wilkins Co. mourns the passing of our past president Esther Elizabeth Fischle Flowers on Thursday, August 21, 2008, at her home in Rye, New York at 91. Mrs. Flowers, a 1937 graduate of Mt. Holyoke College, served as an officer of the company for over sixty years. She assumed the role of president upon her husbands death in 1993, serving until 2007. Her late husband, Roy Malcolm Flowers, was the greatgrandson of George Malcolm Clark who co-founded the business in 1870. Mrs. Flowers is survived by her five children and their spouses, William Ellwood (Mary Kay), Kenneth Fischle (Glory Jones), and Richard Clark, all of New York City, Carolyn Muriel Flowers Wilson (Dr. Dana Wilson) of Salt Lake City, and Donald Foster (Maria) of Larchmont, New York, along with her sister, Lois Ann Fischle of Upland, California, nine grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday morning, September 13, 2008, at 11am at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church. William E. Flowers, Chairman; Kenneth F. Flowers, President

BEIJING -- He stood in the crowd with a smile creased across his face and his hands clapping with fervor. It was one of the most telling scenes following a transcendent gold medal game on Sunday.

BEIJING -- I just got back to my seat in the press room following the United States men's scintillating 118-107 victory over Spain in the gold medal game. The consensus in the postgame interviews from both sides is that this one will resonate in history as one of the best Olympic games ever played. Hard to argue, as the United States shot 60 percent from the field and still didn't really seal the game until Dwyane Wade drilled a left-wing 3-point shot with 2 minutes 2 seconds remaining.

Dathan Ritzenheim, the top American in the men's marathon race Sunday, ran fast, finishing the race in ninth place with a time of 2:11.59. But he was left far behind by the lead pack that started out fast and kept it up.

Tanner Tokunaga hit a two-run double with the bases loaded and two outs to cap a six-run sixth inning for Waipahu, Hawaii, in its come-from-behind 7-5 victory over Lake Charles, La. Hawaii earned a spot in the Little League World Series title game Sunday in South Williamsport, Pa. It will play Matamoros, Mexico, which defeated Tokyo, 5-4.

Scott Simpson matched the lowest round of the tournament with a six-under-par 66 and held a two-shot lead over David Edwards after two rounds of the Boeing Classic at the T.P.C. Snoqualmie Ridge in Snoqualmie, Wash. Simpson made five birdies on the back nine.

Jaromir Jagr, who left the Rangers last month to sign with the Russian league team Avangard Omsk, received the Golden Stick award as the top hockey player from the Czech Republic for the fourth consecutive year and a record ninth time over all. Jagr, 36, finished ahead of Montreal Canadiens forward Tomas Plekanec and Toronto Maple Leafs defenseman Tomas Kaberle in the voting.
Darren Clarke, a Ryder Cup contender, shot a four-under-par 66 to take a three-stroke lead over Henrik Stenson at the KLM Open in Zandvoort, Netherlands.

Carl Edwards watched Kyle Busch lead 415 consecutive laps Saturday night at Bristol Motor Speedway in Tennessee, then used his bumper to nudge Busch in the first turn on the 470th lap of 500. That move caused Busch’s car to wiggle just enough so that Edwards could drive by on his way to his second consecutive Nascar Sprint Cup victory.

Houston Coach Gary Kubiak said that receiver Harry Williams would have surgery Sunday to repair a fractured vertebra in his neck. Williams, 26, was hurt Friday when he collided with teammate Nick Ferguson while trying to make a tackle on a kick return early in the Texans’ 23-22 loss to Dallas. Williams was taken to Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. Kubiak said Williams’s condition had not changed since the team doctor Walter Lowe said early Saturday that Williams had regained feeling in his extremities and most of his normal neurological function.
Danny Lee moved to the brink of supplanting Tiger Woods as the youngest champion in United States Amateur history by defeating Patrick Reed 3 and 2 in the semifinals Saturday in Pinehurst, N.C.

Helen Alfredsson shot a five-under-par 67 for the second day in a row to take a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the L.P.G.A. Safeway Classic at Columbia Edgewater Country Club in Portland, Ore. Alfredsson had a 10-under 134 total, one shot ahead of Sophie Gustafson, who shot 68.

Honey Brook Organic Farm, 260 Wargo Road, Pennington; (609) 737-8899; www.honeybrookorganicfarm.com. Started in 1991, Honey Brook’s C.S.A. is one of the largest community-supported agriculture programs in the country, with 2,313 members participating from June through November. Pickup at the farm is available, as is delivery to off-site locations. Members can also pick some of their own produce — currently edamame, tomatillos and okra, for example. The C.S.A. is fully subscribed for the season; visit the farm’s Web site starting in January to apply for 2009.

I was pleased to see Elizabeth Royte’s discussion of wastewater. (Aug. 10). Watercourse (www.watercoursefoods.com) at 837 East 17th Avenue serves excellent vegetarian meals. I also suggest the Denver Public Library’s coffee shop for a good coffee and cookie break. To the Editor: Visitors to Kosice, Slovakia ("Once Soviet Gray, Now a Colorful Mix," Aug. 10), with Jewish roots may be interested to know that up until 1941 the city (below) had a vibrant Jewish community — approximately 15 percent of the population were Jews. In 1944, about 12,000 Jews were deported; less than half survived the Nazi concentration camps.

To the Editor: The photo of the Taj Mahal in “Why We Travel” (July 27) brought back memories. My father served in India from 1942 to 1945 as part of the Army Air Forces. He always carried a camera with him, and while stationed in Agra, he took a photograph of the Taj Mahal by moonlight. I’m looking at his photo while writing this letter. Amazingly, the viewpoint for both photos as well as the condition of the Taj appear to be almost exactly the same.

An article last Sunday about concerns over the expanding prescription use of methadone for various injuries erroneously included a drug among those that killed the television personality Anna Nicole Smith in 2007. An article and a picture caption last Sunday about the lagging ability of the United States to patrol Arctic waters misstated the size of the Healy, an ice-breaking vessel used mainly for science. Though it is not designed to crush the thickest ice, the Healy is longer and heavier — not smaller — than the United States’ two heavy icebreakers, the Polar Sea and the Polar Star.

Though the hotel is well appointed, some glitches prevented it from offering a true four-star experience.
John Flansburgh of They Might Be Giants shared what kind of music he would listen to if he had children.
Recordings for television from the 1960s and early ’70s capture both a composer and the tenor who was his collaborator and life partner.

A fable about a giant who tries to accomplish impossible tasks set for him by the woman he wants to marry.

Why did the Chinese authorities react so strongly against an exercise society?
A scientist explains what makes Homo sapiens so unlike other beasts.
Stephen Hawking said when something falls into a black hole, all its information is lost. To one academic, that sounded like curtains for quantum mechanics.
Anne Roiphe describes her life after the death of her husband.
How to steer people toward healthier, more prosperous lives, with a little help from the powers that be.
A novel from 1969 comes as a box of unbound sheaves, giving the reader a sense of the fragile experiences it contains.
A foreign correspondent recounts the history of the Kurds.
A year in the life of a mom -- the performance artist Sandra Tsing Loh.
Paul Theroux retraces the journey that established his career.

Brenda Wineapple explores the friendship of Emily Dickinson and Thomas Wentworth Higginson.

Norman Mailer’s account of the 1968 conventions is a portrait of America, and Mailer, at a bad moment.
Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
Paperback books of particular interest.
At the city’s often-threadbare fringes, there is an inescapable sense of lonesomeness.
Evelyn Waugh’s satirical masterpiece “Scoop” (1938), about hack journalists in London, is 70 years old this summer and back in the news.
Despite the cooling economy, prices held steady at the vintage car sales around Monterey, Calif.
Electric vehicles designed and built by teams of students are being raced in an attempt to improve public awareness.
Gorden Wagener, the new design head at Mercedes-Benz, says that in a market motivated by innovation, constancy is a challenge.
Resources for disable veterans who drive.
The EX35, which Infiniti positions as a “reward” vehicle for women, is a smaller, softer-edged crossover utility vehicle.

What it’s been like reporting a conflict that never seems to end.
A casino job in Atlantic City that lasts until school starts or until whenever.
Hollywood, Schmollywood. The Red Bucket Films crew will take Manhattan.
Scented with lemon, cloves, cinnamon and ginger, this combination, which ran in The Times in 1948, has roots going back to the 18th century.
This recipe was created by Ruth P. Casa-Emellos,.
By Maria Hines, the chef and owner of Tilth in Seattle.
And other mysteries of the yoga lexicon illuminated.
Unspecial delivery; unendowed chair.
Corny salesmanship or entertainment — what’s the difference?
The Ohio congressman talks about why he’s speaking at the convention, why he continues to work for the president’s impeachment and the role of U.F.O.’s in Washington.
What, exactly, is wrong with a celebrity candidate?
Explore the West Indian restaurants concentrated along Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues and get a taste for jerk chicken, roti and cassava pones.
Membership prices and terms are for the current 2008 growing season, for which most C.S.A.’s are fully subscribed.

Shares in community-supported agriculture programs have been almost impossible to come by this summer, even with prices that run as high as $600 for the season. If the C.S.A.’s near you are filled, check back; several are already planning major expansions for 2009.
In recent years, this old beach resort has experienced a kind of cultural revival. Elders idling on park benches have been replaced by artists and young professionals gathering at cafes.
Though just a short ferry hop from Vancouver, the 50-mile stretch of craggy forest and marine parks that make up this coast feels far away from the city’s action.
A tour company offers travelers interaction within traditional communities.
This week, answers to readers’ questions about what to say when an acquaintance has had plastic surgery, book club rules, your daughter’s college boyfriend's sleeping arrangements and more.
Faced with sticker shock at the gas pump, more travelers are turning to hybrid rental cars in search of savings. But with demand high, these green cars are commanding a premium.
This is not the tourist Africa of upscale game parks and locals decked out in quaint native dress, but a land of stark beauty and riveting contradictions.
The filmmaking Pang twins can always be counted on for a few searing images, like in their latest movie, “Bangkok Dangerous.”
To ensure that no theater reference goes unappreciated in their musical, the creators and two of the co-stars of “[title of show]” created a cheat sheet.
Nicky Silver, a bit less angry, is back with a new play, “Three Changes.”
In Bollywood the motion picture industry remains resolutely star struck, even as special effects have helped to reduce Hollywood’s dependence on big-name actors.
Karen McCullah Lutz and Kirsten Smith are that rarest of Hollywood commodities: a successful female writing team. Their latest film is “The House Bunny.”
Woody Allen on how to film a love quadrangle when everyone in the cast clearly idolizes the director. “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” is now on DVD.

Matt Bai (Aug. 10) raises an interesting question: If Obama gets elected into the White House, will black politics as we know it disappear? Even if black politics has morphed to reflect generational and class differences arising from the post-civil-rights era in the greater black community, black politics will continue as long as the concept of race and political institutions such as the Congressional Black Caucus exist.
Barack Obama is both more left-wing and more right-wing than many people realize. A 15-year debate among economics experts in the Democratic Party helps explain why.

The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 10, about airlines that are cutting back on routes, misstated Continental Airlines’ plans to alter service to Tallahassee, Fla. Starting Sept. 3, Continental will no longer fly from Houston to Tallahassee; it is not canceling all service to Tallahassee. (Continental Connection, operated by Gulfstream, will continue to offer service between Tallahassee and Tampa, Fla., and Tallahassee and West Palm Beach, Fla.) As the column correctly noted, Continental is ending service to Sarasota.

While banners remind New Yorkers to eat their vegetables, color speaks clearly of the evolving season. Spring and early summer's sweet-pea pastels, top left, segue into the bright primaries of full summer -- tomato red and sunflower yellow. And now as August draws to a close, a surprise: brown in many shades, including a few men's suits.
Knowshon Moreno GEORGIA RUNNING BACK The SEC's top returning rusher, he will need a big season for the Bulldogs to remain national championship contenders during a brutal conference schedule.

Mr. Haysbert may be the only man ever elected to the presidency despite having been captured on camera practicing voodoo wearing only a towel. That was in the 1989 baseball movie ''Major League,'' in which his character, the slugger Pedro Cerrano, spoke in the kind of thick Caribbean accent usually associated with the word ''ganja.'' Cerrano turned to voodoo rituals to overcome his inability to hit breaking balls, generally performing these rituals shirtless. (He was, for a future president, remarkably buff.) By 1999 Mr. Haysbert was a doctor in the CBS series ''Now and Again,'' advising a man whose brain had been implanted in a bio-engineered body. He was elected to the United States Senate in 2001, in time for the first season of the Fox series ''24,'' and by Season 2 he was President David Palmer.

GOODWIN--Hope Talcott Passed away on August 17, 2008, in Glen Cove, New York, at the age of 88. She was a resident of Peconic Landing, Greenport, New York. Previously she had lived on the North Shore of Long Island and in New York City. She was first and foremost a loving wife, mother and grandmother and will be sorely missed by her family and friends. Born in 1920 in New York City, she was the daughter of James and Mary Talcott of Rye, New York. She attended the Rye Country Day School, Miss Halls, and graduated from Finch and The Empire State Colleges. She also earned a nursing degree from the Columbia School of Nursing. Among her civic activities, Hope worked for the United Hospital Fund and served as President: of the Society of the Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Center. She was also deeply involved in the political life of her late husband, Elliot H. Goodwin, who was a leader of both Nelson Rockefeller and Richard Nixon's presidential campaigns and who, In 1959, ran for Congress from New York City. She is survived by her daughter, Ellen T. Goodwin, of New York City, son, Dr. Charles B. Goodwin of New York City and Mill Neck, New York, and grandchildren, Emily, Alexandra and Jack Goodwin, also of New York City and Mill Neck. Funeral Service will be held on Tuesday, August 26, 2008, at St. John's Church, 1670 Rt. 25a, Cold Spring Harbor, New York, telephone (516) 692-6374. Burial will follow at the Memorial Cemetery of St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor. An avid gardener, Hope was an early volunteer at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park. The family is establishing a memorial bench in her name. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made out to the Central Park Conservancy and mailed to Dr. Charles Goodwin 635 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10022.

AT 7:11 on a recent Sunday morning, a box truck making its sixth delivery of the day turned onto a quiet residential street in South Orange, N.J. The truck, which bore no name but was well known to the neighbors because it appeared every Sunday from June through November, backed into the driveway of a large white house. Two men wordlessly jumped out of the cab and unloaded 20 identical bushel boxes, including one that was mine. Each contained garlic, eggplants, sweet and hot peppers, chard, cilantro, potatoes, shallots, green beans and grape tomatoes. The men also left behind 20 bunches of flowers and 20 smaller boxes of tomatoes.
PETRONE--Emiel N. 3/23/43--8/23/04. Eternal love, we miss you so. M.

BLOHM--Christel, age 88, of Watkins Glen, formerly of Buffalo, left the mortal bounds of this earth the morning of Tuesday, August 19, 2008. Her daughter, Helen, was there to bid her adieu and bon voyage. For forty years, Christel worked for the Pieper Travel Bureau in Buffalo, NY. She was a travel agent extraordinaire, being one of the top twenty-five agents in the United States. While creating unique travel adventures for individuals and groups such as the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, she traveled the world visiting far away places like the Galapagos Islands, Vietnam and China. On her second visit to China in 1981, she attended the opening of the Grand Canal to western tourists for the first time since the revolution in 1948. Her home is lovingly filled with artwork and mementos of her worldwide travels across five continents. Christel had a lifelong passion for politics and foreign affairs. A native of Germany, Christel became an American citizen in 1973 so that she could participate in our electoral process. Upon retiring to Watkins Glen, she immersed herself in the activities of the League of Women Voters of Schuyler County, serving on the Board for a number of years. An avid reader with an insatiable quest for knowledge, Christel supported or volunteered for many local organizations; Friends of the Watkins Glen Library, the Schuyler County Historical Society, ARC, and the Schuyler Hospital Auxiliary, to name a few. Per her wishes, memorial services will be private. Those wishing to remember Christel are encouraged to do so with a memorial gift to the Watkins Glen Public Library which will be matched by her family.

As anyone over 50 could sing you in musical-jingle form, for three seasons beginning in 1963 Ms. Duke was both Cathy and Patty Lane (''They're cousins. Identical cousins ... '') in ''The Patty Duke Show.'' One of them -- it's not clear which -- grew up to be the manipulative pill-popper Neely O'Hara in the 1967 film ''Valley of the Dolls,'' but the other went straighter: she spent time as a nun, in the 1983 TV film ''September Gun,'' then the next year found herself as the first first lady, Martha Washington, in a TV mini-series about George. A year after that she was President Julia Mansfield in the ABC series ''Hail to the Chief.'' The country, alas, was not ready for a female president; the show was canceled after a few months. (After being run out of office Ms. Duke returned to the convent, as a character named Mother Joseph in the 2004 TV movie ''Murder Without Conviction.'') EERIE CONNECTIONS TO OTHER PRESIDENTS William Schallert, who played Patty Lane's father, later played Herbert Kalmbach, President Richard M. Nixon's lawyer, in the 1979 mini-series ''Blind Ambition.''

BROOKS--John, 45 year resident of Greenwich Village, an unofficial mayor of Washington Square Park, died August 13th, 2008 at the age of 86. Born in Danville, VA. Served in the 1697th Engineering Company in WWII. Worked as a disc jockey at WBTM in Danville and later managed a bowling center in New York, he worked in the Dom, 9th Circle and Reno Sweeney's as a bouncer and greater. He loved to travel and learn foreign languages and made many friends abroad. He is survived by his wife Karen and his children Allen Brooks, Audrey Hubbard and Iris Boswell.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''After the Anthems'' Aug. 18: Olympic athletes like Michael Phelps and Dara Torres should not only continue to be revered and immortalized, they should also be respectfully asked to allow molecular genetic analysis of their DNA for research.

A year ago, Yale running back Mike McLeod was the Ivy League player of the year and its only all-American. In a 10-game season, he rushed for 1,619 yards and 23 touchdowns. He played the last five games with a broken right big toe that prevented him from planting and cutting. This year, as a senior, he could be even better. ''I think I will be, because we're bringing in a passing game,'' McLeod said in a telephone interview. ''We're used to seeing eight or nine men in the box, but I don't think we'll see that again.'' The defenses that crowded the line of scrimmage were designed to stop McLeod, a 5-foot-11, 205-pound tailback from New Britain, Conn. He usually foiled them. ''I feel I can see the field better than most people,'' he said. ''I'm not the biggest guy, but I can still bring it up the middle on third-and-short, and I can bust big runs. I think I'm an elusive back who runs angry with deceptive power.'' This season, McLeod hopes to be more involved in a short passing game and return some kickoffs. His future goal is to play pro football. ''If not,'' he said, ''then the financial world. Hopefully, the economy will improve by the time I graduate. Otherwise, maybe law school.'' But first things first. ''It should be the best we've had in four years,'' he said. ''We're a lot stronger, a lot more dedicated, and people who didn't give it their all are all gone.'' In this year's preseason news media survey, Yale and Harvard finished in a tie for league champion. A look at all of the teams, in order of predicted finish: YALE (2007 record: 9-1, 6-1) A decade ago, the Elis threw 45 or 50 times a game. Now they run, because of Mike McLeod, one of 35 seniors on the team. Jack Siedlecki, entering his 12th season as Yale's head coach, calls him the best short-yardage runner he has coached and probably the quickest 10-yard runner he has coached. ''He doesn't try to juke you,'' Siedlecki said. ''It's just one move and go.'' But for McLeod to be most effective, the offense must improve play-action calls to keep defenses guessing. PLAYERS TO WATCH TB Mike McLeod, LB Bobby Abare, OT Darius Dale, DE Brady Hart, FS Steve Santoro, C Ty Davis, P Tom Mante. HARVARD (8-2, 7-0) Last year, the Crimson had the league's best total defense (274.6 yards a game) and rushing defense (77.5), and that unit should be strong again. So should the front seven for an offense that averaged 407.7 yards a game last season. Chris Pizzotti is 11-1 as the starting quarterback and does not make mistakes. He threw only four interceptions last year. ''We have a chance to be good,'' Coach Tim Murphy said, ''but we're concerned about depth and the secondary.'' PLAYERS TO WATCH OT James Williams, DT Matt Curtis, LB Glenn Dorris, CB Andrew Berry, TB Cheng Ho, DE Peter Ajayi, LB Eric Schultz. BROWN (5-5, 4-3) The Bruins' offense last year averaged 424 yards and 32.1 points a game, the best in the league, and this year's team could do the same. Michael Dougherty, in his first year as starting quarterback, passed for 3,039 yards and 19 touchdowns. Jim Develin, an excellent pass rusher, leads the defense. As Coach Phil Estes said, ''We have experience, we're a lot better, and we have a chance to contend.'' PLAYERS TO WATCH WR Buddy Farnham, WR Bobby Sewall, TE Colin Cloherty, OT Paul Jasinowski, QB Michael Dougherty, DE Jim Develin. PENNSYLVANIA (4-6, 3-4) The defense can be good, especially with its strong cornerbacks. The offensive line is inexperienced. The big question mark is at quarterback, where Robert Irvin starts after missing his freshman season and most of his junior season with an injured passing shoulder. As a sophomore, he passed for 2,128 yards. He's big and smart and has a strong arm, and if he does well, Coach Al Bagnoli said, ''We have a chance to be pretty good.'' PLAYERS TO WATCH S Chris Wynn, LB Jay Colabella, OT Chris Kovalcik, CB Tyson Maugle, TB Michael DiMaggio. PRINCETON (4-6, 3-4) The offensive line has four players who have started since their freshman seasons. Brian Anderson, the senior quarterback, has started only one game, last year's finale (he won). Coach Roger Hughes's assessment: ''I like this team a lot -- chemistry, work ethic, unselfishness -- but I don't know how many games we're going to win.'' PLAYERS TO WATCH P Ryan Coyle, DE Pete Buchignani, QB Brian Anderson, DE Tom Methvin, DT Matt Koch. CORNELL (5-5, 2-5) This is Nate Ford's third year as the starting quarterback, and because of injuries he has yet to finish a season. The offensive and defensive lines were pushed around last year and must improve physically. But there are 33 seniors from Coach Jim Knowles's first recruiting class. ''No more excuses,'' he said. PLAYERS TO WATCH QB Nate Ford, OT Steve Valenta, S Tim Bax, WR Zac Canty, LB Graham Rihn. DARTMOUTH (3-7, 3-4) Coach Buddy Teevens said his team would be much improved and more competitive. He cited ''more depth, more team speed, more pressure from the defensive line.'' He also said athleticism would make up for inexperience. He plans to use two quarterbacks: the junior Alex Jenny and the sophomore Tim McManus, who started at wide receiver last year. PLAYERS TO WATCH LB Andrew Dete, OT Alex Rapp, TB Milan Williams, DE Charles Bay, S Ian Wilson. COLUMBIA (1-9, 0-7) The Lions need to improve everywhere, starting with better blocking and better defense up front against the run. They must also choose a starting quarterback from a group of three: the juniors M. A. Olawale and Shane Kelly and the sophomore Paul Havas. Still, Coach Norries Wilson said, ''We have a chance to have a decent team.'' PLAYERS TO WATCH WR Austin Knowlin, LB Alex Gross, P/K Jon Rochell, DE Phillip Mitchell, OT Mike Brune.

GILES--Thomas Jefferson, 79, died Tuesday, August 19, 2008. Born in Baltimore, MD and raised there and in Philadelphia, PA, Giles was a respected Senior Project Manager for over three decades at SLCE Architects in NYC. He was a graduate of Penn State, class of 1949, and taught mathematics at Prairie View A & M University in Texas, then moved to NYC, where he met and married Dorothy Aileen Dove. They were married for 47 years until her death in 1998. They settled in St. Albans, Queens in 1956, where they raised seven children, who survive him: Leland, of Brooklyn, Lorna, of Martha's Vineyard, MA, Jeffrey, of NYC, Dwayne, of Winsted, CT, Nancy, of Weehawken, NJ, Gilbert, of Jersey City, NJ, and Susan, of Hamilton, NJ; son-in-law Kenneth Armstead and daughterin-law Gail Giles; six grandchildren: Julius and Carmen, Melora and Emelia, Jazmin and Guy; one great-grandchild: Olivia; and dozens of nieces, nephews, friends and colleagues at SLCE, fellow Lance Hayward Singers, loving family members and dear friends. Viewing will be held this afternoon, Sunday August 24th, at John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 W. 51st St. from 2-5 and 7-9pm. A memorial service will be held on Monday August 25th at 2pm at Christ & St. Stephen's Church, 120 W. 69th St., NYC. Burial will be private.

As Victor Frankenstein in his own 1994 film, Mr. Branagh constructed a monster that looked a lot like Robert De Niro. Then he took his turn as Hamlet in his 1996 film before signing on as the vain, blundering and ultimately duplicitous Prof. Gilderoy Lockhart in the Harry Potter films. All that havoc, and that he is Irish, didn't keep Mr. Branagh from the presidency, or at least the doorstep of it: he delivered an Emmy-nominated performance as a young Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 2005 HBO movie ''Warm Springs.'' EERIE CONNECTIONS TO OTHER PRESIDENTS Mr. Branagh was, in effect, married to his own mother, Sara Delano Roosevelt. She was played in ''Warm Springs'' by Jane Alexander, who in 1977 played Eleanor Roosevelt in the TV production ''Eleanor and Franklin: The White House Years.'' Also, Kevin Kline, the adversary to his villain in the 1999 film ''Wild Wild West,'' had been one of the country's more genial presidents, in the 1993 film ''Dave.''

Ignore the warm weather and carve out some time to watch these games. Rankings from The Associated Press. SATURDAY, AUG. 30
TRIPP--Mary. Your voice and love, with me in memory and in my heart. I 'm never alone. Norma

WETZEL--Harry Herman, Jr. January 27, 1920--August 14, 2008. Aviation pioneer Harry Herman Wetzel Jr. died on August 14, of complications of old age. He was 88. Harry made important contributions to aerospace, to the wine business, and to his community and the arts. He will be remembered as an engineer's engineer with an extraordinary memory and powerful intellect, coupled with boundless curiosity, impeccable courtesy, and an impish sense of humor. Born on January 27, 1920 in Howard, PA, Harry was the only child of Maude T. and Harry H. Wetzel. His father, a vice president at the Douglas Aircraft company, played a key role in the development and manufacture of the DC3. Harry graduated from Cornell University in 1941 with a bachelors degree in engineering. He then joined the Army Air Force, where he served as an experimental test pilot. In 1945, he married Margaret Kirkpatrick of Hampton, Virginia. They moved to California and in 1946 he joined the Garrett Corporation, a supplier to the burgeoning aerospace industry, as a laboratory technician. In 1963, Harry became president of Garrett and he held the position of CEO when he retired in 1985. Under his leadership, Garrett became the world's largest producer of aircraft auxiliary power units as well as truck and car turbochargers. Harry also initiated the development of a new and very efficient aircraft fanjet engine, which enabled business jets to make the coast-to-coast trip non-stop. Harry was often referred to as ''A man with a plan for a fan.'' In 1962, the Wetzels purchased a piece of land in California's Alexander Valley, on the site of Cyrus Alexander's original homestead. In 1975, they established Alexander Valley Vineyards winery, which, guided by their son Hank, produces premium varietal wines to this day. Harry loved to travel, and up until his death he continued to plan family trips. He was also an excellent cabinetmaker and many members of his family have beautiful pieces of furniture that he made. An avid fisherman and hunter, he was a crack shot with a pistol, rifle and shotgun. He did the New York Times crossword puzzle every day. On the cultural side, he served as chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Performing Arts Council Music Center; as a Trustee of the Donald Douglas Museum and Library; and as a board member of the California Institute of Technology. Beneficiaries of his time and philanthropy also include the Santa Rosa Symphony and the Wetzel Emergency Department at Healdsburg Hospital. He is survived by his children Sally Fallon Morell, Hank Wetzel, Katie Wetzel Murphy, and John Wetzel; his thirteen grandchildren and their spouses; and his three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Tuesday, August 26 at Alexander Valley Vineyards, 8640 Highway 128, Healdsburg, CA.
Television Ginia Bellafante

JEWETT--Thomas Hardin. August 14, 2008. A devoted husband and son, a patient, generous father who never failed the people he loved, Tom was a true Southern gentleman. Born in Wilmington, North Carolina, July 4, 1922, he grew up in Winston Salem. After two years in the infantry during WWII, he returned to graduate from the University of North Carolina in 1947. He joined the newly formed Coca Cola Export Corporation in July 1947, retiring as Assistant Treasurer of the Coca Cola Corporation and Senior Vice President and Treasurer of the Coca Cola Finance Corporation in 1984. During his years at Coke, Tom worked in Hawaii, Manila, Japan, New York, Nassau, Buenos Aires and Atlanta. After retirement, he taught at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Virginia. At the time of his death he lived at Fearrington Village in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. He will be missed and remembered by Jean Curtin Jewett, his wife of 61 years; his six children: Kelleher, Curt (Maria), Robert (Amy), Susan (Marsha), Leslie (Patrick) and David (Paula); and nine grandchildren (Valerie Jewett, Beth Toriello, Tom and Joe Jewett, Patty, Danny, Andrew, Sarah, and Emma Paddon). ''Love has no ending.'' A service will be held at 11:00 on August 30 in the Chapel of the Cross on the campus of the University of North Carolina. Friends and family are invited to the service and to join the family at home afterwards.

FABIEN BARON, the art director and creative force behind Interview magazine's redesign, is known for a lot of things. Until recently, photographing the sea was not one of them. ''It's a very personal thing,'' he said of the ethereal images of sea and sky in his first book, ''Liquid Light 1983-2003.'' Evidently Mr. Baron spent a good portion of 20 years waking at 4 a.m. and lugging a 50-pound 8- by-10 Deardorff camera to beaches from Southampton, N.Y., to Skane, Sweden. Then he would wait for hours until the light was just right. ''It was a big part of my routine, like going to the gym,'' he said. ''And it allowed me to reconnect to the basics. It was very Zen.'' After taking some 2,000 seascapes, though, Mr. Baron admitted it's very much over. ''I'm done doing that picture,'' he said.
BAROTZ--Miriam Ruth, Beloved mother and friend of Barbara and Jeff Chase, passed away on August 20th, 2008 in Florida. She will be in our hearts and prayers forever and will be missed dearly.

SHATTUCK--Julie Follansbee-Pratt. Our Mother, grandmother, aunt and dear friend, Julie Follansbee Pratt Shattuck, who found pure joy in nature, food, language, art, and friendship died August 16th at the age of 88. An actress, she was the youngest of five children, certainly the most Bohemian, and always championed the underdog, in her heart and in her life, perhaps because she felt she was one. Although Julie was a master gardener, an accomplished French cook-worshipped all things French--who served food as if it were love itself, a world traveler, a Thespian from Brecht and ''The Gin Game'' to ''Regarding Henry'' and ''Law and Order,'' was adored by two husbands, the photographer, Charles Pratt and International Attorney, Francis Shattuck, she never quite fathomed how powerfully she affected those around her. Julie read everything from Marcel Proust to Bill Maxwell, who was her dear friend and on whose birthday she died, ever loyal. She was as disarmingly hilarious as she was generous to her friends and family. We will miss her passion for peonies and her apple tree, for smelly cheese, for a rare bottle of wine, for the Democrats, for the pitch perfect dramatic moment. She is survived by her only child, Mike Pratt, her ''one miracle,'' and his wife, Carol, her grandchildren, Julian and Sam Pratt, stepchildren, John Shattuck and Tina Stenhaus and the many devoted friends and family who will hold her enchanting, irreverent presence close to them, always.
Film Manohla Dargis

THE Volkswagen Polo has never been sold in the United States, though more than 300,000 are sold each year in Europe, Asia, South America and Africa. There might be compelling reasons to bring Polos here, especially the diesel versions. Why? Because they get incredible fuel economy, better than most hybrids. In the European driving cycle, the Polo 1.4 TDI is rated at 41/62 miles per gallon.

BEVERLEY--J. Gray Jr., 73, of Manhattan and Roxbury, CT, on August 5. Mr. Beverley, born in Winchester, VA, graduated from The Episcopal High School in Alexandria, VA, and, in 1958, from The University of Virginia. He spent his entire business career in Manhattan, first in advertising at firms such as Geer DuBois, BBDO and Wells Rich Green, then in tax management and investment banking at Blandfield Securities Inc. and Selma Capital Inc., names borrowed from ancestral homes in Virginia. He was a onetime member of The Squadron A Association and the Dance Notation Bureau. Mr. Beverley retired a captain from the U.S. Army Reserves. He also was an avid tennis, polo and poker player who loved poetry, philosophy and laughter. He is survived by J. Gray Beverley III of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, and Caroline Noel Blackmon of Winterville, GA, as well as by family in Virginia, Maryland, and North Carolina.

WEEKEND beachgoers lately find themselves inching through Highlands, N.J., if they move at all. Charming but obsolete, the 76-year-old drawbridge over the Shrewsbury River linking Highlands to Sandy Hook is being replaced with a fixed-span bridge, and the waterfront is cluttered with construction cranes and orange traffic cones. The project is scheduled to go on for the next two summers, said Anna Little, the part-time mayor of Highlands, a Monmouth County borough of about 5,000. That might not make the town seem so desirable now, but consider this: those who live in Highlands are close enough to walk, jog, pedal, paddle or even take a water taxi to the beach.

DOMESTIC DISTURBANCES John Edwards obviously owed his wife the truth. He did owe his supporters an apology for having led them into a venture that would necessarily have exploded, disastrously, had the adultery revelations surfaced in the general election campaign. But besides this narrow and deserving audience, the only person for whom John Edwards ''had'' to make his confession was John Edwards. It was a necessary, preliminary step on the road to redemption, the beginning of the dance of sin and sorriness that may, eventually, pave the way up from his current depths of shame to new heights of wiser, smarter, deeper, public service. He made no secret of this. ''I don't think anything's ended,'' he told Bob Woodruff. ''My Lord and my wife have forgiven me. So I'm going to move on.'' This particular round of re-branding doesn't much seem to have worked, judging by how ''unsatisfying'' reviewers have judged Edwards's ''Nightline'' performance to have been. But I have no doubt that, in the future, he'll be back -- with a few well-planned wrinkles, a few grizzled hairs to connote wisdom and suffering, and, most important, a more personal and immediate relationship with God. One simply wonders, with a shudder, whether Elizabeth will be with him.

10 P.M. (Animal Planet) ANIMAL WITNESS: THE MICHAEL VICK CASE By many standards Mr. Vick, left, had it all: a 10-year, $130 million deal as a quarterback with the Atlanta Falcons and sponsorship by Nike, Coca-Cola and Kraft. Then, in April 2007, a drug investigation sent the police to Mr. Vick's Virginia home, where instead of illegal substances they found 66 pit bulls -- part of a dogfighting circuit financed by Mr. Vick. This hourlong report, the premiere episode of a new series, examines the case through Mr. Vick's testimony, film of actual dogfights and interviews with boyhood friends of Mr. Vick, representatives of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, and Bill Brinkman, lead investigator on the case. It also visits rehabilitated dogs that used to belong to Mr. Vick, many of which now live as pets and even as therapy dogs, providing companionship for the sick and elderly. 9 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS From Denver, Caroline Kennedy, co-chairwoman of Barack Obama's vice-presidential search committee; Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California and House speaker.

FLOWERS--Esther F. On Thursday, August 21, 2008 at her home in Rye, New York, at 91. Beloved wife of Roy, who predeceased her in 1993, loving mother of William, Kenneth, and Richard, all of New York City, Carolyn Wilson, of Salt Lake City, and Donald of Larchmont, New York, dear older sister of Lois Fischle of Upland, California, and nurturing grandmother to nine grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday morning, September 13, 2008, at 11am at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church. FLOWERS--Esther F. The Clark & Wilkins Co. mourns the passing of our past president Esther Elizabeth Fischle Flowers on Thursday, August 21, 2008, at her home in Rye, New York at 91. Mrs. Flowers, a 1937 graduate of Mt. Holyoke College, served as an officer of the company for over sixty years. She assumed the role of president upon her husbands death in 1993, serving until 2007. Her late husband, Roy Malcolm Flowers, was the greatgrandson of George Malcolm Clark who co-founded the business in 1870. Mrs. Flowers is survived by her five children and their spouses, William Ellwood (Mary Kay), Kenneth Fischle (Glory Jones), and Richard Clark, all of New York City, Carolyn Muriel Flowers Wilson (Dr. Dana Wilson) of Salt Lake City, and Donald Foster (Maria) of Larchmont, New York, along with her sister, Lois Ann Fischle of Upland, California, nine grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday morning, September 13, 2008, at 11am at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church. William E. Flowers, Chairman; Kenneth F. Flowers, President

One of Mr. Quaid's earliest roles was Larry Meadows, the shoplifting sailor who is being escorted to the brig in the 1973 film ''The Last Detail.'' The kleptomania was apparently overlooked by those who elected him president in 1987, when he played Lyndon B. Johnson in the acclaimed mini-series ''LBJ: The Early Years.'' Then, though, he went back to crime: Mr. Quaid robbed that bank in ''Quick Change'' in 1990 and played the murderous John Wesley Hardin in the 1995 mini-series ''Streets of Laredo.'' Yet despite being a three-time offender, he was elected again in 2000, playing President A. Thornton Osgood II in a TV movie called ''Mail to the Chief.'' EERIE CONNECTIONS TO OTHER PRESIDENTS President Osgood's daughter was played by Elisha Cuthbert, who a year later would appear as the daughter of Jack Bauer, the agent who saved David Palmer's life, at least temporarily, in ''24.'' Mr. Quaid's brother, Dennis Quaid, also had a presidency, an embarrassing one, in ''American Dreamz'' in 2006.

Mr. Sinise was Tom Joad in a 1991 adaptation of Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath,'' a story that begins with Joad bring released from prison and later turns him into a cop-killing fugitive. Three years later he was the lone survivor in his Texas town of a plague in a TV version of ''The Stand,'' one of Stephen King's sprawling nightmares. That same year he was a scruffy, legless Vietnam veteran in ''Forrest Gump.'' Then, legs restored, came a stint as an astronaut in ''Apollo 13'' in 1995 (his Ken Mattingly didn't make that trip but did fly on Apollo 16), followed by immediate election to the White House: he had the title role in the 1995 TV movie ''Truman.'' EERIE CONNECTIONS TO OTHER PRESIDENTS Mr. Sinise also spent time as a Watergate prosecutor, playing Richard Ben-Veniste in the ABC movie ''The Final Days'' in 1989.

LATTA--Geoff, magician, famous for close-up card and coin work, died on August 19th. His seminars influenced magicians worldwide and his Zarrow shuffle is legendary. Services Monday 25th, 7pm, Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St.

The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 10, about airlines that are cutting back on routes, misstated Continental Airlines' plans to alter service to Tallahassee, Fla. Starting Sept. 3, Continental will no longer fly from Houston to Tallahassee; it is not canceling all service to Tallahassee. (Continental Connection, operated by Gulfstream, will continue to offer service between Tallahassee and Tampa, Fla., and Tallahassee and West Palm Beach, Fla.) As the column correctly noted, Continental is ending service to Sarasota.

THE NEWS A federal team of investigators reported that the 7 World Trade Center building, which collapsed on Sept. 11, 2001, was brought down by a raging fire that weakened its structure, not by explosives or other causes. BEHIND THE NEWS The collapse of the building, almost seven hours after the neighboring Twin Towers, has been Exhibit A for theorists who say the terror attacks were an ''inside job'' or for those who fault the city for putting its crisis headquarters there, including large diesel fuel tanks for emergency power. The investigators said the mystery was over, and that the heat of fires left unfought for lack of water fully accounted for the building's collapse.
To the Sports Editor: Michael Phelps accomplished much by winning eight gold medals, but we must not forget that there are other Olympians who deserve our respect and gratitude.

I love roundies! In the cities where they use them, they work wonderfully. Americans can figure them out, and they're much faster to get through than a traffic light. No wasted electricity, fewer traffic emissions, faster traffic and less damage from traffic collisions.

SINCE opening their vintage boutique Resurrection 12 years ago, Katy Rodriguez and Mark Haddawy have squirreled away the more exceptional pieces they have come across. Like the Paco Rabanne metal and leather biker jacket customized for Brigitte Bardot in 1967. Or the muslin ''God Save the Queen'' and ''Destroy'' tops designed by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren and made infamous by the Sex Pistols. ''We gravitate towards the avant-garde,'' Mr. Haddawy said. ''It's definitely not traditional clothing.'' Now some 270 of these iconic pieces from visionaries like Pierre Cardin, Jean Paul Gaultier, Norma Kamali (shown) and Yves Saint Laurent are going on the block at Christie's in London. ''It's a very youthful collection, with a lot of attitude,'' Ms. Rodriguez said. Simon Andrews, Christie's head of modern design, added: ''These garments are not only avant-garde, but indicative of the way our culture has changed.''

''This is an industry in crisis.'' Amy Myers Jaffe, associate director of Rice University's energy program in Houston, on the oil industry. Oil production has begun falling at all of the major Western oil companies.

An article last Sunday about politically themed art exhibitions opening in Denver around the time of the Democratic convention and in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area around the time of the Republican convention misstated the given name of an artist who created a media project called ''Political Science 101.'' His name is Fang-Yu Lin, not Fang. Because of an editing error, the article also referred to the artist on second reference by his given name instead of his surname.

Fifteen years before she became President Mackenzie Allen in the ABC series ''Commander in Chief'' in 2005, Ms. Davis was part of a crew that robbed a bank in the film comedy ''Quick Change.'' Like Mr. Haysbert she then played some ball, donning the tools of ignorance in 1992 in ''A League of Their Own,'' and then it was back to the outlaw life as a female pirate in ''Cutthroat Island'' in 1995. Ms. Davis's presidency, a full 20 years after Ms. Duke's, proved that the country still wasn't ready for a female head of state; ''Commander in Chief'' was off the air by 2006. EERIE CONNECTIONS TO OTHER PRESIDENTS Ms. Davis's fellow bank robbers in ''Quick Change'' included the multiple president Randy Quaid (see below), and in ''A League of Their Own'' her character was married to one played by Bill Pullman, who at the time was four years away from his own presidency in ''Independence Day.''

STURTEVANT--Ira, awardwinning advertising executive, died August 13 of lung disease. He was ''84 and three quarters.'' A life-long New Yorker, he founded the firm Ponzi & Weill with his partner of 41 years, Meg Crane, and was previously at BBDO and Foote, Cone & Belding. He was awarded a Clio and The One Club Gold Medal among many others. He specialized in advertising for pharmaceuticals, and financial services. Ira was a consummate gentleman with a quick wit and generous spirit. He earned a BS from New York University and was a Director of the NY State Phi Beta Kappa Association. He is survived by Meg, a daughter Loren Guinnebault of Paris, grandsons Maxime and Aladin Guinnebault and innumerable friends. A celebration of his life is planned for 2pm September 14 at Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, NY 10016. Donations may be made to God's Love We Deliver.

BEATLE boots, as cobbler lore has it, originated in October 1961, when John Lennon and Paul McCartney commissioned the British footwear company Anello & Davide to take the then-fashionable Chelsea boots and add some higher Cuban heels. Needless to say, the look took off, ultimately becoming synonymous with '60s rock. Now Beatle boots are back and experiencing a similar frenzy. Both Etro and Chloé have buckled variations for fall, and Sigerson Morrison's sold out at a trunk show months before they were due to hit stores. (They've been reordered and will be available in October.) So why all the fuss? Fashion's bohemian-rock revival has a lot to do with it. ''They're also the perfect mix of masculine and feminine,'' said Erin Wasson, whose own Chloé pair is pictured here. Black leather boots, $1,245 at Chloé.

PEOPLE may pooh-pooh his theory, but George Taylor, the Wharton economist who posited the ''hemline index,'' could have predicted a floor-length silhouette for fall. For him, the slumping economy would have spelled the end of the micro-mini, and, to a certain extent, that's just what happened. Though short skirts still live, a slew of forward-thinking designers, including Marc Jacobs, Marios Schwab and Junya Watanabe showed strikingly new long-and-lean looks for fall. And Kate Moss, Nicole Richie and both Olsens have taken to wearing them. Of course there are holes in the theory: The Los Angeles designer Jenni Kayne has been showing sinuous floor-length skirts for several seasons now. ''I just think they're so chic,'' she said. ''It's such an effortless way to dress up without looking over the top.'' She does note, however, that it was only this fall that store buyers took a keen interest in them. ''I guess they're just catching on,'' she said.

She was an accomplished sculptor and painter. She leaves her cousin Kenny whom she adored, two nieces much loved and her two devoted friends Carolyn and Betty. Contributions may be made in Terry's memory to Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice Care 1250 Broadway 7th Floor New York, New York 10001.

A CURIOUS GAME OF CHESS, JULY 10, 2008 Matthew Greco, 51, an English teacher from Harlem, contemplates his next move at the Lomas de Tzununá hotel, in Tzununá, by Lake Atitlán, while the San Pedro volcano looms in the background. ''I'm trying to get a novel published, so I was down there for about 10 days attending a writing workshop and to practice my Spanish -- and, yeah, for a little bit of vacation, of course. I had been down there before on a kind of social justice research trip when I was a seminary student, so I had seen a bit of the country and a lot of different aspects of it, including seeing outright violence, and had talked to organizations that were dealing with the aftereffects of the civil war. I travel quite a bit, and I would say I've done a number of social research trips to different places like Afghanistan and Syria. I like to see what people's vibes are about when I travel. It's not just, you know, get drunk on a beach.'' As told to Austin Considine

To the Sports Editor: Re ''An Olympian Debate,'' Aug. 15: Let us not forget Emil Zatopek when we speak of the greatest performances in Olympic history. At the 1952 Olympics in Helsinki, Finland, Zatopek achieved an incredible triple: he won the 5,000- and 10,000-meter races and the marathon. He also won the 10,000 and finished second in the 5,000 in London in 1948. He created a ruthlessly demanding personal training regimen without the support of a platoon of coaches, dietitians and stretchers.

TRUTANIC--Nina Bogdanovich, a prominent Californian patron of the arts and music, has died. She was 90 years old. Nina Trutanic died on August 19 after suffering a stroke while obtaining care at a medical facility in Maryland, according to her son, Richard Trutanic. Born on November 4, 1917, in the Los Angeles port community of San Pedro, Nina Trutanic was one of seven children and the last surviving child of Antoinette Simic and Martin J. Bogdanovich, a Croatian immigrant, and the founder and Chief Executive of StarKist Foods until his death. Nina served on the company's board of directors, along with her siblings, including Joseph Bogdanovich, who succeeded Martin as the Chief Executive and served in that capacity for many years after it was acquired by HJ Heinz & Company. StarKist was later sold to Del Monte Foods and Dongwon Enterprises. Nina Trutanic was married to Nicholas F. Trutanic, a leading tuna industry executive, who worked in senior international management capacities for StarKist, for over thirty years, and died aboard a Star Kist vessel in New Zealand. Nina, along with her husband, lived and traveled in various countries around the word, including Europe, South America, Asia and Africa, as the company's operations expanded and StarKist became a leading global company. Nina Trutanic grew up in San Pedro, CA and graduated from Mills College, where she studied language and music. Fluent in four languages, Nina was an ardent lover of music who studied opera and performed at various venues. She was a founder of the Los Angeles Music Center and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and active in several other philanthropic arts and educational fields thoughout her lifetime. Nina was also a personal friend of President Richard M. Nixon, his wife Pat and family. In addition to her son, Richard of Los Angeles, she is survived by her daughter, Michele Trutanic Kearney of Washington, D.C., her two grandchildren, Nicholas Trutanic and Michael Kearney, and several nieces and nephews. A funeral mass will be held on Wednesday, August 27, 2008, 10am, at the Holy Redeemer Chapel at Holy Cross Cemetery, 5835 West Slauson Avenue, Culver City. Donations to the Stroke and Cerebral Research Fund at Johns Hopkins University Medical School, 100 North Charles Street. Suite 401. Baltimore, MD 21201 Attention: Jacquelene Redmond are requested in lieu of flowers.

THE composer Joan Tower, who turns 70 in September, said she received the nicest compliment about her music after a recent performance in Arizona of her orchestral work ''Made in America.'' A 94-year-old woman shuffled up with a walker and said, ''Now I can die in peace.'' Ms. Tower's richly textured music, peppered with seductive melodies and vibrant rhythms that reflect her childhood in Latin America, often elicits an enthusiastic response. URDANG--Laurence, of Old Lyme, Connecticut, age 81, died peacefully on August 21, 2008 at Connecticut Hospice. Cherished life long companion of Irena Urdang de Tour (Saybrook Point, CT), beloved father of Nicole S. Urdang (Buffalo, NY) and Alexandra S. Urdang (NYC and Quogue), grandfather of Madelaine Urdang Criden, Maxwell Urdang Criden and Harrison Urdang Messer, father-in-law of Irwin W. Messer. Laurence was a true Renaissance man: eminent lexicographer, Phi Beta Kappa from Columbia University, linguist, wit, gourmet cook, scholar, Anglophile, and polymath. He was adept at everything in which he evinced an interest, whether it was sailing his vintage sloop, swimming from one community to the next off Fire Island, singing in his basso profundo, or playing Scrabble. His zest for life and never-ending quest for knowledge were evident to all who knew him. A prolific writer of over 200 reference books and articles, Managing Editor of the first edition of the Random House Dictionary of the English Language, Editor of the Oxford Thesaurus (affectionately dubbed Thesaurus Rex), he also created and edited Verbatim: A Language Quarterly. As a longtime member of the Dictionary Society of North America, Laurence delighted in providing a scholarship for lexicographers, and supporting their unpaid work through donations to Eurolex. His quirky sense of humor, ability to see the lighter side of almost anything, and hearty laugh will be sorely missed. Contributions may be made to Connecticut Hospice (203-315-7500) or Yale-New Haven Hospital (203 688-9644).

KHATAMI--Marie Hoguet Passed away on Wednesday, August 13, 2008 from a blood clot following cancer surgery in New York City. Her loving family will miss her profoundly. She was a brave and forward thinking 85-year-old who loved art and European and Asian cultures, a passion she shared with her husband of 57 years, Abul Khatami. We will remember so many things about her, but what stands out in our minds is her incredible spirit, fierce intelligence, and deep resounding laughter. She was as complete a human being as one could be. Marie Khatami was born in Millburn, New Jersey on February 3, 1923. She grew up in Manhattan with her five brothers and two sisters at 47 East 92nd Street. The girls attended Convent of the Sacred Heart; Marie's mother, Louise Hoguet, helped to found the St. David's School in 1951. Marie also attended Sacred Heart in Noroton, CT. and continued her studies in Paris and Siena until the imminent outbreak of World War II brought her home. She attended Barnard and completed her college education at Radcliffe in 1946, where she received a B.A. Her interests in Art History and Asian culture can be traced to the gift of a book from her father, Robert Louis Hoguet, when she was a girl, ''Folktales of Bengal'' by Lal Behari Day. Her parents had traveled to Asia and also traveled with their eight children throughout Europe when she was a child, instilling in her a lifelong love of European and Asian culture. That love compelled her to continue her studies in Chinese Art at the Asia Institute, where she obtained her Masters degree and where she met her husband, Sayyid Abulquasim Khatami, from Isfahan, Iran, who became an anthropologist at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. It was an art book lent by Marie to Abul that brought them together. They were married on January 9, 1951 and raised their four children in Manhattan. Marie is survived by her husband, Abul, who lives in Manhattan, Marie Norton of Manhattan, Jim Khatami of San Francisco, Renee Khatami of Manhattan, Jessie K. Wallen of Del Mar, California, and proud grandmother of Christopher Khatami, Patrick Norton, Sophie and Emme MacArthur, and Johnnie and Jimmy Wallen, and her sister Eleanor Hoguet de Give of Newburyport, Massa chusetts. A memorial service will be announced. She will be interred at Most Holy Trinity Church Cemetery in Easthampton, NY. Contributions may be made in her memory to the charity of your choice.

Survived by her loving husband Arthur; sons David of Hong Kong and Chris Lund (Diane Wallace) of Ontario, Canada, and grandchildren Sam, Hannah, Ethan and Helen. Grace worked for many years in healthcare administration, most notably at Montefiore Hospital. Memorial services to be announced.

JANOWITZ--Henry D. National Co-Founders, Board of Trustees, staff, and volunteers of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America, Inc., deeply mourn the loss and celebrate the life of our CoFounder, Henry D. Janowitz, MD. A pioneer in and leader of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) research, Dr. Janowitz was a brilliant physician dedicated to the Foundation's mission of research, education, and support and was the first Chairman of the Foundation's National Scientific Advisory Committee. Founder of the clinical and academic gastroenterology unit at Mount Sinai School of Medicine over 50 years ago, Dr. Janowitz truly helped to develop the field of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis research. Through his efforts in establishing and building the Foundation, and by improving the medical treatment of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, his work made a difference in the lives of over 1.4 million people, including 140,000 children under the age of 18, affected by these difficult intestinal diseases. As a clinician, consultant, and teacher, his legacy will live on in the hundreds of physicians that he trained and who will carry on the tradition of excellence in patient care. National Co-Founders, Irwin M. and Suzanne Rosenthal, and William D. (deceased) and Shelby Modell; Chairman of the Board, Mark Goldman; Chair of the National Scientific Advisory Committee, Jonathan Braun MD, PhD; and President, Richard J. Geswell.

PASAROW--Claire. Those associated with the Robert J. and Claire Pasarow Foundation, including the Board of Directors, Advisors, and Awardees, extend our heartfelt condolences to the Pasarow Family on the passing of Claire Pasarow. The Pasarows established the Foundation over twenty years ago to celebrate extraordinary achievement, creativity, and distinction in research in three areas of medicine: cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neuropsychiatry. The late Robert Pasarow started a business in which Claire actively participated; she was also a gifted sculptor and artist. Their shared enthusiasm, passion, and enjoyment in learning the stories of the work of the medical researchers who received the Pasarow Awards were deeply appreciated. After the death of Robert, Claire continued as the inspirational source for the work of the Foundation. Claire Pasarow's spirit and love of creative effort was a joy to all of us who knew her.
