I've been saying for weeks now -- well, two weeks, anyway -- that putting so much of the Games on live television probably made the difference between a successful Olympics and an unsuccessful one, at least from NBC's point of view. Live sports are simply more compelling than taped sports, as the ratings -- and the NBC's $100 million in Olympic profit -- clearly proved. But given the 12-hour time difference between Beijing and the East Coast of the United States, I had assumed that the deal to move many key events to the morning so that we in the United States could see them live in the evening had been struck between the International Olympic Committee and NBC, which paid $894 million for the rights to the Beijing Games.

In the second set of a close opening match at Arthur Ashe Stadium, between Elena Dementieva of Russia and Akgul Amanmuradova of Uzbekistan, both players tightened up. Dementieva was leading 6-4, 3-4, but at 30-40 it was break point for Amanmuradova. Both players pushed the ball back and forth, no one willing to take command, until Dementieva sailed an easy shot long to give Amanmuradova the break.

It's hard to believe that New York wasn't always as dessert obsessed as it is now, with dessert restaurants, dessert trucks and a chocolate shop in every neighborhood. But when François Payard left the restaurant Lucas-Carton in Paris to become pastry chef at Le Bernardin in 1991, his creations were among the first to show New Yorkers that the last course deserved pride of place as great as the first. When he worked at Le Bernardin and later at Daniel his composed plates like pomme, pomme, pomme -- apple sorbet on crisp apple sticks, with apple syrup and rings of baked apple chips -- were highlights of the meal. Lines formed out the door for his fanciful pastries and fine croissants, brioche and chocolates when he opened Payard Pâtissserie & Bistro on the Upper East Side in 1997. Mr. Payard, 42, a third-generation pastry chef now has opened branches of the bistro in Brazil, Japan and Las Vegas and has written three books.

World | The bleak ingenuity of malnutrition: North Korea's hunger-quelling noodle, and Haiti's mud cakes -- clay with margarine and salt baked in the sun. Seattle was the second-worst team in baseball at the time — not the worst, a claim belonging to Washington. (The Mariners were 46-81, and the Nationals were 45-83 after Thursday’s games.).

A Sports of The Times column on Aug. 11, about Michael Phelps’s pursuit of a record eight gold medals in swimming at the Beijing Olympics, misstated his gold-medal count through his first victory of these Games and the number of medals he was behind Mark Spitz’s career total at the time. Phelps had seven — not nine, which was his total for all medals at that point, including two bronze ones from 2004. And he was two medals behind Spitz’s career total, not one. (Phelps ultimately went on to win eight gold medals in Beijing, lifting his career totals to 14 gold and 16 over all.).

An article on Saturday about the varied styles of marathon runners at the Beijing Olympics misstated the year and the time for the women’s world record set by Paula Radcliffe of Britain. Her record of 2 hours 15 minutes 25 seconds was set in 2003; it was not 2 hours 17 minutes 2 seconds in 2005.

An article on Friday about the declining value of commercial real estate and its effect on lenders misstated the amount of commercial loans held by Deutsche Bank. It holds $23 billion in such loans, not $25.1 billion.

An article on Wednesday about a lawsuit filed by a Dominican detainee whose complaints about the health care he received at an immigrant detention center in Rhode Island mirror accounts of how the center treated Hiu Lui Ng, who died Aug. 6 in immigration custody, misstated the name of the Vermont county that includes St. Albans, where Mr. Ng spent time in the sheriff’s lockup before being transferred back to Rhode Island. An article last Monday about efforts to prevent a businessman from trademarking a term referring to Montana, “The Last Best Place,” misidentified the government department that issues trademarks. It is the Patent and Trademark Office, not the Copyright Office.

An article on Tuesday about the effect that ethics rules are having on parties at the national political conventions this year referred incorrectly to the entertainment for a reception that Medtronics, a medical technology company, is sponsoring at the Republican National Convention. Hot on Broadway is an entertainment agency that is providing performers who will sing songs from the Broadway show “Jersey Boys.” Hot on Broadway is not a touring company of “Jersey Boys.” The article also misstated the given name of Medtronic’s spokesman. He is Rob Clark, not Ron.

ISRAEL--Lawrence J. With the passing of Lawrence J. Israel in Chicago on August 12, the world lost a unique and remarkable citizen. He was a man with a huge intellect and a joie de vivre as large as his more than ample frame. A long time superb golfer he was a regular member of our foursome and we spent many informative and blissful hours with him. Larry, or ''Awrence'' as we referred to him, was the rare individual who knew both royalty and the ordinary man, but who never lost the common touch. He was equally comfortable with both as they were with him. Awrence had many significant philanthropic interests and he made a positive impact on all that he touched. In addition to his recognized skill in the commodities industry, having fun was his mantra. Besides golf he loved horse racing, fishing and wagering on, as he said, ''anything that moved.'' All was always in good taste and made everyone around him happier and with a true belief that they were lucky to know him. He lived his life breaking par every day. He is irreplaceable. Our deepest thanks go to him and our love to his magnificent wife, Ann and his family. Richard L. Siderowf Roger J. Weiss

PASAROW--Claire. Those associated with the Robert J. and Claire Pasarow Foundation, including the Board of Directors, Advisors, and Awardees, extend our heartfelt condolences to the Pasarow Family on the passing of Claire Pasarow. The Pasarows established the Foundation over twenty years ago to celebrate extraordinary achievement, creativity, and distinction in research in three areas of medicine: cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neuropsychiatry. The late Robert Pasarow started a business in which Claire actively participated; she was also a gifted sculptor and artist. Their shared enthusiasm, passion, and enjoyment in learning the stories of the work of the medical researchers who received the Pasarow Awards were deeply appreciated. After the death of Robert, Claire continued as the inspirational source for the work of the Foundation. Claire Pasarow's spirit and love of creative effort was a joy to all of us who knew her.

OLLENDORFF--Anne (nee Riess), 91, died on Saturday, August 23, 2008, peacefully in her sleep, at her home in Englewood, New Jersey. She is survived by her two sons, Stephen and David, three grandchildren, Arthur, Linda and Robert, four greatgrandchildren, Kayla, Holden, Sawyer and Graham and two brothers, Rudi and Stefan Riess. She fled Germany in November, 1938 with her beloved husband, Dr. Ulrich Ollendorff, and her infant son, Stephen. Together, she and her husband established a successful life in America, with her husband becoming a prominent ophthalmologist and she devoting her life to raising her family. In honor of her husband, she helped establish The Ollendorff Diagnostic Center at The Columbia Eye Institute. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 26 at 10:30am at Wien & Wien Funeral Home, 402 Park Avenue, Hackensack, New Jersey.

With their elbows locked, their smiles iridescent and their extreme image makeover complete, the United States men's basketball players took their final step into Olympic lore in the most appropriate way -- together. They pulled one another up to the gold medal podium on Sunday after a 118-107 victory over Spain. The game was an old-fashioned shootout that could long resonate as a standard for international play. After hammering their opponents by an average of 30.2 points through their first seven games, the Americans outlasted the Spaniards in their first wire-to-wire test of the Olympics, a game as aesthetically pleasing as it was entertaining.

RAFAEL NADAL'S DRAWAt the top, if play goes according to seeds, No. 1 Nadal would face No. 7 David Nalbandian in the quarterfinals, but that seems unlikely. Nalbandian could be defeated in the second round by Juan Carlos Ferrero, who thumped him in the third round of this year's Australian Open. In fact, Nalbandian, 26, has not made it past the fourth round of a major since 2006. Ninth-ranked James Blake, a fan favorite at the Open, may have more confidence against Nadal, whom he handled before Nadal's monster 2008. But Blake's supporters should dread the prospects of Nalbandian against Blake in the Round of 16 in a fifth set, in which Nalbandian is excellent but Blake has had little success. One anticipated first-round match is between tall big servers, Tomas Berdych and Sam Querrey. It may be quick, even if five sets. DAVID FERRER'S DRAWNo. 4 Ferrer and No. 6 Andy Murray, who was a semifinalist in Toronto and the winner in Cincinnati this summer, are the strongest players in this quarter. But No. 10 Stanislas Wawrinka could assert himself. He won Olympic gold with Roger Federer in doubles, and with it, a lift in confidence. Wawrinka, who reached the Open's fourth round last year, could use a break at a major: in 2008, he retired in the fourth set in the second round in Melbourne, squandered a two-setsto- love lead against Fernando González in the third round in Paris and lost to Marat Safin in Wimbledon's fourth round. No. 17 Juan Martin del Potro, who has won 19 straight matches since June 25, could be motivated or exhausted after winning two hardcourt events while the stars competed in Beijing.

THE GAME ''LAX'' (Geffen) Sometimes it seems that the best way to evaluate the Los Angeles rapper the Game is by the names he drops. He is the most reference-thick artist in any medium since the Bret Easton Ellis of ''American Psycho'' -- whom he's been influenced by, whom he's beefing with, what he owns, where he's been. Over two strong albums he has been a charismatic and sometimes mischievous rapper, but the question remains: Is the Game more than the sum of his proper nouns?

HWANG--Rosamonde Ling-E Rowena K'ung, age 92, passed away in New York City on Friday August 22, 2008 to be with the Lord. She was born in Shanxi Province, China on September 19, 1915 and her home was Shanghai. She was a member of the K'ung family and a 75th generation lincal descendent of Confucius. Her father, Dr. H.H. K'ung, was a wealthy industrialist and banker who later became the Premier and Minister of Finance of Shina. Her mother, Ai-Ling Soong K'ung, was one of the 3 famous Soong sisters. Her aunt, Mayling Soong, marries Generalissimo Chiang Kai-Shek, who led the Chinese against the Japanese during WWII and later against the Communist regime. Her aunt, ChingLing Soong married Dr. Sun Yat-Sen who formed the Kuomintang Party and established the Nationalist Government of China after the end of the Manchu Dynasty. Her uncle, Dr. T.V. Soong was also Premier and Minister of Finance at one point. Her deep Christian faith came from childhood, as her grandfather Charles Soong had come to the U.S. and had been educated and converted to Christianity. He printed bibles in China and spread the word of God. She moved to New York in 1948 and married Col. Hsiung Sheng Hwang in 1962 and had forty four years of blissful marriage until her husband's passing in 2006. She devoted her life to family and others. She ministered to her mother and father and to Madame Chiang Kai-shek until their deaths. She was a faithful and loyal servant of God. Rosamonde Hwang is survived by her nephew Gregory K'ung and her sister-in-law Debra K'ung who love her and will miss her greatly, as will many other of her extended family and friends. A viewing for family and friends will be held at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 81st and Madison on Tuesday 9:30 to 11:30am. Funeral service 1:00pm at the Ferncliff Cemetery.

ANA IVANOVIC'S DRAWTop-seeded Ivanovic vs. No. 6 Dinara Safina would be a prime-time quarterfinal (and French Open final rematch). But Ivanovic, who pulled out of the Olympics with a thumb injury, is facing several obstacles, including fatigue and Amélie Mauresmo, barely seeded at 32nd. Mauresmo, whose drastic fall since an appendectomy in March 2007 almost led to her retirement, reached the semifinals at the Pilot Pen in New Haven last week. Mauresmo is one of eight Frenchwomen in this section of the draw, including her first-round opponent, Nathalie Dechy, No. 17 Alize Cornet and No. 31 Virginie Razzano. Even if Ivanovic regains some emotional and physical energy, few would be shocked if she lost to Safina, who this summer has won two hardcourt events and a silver medal in singles at the Olympics. SERENA WILLIAMS'S DRAWSure, Kateryna and Alona Bondarenko could face each other in this quarterfinal, but the more famous sisters are expected to meet, No. 4 Serena Williams vs. No. 7 Venus, pictured below. The Bondarenkos took the first set off the Williamses in the doubles semifinal at the Olympics and won the Australian Open doubles title. Alas, this is singles. Alona, seeded 27th and coming off a knee injury, could face Venus in the third round. Her younger sister Kateryna opens against Serena. Agnieszka Radwanska, whose younger sister Urszula is a junior champion, is seeded No. 9 and could face Venus in the Round of 16. Last year, the older Radwanska upset Maria Sharapova, who is missing this year's Open because of a shoulder injury. Also watch out for No. 18 Dominika Cibulkova of Slovakia, who upset Jelena Jankovic in Montreal earlier this month.

B. B. KING ''One Kind Favor'' (Geffen) The bluesman B. B. King's latest album, ''One Kind Favor,'' is part throwback, part twist. At 82, Mr. King is considering his past; the album release anticipates the Sept. 10 opening of the B. B. King Museum and Delta Interpretive Center in Indianola, Miss., where he grew up. The songs on ''One Kind Favor'' were current when Mr. King's career got under way in the 1940s and 1950s, among them ''Sitting on Top of the World'' and lesser-known gems like ''Get These Blues Off Me'' from T-Bone Walker. The performance, recorded live in the studio, might almost be a late set at a very attentive club.

The city has provided a new kind of thrill right in the heart of Midtown: an esplanade carved into Broadway where people can sit and relax as cars and trucks whiz by. While the esplanade seems to have become an instant hit with office workers and tourists — the metal benches, tables and chairs (some under red umbrellas) were rarely empty on Monday morning, even though they have been out for only a few days — many eyed the traffic warily. The city Transportation Department, which created the esplanade, assured that it was safe, citing the buffer by provided by parked cars in some areas and heavy planters in others.

DENVER — A confrontation between demonstrators and the police involving pepper spray and dozens of arrests disrupted the New York delegation’s first night at the Democratic National Convention.The Denver police locked down the hotel where many of New York’s delegates were staying on Monday night, stranding many of them in the lobby and leaving one Albany County legislator wheezing and coughing from the release of pepper spray.

DENVER — Speaking to Democratic delegates from California on Tuesday, Gov. David A. Paterson of New York ratcheted up his calls for more federal assistance to states, saying that Washington’s intervention is needed to help soften the impact of the slowing economy. Mr. Paterson, who has made the economy a top priority of his administration, has called on the federal government to send more money back to New York as the state grapples with a growing budget deficit and a lagging economy. But on Tuesday in a speech to the California delegation at the Democratic National Convention, Mr. Paterson made his loudest appeal yet.

Bucking a national trend, New York City’s poverty rate declined slightly in the year ending on July 1, 2007, the Census Bureau reported on Tuesday. Median income rose at least marginally in every borough but Staten Island.Nonetheless, New York’s gap between rich and poor, already the highest of any state in the nation, grew even more compared to the year before. The top fifth of earners collected more than 53 percent of the income; the bottom fifth took home less than 3 percent. In New York City, nearly one in 10 married couple families made $200,000 or more.

The Federal Aviation Administration on Tuesday threatened to cut off $27 million in annual grants to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, escalating a legal battle over the Bush administration’s plan to auction off landing slots at some of the nation’s busiest airports, a plan that the authority bitterly opposes and that has divided elected officials.The Port Authority had said on Aug. 4 that it would prohibit planes from landing or taking off at slots acquired by auction. Two days later, the Bush administration vowed to move forward with its auction plan, starting with two slots at Newark Liberty International Airport that were previously allotted to EOS Airlines, a bankrupt carrier that folded. The auction is to begin on Sept. 3.

Last week's post about a virtual assistant, Emily Morgan, who had taken an entrepreneurial approach to her work, evoked some heated discussion in the comments about the nature of entrepreneurship. The comments touched on what motivates people to choose different types of work arrangements, particularly whether the trappings that tend to accompany employment, like health insurance and paid vacation time, are more valuable than those that flow to the self-employed -- like the ability to choose which projects to work on, the flexibility to work how and where a person wants, and a general feeling of controlling one's destiny.
